column2: STREET SCENE There's a little park up on 106th Street where Broadway meets West End Avenue, and today and tomorrow it will be filled with the fourth annual West Side Music Festival.
Winning numbers drawn on July 19 were: NEW YORK 750162 Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000.
The British Government announced today that it had decided to introduce legislation that would make the payment of welfare benefits part of the income-tax system.

Chuck Connors, the actor, has been given a samovar by one of his fans, Leonid I. Brezhnev. When the Soviet party leaderwas at the Western White House recently, Mr. Connors presented him with two .45-caliber frontier guns and a Western hat,
WHY JOHNNY CAN'T ADD: THE FAILURE OF THE NEW MATH. By Morris Kline. 173 pp. St. Martin's Press. $6.95.

WHY JOHNNY CAN'T ADD: THE FAILURE OF THE NEW MATH. By Morris Kline. 173 pp. St. Martin's Press. $6.95. This is an important book. Its significance goes far beyond its immediate topic. Rather it raises the broader issue of how, in field after field in American life, there come to be sudden fixations on supposed panaceas for perceived problems.

MINNEAPOLIS--Reversing: the usual process by which one museum tries to wheedle others into lending their finest paintings and sculptures for temporary exhibition, the Minneapolis Institute of Arts has opened "Fakes and Forgeries,"
The good old boys from the South shattered the suburban quiet this morning with a rebel yell during the Jets' practice.
A half-million-dollar deficit is threatening the future of the Rough Rock Demonstration School on the Navajo Reservation in Arizona, the first Indian school in modern times to be operated by Indians.
More than 65,000 California cannery workers went on strike today, immediately endangering crops worth $200million and threatening to drive food prices even higher across the nation.

Ocean racing created interest off Sea Bright and Sandy Hook long before the turn of the century. A spectator fleet of 400 boats jammed with about 50,000 persons sailed forth to watch the 1885 America's Cup battle between Puritan and England's fifth unsuccessful challenger, Genesta, off the Sea Bright beach.
For the family thinking of moving from an apartment to aa house, or from a small house to a larger one, these warm, sunny summer days may seem ideal for house-hunting.
Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden testified for almost three hours today before a state grand jury investigating alleged corruption in his city.

Paul A. Volcker, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, told Congress today that the value of the dollar had not declined in recent months against the currencies of countries with which the United States does three-quarters of its trade.

Premier Marcello Caetano of Portugal, ending an official four-day visit to London that was marked by protests against his presence, today promised an inquiry into charges that Portuguese troops slaughtered 400 African villagers in Mozamhique last December.
The chairman of the Permanent State Commission on Public Employe Pensions yesterday sharply criticized the recommendations of the Select Committee on Pensions.
Following are excerpts From the transcript of testimony today on the 24th day of hearings on the Watergate case before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:

James Chapman, a medical student from Marietta, Ga., battered. Ion Sileste helpless and stopped him in the third round of their heavyweight bout today in a meet between merican and Rumanian amateur boxers.

A move is under way in the Senate to prevent repeal of a restriction that bars companies and labor unions with Federal Government contracts from raising money from their employes for political campaigns.
Winning numbers drawn on July 19 were: NEW YORK 750162 Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000.
In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Lamb shanks casserole* Corn-on-the-cob Water cress salad Nectarine mousse
Norman A. Carlson, director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, urged Congress today to permit the bureau greater flexibility in granting furloughs to prisoners.

Henry A. Kissinger said the White House "neither ordered nor was it aware" of any falsifications of Pentagon records to conceal the bombing of Cambodia ordered by President Nixon in 1969. His comments came after the Pentagon said the Strategic Air Command might have ordered the falsification, which the Defense Department spokesman continued to defend despite public criticism of the procedures. [Page 1, Col. 1].
Dr. John Robert Moore, an internationally known specialist in the political and literary activities of Daniel Defoe, died here yesterday. He was 82 years old and lived in Madison, Ohio.
Tanks and armored cars remained posted at key points in Kabul today, two days after a coup d'etat that turned Afghanistan from monarchy into a republic.
Henry A. Kissinger declared today that the White House "neither ordered nor was it aware of any falsification of records" on the secret bombing of Cambodia ordered by President Nixon in March, 1969.

King Van Nostrand of Brightwaters, L. I., defeated Reynaldo Garrido of Woodbury, L. I., 6-1, 6-4, today and reached the quarterfinal round of the Nassau invitation tennis tournament at the Shore Tennis Club.

E. F. Hutton Co., one of the nation's largest investment houses, reported yesterday that it lost $922,000 in the second quarter of this year, a period of extremely depressed earnings for the securities industry.

Andrew Jackson, a reputed member of the Black Liberation Army, has been identified by eyewitnesses as a participant in the ambush shooting last January of two policemen in Queens, the police reported yesterday.

Robert C. Mardian, a former Assistant Attorney General, testified today that a Watergate conspirator, G. Gordon Liddy, gave him the clear "impression" a year ago that President Nixon had authorized a 1971 burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.
Next week's $175,000 Canadian open lost one of its chief drawing cards yesterday when Jack Nicklaus sent his regrets to tournament officials in Toronto.
The nation's economy grew at the usually small rate of 2.6 per cent in the April-June quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

Princess Irene Galitzine invited a few hundred close friends to her terraced apartment overlooking the Spanish Steps last night. Her cocktail party was sandwiched between her showing and that of Mila Schoen, the other grand lady of the Italian high fashion scene.
The Food and Drug Adminis tration ordered meat processors today to stop using certain curing mixes for prepared meats because they could produce a cancer-causing agent.

Monetary expansion continued at a rapid rate in recent weeks, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday. At the same time, the steep upward climb in short-term interest rates threatened to push the prime lending rate of the nation's banks to a record 83/4 per cent level -- and probably still higher -- in the days immediately ahead.

Michel Gauvin, head of the Canadian delegation to the International Commission of Control and Supervision, left Saigon today after having struggled for nearly six months to make the commission an effective peace-keeping organization.
The defending champion, Art Silvestrone, fired a five-under par 65 to tie with Pat Schwab for the second round lead in the 53d New Jersey State open championship today at Spring Brook Country Club.

The Government will be comparatively lenient in granting exceptions to Phase 4 pricing rules because they are more stringent than the old rules, John T. Dunlop, director of the Cost of Living Council, said today.

President Nixon has decided not to give Senate investigators access to the tape recordings of his personal and telephone conversations with Watergate suspects in 1972 and 1973, a White House official said today.

A "bricks-and-mortar" bill to provide Federal aid for the maintenance, repair and construction of museum display areas drew strong support from museum spokesmen yesterday at a Senate Labor subcommittee hearing In washington.
The first of France's nuclear tests in the South Pacific for 1973 was postponed at the last minute today because of bad weather, the Government radio reported here.

Delegates to the annual meeting of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks gave the necessary two-thirds approval today to rescind a "whitesonly" membership clause that threatened local lodges with loss of liquor licenses in several states.

Joseph M. A. H. Luns, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, has presented the alliance countries with a set of guidelines for their talks on a new declaration of principles for the organization.

Mrs. Eleanor Brown, looking chic and slender in her yellow Halston Ultrasuede dress, tossed a red, white and blue basketball into the air yesterday at the "21" Club. The ball was caught by Dan Issel, star forward of the Kentucky Colonels.

Robert C. Mardian, a former Assistant Attorney General, testified today that a Watergate conspirator, G. Gordon Liddy, gave him the clear "impression" a year ago that President Nixon had authorized a 1971 burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

The Lindsay administration's latest program for increasing minority-group employment in the building trades, which goes into effect today, was strongly endorsed yesterday by city officials, leaders of minority groups and rank-and-file union members at a noon-hour rally in City Hall Park.

Of the many Watergate disclosures, one it seems to me has been somewhat misinterpreted. That is the plan for increased intelligence on internal subversion which President Nixon approved in July, 1970, and dropped after F.B.I. Director J. Edgar Hoover objected.
The nation's economy grew at the usually small rate of 2.6 per cent in the April-June quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

A public offering to 6,000 units of The National Housing Partnership--II, a limited partnership formed to invest in Government assisted housing projects by purchasing from the National Housing Partnership a portion of its interests in about 60 local housing partnerships, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Goldman Sachs; Kuhn, Loeb; White, Weld; and Dean Witter.

In March, 1969, President Nixon authorized a secret B-52 bombing campaign against Vietcong supply and staging areas in Cambodia. Over the next 14 months 3,630 raids were flown and more than 100,000 tons of bombs dropped--all without public acknowledgment by the United States.

General guidelines to be used n drafting regulations to protect the rights of minors and adults who have been declared legally incompetent in sterilization procedures were issued today by Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

The United States believes that the admission of both South Korea and North Korea to the United Nations would "recognize the reality" of the two Governments, Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today.

The National Football League and the three major television networks have virtually agreed on new four-year contracts through the 1977 season for an estimated total of $200million, an increase believed to be close to $10-million a year.

The Senate Armed Services Committee said today that it would reopen public hearings tomorrow to hear testimony against President Nixon's nomination of William E. Colby as the new Director of Central Intelligence.

Fist fights broke out last night at a community school board meeting on the Lower East Side after a board member punched the board president as the panel was moving to strip the controversial district superintendent, Luis Fuentes. of much of his power.

The summer national championships of the American Contract Bridge League returned to the nation's capital today with attention focused on a mini-Watergate situation, involving suspicion of misconduct, privilege, tape recordings, and the separation of powers.
Dr. Karl Pribram, a retired Government economist, author and emeritus professor of the University of Frankfurt, died Saturday in Washington, where he lived. He was 95 years old.

The Connecticut Civil Liberties Union warned this affluent Fairfield County town today that its plan to build electronically bugged jail cells was illegal and threatened court action if its warning was ignored.
The State Commission of Investigation put off questioning two reputed members of the Mafia until next Thursday, when their lawyer failed to show up at today's scheduled closed-door hearing.

Donald Blake Cook, long active in Government-sponsored international-exchange programs before his retirement from the State Department last year, died yesterday of cancer at his home here. He was 61 years old.
Presidential elections, in which former dictator Juan D. Peron is expected to run and to win, will be held Sept. 23, the provisional Cabinet announced today.

This week's coup d'etat in Afghanistan might well change the ultimate power balance in South and Southwest Asia. The Soviet position is certainly convenience even if there is no known evidence that Moscow played any role in the ouster of King Mohammad Zahir Shah and the creation of the first Afghan republic by his cousin, Prince Mohammad Daud.
The First National City Bank announced yesterday that it was raising its base, or prime, lending rate to 8 1/2 per cent from 8 1/4 per cent, effective for the week beginning Monday.
One hundred anti twenty-five years after the first women's rights convention was called to order near the banks of the Seneca River by Elizabeth Cady Stanton,
Gourgen Yanikian, 78 years old, was sentenced today to life imprisonment on each of two first-degree murder counts in the slayings here last Jan. 27 of two Turkish diplomats.
Two major championships were in progress here this afternoon at the start of the American Contract Bridge League's summer nationals.
The executive director of the Maine Potato Commission, Chipman C. Bull, told United Press International yesterday that the nation has a serious potato chip shortage.

Jay G. Gilfillan, co-founder of Gilfillan Radar Development and Manufacturing Company (since 1964 a division of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation), died Wednesday at the age of 81.

At times the show -- Hot Peaches in "The Watergate Scandals of '73"--is almost as funny as the title. It looks thrown together hurriedly, in a 36-seat theater at 200 West 24th Street (first door west of Seventh Avenue, third floor, via elevator). The humor is political camp, dominated by drag but surprisingly clean as such.

State Insurance Commissioner Joe B. Hunt asked the Illinois State Insurance Department today to call a nationwide examination of the Combined Insurance Company of America, whose chairman, W. Clement Stone, has said he donated more than $5-million to political campaigns since 1968.

Volume Merchandise, Inc., a retail organization operating 282 stores and leased departments throughout the United States filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in the Federal Court Southern District, listing assets of $32,940,000 and liabilities of $20,640,000.
In the face of declining daily and weekly sales, the New Jersey Lottery Commission has announced plans to offer cars to lucky ticket holders.

My neighbor died in a fire, in his apartment, late Friday afternoon. Nobody knows how it happened. On my way home, I stopped at the little superette to pick up some ice cream for dessert. "Did you know that man?" the woman who works there asked.
A police officer and a towtruck driver were arrested yesterday and charged with stealing $100 in marked bills from an automobile illegally parked in Greenwich Village.

The Bank of England's minimum lending rate--a basic gauge of the cost of borrowing money - shot up today in the wake of official moves yesterday aimed at dampening inflation and strengthening the pound.
The Cost of Living Council's senior food expert, Kenneth J. Feder, said today that the continua-tion of ceiling prices on beef was unlikely to cause "any widespread shortage."

Governor Rockefeller yesterday proposed to put a $3.5billion bond plan to the voters this fall to finance new masstransit operations and highways and to provide $183.8million in state aid for subsidizing the 35-cent fare and commuter rates for the next two years.
There are always "in" watches: the Tiffany classic, the Cartier and its trick strap, the coin-thin Piaget or the Patek Philippe, which cost more than $1,000.
Gordon Creighton Strachan's infatuation with politics started 24 years ago when he was elected president of his kindergarten class in Santa Rosa, Calif.

The Yankees, who had seen much too much of Wilbur Wood in the previous two years, saw him double last night and promptly doubled their pleasure and doubled their fun. After Wood had beaten the Yankees eight straight times since last losing July 18, 1971,

Some years ago an article in this newspaper described some of the techniques used by Port Authority policemen stationed on the catwalks of the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels to cope with the boredom that is their chief problem. One man sang at the top of his lungs; another recited poetry; still others played license-plate games, trying to see how many different states they could "collect" during a two-hour shift.

Following are questions and answers on current problems confronting the United States dollar: Q. How did the present dollar crisis come about? A. Because of a lack of confidence in the dollar in the United States and abroad.

The American premiere of Marco da Gagliano's 1608 opera, "La Dafne," which was to have been given last night by the New York Pro Musica Antiqua at the Caramoor Festival in Katonah, N. Y., was postponed because of a delay in the arrival of music and other elements of the production.

Two soldiers were killed in separate attacks by terrorists today as the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army sought to demonstrate that it was still operating effectively despite the arrest of 18 leaders yesterday.
The sponsor of two telethons to raise funds for research on sickle cell anemia was accused this week of impropriety in the handling of funds by the foundation that was to receive the contributions.

Joseph Ferdinando, whose getrich-quick scheme eventually resulted in the indictment and resignation of former District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens and his son-in-law and former deputy chief assistant District Attorney, James Robertson, was give a three-year suspended sentence in State Supreme Court here today.

Here were people with a lust to know everything. They had a vision of total information. They believed in Intelligence with a faith which bordered on religion. Intelligence. One still senses a vocal genuflection when the word passes over their lips.
The army magistrate who investigated a navy plot in May today recommended conspiracy charges against 73 officers and civilians. They are all in custody.

Dozens of policemen guarded the entrances, corridors and even the hearing room of the Federal Courthouse in Brooklyn yesterday as Joanne Deborah Chesimard, the militant who has been called the "soul" of the Black Liberation Army, pleaded not guilty to a threecount indictment stemming from a 1971 bank robbery in Queens. ..
President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he would cancel a referendum set for next Friday, if necessary, in places where there is violence, terrorism or calamity.
Forbes Dunbar Shaw, a partner in the New York law firm of Whitman Ransom, died today at his home, 12 Stonehouse Road. He was 67 years old.

With food prices rocketing upward this past year, profits of commercial crop growers have been soaring at a fabulous rate. Department of Agriculture statistics tend to minimize the rate of enrichment of large farmers, but even they give important clues. This year, for example, the department estimates farm profits will exceed $22 billion, i.e., they will be 40 per cent higher than they were as recently as 1970.

Economic activity in New York City dropped in several categories in the first half of 1973 despite a significant rise throughout New York State, according to figures released today by the State Department of Commerce.

The Democratic party hopes to take its civil lawsuit against the Committee for the Re-election of the President into court next fall, Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic National chairman, said yesterday.

The Senate today overwhelmingly approved legislation that would limit the power of the President to commit United States armed forces to future hostilities without Congressional approval. The vote was 71 to 18.

Henry A. Kissinger told three prominent Jewish leaders last night that Leonid I. Brezhnev had assured President Nixon that a large number of Soviet Jews who had repeatedly been denied permission to leave the Soviet Union would soon be allowed to emigrate to Israel.

ALLING--Stanley Joseh of Lakeville, Conn. formerly of Bronxville, N.Y. Yale 1923. Retired publisher of McGraw Hill. On July 18, of cancer, age 72. Beloved husband of Mary Hubbard Ailing, devoted father of Duncan Wells Ailing, Janet Dickey Ailing, and Judith Ann Ailing Manchester. Grandfather of Elizabeth Scott Sykes Alling and Gregor Wells Alling. Memorial Services on
The military services yesterday were restrained for 10 days from issuing death notices to families of the 3,500 servicemen who are listed as missing in action in Indochina.
Somewhere along the line during the last few years, the mini-exhibition, or showlet, has become a staple of American museum programs.
The Communications Satellite Corporation achieved record revenues and earnings in the quarter and six months ended June 30. In addition to the earnings report issued yesterday,
The Security Council resumed its debate on the Middle East today, with Egypt charging that the support that Israel received from the United States "blocked the way to peace."
The leader of the Jewish Defense League, Rabbi Meir Kahane, pleaded not guilty in District Court today to charges of having conspired to kidnap and murder foreign officials in the United States.

The Quebec Nordiques of the World Hockey Association failed to lure Jean Beliveau, one of hockey's greatest scorers, out of the Montreal front Canadiens' front office and back onto the ice with a million-dollar offer, but sucneeded instead with a younger Canadien talent. Rejean Houle, the 23-year-old forward who helped Montreal win the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup last season, signed a three-year contract with the Nordiques.
Consumer prices in June, reflecting increases before the recent freeze, continued to rise at the fastest pace since the Korean war, the Labor Department reported today.
A $2-million turbine-powered train undergoing a final test run before acceptance by Amtrak was burned into "a pile of scrap" today-after it sideswiped a freight train.
All roads lead to Valentino in Rome. If his collection, always the last to be shown in the semiannual week of high fashion presentations, is good, everybody will come back next time.
South Vietnam today proposed for the first time that it and North Vietnam join the United Nations while awaiting reunification.

To a few rich Londoners, the living presence of Inigo Jones amounts to a rather precious restaurant by that name where they can eat carefully cooked lamb chops while somebody noodles on a harpsichord downstairs.
Dr. Herbert H. Hyman, a senior chemist and assistant director of the chemical division of the Argonne (Ill.) National Laboratory, died today of a heart attack. He was 53 years old and lived here.

The space agency extended today the planned length of the second Skylab crew's orbital research mission to 59 days from 56 after a nearly flawless dress rehearsal cleared the way for launching the astronauts next Saturday.
Net income of the Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, climbed sharply in the quarter and six months period ended June 30.

Port Authority policemen returned to work yesterday following court orders that they end their walkout, but 60 of them staged a creeping, stopand-go motorcade that created massive morning-snarls at the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels.

In this resort area, best known for its beaches, salt-water taffy, the Miss America contest and the Steel Pier, interest in harness racing continues to grow. "Until recently, when it came to horses," said Joe Lynch, general manager of the Atlantic City Raceway at nearby Mavs Landing.
The American League said today that Manager Dick Williams of the Oakland A's would be sufficiently recovered from surgery to manage in the AllStar Game next Tuesday in Kansas City.
Scientists have been unable to determine whether underground nuclear explosions in western Colorado freed enough natural gas to ease the energy crisis, a test official said yesterday.
Federal Judge Anthony J. Travia yesterday ordered the forfeiture of $325,000 bail posted by Frank Matthews, a suspected major drug dealer.

Robert C. Mardian, the forme chief of the Justice Department' Internal Security Division, test field today that President Nixo: personally asked him two year ago to transfer from the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation to the White House the log of telephone wiretaps that the White House had authorized

The authorities evacuated more than 3,000 persons from an affluent west side suburb here today when a railroad tank car loaded with an industrial chemical caught fire and exploded after a train derailment.

One of the marks of recent religious history has been a breakdown of traditional sources of authority. Leaders ranging from the Pope to local pastors have lost much of their influence over people's lives.

Several radio stations delivered to the United States Attorney's office in Newark yesterday records and documents subpoenaed for use in a Federal grand jury investigation of allegations of payola, drug use and involvement of organized crime in the record industry.

The Ashland Oil Company of Kentucky admitted today that it illegally contributed $100,000 in corporate funds to President Nixon's re-election campaign last year. It was the second such disclosure by a major American company this month.
The military leaders who overthrew King Mohammad Zahir Shah and set up a republic said today that members of the royal family in the country were safe.
Not a salvo, postage stamp, museum exhibition or updated published history has marked this, the centennial year of the birth of the typewriter industry. And no such event appears to be planned.

The Consolidated Edison Company plans a major realignment of its top management next Tuesday. In the major moves, William W. Lapsley, 63, who is now an executive vice president, will become president.

Mrs. Ethel Ericson Redjives, a former English teacher at Midwood and Wadleigh High Schools and originator of the city's Inter-High School Poetry Contest, died Thursday at Adelphi Hospital in Brooklyn.
A House Armed Services subcommittee voted today to cite G. Gordon Liddy for contempt of Congress for refusing to take an oath as a witness in a Watergate investigation. The vote was unanimous.

President Nixon declared New York State a "major disaster area" today and designated six counties for disaster relief of up to $10-million. The designation was for the flooding that occurred between June 29 and July 5 during a series of thunderstorms and heavy rain.
After 11 months in prison, Clifford Irving, creator of the Howard Hughes autobiography hoax, is seeking parole from the Federal Correctional Institute at Danbury, Conn.

ALBANY, July 20--A Public Service Commission examiner recommended today that the commission authorize the New York Telephone Company in modify a discount service now offered to high-volume business subscribers.
The House voted 363 to 14 today to authorize $175-million for public broadcasting for the next two Years.
Henry Aaron must be marching to the same drummer that propelled Babe Ruth into baseball history. Last night in the seventh inning at Atlanta Aaron struck the 699th home run of his illustrious 20-year

Most commodity futures prices continued to increase yesterday, still reflecting some speculative euphoria about Phase 4. With fewer controls on food, traders apparently believe that prices will move higher.

Three youthful gunmen held up a coffee shop this morning and after getting $1,800 in cash without any resistance, opened fire on a group of nine customers and employees lying on the floor in a back room.
A former convict from Houston was charged with two counts of murder yesterday after an Atascosa County sheriff's deputy and his wife had been shot to death.

The Internal Revenue Service has subpoenad the personal financial records of C. G. Rebozo, a close friend of President Nixon, from a Key Biscayne, Fla., bank that Mr. Rebozo operates, A.B.C. News reported last night.
Brad Van Pelt shipped nine New York Giants warmup jackets to his parents and relatives today, which may mean that he plans a longer stay with the club than another rookie, Rod Freeman.

Willie Mays is going to the All-Star game in Kansas City, his 24th, in the embarrassing position of having been done a favor-something baseball authorities managed to avoid when they named Mickey Mantle and Stan Musial to All-Star squads at comparable stages of their careers . . .

Hijackers who said they were fighting for the Palestinian people, seized a Japan Air Lines jumbo jet yesterday 30 minutes after take-off from Amsterdam, the Netherlands, and brought it to this Persian Gulf sheikdom.

The Defense Department knowingly provided the Senate Armed Services Committee with a false report last month that did not reveal the secret Cambodian bombing, the Pentagon's chief spokesman acknowledged today.
Joe Namath is scheduled to arrive at the Jets' training camp Sunday. He will have missed the first week of practice and a week's salary of $101.50.
Alfred Walker Barr, one of the last sea captains to hold master mariner's papers for square-rigged sailing ships as well as steam vessels, died today at the Mount Auburn Hospital here.

Garrett Brock Trapnell, who boasted he had feigned insanity to avoid prison sentences, was sentenced to life imprisonment yesterday for the armed hijacking last year of a Trans World Airlines plane going from Los Angeles to New York.

In a milestone decision by an Administrative Law Judge, the Securities and Exchange Commission rejected today a proposal by the American Electric Power Company to acquire control of the Columbus Southern Ohio Electric Company through an exchange of stock.

President Nixon's nominee as director of the Office of Economic Opportunity told a Senate committee today that he felt "very strongly" there should be "an agency of advocacy for the poor," and that he supported Congress's efforts to retain the embattled antipoverty program.
President Nixon emerged from tile hospital today, pale but combative, and immediately denounced suggestions that he resign as "just plain poppycock."

Jim Dietz of the New York Athletic Club, Neil Haleen of Wisconsin and Bill Belden of Undine Boat Club qualified today for the final tomorrow in the Elite singles race to decide who represents the United States at Moscow Sept. 5-9. The races were held on the new Albridge C. Smith 3d course on Lake Carnegie.

The Quebec Nordiques of the World Hockey Association failed to lure Jean Beliveau, one of hockey's greatest scorers, out of the Montreal Canadiens' front office and back onto the ice with a million-dollar offer, but succeeded instead with a younger Canadien talent.

Superior Court Judge Chester A. Weidenburner rejected an appeal today against his order requiring more than 40 eighthgrade boys in Newark to submit to fingerprinting in an Elizabeth murder investigation.

Hijackers who said they were fighting for the Palestinian people seized a Japan Air Line 747 jet 30 minutes after take-off from Amsterdam yesterday and forced it to fly to this Persian" Gulf sheikdom.

Governor Rockefeller yesterday proposed to put a $3.5billion bond plan to the voters this fall to finance new masstransit operations and highways and to provide $183.8million in state aid for subsidizing the 35-cent fare and commuter rates for the next two Years.

Specials and presentations of major films have been scheduled by the National Broadcasting Company's television network for time periods where premieres of series have been delayed by the 16-week strike of the Writers Guild of America, it was announced yesterday by Herbert S. Schlosser, president of the N.B.C.-TV network.
Two men robbed a Vietnam veteran on a disability of his $10,000 life savings after he drew it out of a bank here, the police said.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday it has received an order for two nuclear reactors and initial fuel valued "in excess of $100-million." This is the second contract announced by the company this week.

Superior Court Judge Chester A. Weidenburner rejected an appeal today against his order requiring more than 40 eighthgrade boys in Newark to submit to fingerprinting in an Elizabeth murder investigation.

Supporters of Luis Fuentes, the superintendent of Community School District 1, said yesterday that they would appeal to School Chancellor Irving An ker or, if necessary, to State Supreme Court to set aside the resolutions adopted by the
Joe Namath is scheduled to arrive at the Jets' training camp Sunday. He will have missed the first week of practice and a week's salary of $101.50.

The South Vietnamese Government issued a 48-page booklet today designed to refute news reports of poor conditions in the nation's prisons, particularly the maximum security facility on Con Son Island.

The Senate today overwhelmingly approved legislation that would limit the power of the President to commit United States armed forces to future hostilities without Congressional approval. The vote was 71 to 18.

The increase in Social Security benefits recently enacted will be 5.9 per cent next year instead of the 5.6 per cent that had been estimated, because of the rise in prices, the Social Security Administration said today.

Walter J. Hess, president of the Ridgewood Savings Bank in Queens from 1948 to 1971, died of cancer yesterday in Memorial Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 193-18 McLaughlin Avenue, Hollis, Queens.
The American League said today that Manager Dick Williams of the Oakland A's would be sufficiently recovered from surgery to manage in the AllStar Game next Tuesday in Kansas City.

A former aide to H. R. Haldeman testified today that the former White House chief of staff was advised more than two months before the Watergate break-in that President Nixon'sre-election committee had set up "a sophisticated political intelligence-gathering system."
Brad Van Pelt shipped nine New York Giants warmup jackets to his parents and relatives today, which may mean that he plans a longer stay with the club than another rookie, Rod Freeman.

THE BERN BOOK: A Record of a Voyage of the Mind. By Vincent O. Carter. 297 pages. John Day. $8. "O saisons, O chateaux!/ Quelle ame est sans defauts?" ("O seasons, o castles!/ What soul is without blemishes?") wrote Arthur Rimbaud, creating the mystique of the poet's "season in hell" en route to an ultimate vision of the world.

WASHINGTON, July 20--Senate and House conferees completed action today on a Federal highway bill that had been stalled for 10 weeks by a deadlock over whether to use part of the Highway Trust Fund for mass transit.

Central Park in New York City will be closed to vehicular traffic today and next Thursday until midnight because of two special concerts to be offered in the Sheep Meadow by the New York Philharmonic.
Connecticut's birth rate in 1972 was the lowest since the state began keeping records in 1848, the State Health Department said today.

John L. Mott, from 1935 to 1954 director of International House, a cultural and educational residence center for foreign and American graduate students at 500 Riverside Drive, flied Thursday in Waterbury Conn.

" Whoever, knowing that an offense against the United States has been committed, receives, relieves, comforts or assists the offender in order to hinder or prevent his apprehension, trial or punishment, is an accessory after the fact."
Communist-led insurgents attacked Government positions today in at least seven fiercely contested sectors around Phnom Penh, according to the Cambodian high command and field reports.
Mrs. Gertrude Rose O'Brien Lyons, widow of James J. Lyons, Bronx Borough President from 1933 to 1961, died of cancer Thursday in Union Hospital, the Bronx.
Following are excerpts from the transcript of testimony today on the 25th day of hearings on the Watergate case before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:
Consumer prices in June, reflecting increases before the recent freeze, continued to rise at the fastest pace since the Korean war, the Labor Department reported today.

Second-seeded Arthur Ashe, overcoming three match points and the heat, defeated seventhseeded Roscoe Tanner, 4-6, 6-4, 7-5, today and advanced to the semifinal round of the $60,000 United States professional tennis championships.

An experimental program establishing seven centers to handle consumer complaints on automobiles was disclosed today by Mrs. Virginia H. Knauer, the special assistant to the President for consumer affairs, and representatives of new car dealers.
Jamaica's Government tonight declared United States Ambassador Vincent W. de Roulet persona non grata and asked the Secretary of State to terminate his appointment here quickly.

Three youthful gunmen held up a coffee shop this morning and after getting $1,800 in cash without any resistance, opened fire with no provocation on a group of nine customers and employes lying on the floor in a back room.
The House Interior Committee approved today the first section of the bill authorizing construction of the Alaskan oil pipeline and will take up more controversial sections of the measure on Monday.

Two Penn Central freight trains collided here today, killing one trainman and injuring two other railroad employes. According to a Penn Central spokesman, the three victims of the crash were aboard the engine of the train that ran into the rear end of another train.
On the fourth anniversary of mankind's first step on the moon, the New York Mets took a step deeper into the National League Eastern Division cellar by losing to the Houston Astros tonight, 16-2.

Port Authority policemen returned to work yesterday following court orders that they end their walkout, but 60 of them staged a creeping, stopand-go motorcade that created massive morning snarls at the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels.

Bruce Lee, the Chinese actor who made a career of karate, kung-fu and other martial arts on the screen, died tonight at Queen Elizabeth Hospital after having been found unconscious in his home here. He was 32 years old.
A Soviet space official said today that American specialists would train in the Russian flight control center near Moscow for the joint 1975 flight by the two countries.
A Federal judge found the state of Indiana guilty today of school segregation and ordered the legislature to dcvise a desegregation plan for the Indianapolis metropolitan area.

A Ranger-37 sloop, Puff, of the home club's A.M.B. Syndicate, was the only undefeated senior series boat remaining in the Larchmont Yacht Club's 75th Race Week today. A fleet of 152 sailed on Long Island Sound on the seventh day of the regatta which closes tomorrow.
Gene Littler sank birdies on six of his last seven holes for a 66 and a one-stroke lead today after the second round of $210,000 St. Louis Children's Hospital golf classic.

Dennis Nahat's "Medelssohn Symphony" was originally given by American Ballet Theater two years ago. It subsequently lapsed from the repetory until last Thursday, when, in a new production, it was given at the New York State Theater.
The Government formed two weeks ago by Premier Mariano Rumor was approved by Parliament tonight.

The Defense Department knowingly provided the Senate Armed Services Committee with a false report last month that did not reveal the secret Cambodian bombing, the Pentagon's chief spokesman acknowledged today.

As he unveiled his latest statewide bond proposal, Governor Rockefeller was asked about the stewardship of Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which runs the city subways and suburban commuter lines.

Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor ("Maybe we loved each other too much") ended their 16-day marital separation in a parking lot yesterday. Miss Taylor arrived in Rome in a private jet after switching planes in London, where she was accompanied by her manager, two dogs and a cat.
Dennis Gabor who discovered holography more than a quarter-cenutry ago, has applied the art to medical diagnosis. Holography is three - dimensional lenseless photography.
This is a tale of two tastings. One took place in a small country inn in Massachusetts, the other at the New York Hilton. Together, they say some interesting things about the world of wine.

WASHINGTON, July 20--A former aide to H. R. Haldeman testified today that the former White House chief of staff was advised more than two months before the Watergate break-in that President Nixon's re-election committee had set up "a sophisticated political intelligence-gathering system."

Senator John C. Stennis, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said today that he had ordered a full-scale review of the laws governing the Central Intelligence Agency in light of the agency's secret activities in Laos and its role in the Watergate scandal.
The dollar took a beating today in West Germany but was up on a number of European markets and in Tokyo and was uncertain on others.

Thirty persons were arrested and more than $5,000 in narcotics seized in a series of raids by 93 policemen from 11 communities in Essex County. Those arrested included two women and ranged in age from 15 to 25 years. Charges included sale of heroin, cocaine, LSD, hashish, marijuana, barbiturates and amphetamines. There were also related arrests for armed robbery, burglary, breaking and entering, and possession of stolen property. Bail was set from $1,000 to $25,000.

In a decision of potentially great damage to the First Amendment, the Florida Supreme Court has upheld an old statute, long regarded in the state as a dead letter, which requires newspapers to print the replies of political candidates whom they criticize. Six of the court's seven elected justices made the point that the First Amendment was not intended "for the benefit of the press so much as for the benefit of us all." Precisely.

The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may he translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.
Nolan Ryan isn't the sulking kind. "Two no-hitters don't make a season," he had said after being snubbed in the American League All-Star pitching selections.
The wholesale prices of two more staples in the shopper's weekly food basket - butter and cheese - rose yesterday, heralding a broad advance next week in food prices.

Mayor Lindsay gave his support yesterday. to Governor Rockefeller's proposed $3.5-billion transportation bond issue, but said it offered an "incomplete" answer to the city's finance problems for mass transit.
Eugene E. Ayres, a chemist who formerly directed the chemicals division of the Gulf Research and Development Company, died yesterday in a nursing home here. He was 82 years old.

Henry A. Kissinger told three prominent Jewish leaders last night that Leonid I. Brezhnev had assured President Nixon that a large number of Soviet Jews who had repeatedly been denied permission to leave the Soviet Union would soon he allowed to emigrate I.o Israel.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation acknowledged today that a Black Muslim killed Wednesday by an agent was the wrong man.

The Senate today overwhelmingly approved legislation that would limit the power of the President to commit United States armed forces to future hostilities without Congressional approval. The vote was 71 to 18.

A 21-year-old Indiana woman who recently came to New York to study acting was stabbed to death early yesterday in the entrance hall of her apartment building on a quiet, fashionable street of Brooklyn Heights.

As United States ambassador to Laos, career diplomat G. McMurtrie Godley helped to carry out policies which most Americans now regard as mistaken, if not disastrous. Because of his long and intimate identification with the Indochina fiasco and the apparent enthusiasm with which he dispatched duties that many Americans now find reprehensible, there is good reason for concern over his nomination by President Nixon to an important new assignment in the Asiatic area.
Senate and House conferees completed action today on a Federal highway bill that had been stalled for 10 weeks by a deadlock over whether to use part of the Highway Trust Fund for mass transit.

To the Editor: A recent Times editorial celebrates Mr. Richardson's kindness to Puerto Rico in ordering the termination of Navy gunnery and air bombardment practice that for years has harassed the 726 residents of the islet of Culebra and preparing new Navy ranges on the "uninhabited islands of Desecheo and Monito on the other side of Puerto Rico." I fail to see any cause for rejoicing.
A caravan of 40,000 Libyans drove past this coastal resort toward Cairo today but they were halted 50 miles away when Egyptian security officials blocked the highway with a train.

A House Armed Services subcommittee voted today to cite G. Gordon Liddy for contempt of Congress for refusing to take an oath as a witness in a Watergate investigation.

The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered Amtrak today to continue operating its passenger service between New York City and Kansas City, Mo., and between Chicago and Miami, Fla., for four more months.
Robert Ryan left an estate estimated at $250,000 to $500,000 at his death July 11, it was disclosed yesterday when the actor's will was filed for probate in Manhattan Surrogates Court.

" Wicked John and the Devil" and "After the Ball," both one-act stage works running about half an hour each, received their New York premieres on Thursday night, and it was surprising that the Cubiculo should be the locale.

Volume declined but prices moved ahead yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market. The advance in the price indexes made it five straight for the week with investors generally responding to favorable quarterly earnings reports.

The Laurels Hotel, once a leading Catskills resort here, was seized by the Sullivan County sheriff, Joseph Waseer, tonight in a foreclosure action that forced dozens of angry guests to find other accommodations.

Leonard H. Goldenson, board chairman of the American Broadcasting System, Inc., and Elmer W. Lower, president of A.B.C. News, entered the People's Republic of China yesterday for a three-week "working tour" of five major cities -Peking, Canton, Shanghai, Nanking and Hangchow.
1. Vote on amendment to Alaska Pipeline Bill that would prohibit court challenges to project on basis of environmental faclors. Amendment passed, 49 to 48, July 17.
Coach George Allen of the Washington Redskins denied today that Duane Thomas had been acquired as a retaliation toward Larry Brown, the star running back who has refused to report to training camp.

Raw steel production in the non-Communist world soared by 12.2 per cent in June from output in June, 1972, the International Iron and Steel Institute reported today. Total production for the first six months of 1973 was 14.4 per cent, up from the 1972 period, the institute said.
