Hovering like a big, noisy dragonfly, the eggbeater settled slowly until the plastic tub slung under its belly was about 15 feet from the lake's surface.
Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley indicated yesterday that height requirements might be eliminated for police officers so that men no taller than jockeys could be patrolling the city's streets.
Prime Minister Forbes Burnham, returned to power for the third time, appointed his new Cabinet over the weekend. Mr. Burnham's People's

Hijackers, who said they were pro-Palestinian guerrillas, and hostages sweltered through a second day of torrid desert heat aboard the Japan Air Lines jumbo jet on a runway of the airport in the Persian Gulf sheikdom of Dubai. The hijackers, who seized the jet Friday over the Netherlands, have ordered the plane refueled and released a wounded member of the aircraft's crew,
A drunken gunman was beaten unconscious by a crowd of residents of West 134th Street yesterday morning after he shot and killed one man and wounded two of the dead man's brothers.

The American Nurses Association has sent a letter of apology to the Kennedy family for a "breach of ethics" by the late Joseph P. Kennedy's nurse, who wrote a book about her experiences, says Jean Bowen, president of the Connecticut Nurses' Association.
Joe Namath checked into the New York Jets' training base at Hofstra University today and said he was ready to begin two-aday workouts tomorrow with the National Football League club.

The Soviet Union has launched an unmanned spaceship on a six- month, 290- million- mile flight to Mars, taking advantage of infrequent firing "window" in an apparent attempt to set a package of electronic gear down softly on the planet.

A Senate investigation into secret bombing raids in Cambodia is beginning to unravel another sordid tale of cover-up by the Nixon Administration, of contempt for the truth, the law and the Constitution by military and civilian officials extending to the highest levels of Government.

ALBANY-Two years ago, a nonpartisan group surveyed the 50 state legislatures and decided that New York's was second only to California's, a rating that has often been bandied about by many of the state's 210 lawmakers, particularly when they are about to do such things as increase their pay and expense allowances.
Pope Paul VI expressed support today for the cause of missionaries who condemned "misdeeds perpetrated against defenless populations."

Since the coming of summer, an increasing number of callers to the Police Department's 911 emergency service say they must wait long periods-from 5 to 45 minutes on busy Saturday nights-before getting a response.
Mikhail V. Isakovsky, whose songs and poems have passed into Russian folklore, has died at the age of 73, Tass, the government press agency, reported today.
A Federal suit that charges that the State of New Jersey and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico have illegally condoned abuses of migrant workers by New Jersey farmers is moving toward a resolution.

The Yankees stuck persistently to one script yesterday, despite losing the first game of a double-header with the Chicago White Sox, 4-2, and it paid off with a 2-0 second-game victory before a Bat Day crowd of_53,664 at Yankee Stadium.

The marriage of Miss Diane Scharf to Herman Kaufman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis S. Kaufman of South Orange, N. J., took place here this afternoon. Robert M. Anstett, Judge of Probate in Westport. performed the garden coremony at the home of Mrs. Leonora Scharf, mother of the bride.

The New York Coliseum and several individuals are filing a wide-ranging lawsuit in State Supreme Court today, aimed at halting further action on the 200-million convention hall on Manhattan's West Side.
In Mindanao, Moslem insurgency has shattered communities by setting Filipino Moslem against Filipino Christian.

Tom Terrific, as the New York Mets fondly call Tom Seaver, is so terrific that even when he fails he succeeds, and today he enabled the Mets to enter the All-Star vacation on the upbeat by pitching a 3-2 victory over the Houston Astros and driving in the winning run with a squeeze bunt in seventh inning.

Prince Norodom Sihanouk, leader of the Cambodian government in exile in Peking, said today that he would reject any solution proposed by the United States to end the fighting in Cambodia, according to a report by North Korea's Central News Agency.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 22-A man was shot dead early today and two terrorists were slain by their own bomb during a night of violence in Ulster.

Roosevelt Raceway has raised the purse of its International Trot to a record $150,000$25,000 more than its high of last year. The race, in which Une de Mai, harness racing's leading money winner, is the first entrant, is scheduled for Aug. 25.

Not long ago, Gay Talese, the best-selling author, received a postcard from a nun that told him: "Your wife and daughters must be proud of you-you filthy, foul lecher. You are not fit to inhabit Christian society."

With jets of steam hissing from massive pistons, Steam Locomotive 759 and a string of 20 passenger cars rolled smoothly out of the Erie Lackawanna Terminal in Hoboken at 8:45 A.M. today on an excursion run to introduce the American Freedom Train, a planned bicentennial exhibition.

Jimmy Andrews, a pianist whose love affair with the music of Fats Waller shines through almost every note he plays, has started a jazz policy at Brew's, 156 East 34th Street, a rambling, colorful rabbit warren of rooms decorated in a mixture of period styles.
The authorities toda identified a decapitated body found yesterday encased in concrete in a Miami house as that of Mark B. Matson, 16 years old, of Washington County, Ohio.

" Hey Ted, hey Ted, there's something for your bookWatergate!" someone said as Theodore H. White, whose fourth "The Making of the President" is about to be published, scurried across the room toward luncheon at the Century Club.

State Senator Ralph C. De Rose of Essex County, who finished third in the Democratic Gubernatorial primary, is reported to be blocking efforts to bring the important Essex Democratic organization in line behind Brendan T. Byrne, the party's gubernatorial candidate.
Mrs. Katharine Francis Gaylord, wife of Brig. Gen. Bradley Gaylord, U.S.A., retired, died Saturday of cancer at her home in Palm Beach, Fla. Her age was 71.
Luis Ocana of Spain scored a crushing victory in the Tour de France bicycle race today, winning by more than 15 minutes.
SUBOTICA, Yugoslavia--On a warm morning in May two years ago, Lake Palic died. Fish by the scores of thousands floated to the surface, bellies flashing in the sun.
A gracious reader in Hastingson-Hudson gently warns us against philistinism (meat-and-potatoism) regarding seasonings. This calls for further discussion.

An international protest arose yesterday over the start by France of another series of nuclear tests in the South Pacific. Five countries-Japan, Australia, New Zealand, Canada and Sweden-expressed their opposition.
A leadership body of the Democratic party voted by a narrow two-vote majority here today against discussing national issues at next year's midterm Democratic convention.

American warplanes, including B-52 bombers, struck guerrilla positions on all sides of Phnom Penh today. United States air strikes were particularly concentrated southwest and northwest of the capital as Communist troops tried to move through sections of the defensive perimeter 10 miles from the city.

Jimmy Connors kept fifth-seeded Cliff Richey on the defensive tonight as he stroked his way to a 6-0, 6-2 triumph in a 50-minute semifinal match at the United States professional tennis championships.

Construction of a proposed sea level Panama Canal, recommended by a Presidential commission in 1970, received little support from shipping interests and the Governor of the Canal Zone in a Congressional hearing last week.

The Leonia Sports Boosters Club, in its 11th year, now has four women's teams in addition to eight boys' squads. The program, co-sponsored by the Sports Boosters and the Recreation Commission, provides an extra season of play for local high school and college athletes. Games are scheduled four nights a week at Leonia's Wood Park, or in the nearby Recreation Center if weather is a problem.
Italy qualified for the Davis Cup European Zone Group B tennis final against Czechoslovakia in Prague Aug. 4-6, by earning a 3-2 victory over Spain today.

The disclosure that Liberal party fund raisers solicited United States international companies for campaign contributions last year has brought demands on Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau for a Federal investigation.

The Metropolitan Transit Authority's plan for an eastside Long Island Rail Road terminal on Third Avenue is being tentatively questioned by the Federal Urban Mass Transit Administration. It should be-and severely.

WASHINGTON, July 22--Herbert Stein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, predicted today that a recession was not a "likely development" and that the Phase 4 economic program would lead to high employment and a high level of economic activity.
Cincinnati's manager, Sparky Anderson, announced today his starting National League pitcher in Tuesday's All-Star Game would be Rick Wise of the St. Louis Cardinals.
America's next space station crew relaxed today, doing only last-minute reviews before attempting man's longest stay in weightlessness beginning next Saturday.

Hijackers and hostages alike sweltered through a second day of torrid desert heat yesterday on board a red-and-white Japan Air Lines jumbo jet that sat motionless on the shimmering tarmac of an airport in the Persian Gulf sheikdom of Dubai.
Short-term interest rates have swept to record high levels in the last two weeks but there seems little immediate prospect that the long advance is at an end. In fact,
Leonard F. Woodcock, president of the United Auto Workers union has predicted that a strike against the Big Three auto makers or Big Three farmimplement corporations is "unlikely."

Housing and Development Administrator Andrew P. Kerr yesterday announced the awarding of a two-year contract to Relocation Management Services to replace the much-criticized City Urban Renewal Management Company in maintaining city-owned buildings on urban-renewal sites.

Anyone who thinks that a room housing a pair of iguanas has to be something out of Tennessee Williamsall drooping palms, derelict wicker and empty tequila glasses-is going to be in for a surprise on Abraham Straus's seventh floor.
Eight Indians have filed a suit charging the Government with violating the Jay Treaty of 1794 by denying them free border crossing privileges between Canada and Maine.
HOMESTEAD, Fla.-A fragile breeze coursed through the mango groves, stirring the dense Florida heat. "Didn't that little breeze feel nice?" Don Campbell said, and then he shook his head.
The United States announces new wage and price controls, Australia slashes tariffs, the West Germans tighten money with a vengeance, and the British start to do the same.

Has former Attorney General John N. Mitclhell been deprived of his right to a fair trial on conspiracy charges because the Senate Watergate committee questioned him sharply about related political matters for two days over national television?

Black Americans remained far behind whites in most social and economic categories over a five-year period ending last year, and there were indications that the gap was widening in some areas, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

The. St. Louis Cardinals are in first place in the National League Eastern Division, but they are not getting too worked up over it-in the same way that they didn't get excited after a woeful start this season (a 5-20 won-lost record on May 9).
The showdown between the Senate Watergate committee and President Nixon over the committee's urgent request for tape recordings made in the President's office is expected to come tomorrow.

President Nixon's threat to veto the war powers legislation that was adopted by both houses last week only serves to underscore the need for strong legislation reasserting the essential role of Congress in determining when this country's armed forces should be committed to combat.
As a result of mounting complaints. West Orange is scheduled to adopt an ordinance regulating garage sales, the increasingly popular weekend sport. The ordin-

The favored entry of Le Cle and Pallisima finished one, two today in the $83,650 Beverly Hills Handicap for fillies and mares at Hollywood Park. The winnings entry paid $5.80. Bill Shoemaker got the 4year-old Le Cle home by one length over Pallisima, ridden by Laffit Pincay Jr.

A damaged Volkswagen has collided with a New York State garageman's lien law, with the result that the law may be declared unconstitutional. That. was the thrust of an opinion handed down early this month by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, which covers New York.
The Budweiser shot past a dead-in-the-water Pay 'n Pak and fought off a challenge by the Atlas Van Lines to win the Gold Cup regatta of unlimited hydroplane racing today.

FOR SHOW The Jewish holiday of Tisha B'Av, which occurs this year on Aug. 7, is a sad one, a day of mourning, because it is associated with so many disasters that befell Jews about that datethe destruction of the first and second temples, the expulsion from Spain.
State Senator John J. Marchi of Staten Island returned from a trip to Israel and Italy yesterday, called for pension reform and said he backed Governor Rockefeller's transportation bond bill.
Joe Namath checked into the New York Jets' training base at Hofstra University today and said he was ready to begin a two-aday workouts tomorrow with the National Football League club.

Unless it becomes diverted along the way, the Federal Government has embarked on a thorny new inquiry in the century-old search for proper relationships between capitalist profits, state and society. No less than this is inherent in the formal complaint filed last week by the Federal Trade Commission against the nation's eight largest oil companies for alleged conspiratorial practices over the last 23 years.
Mark Donohue needed to do little more than go through the motions this afternoon to win the Glen Can-Am after the virtual disintegration of what competition there was around him.

At 44 years of age, a prosperous, soft-spoken Mennonite farmer and father of six, Robert L. Bear seemed oddly cast as a heretic, excommunicated from his church and angrily challenging the faith of his fathers.
THE BILLION DOLLAR SURE THING. By Paul E. Erdman. 248 pages. Scribners. $6.95. THEY'VE SHOT THE PRESIDENT'S DAUGHTER! By Edward Stewart. 298 pages. Doubleday. $6.95.
About 65,000 cannery workers began returning to work today, ending a three-day harvest strike that paralyzed canneries in northern California and left fruit rotting on the ground.
As Premier Fidel Castro watched, the Cuban Government unveiled its newest military arsenal today in an armed forces parade marking the 20th anniversary of the Castro revolution.
Walter Ulbricht, the veteran East German Chief of State who suffered a stroke on Thursday, apparently continued to be in a coma tonight.

Secretary of Commerce Frederick B. Dent's current visit here to announce the creation of an American trade center in Taipei reflects the fast-growing economic relationship between Taiwan and the United States. But many Chinese Nationalists are wondering what it signifies for the political relationship between the two countries.
A historical survey of Puerto Rican art will open at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Wednesday and continue through Sept. 16 on the second floor of the museum's north wing.
The United Nations finds itself with a new and troublesome problem, not much larger than a thumbnail.
The United States formally told Afghanistan's new republican Government today that it intended to continue close and cordial relations between the two countries.
The leader of a Canadian truce team said today that interrogation of six North Vietnamese prisoners disclosed infiltration into Cambodia and South Vietnam as late as June.

State police officials said today that heavily wooded terrain in the Adirondack mountain area near here was hampering efforts to search for a Boston University coed missing since the body of her camping companion and fellow student was found Friday.

The Rev. Louis Gigante, a Democratic district leader in the South Bronx, yesterday urged Representative Herman Badillo to stop circulating petitions to be listed as an independent in the November mayoral election.
Gene Littler, once a cancer victim whom many thought would never play golf again, capped his comeback with a one-stroke victory today in the $210,000 St. Louis Children's Hospital Classic.

The much-publicized gasoline shortage and recent charges of corporate wrongdoing brought by the Federal Trade Commission have thrown a fresh spotlight on the close relationships between the oil industry and Government regulators.
George F. Mitchell, a leader in the development of the lea industry in the United States, died yesterday at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 91 years old.
A drunken gunman was beaten unconscious by a crowd of residents of West 134th Street yesterday morning after he shot and killed one man and wounded two of the dead man's brothers.

The new head of the city's Criminal Justice Coordinating Council is a former beat patrolman who is known as a smooth and strong-willed administrator at his city office, but is teased by his wife for being "a pushover for children and old ladies."
The Olympic gold medalist, Rod Milburn of the United States, equaled his world record of 13.1 seconds to easily win the men's 1l0-meter hurdles event in a 10-nation track meet today.
A new ship name, the Doric, is scheduled to be added to the liner tonnage active in the port. That name will be on the latest addition to the cruise ship fleet of Home Lines.

Slowly, relentlessly and with surprisingly little public acknowledgment, Wall Street has slipped into another serious financial crisis that is wiping out profits in the securities industry and forcing investment firms out of business.

ALBANY-Two years ago, a nonpartisan group surveyed the 50 state legislatures and decided that New York's was second only to California's, a rating that has often been bandied about by many of the state's 210 lawmakers, particularly when they are about to do such things as increase their pay and expense allowances.
The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown re-

We had a strange first in "La Sylphide" at the New York State Theater Saturday night when Michael Denard from the Paris Opera Ballet danced in the Erik Bruhn staging of the original Bournonville ballet for the first time.
Magic might be considered the theme of this summer at the Lenox Arts Center. The season began with "Houdini," and in two weeks there will be a visit from a musical "Mandrake the Magician."

Russell Hardie, a featured player in many Broadway shows, as well as a performer in many television plays and films, died yesterday in a nursing home in Clarence after an illness of several years. His age was 69.
" What! And Leave Bloomingdale's?" is the label for a package of four one-act plays about boy-and-girl complications that tinkle along as pleasantly, aimlessly and transparently as ice cubes.
President Nixon based his refusal today to furnish the White House tapes to the Senate Watergate committee on the intertwined legal doctrines of separation of powers and executive privilege.
Authorities of the Common Market are seeking to put multinational companies under tighter surveillance to narrow their scope for avoiding or reducing taxation in Europe.
A small airplane carrying four officials of the Chicago. based Better Boys Foundation crashed in a field near here this weekend, killing all four.
To the Editor: An interesting coincidence of news reports appearing in the July 8 Times serves to underscore why the middleclass family is a decreasing breed in New York City.

A police official said last night that the Thai Government would press charges of trafficking in drugs against Lo Hsing Han, the so-called "heroin king of the Golden Triangle," though no other country has offered evidence against him.
A Burlington County jury convicted three Delaware River Port Authority officials today of conspiracy to use employes and materials of the authority to build an addition to one of their homes.

WASHINGTON. July 23--Senator Stuart Symington, acting chairman of the Armed Services Committee, declared today that $145-million appropriated by Congress to pay for the secret B-52 bombing of Cambodia may have been obtained under "false pretenses."

DPF, Inc., a computer leasing company, has filed suit against two New York Stock Exchange firms-Edwards Hanly, Inc., and F. S. Moseley Estabrook, Inc.-and three individuals for alleged violations of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

The Chrysler Corporation reported today record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first half. The United Automobile Workers union, which started new contract negotiations with the Big Three auto makers last week, said the report put the U.A.W. in a better bargaining position with Chrysler.

The Museum of Modern Art, which boasts the finest and most complete collection of the art of Joan Mir6, will hold an exhibition of his paintings, sculptures, collages and drawings from Oct. 10 to Dec. 10.

Johnson Johnson, worldwide manufacturer of medical, consumer and industrial products, reported yesterday that net income for the second la quarter this year reached $36.2million, or 65 cents a share, compared with $31.3-million, or 56 cents, a year earlier.

ON THE HEIGHTS That splendid assortment of museums and institutions clustered in the enclave known as Audubon Terrace, on Broadway between 155th and 156th Streets, in the foothills of Washington Heights, has several current attractions that call for a trip.
One of New York's most famous players teamed with a veteran Californian star and led the field of 192 pairs into the semifinal stage of the Life Master Pair Championship here this afternoon.
A strike was called last night by the International Union of Operating Engineers, forcing suspension of racing today at Aqueduct race track. Thomas J. Fitzgerald, vice
The Atomic Energy Commission said today that it had recorded seismic signals from a Soviet underground nuclear test yesterday in the Semipalatinsk area of Kazakhstan.

The police here suspect that the Japanese member of a group that hijacked a Japan Air Lines jumbo jet is associated with a radical student organization at Kyoto University that has been linked with the massacre at Tel Aviv airport last year.

Premier Kakuei Tanaka said today that he hoped to advance a new "triangular relationship" between Japan, the United States and Wesern Europe in his discussions with President Nixon in Washington next week.

The partnership between the United States and Iran, symbolized by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi's visit to Washington this week, offers many obvious advantages to this country; but Americans should also be aware of the dangers inherent in this expanding involvement.
Unseeded Jimmy Connors defeated Arthur Ashe, 6-3, 4-6, 6-4, 3-6, 6-2, tonight to win the $12,000 first prize at the 46th United States professional tennis championships at the Longwood Criket Club.
Following are the texts of a letter from the special Watergate proseccutor. Archibald Cox. to J. Fred Buzhardt. Presidential counsel dealing with Watergate;
A hijacked Japanese airliner was blown up at Benghazi airport, Libya, this morning, the Middle East News Agency reported here.

Bronzed and brawny young men, urged on by bikini-clad cheerleaders, displayed their mastery of the surf and tide here this afternoon as 13 lifeguard teams competed in a program of boating and swimming events for medals, scrolls and applause.

Robert Smithson, a sculptor, was killed in the crash of a light plane on Friday, along with the pilot and a photographer, as they were inspecting one of his "Earth works" under construction on a ranch near Amarillo, Tex.
The trade association for the record industry yesterday endorsed the current Federal and local investigations into alleged payola and called on Congress to pass stronger laws against payola.

New York City has lost more than 28,000 jobs while its suburbs in New York StateNassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties-gained more than 24,000 and the eight counties of northeastern New Jersey gained 23,300.
A group of youths, ranging in age from 14 to 17 years, ran shouting through the downtown shopping area.
The Cost of Living Council has granted to clothing and textile manufacturers a partial exemption from the price freeze, a council spokesman reported today.
Stereotypers Union No. 1 announced yesterday that it had voted to ask its international officers for permission to strike the city's four major daily newspapers.

Michael Burke, the former president of the New York Yankees, may be headed for a new career as president of Madison Square Garden. Negotiations are in progress and one Garden executive, who preferred not to be named, said yesterday, "I would be very surprised if negotiations fell apart."

Charles Alan Wright, the White House lawyer who said "no" today to the Watergate prosecutor's request for tapes of President Nixon's office conversations, is a self-styled "conservative" law professor from the University of Texas.
President Nguyen Van Thieu has called for an economic blockade of the areas of South Vietnam controlled by the Vietcong.
The voice print is not yet a reliable means of identification for scientists, let alone the courts, a Superior Court judge said today in acquitting a telephone installer of a bomb threat charge.

Clay T. Whitehead, director of the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy, may leave his post by the end of the year or shortly thereafter, his office said yesterday, confirming reports recently published in the broadcasting trade.

The tempo picked up yesterday in the march of short-term interest rates to record levels, reflecting efforts of the Federal Reserve to curb the business boom and the rapid inflation that has accompanied it.
Frances, a white whale at the New York Aquarium in Coney Island, will he going into seclusion next week to await the birth of her second offspring,

A high State Department official told Congress today that Canada had repeatedly refused to negotiate an agreement with Washington for a trans-Canada oil pipeline from Alaska to the United States border.

The designated hitter will be absent-but Dick Williams, Nolan Ryan, and Willie Mays will be present-when baseball stages its 44th All-Star Game here tomorrow night in the new $70-million home of the Kansas City Royals.

Jerome Elias, assistant manager of the accounting department of Schenley Industries and a past president of the Village Independent Democrats, was drowned Sunday in heavy surf while swimming at Fair Harbor on Fire Island.
Security guards discovered a secret eavesdropping device in Gracie Mansion in 1969, officials disclosed yesterday.

A compromise worked out by the Securities and Exchange Commission and C. Arnholt Smith's Westgate - California Corporation today averted, at least temporarily a receivership for the $190-million corporation.

This is the season of death in Calcutta. It is the season when the warm monsoon rains break at dawn and flood the sewers and turn the streets into streams of squalor. It is the season when the mud hovels and straw shacks are swamped; when drenched.
Assembly Speaker Thomas H. Kean, Republican of Essex, asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to delay the proposed fare increase on the PATH commuter line until the Port Authority of New

Fred W. Hooper's Special Team took command in the stretch today and gave the 2-5 favorite, Thirty One Jewels, her first loss in seven races in the $106,790 Arlington-Washington Lassie at Arlington Park.

Following are excerpts from the transcript of testimony by Gordon C. Strachan today on the 26th day of hearings on the Watergate case before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:

The beginning of what has been widely predicted as a "bulge" or "peak" in food prices following the lifting of the Government's freeze became evident yesterday, as price increases--some of them extraordinary--went into effect at the wholesale and retail levels.

Charles Owens, a 21-year-old Tuscaloosa, Ala., player, eliminated 11th seeded Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, 7-6, 6-2, tonight as the $75,000 Washington Star-News international tennis championships began.

New orders for durable goods remained essentially unchanged in June at the record May level, the Commerce Department reported today. With orders still far exceeding shipments, the huge backlog of unfilled orders grew by $2.85-billion to $96.73-billion at the end of June.

An apparently deranged young man with two fire bombs and a revolver in a brown paper bag walked into the 19th Precinct police station on East 67th Street last night and shot a sergeant and a lieutenant before being killed in a fusillade of police bullets.
A powerful Soviet team took a 66-51 lead over the United States men in the first day of a dual track and field meet today despite the brilliant running of Steve Williams of San Diego.
Governor Rockefeller yesterday proposed giving the State Banking Board the power to set home mortgage loan rates at whatever ceiling it judges necessary for changing market conditions.
The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, announced tonight that he was withdrawing his resignation, and said that he would stay on as Libya's head of state until union with Egypt was carried out.
President Nixon based his refusal today to furnish the White House tapes to the Senate Watergate committee on the intertwined legal doctrines of separation of powers and executive privilege.

Special Prosecutor Archibald Cox, who said last May 21 that he would either resign or seek "some public recourse" if anyone attempted to block his criminal investigation of the Watergate scandals, ran into a block today. He did not resign.
The life of the average Afghan seems little touched by the coup d'etat that overthrew the monarchy last Tuesday, but the prices of many basic commodities have dropped in Kabul.

Superior Court Judge Gordon H. Brown ordered offduty policemen and firemen pickets in Paterson to stay 100 feet away from any government construction site. The pickets, according to a complaint by Mayor Thomas C. Rooney Jr., were "harassing" delivery trucks to construction sites in Paterson for an office building, parking garage and senior citizens apartment house.
The Senate, without a dissenting vote. approved today a bill to prohibit discrimination in access to credit on the basis of sex or marital status.
In the anonymity that 65,000 empty seats provide, the third annual all-stargame between Atlantic Collegiate Baseball League and the Cape Cod League was played at Yankee Stadium yesterday.

Gordon C. Strachan, a former aide to H. R. Haldeman, testified today that three days after the Watergate break-in, under what he believed to be orders from Mr. Haldeman, he destroyed documents indicating that Mr. Haldeman knew that G. Gordon Liddy was conduct. ing a political intelligence operation with a sizable budget.

The Senate Finance Committee voted today to change a law under which doctors, lawyers and other professionals have been able to save thousands of dollars of Federal income taxes each year by incorporating and taking large tax-free deductions for their own retirement plans.

A Securities and Exchange Commission staff attorney urged the S.E.C. today to approve the proposed merger of E. I duPont de Nemours Co. and the Christiana Securities Company while questioning whether the companies' financial advisers were sufficiently inde pendent.

Contract negotiators for the City University and its facultystaff union have reached a tentative agreement on a threeyear contract to cover the university's 16,000 faculty and staff members, the union announced yesterday.
J. Gilpin Bright, a former "Flying Tiger" and a World War II ace who shot down 12 Japanese, German and Italian planes, died Sunday in the Veterans Administration Hospital.
Constantine, the deposed Greek King, issued a statement today calling on the Greek people to vote "no" in the referendum, scheduled for Sunday, on the abolition of the monarchy.

A top official of the Department of Agriculture denied under oath today any recollection of advance information on the big Soviet grain deal that three officers of the Continental Grain Company have testified he received last July.
The bulls gored the bears badly in the nation's commodities markets yesterday as the price of almost every raw material for future delivery advanced in active trading.

When Congress passed the Anti-Deficiency Act in 1905, it specifically recognized the right of the President to withhold appropriated funds in order "to effect savings whenever savings are made possible by or through changes in requirements, greater efficiency of operations, or other developments."

" It is very contemporary, very American," the tape salesman had said. "You will never regret it." I bought it. "The Big Nosy Ear System," it was called. A secret tape recorder for every wall in the house. It had to be installed in the dead of night, of course, so the family and neighbors would not know.

Louis L. Levine, State Industrial Commissioner, has announced that a total of 7,936 million people were employed In New York State in June, an increase of 85,000 over the total for May and 15,000 over the total for June, 1972.

COLUMBIA, S. C.-J. Bonner Manly answered the telephone, then cupped his hand over the transmitter and asked a visitor in his office if he would like to eavesdrop. The visitor nodded. The caller was an industrial executive somewhere in the Middle West.

Bronzed and brawny young men, urged on by bikini-clad cheerleaders, displayed their mastery of the surf and tide here this afternoon as 13 lifeguard teams competed in a program of boating and swimming events for medals, scrolls and applause.
Carlos Griffin, long-time part-time correspondent for The New York Times in Chile, has died in an automobile accident in Mendoza, Argentina, according to word received here.

Although no such talk has yet been heard in public, some members of the Senate Armed Services Committee are convinced that the secret bombing of Cambodia will emerge as another, perhaps more dangerous, facet of the Watergate scandal.

The West German Government acted today to discourage the flow of money into the country. The effect was to check the advance of the mark, which gained against other European currencies. The dollar closed slightly weaker in relatively quiet trading.
A fire roared through Haiti's presidential palace early today and hiew up an amnunilion dump in the basement, and President Jean-Claude Duvalier tied to his summer residence.

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., after signing subpoenas today for tape recordings and documents President Nixon has refused to yield voluntarily, declared at the Senate Watergate hearings that the constitutional doctrine of separation of powers did not apply to "alleged criminal activities."

President Nixon refused today to release tape recordings of his conversation about the Watergate case. Both his special prosecutor and the Senate Watergate committee moved at once to subpoena the tapes.

A 16-year-old boy who got his first job two weeks ago as a Parks Department summer worker was robbed of $1 and stabbed to death yesterday morning in the maintenance building of a Lower East Side park swimming pool.

A hijacked Japanese jumbo jet, parked since Saturday on a sun-baked desert airfield in the Persian Gulf sheikdom of Dubai, took off with 141 hostages early today and landed two and a half hours later at Damascus, Syria, 1,200 miles to the northwest.

The American Stock Exchange has told the Securities and Exchange Commission that its very existence as an equity market is threatened by the New York Stock Exchange's proposal to start trading in stock warrants.
An empty subway train derailed at. 86th Street and Lexington Avenue on the southbound express track last night the Transit Authority reported.
A United States District Court judge here today ordered resumption of three Federal subsidized housing programs, which he said had been illegally suspended last January.

Statistics took center stage at the National Urban League convention today and all were a matter of dispute. Dr. Robert B. Hill, the league's director of research, said that most of the 1.8 million black persons missed by 1970 census takers were in New York City.

It seems as though there are always new shops opening in New York, even in the doldrums of summer when "Sale" and "Closed on Saturday" notices are out all over town. One such shop is Chinoiserie, which opened at 235 East 60th Street on June 27.

The great virtue in Governor Rockefeller's $3.5-billion bond plan for mass transit, up a full $1 billion from the previous transportation bond issue rejected in 1971 by the voters, lies outside the borrowing scheme altogether. Miss Murphy, who is 45 years old, is scheduled to be sworn in to the post on Aug. 5 in Washington.

The Soviet Union held off a fast-closing performance by a young but tired United States track team today for a 216-163 aggregate victory, their eighth in the 11 dual meets between the two nations.

Thomson McKinnon Auchincloss, Inc., and Kohlmeyer Co., both member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday they had agreed in principle to combine their businesses. The Canadian Government moved yesterday to gain effective control of Texas Gulf, Inc., a huge United States metals and sulphur-producing company with major mines and processing plants in Canada.

For the third time in eight days, wholesalers yesterday raised the price of eggs. The price for large grade A eggs was up 5 cents a dozen at the twice-weekly wholesalers' auction, to 73 cents a dozen.
The 44-story Avianca tower building, Bogota's tallest, was badly damaged in a fire yesterday that cost at least six lives and injured 63 persons. Thirty floors were gutted.

Travelers checks worth $500,000 were stolen from the First National City Bank branch at 399 Park Avenue on July 9, the police disclosed yesterday. The bank confirmed the loss but would say only that the checks had "'disappeared somewhere in transit about 10 days ago."

The Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday a proposed public offering of $150-million of first and refunding mortgage bonds in October and reported gains in first-half operating revenues and net income.

BECKER-Eleanor. Beloved wife of the late Frank, devoted mother of Claire and John. Services were held Tuesday, July 24th.

The two-income family pays the most in Social Security taxes and, proportionally, gets the least back, a witness before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress said today.
Two Japan Air Lines jetliners were directed to Libya today to pick up 137 persons who went through a three-anda-half-day air piracy that ended with their plane's being blown up here.

The dramatic confrontation this week in Washington between the Department of Agriculture and the major grain exporters leaves the question of responsibility for the Soviet grain-deal fiasco very much up in the air. Depending upon whom one chooses to believe, the department either knew all about the huge Soviet grain purchases a year ago and chose to hide the facts from the public and the farmers,

The $6.9-billion Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company, one of the most conservative insurers in the country, disclosed yesterday that it was investing nearly $60-million on an oil and gas wildcatting venture off the coast of Louisiana and Texas.

The State Department today defended the 1969-70 secret bomb. ing of Cambodia by asserting that Prince Norodom Sihanouk, then Cambodia's leader, solicited the secret American raids to rid his country of North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces.
The United States Senate spent a long afternoon today in a family argument about money --its own members' $42,500-a-year salaries. In a four-hour free-for-all all, there were no winners.

For Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, who saw President Nixon again yesterday for a second round of talks since the Iranian Emperor's arrival Monday, meeting with American Presidents must seem like a bit of djiavu.

Thailand's Premier, Fieldi Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn, has formally criticized a United States Congressional report that accused Thai officials of at least tacit complicity in the huge narcotics traffic here.

President Nixon's refusal to release the tape recordings of his conversations about the Watergate case was criticized today by The Times of London, which had been one of his most sympathetic supporters in the controversy.
Meyer Halpern, a New York lawyer and president emeritus of the New York Civil and Criminal Courts Bar Association, died yesterday. He was 75 years old and lived at 5 Tudor City Place.

John D. Ehrlichman categorically denied today a series of charges linking him to the Watergate cover-up and insisted that he never sought President Nixon's pledge of executive clemency for the conspirator E. Howard Hunt Jr.
Soon after John D. Ehrlichman, the former white House adviser, finished answering questions today by Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii whispered, "What a liar!"

The Indian Harbor Yacht Club crew, captained by John Stautner, took a two-point lead today in the 50th annual junior sailing championship of Long Island Sound. The first four races in the final series were sailed off Indian Harbor, with one more to be sailed tomorrow.

Red Holzman, general manager and coach of the world champion New York Knickerbackers, said yesterday the National Basketball Association club would train at Monmouth College on West Long Branch, N. J., for the third straight year.
Louis St. Laurent, Prime Minister of Canada from 1948 to 1957, died today at his residence in Quebec City. He was 91 years old.

Something there is in man which deeply loves an island. As one writer has observed, "Islands are transcendent, magical places capable of magnifying and transforming experiences and emotions beyond the norm of mainland reality." The lure of islands has in recent years brought a speculative land boom and the threat of oppressive overcrowding.

A young woman bank teller who became annoyed after her bank was robbed today for the second time in less than two months dashed from the bank to stamp out the lighted fuse of a pipe bomb that had been left at the entrance by the fleeing robber.

The move by a Canadian Government corporation to acquire control of Texasgulf, Inc., a huge United States metals and sulphur-producing company, stirred skeptical questions by the political opposition today.

Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds claimed today that Bill Singer of the California Angels threw four straight spitballs in last night's AIll-Star game. Rose said he protested to Nestor Chylak, the plate umpire.

In tones of the highest seriousness, the Watergate committee Senators today urged, admonished and instructed their "guests" in the gallery to behave themselves, not to forget the purpose of the hearings and not to turn them into a "circus, show or entertainment."
No surer proof of the concluded war between ballet and modem dance could be given than the Cubiculo's final summer program on Tuesday evening.

Both the Yankees and the Mets go back to work today after an All-Star vacation for most of their members. Although they stand at opposite ends of their respective divisions, their situations are not quite that different.
The possibility of a match race between the Triple Crown winner, Secretariat of the Meadow Stable, and Linda's Chief, will be discussed at Aqueduct today.
Senator Mike Mansfield today renewed his call for reductions of American forces overseas with a demand that 250,000 land-based troops be pulled back by the beginning of 1977, starting now.
To the Editor: I should like to comment on the July 19 full-page General Motors advertisement ("Let's Respond to the Energy Question Before it Becomes Critical") .

President Nixon's argument against letting the Watergate investigators hear his secret tapes rests, in the end, on the premise that the President must decide on his own where the public interest lies. He has played the tapes and given his judgment. His discretion must be absolute.
George Theodore of the Mets, who suffered a dislocated hip in an outfield collision with Don Hahn during a game July 7 in Shea Stadium, has been released from Roosevelt Hospital.
Teimuraz Kakulia crushed Patrick Proisy, France's No. 1 tennis player, 6-3, 6-3, 6-4, today and led the Soviet Union to victory in the European Zone A Davis Cup playoff.
The House Appropriations Committee voted today to prohibit spending Government funds to improve President Nixon's privately owned homes unless Congress approves.

The Rev. Daniel Berrigan and a dozen other war protesters stood vigil yesterday on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral to demonstrate their opposition to the continued bombing of Cambodia. In 1968, Father Berrigan was sentenced to serve three years in prison for having burned draft records in Catonville, Md.

The former Secretary of the Air Force and the four-star general who was serving as the Air Force's Vice Chief of Staff in 1969 told the Senate Armed Services Committee today that they had not been informed of the secret B-52 bombing raids in Cambodia.

Gulf Western Industries, Inc., said yesterday that it was terminating its tender offer to the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company and had instructed the depositary to return all shares still being held.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I.. July 25--The "oneness" that Joe Namath said he detected on the Jets' defense this training camp is as much spiritual as it is physical.

In quite a few recent novels, I've noticed a growing impatience with human nature, a tendency to try to plumb it by way of shortcuts, using the sort of ellipsis that certain drugs are supposed to encourage. It has become a common thing for an author to push his characters to their extremist limits

A Burlington television reporter was held in contempt by a judge today when he refused to reveal his sources. District Court Judge Edward McClallen Jr. delayed sentencin John Gladding of WCAXTV for 10 days pending an appeal.
WASHINGTON, July 25--President Nixon announced today the resignation of former Gov. John B. Connally of Texas as an unpaid, part-time Presidential advisor.

Dr. Daniel Ellsberg said last night that his father- in - law, Louis Marx, had never been a friend of J. Edgar Hoover, the late director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which is contrary to the statements by John D. Ehrlichman that their friendship had caused Mr. Hoover to curtail investigating the Ellsberg case.
A request for a temporary injunction to halt the scheduled fingerprinting of more than 40 eighth-grade boys in a murder investigation was denied today by a Federal judge.
The American Automobile Association said yesterday that gasoline supplies to service stations across the United States increased for the third consecutive week last week.

Daniel Voll took the witness stand in the trial of Ted Patrick yesterday to relate how Mr. Patrick and Mr. Voll's father allegedly seized him on the was street last January and tried to spirit him away.

The dean of a black school of social work said today that black persons had a share of blame for their lack of control in their own communities. "Blacks' reticence to seize the initiative to organize their own communities,"
A Federal District Court Judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that the Government must halt the American bombing of Cambodia on the ground that it is "unauthorized and unlawful."

The third week of New York Philharmonic concerts in the park opened with a bang at the Sheep Meadow on Tuesday night, not to mention the assorted thunks, bongs and whirs that are a prime feature of William Kraft's Concerto for Four Percussion Soloists and Orchestra. The program,

Virginia Electric and Power Company yesterday announced plans to sell about $90 to $95-million in common stock in a negotiated public offering, co-managed by Morgan Stanley and Merrill Lynch, on Sept. 26. The company's stock closed at 19 3/8, down 5/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Two magazine publishers on opposite coasts are carving out their pieces of the burgeoning recreational market. For Ronald Hagen of San Francisco, it's the bicyclist, while William Kemsley of New York is after the overnight hiker.
Nelson (Al) Gainer, a former light-heavyweight and heavyweight boxer who was never knocked down in the ring, died Sunday after a long illness. He was 66 years old.
New York City stands to lose millions in Federal funds for educationally deprived children in the 1974 fiscal year under budget restrictions Imposed by the Nixon Administration.
Mario Merola, the Bronx District Attorney, announced yesterday the destruction of an international narcotics ring allegedly led by a 27-year-old former city welfare investigator.

Following are excerpts from the transcript of testimony by John D. Ehrlichman today on the 28th day of hearings on the Watergate case before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:

A betting institution at race tracks across the United States-the daily double--was replaced by the quinella tonight at Roosevelt Raceway as a 72-night meeting got under way at the harness racing center.

The House Appropriations Committee voted today to wipe out the White House's traditional $1.5million "special projects" fund, from which the Nixon Administration paid, among other things, the $100-a-day consulting fee of E. Howard Hunt Jr., the convicted Watergate conspirator.

The possibility of a match race between the Triple Crown winner, Secretariat of the Meadow Stable, and Linda's Chief, will be discussed at Aqueduct today. Mrs. John (Penny) Tweedy, who directs the racing activities of the Meadow Stable, will attend the discussions.
The second interzonal chess tournament for worldchampionship aspirants, scheduled to begin here last Sunday, has started off as a huge game of Kriegspiel.
Fair American, Astrea and Pooh were corrected-time winners today when a fleet of 32 on the American Yacht Club's 42d annual cruise raced 21 miles from Block Island to Fort an Adams in Newport Harbor.

Communist forces shelled the outskirts of Phnom Penh tonight, in what appeared to be a terror attack on the civilian population. Some of the shells landed inside the capital itself in the western sector. Early reports indicated that at least seven people had been killed and 20 wounded, but these reports were incomplete and the toll was likely to rise.

The Shah of Iran, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, said today that he planned to purchase an unspecified number of F-14 Navy fighter planes and was interested in also buying the latest Air Force fighter, the F-15, to boost his country's defenses.

Denise Wood is quite an athlete. She doesn't have a coach and many times practices in her backyard. She puts the shot and throws the discus and javelin with phenomenal success. The 23-year-old physical education teacher is a multi-champion in the New Jersey Amateur Union since having won her first state title in 1968, and she is raising eyebrows on the national scene.

" I'm walking away from this game healthy," noted John, Mackey as he announced his retirement from a 10-year pro football career. One of the most familiar sights of. the 1960's was Mackey taking a short pass from 'John Unitas, then bouncing off or bowling over five or six tacklers on his way to the end zone.
A bill to curb the President's power to impound funds appropriated by Congress cleared the House late today after two days of lively debate. The vote was 254 to 164.
PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND, Canada-It is difficult to talk of trout and salmon in a gathering of big game anglers just back from a day of trolling for giant bluefin tuna, but it was finally accomplished,
Oil company earnings reports continued to provide an embarrassment of riches for the industry as sharply higher profits were announced yesterday by a number of companies.

CONCORD, Mass.-Raoul Berger thinks of himself as a Dutch housemaid sweeping out dark corners of the Constitution. Impeachment, for example, was a dark corner until Mr. Berger wrote the first comprehensive book about it. Now the dust is flying around executive privilege.
Candidates for public office in New Jersey began filing their first reports this week under a campaign disclosure law that pleases no one.
Pledging to create a close cooperative spirit between Trenton and Washington to shake the Federal money tree, Brendan T. Byrne, Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey, won endorsements and
The police barred thousands of screaming fans from a funeral service today for Bruce Lee, the moive star in kung-fu features. Mr. Lee collapsed and died Friday at the age of 33.

After a heated 10-year legal battle with environmentalists, Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday that it would break ground in November for its controversial Storm; King hydroelectric power plant on the Hudson River 40 miles from New York City.

Just 11 blocks from the Empire State Building, where King Kong was shot down for the love of Fay Wray, is the four-story gray factory of Messmore and Damon, and it is here that the great ape is being reborn.
Top-seeded Stan Smith of Sea Pines, S. C., had little difficulty today in disposing of Brian Gottfried, 6-3, 6-3, in the second round of the Washington Star-News tennis tournament.
The senate passed, 91 to 2, today a bill requiring that Presidential appointments of six Interior Department officials be subject to Senate confirmation. The officials af-
George Theodore of the Mets, who suffered a dislocated hip in an outfield collision with Don Hahn during a game July 7 in Shea Stadium, has been released from Roosevelt Hospital.

LONDON-"The revolution was born at Moncada," said Celia Sanchez, who has been Fidel Castro's closest associate since the guerrilla days of the Sierra Maestra. She was referring to the desperate attack against almost hopeless odds led by Castro against the Moncada Barracks in Santiago de Cuba twenty years ago, on July 26, 1953. Cuba is having one of Its biggest-ever celebrations today.

Consumer protection has been increased by new laws recently enacted in New York State. Assistant Attorney General Mindell, deputy head of the consumer frauds unit, believes knowledge of the new laws can help consumers save money.

The Secretary General of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said yesterday nations that buy American grain should have a voice in deciding how it will be allocated during periods of shortage.
A temporary truce was called here today in a battle between commercial fishing interests and sports fishermen over whose right it is to fish close to the Connecticut shore in Long Island Sound.

The story of the World War II Japanese straggler who had lived as a Filipino ever since the war turned out today to be a hoax. "I'm not Ryoji Miki," said Tanao Tao at a news conference held at the Japanese Embassy. "I'm Filipino born. But they wouldn't believe me."
President Nixon should have dismissed J. Edgar Hoover as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation early in his Presidency, John D. Ehrlichman asserted today.

John D. Ehrlichman denied charges linking him to the Watergate cover-up, and insisted to the Senate investigating committee that he never sought executive clemency for E. Howard Hunt Jr., one of the conspirators. [Page 1, Column 8; Text, P. 28.]

Emiel Puttemans ran the world's second-best two miles at an international track meet today, beating Ben Jipcho of Kenya. The 26-year-old Belgian star was clocked in 8 minutes 16.32 seconds, 2.4 seconds above the record set here last year by Lase Viren of Finland. Viren finished seventh today in 8:35.5. Jipche, the word 3,00-meter steeplechase champion, was timed in 8:16.39, and Rod Dixon of New Zealand was third in 8:17.32.

The Legislature convened today in a special session to deal with the pension and transit crises, and soon found itself facing the question of whether to build a greenhouse for the Boyce Thompson Institute of Yonkers.

FAIR WEATHER This is the time of year for fairs, usually in a dusty plain on some otherwise unused rural acres. It's always dangerous to say that something is a first, but it's fair to say that the first fair to be held downstairs at the Hallmark Gallery, Fifth Avenue and 56th Street, (582-9130) is now in full swing. "Cityfair" is

The Government shocked the nation's grain traders again yesterday by announcing that more than half the expected American wheat crops this year had been booked for export as of July 6. The wheat crop year starts July 1.

The social studies department chairman at West Morris-Mendham High School said today that an alleged investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of one of his pupils could hinder his students' desire to seek out answers to political questions.
President Nixon should have dismissed J. Edgar Hoover as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation early in his Presidency, John D. Ehrlichman asserted today.

Robert Moses, who over the years left an imprint as few others have on the map of New York City, gave the maestro's nod of approval today to Jersey City's face-lifting project for housing, parkland and industrial development along its Hudson River shoreline
Westminster, the nation's most prestigious dog show, has had 66 best-in-show winhers. Of these, 16 have been fox terriers, more than three times as many as the next breed.
Prisoners in the Bergen County Jail are finally getting a place in the sun. Sheriff Joseph F. Job, a frequent critic of the 63-year-old institution's lack of recreational facilities,

The Nixon Administration said yesterday that if its community-development revenuesharing proposal is passed by Congress, by 1978, New York City would be getting nearly $50-million a year more in Federal community-development funds than it has been getting over the last five years.

On a recent afternoon, a group of friends-all of them middleclass young professionals and fervent left-wing followers of former Argentine dictator, Juan D. Peron-sat down for a barbecue on the lawn of a suburban house here.

A lawyer representing President Nixon will ask a Federal court tomorrow to set aside at least one of three subpoenas ordering him to produce confidential documents and recordings dealing with the Watergate case.

An underworld figure who had been fighting to avoid a third trial on double-murder charges was freed today by a three-judge Federal appeals court in Philadelphia that ruled he never should have been tried a sec-

President Ferdinand E. Marcos decided today that Filipinos could Pave two days instead of the one previously decreed for voting on whether they want him to continue in office as head of the martial-law regime he established 10 months ago.
" The duty of the President to see that the laws be faithfully executed is a duty that does not go beyond the laws or require him to achieve more than Congress sees fit to leave within his power."
The Food and Drug Administra tion invited the public today to participate in the agency's safe ty review of 533 food ingredients that have been generally recognized as safe.
Alfred Beno Oshins, a knitwear manufacturer, died, apparently of a heart attack, Sunday. He was 60 years old and lived at 1050 Park Avenue and in Westhampton Beach. L. I.
Margaret Gallaudet Sherman Gillen, widow of Harry A. Gillen, a photoengraver, died today in Franklin General Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived at 525 Dubois Avenue.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass. - The last morels of spring had long since gone to spore. Now a rumor wafted down from the Berkshire hilltops that the first chanterelles of summer were shyly peeping through the brown leaves of the forest floor.
Chris Evert and Linda Tuero advanced today to the quarter finals of the $25,000 Marie 0 Clark memorial tennis tournament.
Ben Grauer began announcing for the National Broadcasting Company in 1930, when radio staffers wore tuxedos for evening shows because they were going into the American home, unseen but heard.

Spokesmen for the ruling junta in Greece have warned that a "no" vote in Sunday's referendum would lead to direct military dictatorship. This is hardly news for Greeks who have already endured six years of military rule under the colonels and who are no doubt painfully aware that a "yes" vote for their proposed "presidential parliamentary republic"

Stewart S. Cort, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corpo- c ration, reported yesterday that net income for the second quarter this year totaled $57.9million, or $1.32 a share, up sharply from a net of $36.9million, or 83 cents a share year earlier.
Mayor Ralph J. Perk was charged today with assault and battery on a Cleveland policeman and will appear before Judge Lillian Burke in Municipal Court tomorrow or Friday.

James L. Ferguson, the 47year-old president of the General Foods Corporation, today was named chief executive of the giant food processing and marketing company that has suffered from profit problems in recent years.

Heinrich Boll, the West German Nobel Prize-winning author, has spoken out sharply against what he sees as a renewed campaign of repression against intellectuals and writers in the Soviet Union and is now warning his readers of the dangers of fellow traveling with cold warriors.
The Dayton Tire and Rubber Company announced today the recall of 5,013 tires in an effort to find an estimated 724 that the firm said might be defective.

A Senate subcommittee approved today a budget reform bill aimed at giving Congress tighter control over its spending decisions, and thus, at giving the President fewer opportunities and reasons for overriding Congress on spending matters.

Five Coast Guard enlisted men stationed on Governors Island were charged yesterday with having conspired to murder two Coast Guard intelligence agents. The agents were investigating the five in connection with the illegal sale of narcotics, the Coast Guard said.
Top-seeded Rod Laver won by default and seven other rated players advanced today to the quarterfinals of the $25,000 Volvo international tournament at the Mount Washington Hotel.

Launching crews began the countdown tonight for Skylab 2, with all preparations running on schedule for a liftoff Saturday. "Everything seems to be going great," William C. Schneider, the Skylab program director, said in an interview today.

An area less than five miles south of Phnom Penh was bombed by American B-52's today in the belief that it was used by insurgents yesterday for a shelling attack on the capital. Government troops entered the area later, but did not find the shelling site.
An American Bar Association study group will recommend that the association support a nearly absolute Federal shield law protecting journalists from enforced disclosure of their confidential sources.
The New Jersey Supreme Court today established the precedent that tenants may pay reduced rents to landlords who refuse to provide adequate housing.
Ideal Basic Industries, Inc., yesterday said it had authorized repurchase of up to 1,000,000 of its common shares. The company's stock closed unchanged at 14 1/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.

The starting offensive and defensive units for the New York Giants' intrasquad practice game here Saturday morning at the Monmouth College training camp are virtually set. The final two-a-day practice sessions will be held tomorrow.

The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

Jorge Sanjines's "Blood of the Condor," reportedly the first Bolivian feature film to be commercially released in this country, is like a lot of mid-20th-century revolutionary art that has its roots in the guilt-ridden middle classes of underdeveloped countries.
Mrs. Jacqueline Radin, editor of the Living section of Newsday, drowned Wednesday in a canal at Ste. Tallaye, France. She was 34 years old.

Young members of the House Armed Services Committee forced a delay today on contempt - of - Congress action against G. Gordon Liddy, a convicted Watergate conspirator. Protesting that they did not want to rush into such an important matter without study, they brushed aside the pleas for prompt action of more senior members, including their chairman, F. Edward Hebert, Democrat of Louisiana.

Clarence M. Kelley, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, defended the late J. Edgar Hoover today against reported feelings by the Nixon Administration that he should have retired before the Watergate investigation.

Following are the texts of President Nixon's letter to Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., declining to respond to a subpoena for tapes and papers relating to the Senate Watergate inquiry; a colloquy on the President's letter between Senator Ervin and Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., including a resolution by Senator Baker to seek court action;

When his teammates needled Thurman Munson before last night's game about his failure to get a hit in the All-Star game, he didn't have much of a comeback. Instead, he saved his answer for the game against Milwaukee.
The Commissioner of London's police. Sir Robert Mark, came out strongly today for the establishment of an independent review body to deal with complaints against policemen.

Two New York couples sued Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the bank's holding company, in Federal Court yesterday on charges that the bank practiced sex discrimination in refusing to grant the couples mortgage financing.
Supporters of the deposed Cambodian chief of state, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, charged in a statement issued here today that the Americans "and their lackeys" had been bombing Cambodia since 1963.

When President Ferdinand E. Marcos declared martial law in the Philippines last September in order, he said, to defeat a Communist insurgency and institute sweeping reforms, he declared: "This is temporary and we will go back as fast as we can to normal constitutional processes."

The Lindsay Amdinistration said yesterday that its productivity program for municipal agencies, now one year old, had produced a budget saving of $100-million and had removed the need for 16,000 additional city employes.

The Senate passed a bill today providing criminal penalties for offering funds to a United States Government employe or agency to influence a foreign election. Acceptance of such money would also be a crime.

Texaco, Inc., and the Shell Oil Company announced yesterday sharply higher profits for the three-month and six-month periods ended June 30, continuing the parade of booming oil industry earning reports.

The Republican majority in the State Senate late today pushed through a pension-revision bill setting a minimum retirement age of 62 years for most civil servants hired after July 1, 1973, with benefits based on the average salary of the three highest consecutive years.
Equation, the record breaker and over-all winner in last month's Annapolis-to-Newport race, won top honors in Class I today in the New York Yacht Club race from Newport to Padanaram.
All of the Port Authority's airports, bridges and tunnels will be operating today, authority spokesmen promised last night, although its policemen plan a mass walkout at 11 A.M.
Two brothers-in-law were arraigned yesterday on charges of having kidnapped a 57-yearold Queens woman and of having killed her "despite her pleas for mercy."
A mammoth package of old and new transit and highway proposals was unveiled today by Governor Rockefeller as he detailed his proposed $3.5-billion transit bond issue.

Several thousand supporters converged on the central plaza here today to cheer former dictator Juan Domingo Per6n in his first official public appearance since his return to Argentina last month after 18 years of exile.

The Ford Motor Company's second-quarter share earnings were the highest for any quarter, in the company's history, while sales and earnings for both the quarter and the half reached record levels, the company reported yesterday.
It wasn't exactly a love feast, but John D. Ehrlichman and the Senate Watergate committee seemed today to have decided to at least stop kicking sand in one another's faces.

Libya's fanatical young leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, some time ago indicated that he would resign if he could not achieve his all-consuming goal of merging his tiny, oil-rich nation with Egypt. Last week Colonel Qaddafi announced that he had already resigned in order, he said, "to facilitate the achievement of union." This week,

The new United States Commissioner of Education is Dr. John R. Ottina, whose nomination by President Nixon was confirmed by the Senate yesterday. The 41-yearold Dr. Ottina succeeds Dr. Sidney P. Marland Jr., who left the post last year to become assistant secretary for education.

Without three, and possibly four of their best players, the Miami Dolphins will oppose the College All-Stars here tomorrow night in a duel of coaches who were undefeated last season-Don Shula of the National Football League champions and John McKay of the University of Southern California.

While the crisis in the executive branch continued to deepen this week as a result of the latest developments in the Watergate investigations, two less spectacular but no less significant actions in Congress and the courts gave evidence of the fundamental health and resiliency of the American constitutional system. These two co-equal branches of the Federal Government both took farreaching steps toward reining in the Executive.
Governor Cahill today approved the spending of $440,000 this year to make repairs on the New York and Long Branch Rairoad.
The nation's major commodities exchanges were unsettled late yesterday by rumors that Washington was preparing to restrict exports of basic raw materials.

Reading Supreme Court decisions is a good deal like reading tea leaves. You can always find what you're looking for. With that caveat, it may be useful to notice that last year's decision by the Supreme Court in the Caldwell case found the four Nixon appointees subscribing to a doctrine which could decide the coming litigation over the Ervin and Cox subpoenas to Nixon.

Little public opposition was being displayed to President Ferdinand E. Marcos's martial-law regime today as Filipinos prepared to vote tomorrow and Saturday in a referendum designed to test national feeling about the regime.

ALBANY, July 26--In votes generally along party lines, the Republican majority in the Legislature late today pushed through a pension-revision bill setting a minimum retirement age of 62 years for most civil servants hired after July 1, 1973, with benefits based on the average salary of the three highest consecutive years.

The unemployment compensation system discriminates against women, the armed services discriminate against women and the welfare laws of many states still encourage fathers to desert their families, the Joint Economic Committee of Congress was told today.
Officials of the International Air Transport Association have recommended a 5 per cent increase in trans-Atlantic scheduled fares next year, a spokesman said today.
Delta Air Lines reported today that it fell just short of doubling its profits in fiscal 1973. Earnings soared to $65.9million, or $3.32 a share, from the previous year's $33.2million, or $1.68.
The nation's foreign trade balance improved sharply in June, with imports exceeding exports by only $15.5-million, the Commerce Department reported today.

State Supreme Court Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff admitted yesterday that he was faced with "a difficult problem" in determining whether the showing of alleged pornographic films violated the obscenity statutes.
Dr. Robert Fiske Warren, director of orthopedic surgery at Brooklyn-Cumberland Medical Center and at Long Island College Hospital, died Wednesday at the Albany Medical Center.

WASHINGTON, July 26--It was history without trappings--a few dry words spoken in a courtroom with the defendant's table empty. Archibald Cox, the special prosecutor in the Watergate investigation, went today to the second-floor courtroom of Chief Judge John J. Sirica in the United States District Court.

Despite a noon deadline requiring more than 40 eighth-grade boys to be fingerprinted in a murder investigation or risk being held in contempt of court, the police said today that they did not know how many had complied.

Another major report of soaring food prices was issued yesterday, confirming that cost of pork, bacon, chicken and eggs in New York City was up sharply since the Government instituted Phase 4 of its economic program July 13, ending the ceilings on food prices.
