Two unmanned Soviet space probes are speeding toward Mars to study the red planet and space conditions around it. Tass, the Soviet press agency, said today that the second unmanned interplanetary station, called Mars 5, had been launched yesterday from a satellite orbiting the earth.

The Philadelphia Phillies lost the services tonight of Larry Bowa. a shortstop, probably for the season with a broken bone in his left ankle. Bowa was carried off the field on a stretcher when he injured his ankle trying to steal second base in the third inning.

The Shah of Iran and his Empress, having discharged their official social obligations - that Is, they have been to dinner at the White House, and the Nixons have come to them--relaxed a bit tonight and took about 500 of their friends and acquaintances to the theater.

To many a motorist these days, the streets of Manhattan seem paved with interruptions. A routine trip on some main avenues or crosstown streets can escalate into an obstacle course adventure that joggles the mind and rattles the teeth.

The Cooper River Yacht Club keeps indoctrinating youngsters in the skills of sailing. Its program, which also is sponsored by the Camden County Park Commission, is held on the five-mile long Cooper River, a stream so narrow that a 20-foot sloop would find navigation on it almost impossible.

A former Green Beret sergeant accused the Pentagon today of continuing to cover up the extent of secret United States military operations in Laos and Cambodia. He also charged that Government officials had deliberately understated the number of Americans killed on those operations.
A mammoth package of old and new transit and highway proposals was unveiled today by Governor Rockefeller as he detailed his proposed $3.5-billion transit bond issue.

The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.8 billion, ton-miles, 10.5 per cent above the corresponding week

Americans have started a record buying run on home freezers and are hoarding food in anticipation of higher prices--when the ceiling on beef prices ends Sept. 12-and a meat shortage, a survey showed today.

The Italian Senate last night approved a more modern and democratic statute for the 80-year-old Venice Biennale to put an end to the disputes and violence that have wracked the oldest and most prestigious of the international art and film shows for the last five years and longer.

John D. Ehrlichman said today that the special White House intelligence unit undertook in 1971 a mission so important to national security that it justified President Nixon's efforts to hide the group's existence.

State Supreme Court Justice Aaron E. Koota, who was Brooklyn District Attorney at the time two cases were allegedly fixed, said yesterday that he was "completely satisfied with my own integrity." But he declined further discussion of the cases, which grew out of the testimony of a convicted bond swindler, because he said, investigations were under way.

Narcotics officers on a court - authorized "no-knock" raid broke into the wrong house, confronting a frightened mother and her two children. The authorities confirmed yesterday that the mistaken raid was made Tuesday by five Los Angeles detectives, acting with the Oxnard police.
In what he described as "a personal act of conscience," Archbishop Iakovos, Greek Orthodox Primate of North and South America, has criticized the Greek Government and American policy toward it.

KWEILIN, China - A highlevel decision to broaden the scope of life for foreigners in China, coupled with the end of the war in Vietnam, has resulted in the reopening of this ancient city to foreign visitors. It has long been celebrated as the site of the best mountain and river scenery in this land of mountains and rivers.

Without three, and possibly four of their best players, the Miami Dolphins will oppose the College All-Stars here tomorrow night in a duel of coaches who were undefeated last season-Don Shula of the National Football League champions and John McKay of the University of Southern California.
The nation's foreign trade balance improved sharply in June, with imports exceeding exports by only $15.5-million, the Commerce Department reported today.

The hair is tousled and dark and longish - long enough to cover the ears, but not, repeat, not, long enough to touch the shoulders. The mustache is thick and grows downward. The eyes are smoldering brown. The teeth, ideally, are as white as new-fallen snow.

The Defense Department put into effect yesterday new regulations designed to cut energy consumption 7 per cent in the Pentagon, the world's largest office building. Similar measures were ordered by President Nixon in Government buildings around the country.

The Senate Armed Services Committee today approved the nomination of William E. Colby as director of Central Intelligence. The action was by voice vote, with Senator Harold E. Hughes, Democrat of Iowa, voting against Mr. Colby.

Peter G. Peterson, former Secretary of Commerce and most recently PresidentNixon's roving trade ambassador, will become the new chairman and chief executive of Lehman Brothers, Inc., one of the world's most prestigious Investment banking firms.

Another major report of soaring food prices was issued yesterday, confirming that the cost of pork, bacon, chicken and eggs in New York City was up sharply since the Government instituted Phase 4 of its economic program July 13, ending the ceilings on food prices.

The judicial conventions being held today by political parties in New York City make a mockery of the law. They expose again, if further exposure were needed, the evils of leaving the judicial selection process to the backroom wheeling and dealing of partisan leaders who dispense patronage at the expense of justice. Judgeships become pawns in a seedy game plan for expanding power.

Ken Bannon, vice president of the United Automobile Workers, said today Ford's surge in profits for the first six months of this year was "shocking, almost unbelievable." He said he was "aghast at the amount."
The United States today vetoed a Security Council resolution that "strongly" deplored Israel's continuing occupation of Arab lands taken during the 1967 war.

The usual midsummer doldrums have slowed striped bass fishing along much of the east coast from southern New Jersey to Cape Cod, but in many areas, Long Island Sound among them, large bluefish have moved in.

The American Indian Movement, which has been talking about expanding into a worldwide movement in behalf of Indian rights, began traditional religious ceremonies today in preparation for its national convention.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company achieved record sales and earnings in the quarter and half ended June 30, despite strikes that limited the profit increase to 2.9 per cent in the second quarter,

What the advertising business sorely needed was a historic event not connected with Government regulation, Congressional legislation, consumer demonstration or self-flagellation. They got it last nightego gratification.
A special three-judge Federal panel ruled 2 to I today that New Jersey's antiobscenity law was unconstitutional.
For an old theatrical necessity, Joseph Papp has found a classic answer "two weeks in Philadelphia."

Three years ago, John N. Mitchell, then the Attorney General and President Nixon's closest political adviser, was overheard to say at a cocktail party: "This country is going so far right you are not even going to recognize it."

Unusually high interest rates in West Germany pulled more money into marks today and contributed to weakness in the dollar and the pound in what some experts warned could be the beginning of a new round of currency disorder.

President Nixon, defying subpoenas, refused to produce the White House tapes; Judge John J. Sirica ordered the President to show why he shouldn't be ordered to release the tapes to the Watergate prosecutor, and the Senate Watergate committee voted to start a separate court action to secure the recordings of the President's conversations with Watergate figures.
Facing strong protests from rank and file policemen on his plan to require them to wear name plates on their uniforms, Commissioner Donald F. Cawley agreed yesterday to carry out the plan in stages.

Two couples angered by the alleged refusal of bankers to consider a wife's income in an application for mortgage financing filed a sex-discrimination suit in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday against the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the bank's holding company.

Three days before a nationwide plebiscite intended to confirm Greece as a republic, the military police have freed professors, lawyers and students rounded up last spring in a bid to curb student agitation.

Ken Norton apparently thinks he needs more than just his fists for his fights with Muhammad Ali. Before Norton beat Ali last March he made a habit of saying and writing, "I will beat Muhammad." "I must have done it 80 times a day," he said. He did beat Muhammad and for his rematch with Ali on Sept. 10 at Inglewood,

A crowd of 1,000 people surged into the gymnasium of Wyandanch High School on this muggy night to debate the hottest issue here in many years-a proposal for 182 units of housing for moderate- and low-income families and the elderly.
A special three-judge Federal panel ruled 2 to 1 today that New Jersey's antiobscenity law was unconstitutional.
Three unheralded teams moved into a tie for the lead today in the opening round of the 54-hole $30,000 Lady Angelo's Ladies Professional Golf Association four-ball golf tournament on Cape Cod.

A suit was filed in Federal Court today to block the Hackensack Meadows Sports Complex on the ground that if it went into operation as planned, it would violate the Federal Clean Air Act by creating unacceptable pollution from heavy automobile traffic.
Plans were announced yesterday to convert one-third of Shelter Island from a game preserve to one of the largest developments in the metropolitan region.
The game people are playing at the fall couture fashion shows this week is, "What is the worst collection you've seen so far?"
The Federal Reserve Board imposed on commercial banks today a limit on the amount of the new high-interest fouryear certificates of deposit they can issue to savers.
A relief plane today flew 104 pas sengers of a hijacked Japanese jumbo jet here from Benghazi Libya. After a brief stopover it took off for Tokyo.
Gloucester County has its first two women fire fighters because there were no men around during a recent daytime blaze.

Steve Rogers, a 23-yearold right-hander who joined the Montreal Expos 10 days ago, allowed only one hitan infield single by Jose Pagan in the fifth inningand pitched the Expos to a 4-0 triumph over the Philadelphia Phils last night in Veterans Stadium.

A Dartmouth student who described himself as a close friend of Daniel Voll's told a jury yesterday that his friend underwent a "complete change" in personality after joining the New Testament Missionary Fellowship, a religious group, and became a person "who ignored me and was cold."
Connecticut has brought a Federal lawsuit against 20 major oil companies and three subsidiaries, charging them with violating Federal and state antitrust laws.

To the Editor: When Mr. Nixon, addressing 200 reporters and members of his staff on July 20, said in a mood compounded of petulance and arrogance, "What we were elected to do, we are going to do, and let others wallow in Watergate, we are going to do our job," he was belittling an honest and much-needed investigation of his own corrupt Administration.

The president of the Clifton Board of Education said today that the board would probably hire replacements for 23 of the school system's 26 athletic coaches if they ma??e good on resignations filed to be effective next fall.

Winning numbers drawn July 26 were: NEW YORK 703595 Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.

The Senate Armed Services Committee voted yesterday to direct the Navy to consider development of a new "lightweight" fighter to round out its carrier-based force after purchase of a limited complement of $14-million Grumman F-14's.

President Nixon refused today to comply with subpoenas requiring him to furnish to the Senate Watergate committee and the special prosecutor tape recordings of his conversations about the Watergate case.

The second-quarter after-tax profits of 926 United States corporations soared 30 per cent from year-earlier levels to $7.3-billion compared with a 28 per cent gain recorded by the same group in the first quarter, the First National City Bank reported yesterday in a preliminary survey.
Isaac Allen, a lawyer and Talmudic scholar, died Wednesday of lung congestion in a nursing home in Hartford. He was 98 years old and lived at the Hotel Ansonia, Broadway at 73d Street.
Dr. Beatrice F. Hyslop, professor emeritus of history at Hunter College and an author, died Monday on a visit to Rochester. She was 73 years old and lived at 75-05 35th Avenue, Jackson Heights.

The constitutional impasse created by President Nixon's rejection of subpoenas, from Congress and from the Government's special prosecutor, for Watergaterelated tape recordings and documents has quite properly been referred to the Federal courts. While the long-range implications of this unique case certainly demand careful deliberation at each stage of the judicial process, it is essential that the proceedings be expedited in every possible way.

The confrontation between President Nixon and Congress today touched off a historic legal struggle that could affect the political prestige and authority of their two branches of government for many years.

Gulf Western Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that the company was entering a joint venture with the Occidental Petroleum Corporation to develop a practical zinc-chloride rechargeable battery that could be a power source for a modern electrical automobile. The project will cost about $10-million, and Gulf Western said here that a workable product might be ready in five to 10 years.

Thousands of Federal employes in five southern California counties were asked to stay home from work today as part of a two-week-old Federal plan to reduce dangerously high smog levels. The aim was to reduce traffic.
This city, the fourth largest in the state, has decided to convert a major portion of its congested downtown district into an area of tree-lined shopping malls serving a new retail center.

The State Supreme Court upheld, 5 to 2, Florida's new capital punishment law today. The law sets up a separate trial procedure after a person has been convicted of a capital crime.
Three unheralded teams moved into a tie for the lead today in the opening round of the 54-hole $30,000 Lady Angelo's Ladies, Professional Golf Association four-ball golf tournament on Cape Cod.
Linda's Chief, who was sold for $2-million yesterday, earned a mere $9,000 today for his new owner, Aaron Jones, as he won a nonbetting three-horse race at Monmouth Park.

Henry A. Kissinger has postponed his trip to Peking for talks on Cambodia and other subjects until after Aug. 15the date that American bombing of Cambodia is scheduled to end - Administration officials said today.

In a stunning upset, 12thseeded Dick Stockton of Port Washington, L.I., defeated topseeeded Stan Smith today in the third round of The Washington Star-News international tennis championships. The scores were 6-2, 3-6, 6-4.
Plans were announced yesterday to convert one-third of Shelter Island from a game preserve to one of the largest developments in the metropolitan region.

During the last year, the Nixon Administration did not spend nearly $1.1-billion in funds Congress had intended for major health programs, according to figures obtained by the House Commerce Committee.

The Columbia Broadcasting System radio network will pre-empt all regularly schedtiled programing, except for newscasts, this weekend to present a marathon series of broadcasts under the umbrella title of "The American Woman."
Charges of truce violations were made today by North Vietnam against the United States and by the Government in Saigon against the Vietcong.

Edgar Stehli, one of the oldest and most versatile actors of stage, screen, radio and television, died last night at his home, 540 Highland Avenue. He was 89 years old.

John D Ehrlichman said today that the special White House intelligence unit undertook in 1971 a mission so important to national security that it justified President Nixon's efforts to hide the group's existence.

Two Phantom jets flying in formation with the Blue Angels, the Navy's precision flying team, crashed into each other during practice maneuvers over the Lakehurst Naval Air Station here this afternoon,

The judge at the Pentagon papers trial, William Matthew Byrne Jr., has disputed a statement by John D. Ehrlichman, the former White House aide, that he showed "strong interest" in the post of director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation while the trial was in progress.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va.-Concluding the Gifford lectures at Edinburgh in 1947, the historian, Christopher Dawson, declared that "the recovery of moral control and the return to spiritual order have become the indispensable conditions of human survival."

In one of the odder incidents of the 1972 Presidential campaign, several law partners of Herbert W. Kalmbach, then President Nixon's personal lawyer, owned part of a computer mailing company that worked for Senator George McGovern during the California primary.
Rejecting an effort to cut on all American military assistance for Cambodia, the House tonight approved a $2.8-billion foreign aid bill, concentrating $650 million on the needs of poor countries.

Madison Avenue has discovered horse racing and has come up with a quarter-million-dollar match race. A sponsor, not particularly preferring to remain anonymous, has put up a trophy called the Marlboro Cup and the sum of $200,000 for a most egregious contest between Secretariat an d Riva Ridge.
The dusty lanes in Chouri are silent now. Outside the mud huts the silence at midday is broken by whining dogs and the feeble wails of old women.
Two men of deep experience, racial and war, speak with impressive and contrasting conviction in a half-hour documentary "news special" at 9 tonight over the American Broadcasting Company.

Air-conditioning of IRT cars,

Replying to Senator Baker's question, Herbert Porter of the Committee to Re-Elect the President, said that he had not spoken up against his bosses' wrongdoings "probably because of the fear of group pressure that would ensue, of not being a team player." He went on to explain that loyalty to the President and his team had taken precedence cover loyalty to principles or to country.

Violence flared briefly at an anti-Castro demonstration yesterday outside the midtown union headquarters where a bomb was set off Tuesday, apparently in an effort to forestall the opening of a pro-Castro political and cultural exposition on Cuba.

Ambassador Daniel P. Moynihan has sent an impish and mocking cable to the State Department, gently threatening to resign, deploring American architecture overseas and castigating Washington officials.

By late October, 1971, Attorney General John Mitchell, exasperated by his difficulties with J. Edgar Hoover, had persuaded President Nixon to fire the elderly and cantankerous F.B.I. director. An appointment for Mr. Hoover was made at the Oval Office; unaware of what was in store, he went over to talk to the President.

A spokesman for a new organization of medium-sized companies whose stocks are publicly traded asked Congress today to provide some new tax advantages for relatively small investors to lure them back into the stock market.
Dr. Hans Albert Einstein, son of the late Dr. Albert Einstein, died today at Falmouth Hospital. He was 69 years old.

William L. White, editor and publisher of The Emporia Gazette, author and former foreign correspondent, died today in Newman Memorial County Hospital, where he had been under treatment for cancer.

Senate-House conferees agreed today on an increase in the minimum wage to $2.20 an hour for most workers by next July 1 and an extension of its coverage to eight million more workers, including domestics.

The first small but significant step toward participation by an oil-producing country in American industry was announced Wednesday by the Shah of Iran who disclosed at a news conference in Washinton a joint venture between country and Ashland Oil, Inc., in refining and marketing operations in the United States.

THREE VIRGINS AND A DEVIL, written by Ramon Reed; choreography, Agnesce Mille; music, Otterine Respighi ("Antique Dances"); scenery and costumes, Motley; costume supervision, David Guthrie; lighting, Nananne Porther; conductor, Akira Endo. Presented by the American Ballet Theater at the New York State Theater.

The nation's money supply continues to expand, according to data released yesterday by the Federal Reserve System. In the week ended July 18, currency plus demand deposits averaged $264.9-billion, up from $264.4-billion for the preceding week. The adjusted bank credit proxy averaged $437-billion, up from $436.6-bilion.

In the view of some constitutional experts, the White House's most recent interpretation of executive privilege has increased the likelihood that the courts will force President Nixon to release the Watergate tapes.
As a result of the mysterious disappearance of at least 13,000 tax returns, taxpayers from New Jersey are filing duplicate returns for 1972.
The United States today vetoed a Security Council res. solution that "strongly" deplored Israel's continuing occupation of Arab lands taken during the 1967 war.

Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev today gave a moderately optimistic forecast for this year's Soviet harvest, but stopped short of predicting the record yield the Kremlin wants in order to recover from last year's farm disaster.
An agreement with China's Central Broadcasting Bureau providing for an exchange of television news, documentaries and sports programs was announced yesterday by the American Broadcasting Company.
Amy Jacques Garvey, widow of Marcus Garvey, black leader of the back-to-Africa movement in the nineteen twenties, died Sunday at her residence at Mona, Kingston. She was 77 years old.

At breakfast today, Hale Irwin said he hoped the rain would continue and wash out the scheduled opening round of the Canadian open golf championship. Later, after the skies had cleared Irwin completed a seven-underpar 65, a course record, and took the lead at the Richelieu Valley Country Club by two strokes.
Ken Norton apparently thinks he needs more than just his fists for his fights with Muhammad Ali. Before Norton beat Ali last March he made a habit of saying and writing, "I will beat Muhammad."
The Chinese liaison mission to the United States, which has been living at a downtown hotel since its arrival nearly two months ago, has finally found a home for its top members.
Bond prices dropped sharply yesterday as long-term securities made further adjustments to the soaring cost of shortterm credit.

SPRING AND TWIG The flower market with the prettiest location in town lies across the street from the United Nations and its adjacent park. It's on the strip of concrete park on the south side of 47th Street between First and Second Avenues, closer to First.
Despite some profit taking, continuing earnings gains pushed prices slightly higher yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Prices in the over-the-counter market moved in the opposite direction.

A friend recently recalled watching Howard Z. Fuchs prepare for a visit to his parents in the Bronx. He pulled out his oldest pair of jeans and grubbiest T-shirt. Then he phoned for a chauffeured white Lincoln Continental rental limousine.

Miss Leslie Karen Cornell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Cornell of this city and Centerport, L. I., was married here yesterday evening to Joel Edward Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Goodman of Lynn, Mass.

The Health Services Administration has announced the names of 21 more restaurants and food stores it has found in violation of the health code. If the reported violations not corrected by the time of a final inspection, the places are subject to closing.

The second round of the Spingold knockout team championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals began here this afternoon, and none of the four top-seeded teams, those captained by B. Jay Becker and Edgar Kaplan of New York, and Malcolm Brachman and Ira Corn of Dallas, seemed likely to have any trouble.

Tomorrow morning, if all goes on schedule, the three astronauts of the Skylab 2 crew will blast off for a record 59-day mission in the orbiting American station in space. Successful completion of these astronauts' assignment will represent another milestone passed toward attaining the capability for long-term manned space flight, whether in orbit as with Skylab or on some future crew's flight toward Mars, Venus or Jupiter.

The Senate voted today to limit an individual's campaign contributions to a Presidential or Congressional candidate to $3,000 in each election, placing what may become the first effective curbs in American political history on the influence of the rich on government.

Over-matched against Bob Gibson in a 13-1 first game, the New York Mets turned out to be their own worst enemies in losing the second game, 2-1, to the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, and sank deeper into last place in the National League's Eastern Division.
It was history without trappings-a few dry words spoken in a courtroom with the defendant's table empty.

Under the watchful eyes of hundreds of sheriff's deputies and state policemen, more than 5,000 young people camped out here today to await the start of Saturday's day-long rock festival at the Watkins Glen Grand Prix race track.
President Nixon. still reshuffling his Administration in the wake of the Watergate scandal, made two new nominations today for top Government positions.
The stock market posted its ninth consecutive advance yesterday and, although the gain was extremely narrow, the market's ability to withstand selling pressure was encouraging to Wall Street.
One reputed Mafia figure reneged today on a promise to tell the State Commission of Investigation all he knew about organized crime.
Government attorneys asked an appeals court yesterday for a stay to block a district judge's decision that the United States must stop bombing Cambodia by 4 P.M., today.
Tanglewood and Saratoga are the festivals mostly of Beethoven and Brahms. Ravinia this year is the festival of Mendelssohn and Berg. The Mostly Mozart is the festival of you know who.

The civilian secretary of a mililary service rates a 19-gun salute and can command a personal airplane, a limousine and a few aides around him. But he no longer has control over the operations of the troops that he is supposed to raise, train and equip.
Thomas P. Jahnige, associate professor of government at Smith College, died Tuesday in New Haven. He was 35 years old.

Governor Cahill announced that the state's triple-A credit rating, the highest given, had been renewed by Moody's Investor Service, a major bond rating service. The Governor said that an AAA credit rating usually saved up to two-tenths of a point in interest payments on state bonds, compared to the next highest rating, AA. He said the higher rating would produce considerable savings to the state in the future sale of bonds.

In a stunning upset, 12thseeded Dick Stockton of Port Washington, L.I., defeated topseeded Stan Smith today in the third round of The Washington Star-News international tennis championships. The scores were 6-2, 3-6, 6-4.
A Clifton lawyer was sentenced today to four days in jail for a "sarcastic" remark in contempt of court at the end of a robbery trial.

Israel today denied any association with the five persons arrested for the murder of a Moroccan in Lillehammer, Norway, last Saturday. Two of the five have reportedly said they are members of an Israel counterterror group trying to prevent Palestinian attacks on Israeli installations in Scandinavia.

Senator Howard H. Baker Jr has released a list of previously undisclosed contributors to his re-election campaign, showing that he collected $264,000 and spent about $80,000 before a new Federal law requiring full disclosure took effect April 7, 1972.

The Nixon Administration reported today that the Government spent $246.6-billion in the fiscal year just ended-well below the President's target ceiling of $250-billion established about a year ago and reaffirmed last January.

Americans have started a record buying run on home freezers and are hoarding food in anticipation of higher prices-when the ceiling on beef prices ends Sept. 12and a meat shortage, a survey showed today.

Skylab scientists feel confident that, with the data returned by the first astronauts to operate the orbiting space station, they are on the verge of important new discoveries about the sun's upper atmosphere.
Constantine Georgakopoulos, president of the Greek Red Cross for a quarter of a century and briefly Premier, died here yesterday at the age of 82.
In 1964, when Jim Palmer broke into organized baseball, he established his potential with an 8-0, no-hit game against Duluth-Superior in the Northern League.

Bernard Cornfeld, the 45year-old American financier and founder of the collapsed Investors Overseas Services financial empire, has written a circular letter to his friends from a Swiss jail stating that he was "not as unhappy as I would have expected."
Joe Fink scored two goals as tile New York Cosmos registered a 3-1 victory over the Atlanta Apollos tonight in a North American Soccer League game.
Prices on the American Stock change and the over-theArket stayed on the fence yesterday after advancing durthe first four days of the ek.

Many candidates who ran in the April primary election are in danger of being fined up to $1,000 as the result of failing to meet the first reporting deadline under New Jersey's new campaign disclosure law.
Mrs. Louise Krisanich Varkonyi, a voice teacher and concert singer in Europe and New York, died Tuesday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 82 years old and lived in the Hudson View Gardens.

The countdown for Skylab 2 entered its final hours tonight as three American astronauts prepared to embark on what would be man's longest voyage in space to date, a 59-day mission aboard a laboratory in earth orbit.
A post-Watergate drive in the Senate to add new and tougher reform provisions to the 18nonth-old Federal campaign finance law lost momentum today.
The scheduled visit to Thailand hy President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam next week has been postponed indefinitely, apparently as a result of cooling in relations between tile two countries.

A former army officer and legislator who was jailed four years ago after he advocated negotiations to end the war has been told that before he can be released front prison he must publicly confess Communist ties and renounce them.
Weather: Partly sunny today; warm tonight. Partly sunny tomorrow. Temp. range: today 72-88; Friday 74-87. Temp.-Hum. Index yesterday 80. Full U.S. report on Page 54.

John D. Ehrlichman sternly defended today the Nixon campaign's practice of spying on opposition political candidates, saying that politicians had an "affirmative obligation" to investigate and expose the drinking habits and personal morals of other candidates.

Donald E. Dawson, an Ail Force captain who is facing a possible court-martial for refusing to fly a bombing mission over Cambodia, said yesterday that he would defend his action on the ground of "sincere religious objection to any furtheir participation in war the war in Cambodia or any other war."
Senate-House conferees reached tentative agreement today on a new four-year farm bill including a price support escalator clause.
New York was strongly represented in the third round of Spingold knockout team play at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here this afternoon.
H. Harvey Pike, long a leadng sugar importer here, died Thursday at his summer home in Ledyard, Conn. He was 85 years old and lived at 320 last 72d Street.

The House signaled another rough passage for foreign aid legislation the other day when it narrowly adopted a curtailed version of the imaginative new economic assistance program that had emerged from its Foreign Affairs Committee.
David Bienstock, curator of films at the Whitney Museum of American Art, died of a selfinflicted revolver shot Tuesday evening. He was 29 years old and lived at 107 West 82d Street.

Senator Harold E. Hughes urged his colleagues today to resist what he said would be the Nixon Administration's inevitable "pressures to bludgeon Congress and the American people" in an attempt to continue bombing Cambodia after the Aug. 15 deadline.

The former state Republican chairman, Nelson G. Gross, moved yesterday for a dismissal of his Federal taxperjury indictment on the ground that he had been unfairly prejudiced before the grand jury that charged him. Mr. Gross was indicted last May 22 on charges of conspiring to commit income tax fraud and of pressuring a grand jury witness to lie about alleged irregularities in fund raising for Governor Cahill's 1969 campaign.

Nicholas Scoppetta, the City Investigations Commissioner, is looking into the alleged payment of kickbacks and "gratuities" to employes of the Medical Examiner's office by funeral directors seeking business and favors.

John D. Ehrlichman, offering a detailed White House rationale for the Watergate cover-up, swore today that President Nixon did not get a thorough briefing on the Watergate conspiracy until April 14 this year.

Unless the scheme concocted this week by City Council for reapportioning itself is substantially modified, it deserves Mayor Lindsay's veto. If passed over his veto as was the previous gerrymandered plan, it, too, ought to be challenged in the courts, where it will in all probability also be declared unconstitutional, as was the last one.

Twenty-five years ago, the average American family spent 25 per cent of its income for food. Now the figure is 16 per cent, according to the Extension Service of Cornell University, but the pendulum is starting to swing the other way, partly because the food production and distribution industry cannot offset higher costs through greater efficiency as much as it has in the past.

The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, the nation's largest investor-owned insurance enterprise, reported yesterday net income for the second quarter of $47-million, $1.76 a share, up 5 per cent from $44.7million, or $1.67 a share, in the year-earlier period.

Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., which announced a major realignment of its top echelon this week, announced yesterday that it expected to report a substantial loss for the fiscal year ended June 30, resulting from several factors.
Archibald Cox, the special prosecutor, and leaders of the Senate Watergate committee tried today to head off a constitutional collision over the Presidential tape recordings in the Watergate affair.

Miss Andray Louise Neal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis F. Neal of York, Me., was married here this afternoon to Robert Steven Silverman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Silverman of Chestnut Hill.
The Legislature deferred action on Governor Rockefeller's $3.5-billion transportation bond proposal this evening and recessed the special session until Monday.
The horse that Billy Haughton gave up on last year and sold to a Swiss importer returned to the United States tonight and almost made Haughton secondguess himself.
Early returns from a referendum on whether Ferdinand E. Marcos should continue as President of the Philippines beyond this year indicate that a huge "yes" vote is being amassed.

The Senate Armed Services Committee, in an economy move designed ultimately to save $1.6-billion a year in defense spending, voted unanimously today to impose a 7 per cent cut in military troop strength in the coming year.

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation asked The Manchester Union Leader today to turn over the "Canuck" letter that attributed an ethnic slur to Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine while he was campaigning for his party's 1972 Presidential nomination in Florida.

Ray Faisst, special agent in charge of the Fedoral Bureau of Investigation office in Little Rock, said today that L, Patrick Gray 3d, former acting director of the bureau, was "a paper shredder" who "dumped the White House trash."

The pension-reform plan for public employes adopted by the State Legislature in special session at Albany sets up so many different categories of workers and contains such liberal benefits for all of them that it hardly qualifies as "reform" or a "plan." Savings to burdened governmental units flowing from the legislation are so modest that they will have little immediate budgetary impact.

A motley macaw named Mac-who took the occasion of his own presentation to the Central Park Zoo Thursday to fly away-was captured in the upper reaches of a lofty Central Park sycamore yesterday afternoon by an agile Dominican youth with a tempter's apple and a spiel of soothing, cooing Spanish.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 27--Thanks to American aid, South Vietnam has avoided the shortages of gasoline and scrap steel that have plagued the United States.

Lindy McDaniel and the rest of the Yanks were struck with "a sinking feeling" when Bobby Murcer slipped and fell on the west outfield grass in the third inning yesterday at Yankee Stadium, but they didn't drown.

Robert E. Henry Jr., who retired in 1954 as president of the Associated Industrials Corporation, an investment company here, died Thursday in Burlington, Vt. He was 67 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla., and Hague, N. Y.

Ed Garvey, executive director of the National Football League Players' Association, disclosed today that his group and Lance Rentzel of the Rams would file a Federal antitrust suit in Los Angeles next week in an attempt to overturn Rentzel's suspension by Commissioner Pete Rozelle.

The General Motors Corporation reported today record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first half of 1973. G.M.'s report followed similar announcements by the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation of record sales and profits so far this year.

Training camp rookies live in fear of the man they have come to call "The Turk," He is usually a trainer, equipment manager or coaching aide, who summons a player to the head coach as a prelude to being told that his services are no longer required.

Stu Holcomb resigned today as executive vice president and general manager of the Chicago White Sox in what apparently was a power conflict with Roland Hemond and Chuck Tanner, whom he hired three years ago.

Lending rates in Britain were lifted today to their highest levels in history, and in West Germany a tight monetary squeeze was eased somewhat in moves that helped halt the slide of the dollar and the pound in the international currency markets.

The United States will be allowed to recover the bodies of 23 Americans who died as prisoners of war and were buried just outside Hanoi.

John D. Ehrlichman sternly defended today the Nixon campaign's practice of spying on opposition political candidates, saying that politicians had an "affirmative obligation" to investigate and expose the drinking habits and personal morals of other candidates.
Raffaele Mattioli, president of the Banca Commercial Italiana, one of Italy's major banks, died here last evening. He was 78 years old.
The music and laughter emanating these days from the fortress-like building at 150 West 68th Street are, no doubt, about the happiest sounds ever heard coming from the red brick structure.

Mrs. Elizabeth McCall Houghton and Walker O. Cain, both of New York, were married here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. William A. McQuoid performed the ceremony in the Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

WASHINGTON, July 27--The Senate today passed a bill authorizing the use of up to $210-million in Federal funds to keep bankrupt railroads operating. The bill, approved 59 to 30, is designed mainly to save the Penn Central Railroad.
Despite new preventive programs and the increased availability of counseling, suicides are on the increase in city prisons, according to a private report by the Board of Correction.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 27--Gunmen assassinated the chief military aide to President Salvador Allende Gossens early today, adding another volatile ingredient to Chile's increasingly tense political situation.
A group of citizens are fighting the proposed demolition of a stately Victorian mansion here in a battle that reflects new concern among Canadians about the future of their cities.
The South Vietnamese command reported today that Government and Communist troops fought one of their most intense battle in months north of Saigon yesterday.

Eight members of a narcotics ring that allegedly had planned to distribute $10-million worth of heroin In the metropolitan area were convicted yesterday after a two-week jury trial in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

In a preliminary setback for President Nixon's theory of executive privilege, a Federal judge ordered the White House today to show him its files on the 1973 increase in Government milk price supports.

Backstage at Thursday night's concert by the New YorK Philharmonic in Central Park, Garrick Ohlsson said that the Brahms First Piano Concerto was one of his favorite works and that he felt particularly lucky in being able to play it in his debut with the orchestra.

The baseball romance that surrounds the Chicago Cubs belongs in a soap opera. It's conducted by the people here in the afternoons because Wrigley Field doesn't have the lights that would create a prime-time drama. It thrives on the heartbreak of false hope. Less than a month ago, the Cubs were leading the National League East by eight games.

The countdown for Skylab 2 entered its final hours tonight as three American astronauts prepared to embark on what would be man's longest voyage in space to date, a 59-day mission aboard a laboratory in earth orbit.

United States Army intelligence has begun a program of "offensive counterintelligence" against anti-Army civilian groups in West Germany - tapping their telephones, photographing their meeting places and trying to infiltrate them, according to some of the participating intelligence agents.

Dr. Franz Matsch, Austria's first Ambassador to the United Nations and a well-known diplomatic figure at the United Nations and the League of Nations for many years, died Wednesday at his home in Vienna after a brief illness. He was 74 years old and made his home in this country in Larchmont, N.Y.
How is "lonescopade"? Delicious. What is it? A brilliantly devised crazy-quilt of flying bits, pieces and characters from Eugene lonesco's contributions to the Theater of the Absurd.
Corydon S. Chamberlain, who retired as New York regional vice president of the F. W. Woolworth Company in 1944, died Tuesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 90 years old.

H. E. Olson, chairman of the Carnation Company of Los Angeles, and A. J. Hackl, president and chief executive officer of the Herff Jones Company of Minneapolis, announced yesterday an agreement in principle for the merger of Herff Jones into Carnation.

BALTIMORE - Several major oil companies have run a series of newspaper advertisements which propound this message: We have an energy crisis; cheap energy Is essential; environmentalists are hostile to growth and are preventing us from supplying everyone's energy needs.
The surging summer rally in the stock market finally was clipped by profit taking yesterday and prices closed on the fence in quiet, pre-weekend trading.

Gunmen assassinated the chief military aide to President Salvador Allende Gossens early today, adding another volatile ingredient to Chile's increasingly tense political situation.

William S. Auchincloss, board chairman of the Schnell Publishing Company, died Thursday at Overlook Hospital, Summit, N. J. He was 73 years old and lived in Short Hills, N. J., and Bridgehampton, L. I.

Melvin R. Laird, the White House domestic affairs adviser, said published speculation that he was planning to quit as an aide to President Nixon was not accurate. Mr. Laird told reporters in Washington that he considered himself a "stayer" on the White House staff.

An attempted escape from the fifth floor of the Brooklyn House of Detention by four inmates, including an alleged member of the Black Liberation Army, was thwarted shortly after midnight Thursday by a surprise sweep of the cellblock oy prison guards, according to Officials.

John D. Ehrlichman's cryptic notes about a meeting April 13 with Charles W. Colson, another former White House aide, indicate that they discussed a way for President Nixon to head off the impact of any possible disclosures by E. Howard Hunt Jr., a convicted Watergate conspirator.

A little instrument invented by a member of the New York Medical College faculty promises the immediate restoration of effortless speech for a person whose larynx, or voice box, has been removed in Week surgery.
Organization Democrats in all five counties easily overrode opposition from Reform Democrats yesterday and nominated their own choices for 16 seats on the State Supreme Court.
Dexter N. Shaw, a lawyer and former president of the Philadelphia Patent Law Association, died Wednesday in Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 72 years old.
In fastball-to-fastball confrontation of All-Star pitchers, Tom Seaver outpitched Rick Wise, 2-1, and sent the New York Mets flying home with a plus record for their longest trip of the year.
More than 40 eighth-grade boys Ordered fingerprinted in conneclion with a murder investigation were given the right to appeal the court order today.
The Democratic State Committee announced yesterday the appointment of Representative Peter W. Rodino of Newark to serve as chairman of a new state campaign committee.
Jack Ward, an associate organist at Radio City Music Hall, lied Thursday in Leroy Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Hewitt. N. J.
Art + Business = People. That is an equation that the Arts and Business Council of New York City uses to describe its exhibition illustrating corporate involvement in New York community projects.

Two touchdowns by Larry Csonka and too many mistakes by the College All-Stars enabled the Miami Dolphins to preserve a their prestige as National Football League champions tonight with a 14-3 victory before 54,103 spectators and a national television audience.

Miss Elizabeth Grayson Blank, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Edward Blank of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to Brian Rogerson Hartley of Leeds, England, who is director of archeological studies at the University of Leeds.

The military corn mand ordered the people of Pnom Penh today to take up arms against the possibility of attack by anti-Government rebels it said had infiltrated the city.
George Papadopoulos closed his unopposed campaign for the presidency of the new Greek republic today by saying he would continue to rule even if rejected at the polls on Sunday.
The Italian Government today announced a 50 per cent nonInterest paying deposit requirement on funds used for investment abroad of any kind.

The nation's foreign trade account was virtually in balance in June, with imports exceeding exports by only $15 million. During this year's April-June quarter, the United States had even a modest trade surplus of $23million-the first quarterly surplus in over two years. Undoubtedly, the major cause of the improvement has been the effect of successive devaluations of the dollar, whose price has now been cut by more than one-fifth.

The Labor Department reported today a small decline in productivity, or output per manhour, in the second quarter but a senior Treasury Department economist promptly said the figures were unintentionally misleading.

The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.
The Triple Crown winner, Secretariat, unofficially bettered two Saratoga track records during practice runs over a sloppy track today.

Daniel Voll underwent a daylong cross-examination yesterday by the defense attorney for Ted Patrick, who sought to show that Mr. Voll, a member of the New Testament Missionary Fellowship, had taken cues from the religious group in making decisions.
Joseph (Newsboy) Moriarty, accused of operating a $6-milliona-year numbers lottery, was convicted today or gambling conspiracy, possessing lottery slips and assaulting a policeman.

Since it is a prime purpose of the 35-year-old National Folk Festival to present traditional, homegrown or regional music in as undiluted a form as possible, it was not surprising that the first evening of the annual four-day festival last night at Wolf Trap Farm Park should lean heavily toward musicians and singers in their sixties and seventies.
Archibald Cox, the special prosecutor, and leaders of the Senate Watergate committee tried today to head off a constitutional collision over the Presidential tape recordings in the Watergate affair.

John D. Ehrlichman, offering a detailed White House rationale for the Watergate cover-up, swore today that President Nixon did not get a thorough briefing on the Watergate conspiracy until April 14 this year.

Leaders of the state's public-employe unions said today that they were determined to win back at the bargaining table any financial losses suffered by new Civil Service workers as a result of the pension-revision bill passed late yesterday at the special session of the Legislature.
Senate-House conferees reached tentative agreement today on a new four-year farm bill including a price support escalator clause.

Bligh A. Dodds, a longtime leader of agricultural fairs in New York State, died yesterday at his home here. He was 80 years old.
Secretary of the Army Howard H. Callaway said today that Army enlisted men had no legal obligation to obey orders from Air Force officers in North Vietnamese prison camps.
Gordon Chase, the first nonphysician to head the city's Health Services Administration, announced yesterday that he would resign Oct. 1 after nearly four years in the post.

Commissioner of Investigation Nicholas Scoppetta said he was investigating the hiring practices of the city's Human Resources Administration family-planning clinics following the arrest of a 20-year-old former Army medic charged with falsely representing himself as a physician and sexually abusing women patients.

The Rev. Dr. Milton J. Hoffman, president of the General Synod of the Reformed Church in America in 1931 and professor of church history at the New Brunswick Theological Seminary from 1925 to 1956, died today in a nursing home in Franklin Township.

The Association of American Publishers, in a 33-page brief filed yesterday, has asked the United States Supreme Court to reconsider its June 21 antiobscenity rulings on the ground that the justices "have reduced the rule of law to a matter of taste."

Some people wait all their lives for a hole-in-one. Andrew Haley ended the long wait last week at the ripe old age of 7. Using a No. 5-iron, Andrew knocked the ball 120 yards on the 13th hole at the Lynwood Country Club in Martinsburg, West Va.
The public got its first close look yesterday at the Federal grand jury that has been deliberating secretly for months in the Watergate case.

Senator Danicl K. Inouyc, Democrat of Hawaii, who was embarrassed Wednesday when a microphone caught him muttering "What a liar" in response to John D. Ehrlichman's testimony, thinks he has found a way to avoid future slips.
Young Vijai Amritraj of India seeded seventh, upset top-ranked Rod Laver of Australia in the $25,000 Volvo tennis tournament today and advanced to the semifinals.

Calvin Frizer, vice chairman of the Brooklyn chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality, died Sunday in Brooklyn. The cause of death was not immediately known, although Mr Frizer suffered from asthma and emphysema, He was 54 years old and lived at 144 MacDougal Street, Brooklyn.

ASPEN, Colo.-One interesting paradox of contemporary politics is the rise in strength of the so-called left virtually on the heels of the split In Communist unity. This has not been a sudden development. It has followed a zigzag period during which relatively conservative forces seemed to be reasserting themselves in many countries.

ABOARD THE PUMP'RSINK, Off the Nantucket Shoals, July 27-Full 40 fathoms and more below these green waters rests the liner Andrea Doria, the victim of one of the worst disasters of recent maritime history.

About 250 Port Authority policemen went to court todaymost having walked off the job--only to hear a judge renew until September an injunction against walkouts or any disruption of the authority's facilities.

France is expanding her nuclear force by constructing sites in southeastern France for a third group of intermediate range ballistic missiles with thermonuclear warheads, according to authoritative United States sources.
While most houses in Wall Street are crying wolf these days, Bear, Stearns Co. is singing a different-and more optimistic-tune.
Howard Keel, the actor, was sued for $1-million yesterday by a couple who charged that the actor had struck them with a sword during a performance of "Man of La Mancha" last summer.

Nicholas Scoppetta, the City Investigations Commissioner, is looking into the alleged payment of kickbacks and "gratuities" to employes of the Medical Examiner's office by funeral directors seeking business and favors.

The manufacture of children's sleepwear that is flammable, blamed for more than 300 infant deaths and up to 6,000 serious injuries each. year, will be prohibited after today by Federal regulations.

The early reaction to the announcement of the match race between Secretariat and Riva Ridge fell noiselessly into the dull thud department at Aqueduct yesterday. Few people seemed aware or interested in the proposed meeting between the colts, both owned by the Meadow Stable.

Jan Ferraris of San Francisco, and Sally Little of South Africa moved into the lead in the second round of the Lady Angelo's Ladies Professional Golf Association four-ball championship today.

John T. Potter's 68-foot ketch Equation swept to her second straight victory on the New York Yacht Club cruise today, winning the Queen's Cup race for the second year in a row.

Most news about science concerns accomplishment: an astronomical discovery, the finding of a cure for a disease. But another fundamental feature of science is that it has a self-correcting mechanism, a formal means of making sure that when a mistake has been made it will be found out and revealed.

Dr. Lan Jen Chu, prof. of electrical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and holder of more than 25 antenna patents, died Wednesday at the age of 59.

Lee Trevino announced today that he would not compete in the $250,000 Westchester Classic that starts Thursday at Harrison, N.Y., because his wife, who expects a baby within a few weeks, wants him home in El Paso.

The annual fuel collection in St. Peter's Church on South Broadway will be taken up on the second and third Sunday in August as usual. In Fox Hollow Inn here this afternoon, Miss Mary Alice Dwyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Dwyer of St. Louis and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married to Leon Dobbin, son of Mrs. George Granath of Freeport and the late Philip Dobbin.

What Navy officials had billed as this year's biggest air show on the East Coast was held at the Naval Air Station here yesterday despite the loss of its star attractions, the Blue Angels, because of a fatal air crash.
Uniformed patrolmen in Prospect Park pedaled their beats yesterday in a new offensive against bicycle thieves.
National Guardsmen with unsheathed bayonets today drove rebellious convicts out of cellblocks into an open compound and took tenuous control of the almost destroyed Oklahoma state prison here.

The cost of food for a family of four in New York City rose last week to the highest price since the city's Department of Consumer Affairs started making its Market Basket Reports almost three months ago. The market basket, which contains 37 foods, cost $53.43 during the week ended July 25, up 69 cents from the previous week. The price represents the average cost of the foods at 150 stores in the five boroughs.

On the eve of Casey Stengel's birthday the Mets went backward yesterday in time, recreating the kind of game they used to lose when the old man was managing them. They bowed to the Montreal Expos, 6-4, and it was extra embarrassing because their children and wives were on hand at Shea Stadium's Family Day.

A late-model yellow Ford struck and killed a 7-year-old girl and critically injured her 4-year-old sister Saturday night as the two girls were trying to cross the street in front of 757 Park Avenue, Brooklyn.
Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson was host to the Governor of Puerto Rico at a breakfast meeting today, after which the 36-yearold Governor, Rafael Hernandez Col6n reviewed the city's Puerto Rican Day parade.
A man identified by the police as a major national distributor of pornographic films was shot to death yesterday in an alley near his home in Nassau County.

Miss Rosalyn E. Levy and Gary F. Jonas, both of Washington, were married here yesterday afternoon in the Tavern on the Green in Central Park. Rabbi Edward Klein of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue performed the ceremony.
President Nixon spent today in the seclusion of his mountaintop retreat, and aides reported that he was following his doctor's orders to relax by swimming and taking walks.
The strike against California table grape growers spread across the entire San Joaquin Valley today when the United Farm Workers Union failed to renew its contracts with growers in the Delano area.

Brother Joseph G. McKenna, former president of Iona College, died Saturday of a heart attack on a vacation in San Francisco. He was 51 years old Brother McKenna became fifth president of the college in 1965.

Miss Gail Kleven, a member of the Education Task Force of the Governor's Commission on the Status of Women in Massachusetts, was married here today to Richard Mark Gelb, who is a candidate for a Master of Law degree in taxation at New York University.
State Senator John J. Marchi of Staten Island, the Republican candidate for Mayor, said yesterday that he was reassessing his previous support of pedestrian malls for New York.
The Federal judiciary in New Jersey, beset by a rising number] of civil and criminal cases, is, involved in a muted struggle, with Washington over the need for more judges.

The city's regular meat suppliers have refused to sign contracts for a two-week supply in of beef--106,000 pounds-normally used in municipal hospitals, jails and other institutions, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.
A roof safari by two policemen with powerful field glasses yesterday turned up marijuana growing in five flower pots of mint on a fourth-floor window sill in Brooklyn, the police reported.

One of the most dramatic moments in the long history of the Spingold knockout team championship occurred here in the small hours of this morning. Play in a tense quarter-final match between teams led by Bob Ewen of New
Yields on United States Treasury bills rose to record highs in the Government's weekly sale of these shortterm securities.

After meeting for more than an hour with President Nixon, Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia said today that his Government wished to remain a friend of the United States but had "independent interests" that could lead to further disagreements with Washington.

Grand Traverse Bay was working her enchantress's magic. The blue hills to the west were still shrouded in morning haze. To the east, a pale sun appeared through the clouds and cast a shimmering hand of platinum across the water, bathing the scene in an unearthly glow.

With the sale of liquor in half-gallon bottles becoming legal tomorrow in New York State, liquor stores throughout the city were reported busy yesterday laying in stocks in the larger size containers.

A four-year college scholarship, issued in the name of the late Jackie Robinson, will be awarded annually to a black youngster who shows a serious interest in playing golf, the All-American Collegiate Golf Foundation announced yesterday.

One day several years ago, a subordinate received from H. R. Haldeman, then the White House chief of staff, a memorandum that the subordinate had drafted. In one corner Mr. Haldeman had written, in his precise hand, "TL2."
The Jets and the Houston Oilers will use their preseason opener Friday night at the Astrodome as a tryout for new faces, but their objectives will not be the same.

New Jersey today won the right to collect damages from polluters in a precedent-setting decision that is expected to inspire new rounds of litigation against those found guilty of damaging the state's waterways and marshlands.

The Union Oil Company realized increases of 44 per cent in earnings for the second quarter and 36 per cent for the six months on revenue gains of 17.4 and 13.5 per cent, respectively the company reported yesterday.
An analysis of viewer response to the televised Watergate hearings shows that New Yorkers have been surprisingly less interested in the hearings than audiences across the nation.

Expressing doubts over the legality of the legislation, Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland signed a measure today requiring complete financial disclosure by all elected officials and most ranking appointed government employes.

Sally M. Gibson's Sadairs Starlet, at 28-1 the longest shot in the field of eight, captured the $12,000 allowance feature today at Monmouth Park by 1 1/4 lengths. The 4-year-old daughter of Sadair-Bright Starlite sped the five furlongs in 59 seconds on a firm turf in the race for fillies and mares 3 years old and upward.
James R. Hoffa opened an office here today to seek prison reform, with an acknowledgment that "it won't hurt" in his quest to recapture the presidency of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
Two 15-year-old boys were arrested yesterday in connection with a hit-and-run accident in which a Queens girl was struck by a stolen car and dragged across an intersection.

The Legislature passed Governor Rockefeller's bill to permit an increase in mortgage interest rates early today after rejecting a batch of Democratic amendments that had been designed to defeat the bill.
The Dal as Colony of the Children ;nd has dropped a $1.1-million hel and slander suit that was led 22 months ago against a group of parents who had icketed in protest against the fundamentalist sect.
The California Board of Equalization refused today to order an investigation of the property tax assessment on President Nixon's estate at San Clemente.
We have to Keep searching because we don't have anything else to go on," a state trooper said as plans were mapped for the fifth day of the hunt for 7-year-old Janice Pockett.

During a visit to the powerful labor confederation that has been his main source of political strength for three decades former dictator Juan Domingo Peron called today for a rejection of the left wing of his movement.
Madison Avenue and the public-relations business have at least one thing in common--an image problem.

Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8:05 P.M. (Television-Channel 9, 8 P.M.) (Radio-WHN, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs Red Sox, at Boston. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M.)

The House slammed the door, today on a possible immediate pay rise for members of Congress. As a result, the annual pay for members of Congress will continue at $42,500 until President Nixon, acting on the recommendations of an independent commission, sets a new pay level next January.
Four teachers who were released from the Bergen County jail last week after being sentenced to 30 days for leading an illegal strike here, found that even prison can offer an education of sort.
John A. Love, the new White House energy chief, said today that oil company compliance with the voluntary petroleum allocation program had deteriorated noticeably in the last three weeks.

The American Biscuit Company plant employing 425 people in Passaic announced yesterday it would cease operations by the end of the year. The closing of the plant is the third shutdown of a major company in Passaic this year. Earlier, the Uniroyal Company, with 1,400 employes, and the Raybestos-Manhattan Company, with 1,200 workers, ceased operations.
Dominick Dominick, Inc.,j a century-old member firm of! the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday it planned to phase out its domestic retailbrokerage business for competitive reasons.
Cargill, Inc., announced last night that it had offered a "deferred delivery privilege" to its foreign buyers of soybeans and soybean meal who were caught in the Government's control program.

Chemalloy Minerals, Ltd., announced yesterday at Toronto that it had raised its posted price for tantalum oxide to $10 a pound, effective immediately. Previously the price of tantalum oxide ranged from $7 to $8 a pound depending on quality and contract conditions.
New Hampshire natives will have a two-day deer hunting season of their own this year. The regular statewide deer season, for both residents and nonresidents, runs from Nov. 1 through Nov. 15.
The manager of a Queens nightclub was found murdered and his apartment ransacked early yesterday in the Corona section of Queens.
The Liberty National Life Insurance Company of Birmingham, Ala., announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Rockford Life Insurance Company of Rockford, Ill.

Jeb Stuart Magruder, the former deputy director of the Committee for the Re-Election of the President, refused to comment on the Watergate case today when he arrived here with his wife and four children for a vacation.
Following are excerpts from the testimony of H. R. Haldeman, former White House chief of staff. before the Senate Watergate Committee today.

Roland Hemond, the personnel director credited with engineering many of the deals that built the Chicago White Sox into a pennant contender, today was appointed general manager of the team to succeed Stu Holcomb.

Chile's Marxist President, Salvador Allende Gossens, began talks today with the leader of his principal opposition, the powerful Christian Democratic party, in what has been termed a last-ditch attempt to save the country from civil war.

" Tales of Hoffmann," a production new to American Ballet Theater this season, received a very hesitant performance Sunday evening at the State Theater. Part of it was because of ill chance, but only part of it.
Downtown Airlines, which operates a scheduled seaplane service between Wall Street and downtown Philadelphia, will introduce a 20passenger float plane on the route this Thursday.
New building contract awards during June rose 19 per cent to $9.9-billion, from the level of June, 1972, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

On July 18 the two of us set out together to read "Remembrance of Things Past" by Marcel Proust. We have been reading it fairly steadily eve since, thanks to our heavily stocked kits of smelling salts, and are determined to keep on reading until we either finish it or die in the attempt.

You'd think that when school ended in June all the boys and girls would bid it a delighted good-by. But a few of the private schools here have found that some children actually enjoy spending part of the summer in the same rooms where they spent fall, winter and spring.

Jim Bibby, whose career was. threatened by major surgery only three years ago, pitched the first no-hitter in Texas: Ranger history and the fourth of the American League season tonight when he beat the Oakland A's, 6-0.
The Republicans scored their 10th consecutive victory in the annual Congressional baseball game, today, whipping the Democrats 12 to 4 behind the pitching of Robert H. Michel and William S. Cohen.
