Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., ice chairman of the Senate Vatergate committee, apoloized today to John D. Ehrlichnan for suggesting that he had een party to an irregular proedure in helping arrange for laurice H. Stans, former Comnerce Secretary and director of he Finance Committee to Relect the President, to avoid a Randd jury appearance in the wiretapping case.

" This is a happy day for me," said Senator John C. Stennis in a statement released by his office as he was discharged by the Walter Reed Army Medical Center yesterday after a stay of six months, while recovering from gunshot wounds suffered in a holdup in January.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company was accused today of anticompetitive practices "which could endanger the lower costs and better service that competitive microwave companies promise."

Governor Cahill announced today that he would meet with the two major gubernatorial candidates-Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., Republican, and Brendan T. Byrne, Democrat-to discuss the state's transportation needs.
Legalization of the privuse of marijuana was proposed today by a 2-to-1 vote of a national conference of lawyers, judges, law professors and state officials who met here to plan model legislation.

An alleged gunman for the Carlo Gambino crime family was sentenced today to life in prison. He was convicted July 11 by a Sullivan County Court jury of the murder of a reputed mobster, Carlo A. Lombardi.

Republican and Democratic House members took the floor today to criticize the President's former chief adviser for domestic affairs, John D. Ehrlichman, in light of his testimony before the Senate Watergate committee.

Guy Middleton, an actor who specialized in portraying English cads, died at his country home today after a long illness. He was 65 years old. Mr. Middelton was a star of the London stage in the nineteen-thirties.
Ben Crenshaw, whose style of play has often been compared with Jack Nicklaus, will make his debut as a pro on the golf tour Aug. 16 in the $200,000 United States industries classic at Sutton, Mass.
The Vietnam international peacekeeping team will come to a virtual standstill with the departure of Canada, according to the chief Hungarian delegate.

Following are excerpts from the transcript of testimony today by John D. Ehrlichman on the 31st day of hearings on the Watergate case before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:
Governor Rockefeller's bill to permit an increase in mortgage interest rates was stalled last night in parliamentary maneuvering and legislative histrionics.

Talking Picture of the Elmendorf interests sped to thrilling success in the Schuylerville, the six-furlong dash for 2-year-old fillies that featured today's opening program of Saratoga's 106th thoroughbred racing season.
A Staten Island man leaped to his death at 3:30 A.M. yesterday from a sixth-floor window to escape a three-alarm fire that had engulfed his apartment, fire officials reported.

In Brooklyn, the owner of a meat market where as much as 30,000 pounds of meat is sold weekly, described the practices he said he and other independent butchers had to follow to assure themselves a supply of beef despite shortages attributed to the price ceiling.

The next nuclear detonation in the, 1973 series might not come until September, the French Government radio said today. The second atomic device in the 1973 series was set off on Saturday above Mururoa atoll in the South Pacific,

A downtown Philadelphia nightclub has become the object of a controversy over racial bias. The club, Harlow's, denies It practices racial discrimination respite the six complaints lodged against it since last september.

The Pentagon acknowledged today that the Army had "always had active intelligence and counterinteligence programs" in West Germany, but denied a report that Army intelligence was condulcting a campaign of surveillance against German civilians without the knowledge of German authorities.

Senator Herman E. Taimade, Democrat of Georgia, who is a member of the Senate Committee investigating the Watergate scandals, was reportedly flown to the Caribbean for a mid-winter vacation early this year by a major Government contractor.

A handsome dark chestnut gelding named M. H. Aswed Dahab, owned by the Tiffany Arabian of Stanfordville, N. Y., won the Arabian Western pleasure horse championship stake today at the Orange County horse show.
The Republican majority's hope to debate and pass Governor Rockefeller's $3.5-billion transit bond proposal with bipartisan support became snagged on Democratic resistance tonight.
Army Sgt. 1st CI. Hershel Anderson of Tracy City, Tenn., won the .22-caliber pistol competition today and gained the first-round lead in the three-day national pistol championship.
Third-seeded Nikki Pilic, fourth-seeded Marty Riessen and fifth-seeded Manuel Orantes scored easy victories today in the opening round of the $75,000 First National Bank tennis tournament.

A Brooklyn woman has been reunited with her daughter and older son after six years of efforts, which included her arrest by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on a charge of having kidnapped another girl in Italy who resembled her daughter.

The Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities, despite weariness, decided today to lengthen the hours of its hearings and to press ahead until it had completed the Watergate phase of its inquiry.

Vincent F. Albano, chairman of the New York County Republican committee, has submitted the name of Elrich A. Eastman for approval as the committee's designee for the City Board of Elections. The nomination of Mr. Eastman, a 50-year-old Harlem lawyer, replaces the committee's previous choice of Vincent J. Velella, whose name had been submitted along with nine other designers from the various county organizations.
Beginning in August, the State Lottery Commission will give away 35 station wagons, each loaded with $500 worth of food, it was announced today.
The Senate gave final legislative approval today to a bill, proposed by Governor Rockefeller, creating a temporary commission to study the cost of living and the economy.

The Senate minority leader, Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, said today that President Nixon was the victim of unfavorable public opinion built by his ousted counsel, John W. Dean 3d. Mr. Scott predicted that Mr. Nixon "will come out fighting" soon after the Senate Watergate committee recesses in August.
More than 1,500 businessmen, many of them confused hy Phase 4 of the Nixon economic stabilization program, crowded into the Town Hall yesterday for a briefing by Administration officials.

A Harlem police officer shot at 10 days ago when he interrupted a Bronx supermarket holdup, seized the alleged ringleader of the holdup gang yesterday morning when he saw him walking along Eighth Avenue, the police reported.

The Hare Krishna sect -whose chanting, bell-ringing, saffron-gowned young devotees have become an eye-catching fixture on the streets of New York and other American cities. -has become so successful that it is about to buy an expensive Manhattan property for its new international headquarters and New York center.
The House Subcommittee on State Department Organization today gave the United States Information Agency about $215-million, most of what it had originally asked for its 1974 operations.

Roy Shuman, an actor known for his role as the villainous Dr. Shea in the television serial "As the World Turns," died yesterday of a heart attack in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived at 161 West 54th Street.
At torney general Elliot L. Richardson today initiated a series of steps that will nearly double the size of the Federal-statecity joint antinarcotics task Force.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested Samuel E. Cohen, 60 years old, of Valley Stream, L.I., yesterday on a charge of possession of goods stolen in at least two armed truck hijackings in northern New Jersey in the last six weeks.

Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, retired chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told a Senate committee today that President Nixon personally ordered the secret bombing of Cambodia to be conducted under the tightest security measures possible.

A Federal judge today dismissed a civil suit by a Ralph Nader group that charged Ken W. Clawson, director of communications for the White House, with illegally trying to influence the outcome of legislation.
The Court of Appeal today reversed a High Court ruling that would have allowed a drug company to raise the price of its tranquilizers in defiance of a Government order.
A resurgence of strong export demand pushed up all prices of wheat, corn and new-crop soybeans for future delivery yesterday to their respective daily limits on Midwest exchanges.

More than 600 prisoners camped in a fenced-off portion of the Oklahoma state prison today and refused to enter the cellblocks out of fear of reprisals from other inmates, They charged that there were "lots of dead inmates" whose bodies had not been found in the charred ruins of the prison after a weekend of rioting.

The Skylab 2 astronauts fell further behind in their work aboard the orbiting space station today as they continued to be troubled with motion sickness. For a second time, the astronauts had to postpone a planned space "walk."

Dr. Milton Helpern, the city's medical examiner, said yesterday that an autopsy indicated no signs of foul play in the death of Lonnie B. Epps, a former member of the Black Panther party whose body was found face down in a fish hatchery pond in Pennsylvania last week.

Public school enrollment in New Jersey will decrease this year for the first time since the end of World War II and then decline steadily over the next decade, according to estimates announced today by the Department of Education.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation says two persons have been arrested and a third is sought on Federal charges in connection with an alleged fraudulent interstate baby-selling scheme.

It takes a very cool individual to withstand sudden fame and fortune. It is even more difficult for a professional athlete. Take last year's Cy Young Award winners, Steve Carlton of Philadelphia and Gaylord Perry of Cleveland, for example.

A young man who was "deprogramed" by Ted Patrick and reunited with his family testified at Mr. Patrick's trial yesterday that leaders of the New Testament Missionary Fellowship had told young memhers that their parents were being used by devils and that they ought to break ties with them.

The trial of 80 leftists charged with plotting the violent overthrow of the Moroccan monarchy began in a criminal court here today. The prosecution charged that the defendants, whom it characterized as "Maoists," had formed an underground movement that sought to depose King Hassan II and establish a "socialist republic."

Jimmy Radcliffe, singer, composer and record producer for Black Patch Productions and for the corporation of his own name, died Friday of a kidney ailment in the Bronx Veterans Administration Hospital.

The local that struck the New York Telephone Company two years ago asked a Federal court yesterday to compel its former president to account for $609,314 in what were described as "questionable expenditures" made during the seven-month walkout.

Nassau County and New York City policemen were trying to determine today whether organized-crime figures were involved in yesterday's slaying of a Long Island man described by the police as a major national distributor of pornographic films.

The Santa Clara Aquamaids dominated the Amateur Athletic Union outdoor synchronized swimming championships yesterday and retained their national titles in every event.

Fulfilling a pledge made last September to President Nixon. the Japanese Government has sharply reduced the huge $4.2-billion imbalance in trade with the United States, so that by the end of this year the Japanese surplus is expected to be about $2-billion-or half last year's total.
Governor Rockefeller's welcome proposal for providing operational subsidies for ailing mass transit systems in cities and suburbs requires local governments to put up matching subsidies of their own.

To prevent what its president called "chaos" in agriculture, the New Jersey Farm Bureau came to the defense today of a member farmer charged with evicting 11 migrant workers from his labor camp last September without notice.
Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court said today that he would rule in 24 to 48 hours on whether there should be an immediate halt in the United States bombing of Cambodia.

Philip Klein, president since 1938 of the Mohawk Savings and Loan Association of Newark, died yesterday in Columbia - Presbyterian Medical Center in New York. He was 79 years old and lived at 1309 Mercer Place.

A former convict suspected of the fatal stabbing Sunday of a teen-aged camper bound to a tree in the Adirondacks State Park was made the subject of a nationwide alarm yesterday while at least 100 lawmen searched for him in the upstate woodlands.
Cesar Chavez called his United Farm Workers out on strike today after negotiations with 29 table grape growers were broken off hours before a contract expiration at midnight.

Despite upward pressure on prices in tile jewelry industry, fed by rising gold costs and a shortage of silver, retailers report record sales and optimism about the future, Victor Paul, chairman of the Retail Jewelers of America, said yesterday.

The number of workdays lost to strikes during the first half of the year fell to the lowest level in nine years, the Labor Department reported today. The department said that idleness declined to I.? working days per thousand in the January-to-June period, compared with 1.4 working days per thousand in the corresponding period last year.

The Consolidated Ediscn Company asserted yesterday that its earnings were "at starvation level" and that it would probably seek a new increase in electric rates here in the next 14 months in addition to that sought in a pending application.

Rich Glover, college football's most honored lineman last year, began his professional career with the New York Giants today with praise from his new coach but with the words of skeptics and cynics still nagging at his pride.

Two alleged Nassau County robbers led the police last evening on a five-mile, 60-mile-an-hour car chase into the Laurelton section of Queens until they were captured finally in the vicinity of Montefiore Cemetery.

The officials and businessmen who handled the 600,000 rock-music fans at the largest festival ever held in the United States said today that they thought the event was an overwhelming success but that they would never permit another one.

The 10-day rally on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market ended yesterday as prices eased in slower trading.

The start of a year-long rehabilitation and modernization project of the Hamilton Grange Branch Library, a historic landmark at 503 West 145th Street, has been announced by the Municipal Services Administration.

Britain has agreed to give the Caribbean island of Grenada full independence on Feb. 7 next year. The Foreign Office said today that the date was agreed on at talks here last week with Grenada's Premier, Eric M. Gairy, subject to approval by the British Parliament.

Vern Mason suffered a cut over his right eye in the seventh round of his welterweight bout against Roberto Sosa of Argentina last night, but that didn't seem to bother him as he won a unanimous decision in a 10-round bout at the Felt Forum.
Barbara Walters Signed To 3-Year N.B.C. Contract Barbara Walters has signed a new long-term contract to continue appearing on the National Broadcasting Company's "Today" television show.

Directors of Genesco, Inc., voted yesterday to set up a reserve of $60,146,000 in the fiscal year ending today to cover losses which may be incurred in restructuring, discontinuing or selling certain operatinr divisions.

The taxi industry is pushing a summertime "sneaker" bill to allow the sale of space on mini-billboards that will be affixed to either side of taxi roofs. The bill will come up in City Council for a vote today-with virtually no warning and totally inadequate public discussion.

OCEANPORT--The Rev. Homer Tricules has resigned as pastor of the First Baptist Church of neighboring Long Branch. The reason? "To bring faith" to the backstretch tenants of New Jersey's three thoroughbred racing tracks--Monmouth Park, Garden State and Atlantic City.

President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto's visit to the United States has again been postponed by a week at Pakistan's request and will begin Sept. 18, it was announced today.

The House Foreign Affairs Committee announced today that it had asked the Ambassador to Greece, Henry J. Tasca, to return to Washington to testify on political conditions under the military-backed Government in Athens.

Two alleged underworld figures were arrested at their homes in Brooklyn and Queens early yesterday and charged with the murder of a man in a Staten Island bar two months ago in what the police described as a dispute among criminal elements.
A $54-billion antitrust suit was filed in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday against five major oil and gasoline corporations.
Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that he did not believe in "any kind of mechanistic, statistical approach" to ending discrimination in employment.

The First Pennsylvania Mortgage Trust announced yesterday that it will buy up to 400,000 of its warrants in the over-the-counter market during the next year. The real estate investment trust, which is run by a subsidiary of the First Pennsylvania Corporaton, has 1,611,974 warrants outstandng to purchase 805,987 shares of common stock at $20 a share. The common closed at 19 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

To the Editor: The U.S.-Soviet accords on nuclear weapons and peaceful atomic programs seem to promise a new era of cooperation between scientists of the two countries. But the hunger strike by six Soviet scientists dramatized deep-lying difficulties in Soviet attitudes toward science and scientists which can make portions of the accords quite unworkable.

The beef shortage became more serious in this area yesterday as retailers reported inadequate supplies and meat processing plants laid off workers.

The New York Yankees have not won a game in Boston in a year, and Manager Ralph Houk knows 'why. "Because of that short left-field fence, the Red Sox make you play their gameand they ruin yours," he said.

Six months after the signing of the Vietnam truce, the war goes on here in the heart of the Mekong Delta. Elsewhere in South Vietnam the fighting has generally diminished, but there are still days in Chuong Thien Province when more than 100 men die, when whole hamlets are laid waste.

HUDSON, N. Y. - An experimental ombudsman program, begun a year ago, has brought significant gains in the human and legal rights of the troubled teen-agers who live in institutions run by the State Division for Youth.

For the. second time in less than two years, the Senate adopted today an important package of reforms-some of them very stringent-in one of the most crucial but unseen areas of the democratic process: the financing of campaigns for elective office.

Governor Cahill, who lost his bid to be a candidate for re-election this year, today expressed the hope that his successor would carry on and expand the summer youth program he established two years ago.

The Bloomfield College chapter of the American Association of University Professors filed a breach of contract suit today in Superior Court in Trenton asking that the college be prevented from dismissing 13 faculty members and putting the rest of its teachers on oneyear contracts.

Henry Moore, giant among the world's living sculptors, marked his seventy-fifth birthday yesterday-by sculpting. He is not counting the candles. Busier than ever this summer, he is carving in the marble mountain region beyond Viareggio in Italy where Michelangelo quarried much of the stone that he, too, turned to life.

OFF DUTY Gilbert and Sullivan told us what the felon does when he's not engaged in his employment; he has great capacity for innocent enjoyment. But what does a noted lawyer do when he's finished arguing and looks for surcease from tension? If he's Louis Nizer,
Attorney General Elliot .. Richardson said today that he would use his special authority to relax immigration regulations to allow 800 Soviet Jews now in Rome to quickly enter the United States.
For the second time in less than two years, the Senate adopted today an important package of reforms-some of them very stringent-in one of the most crucial but unseen areas of the democratic process:

A reader asks what we think of serving a party meal that includes both wine and a salad with vinegar or lemon juice. She has been told the two don't go together. We think, first, that she should serve what she likes.

Steel production last week feel 1.6 per cent to 2.780,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The index dipped to 113.9 from 115.8 in the preceding week, when output stood at 2,826,000 tons.
Ben Crenshaw, whose style of play has often been compared with Jack Nicklaus, will make his debut as a pro on the golf tour Aug. 16 in the $200,000 United States industries classic at Sutton, Mass.
Sharp clashes were reported today as close as five miles from Phnom Penh as advancing Communist troops routed 200 government soldiers from a position east of the Bassac River.

A penguin was born today to a 3-year-old king penguin at the Ocean Underworld Exhibit in Atlantic City. Ornithologists said it was the first time in New Jersey and extremely rare in the world that an egg of a penguin had hatched in captivity.
A ministerial-level meeting of the Committee of 20 nations negotiating world monetary reform began here today, but with no decisions or announcements expected.

New Jersey today won the right to collect damages from polluters in a precedent-setting decision that is expected to inspire new rounds of litigation against those found guilty of damaging the state's waterways and marshlands.
For nearly an hour yesterday afternoon, a sniper on West 38th Street-armed with a 12gauge, single-barreled shotgun and the bravado of an afternoon of drinking-held scores of police officers at bay.

United States exports to the Soviet Union during the first six months of 1973 exceeded two-way trade between the two countries for all of 1972. Commerce Department trade data showed today that United States exports to the Soviet Union from January through June totaled $693.4-million. Imports from the Soviet Union totaled $86.5-million.
Clifford Irving, who was convicted of attempting to write a bonus autobiography of Howard Hughes, the reclusive billionaire, was denied parole today by the United States Parole Board.

Is the American economy headed into another "credit crunch" that could cause a serious slump in housing and business generally? A "crunch"-the term has no generally agreed scientific definition-is characterized by a skyrocketing of interest rates and a choking off of the availability of credit.

Ralph Sullivan, an attorney for The Manchester Union Leader, has turned a photographed copy of the disputed "Canuck" letter over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the managing editor, Paul Tracey, said today.
There were tears and curses from the seven young Americans in the prisoner's dock as a Turkish judge set heavy bail
Rocky Thompson of Wichita Falls, Tex., led 17 qualifiers into the seventh annual Westchester Golf Classic today with a 36, 32-68 over the 6,743-yard, par 35, 37-72 course at Wee Burn Country Club.
Sol G. Atlas, builder of skyscrapers and shopping centers, died of a stroke yesterday at the North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L. I. His age was 66 and he lived in Kings Point, L. I.

Five top officers of Weis Securities. Inc., a former New York Stock Exchange firm now in liquidation, pleaded not guilty yesterday to Federal charges of falsifying their records by more than $3-million to conceal a $1.5-million deficit.

The dollar and the pound strengthened today upon a further easing of interest-rate tensions that threatened last week to precipitate a new monetary crisis. Extremely tight money in West Germany had been pulling funds from Britain and the United States.
NEW LONDON. Conn.--The idea that all the campus, if not the world, is a stage, was taken firmly to heart the American Dance Festival at Connecticut College during its past "melange weekend."

The Environmental Protection Agency allowed the nation's auto makers today to delay from 1976 until 1977 the production of cars that would meet stringent emission standards for nitrogen oxides, the third pollutant for which a year's extension has now been granted.

The conservationists who toured the country with two wolves to promote the preservation of endangered species said yesterday that their educational programs would continue despite the wolves' death Sunday, apparently at the hands of a poisoner.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, July 30, 1973. Petition filed by: EUGENE W. WATSON, launderer, New Young, State Rehabilitation Hospital, Roule, ?? West Haverstraw, Rockland County, ?? Liabilities $6,368; assets $417.
Third-seeded Nikki Pilic, fourth-seeded Marty Riessen and. fifth-seeded Manuel Orantes scored easy victories today in the opening round of the $75,000 First National Bank tennis tournament.

The National Football League Players Association will seek an injunction in the California courts on Wednesday, restraining Pete Rozelle, the N.F.L. commissioner, who has suspended Lance Rentzel from playing with the Los Angeles Rams this season.
Wayne Hulse of the Moriches Yacht Club today won the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association Picken Trophy, emblematic of the midget sailing championship on the bay.
Five years ago, when Richard Nader looked into the future of the music business, what he saw coming was a revival of the rock 'n' roll music of the nineteenfifties.
The Iranian Ambassador, Jahangir Amuzegar, said yesterday that producing nations, consuming nations and the international oil companies must compromise on their respective

A .38-caliber service revolver reported missing last February by a captain in the Department of Correction was recovered last night from a 24year-old man who was observed entering a grocery store in Harlem with the revolver drawn, the police reported.
A High Court judge approved a $50-million award today to compensate children who were born deformed after their mothers took thalidomide.
The Greek Government rejoiced today over its "triumphant" victory at the polls although the results were challenged by many Greeks and questioned by diplomats.

Jim Boulding, Chuck Smith, Dwight Stones and Al Feuerbach of the United States were winners today in the opening of a two-day track and field meeting in which a couple of New Zelanders dominated the distance events.
The prices farmers get for their raw products were unchanged in July from the month before and averaged 35 per cent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

Federal prosecutors moved, yesterday for a prompt trial of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans on charges that they obstructed a major fraud investigation in return for a secret political contribution.

The Japan symbolized by Premier Kakuei Tanaka as he prepares to meet with President Nixon tomorrow is a nation with more self-confidence than at any time since World War IIand a nation with little sense of direction.
The Mets got encouraging performances from two key pitchers last night, but they failed to get any timely hits and dropped a double-header to the Montreal Expos at Shea Stadium.

Marshall T. Mays is a South Carolinian, a Republican, a graduate of the United States Naval Academy and a lawyer. As of yesterday, he has also been designated president of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation by President Nixon, subject to Senate confirmation.

A handsome dark chestnut gelding named M. H. Aswed Dahab, owned by the Tiffany Arabian of Stanfordville, N. Y., won the Arabian Western pleasure horse championship stake today at the Orange County horse show.
Short-term interest rates continued to soar to record levels yesterday and put further upward pressure on bond rates as well.

The General Electic Company proposed today to build 10 "resource-recovery plants" in Connecticut to make fuel and recover other usable materials from the 10,000 tons of trash collected in the state each day.
The stock market continued to drift sluggishly yesterday under the weight of profit-taking following two weeks of rising prices.

Illustrated. Little, Brown. $8.95. Do any of us really care any more who was first to reach the North Pole-Frederick A. Cook or Robert E. Peary?
FIRST $9,000, special weights, f. and m. mans, 3YO and up. 71. Winner, Cynthia Prios's Ch. f. 3 by Bold Ruler--Plum Cake. Trainer, R. Laurin. Net.. $5,400. Times--22 3/5; 1:10 1/5; 1.23.
An insurance fraud ring based on phantom cars has been disclosed by investigators from the Pennsylvania State Police, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and insurance companies.

When he first joined the pro golf tour in 1965, Tom Weiskopf was satisfied to be moderately successful. "He wasn't interested in making a lot of money," recalled Fred Corcoran, his agent then. "He told me 'I just want $30,000 a year.'"

After two freezes and three phases, the economy is in an inflation-ridden shambles. Nobody seems satisfied with Phase 4 and even its promulgators exhibit scant enthusiasm for it. We have come full circle.

From Bash Bish Falls in Columbia County near the Massachusetts line to Cadosia on Rattlesnake Creek in Delaware County near Pennsylvania, Federal and state engineers are in the field surveying damage caused by the floods of June.
The beef shortage became more serious in this area yesterday as retailers reported inadequate supplies and meat processing plants laid off workers.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil-Ljubomir Ljubojevic zoomed into the lead of the Interzonal tournament by defeating Peter Biyiasas of Canada in the third round after taking his. second-round game with Shimo Kagan of Israel.

The hundreds of dead silvery fish found floating on the Hudson River in the last few days were not killed by any ecological enemy but have completed their natural life cycle, according to the city's Environmental Protection Administration.

Members of Dr. Thomas W. Matthew's black self-help group NEGRO made a citizen's arrest yesterday of the owner of a Harlem sandwich shop whom they accused of having induced drug addicts to steal checks belonging to Dr. Matthew's Interfaith Hospital in Jamaica, Queens.
Army Sgt. 1st CI. Hershel Anderson of Tracy City, Tenn., won the .22-caliber pistol competition today and gained the first-round lead in the three-day national pistol championship.

A State Supreme Court justice dismissed yesterday an American Broadcasting Company suit to prevent televising of National Basketball Association games by the Columbia Broadcasting System in the upcoming season.
In October, 1969, a 22-yearold Long Islander boarding a Pan American jet in Istanbul underwent a routine antihijacking search. In his possession were found four and a half pounds of hashish.

" It wears me out a bit," says 21year-old Miss Denice Boschen, about her summer job as a beer cooler stocker. "But I'm building up muscles so quick that by the end of summer I should be able to handle anything."
The New York Yankees held onto first place by their fingertips tonight when they scored three runs in the ninth inning to defeat the Boston Red Sox, 5-4, and snap a four-game losing streak.
The Senate voted 74 to 21 today to continue the public service jobs program for two more years, although the Nixon Administration had not budgeted any funds for it.
" I drink 10 to 15 glasses of this water a day," said Charles Minowitz. "What are you talking about"
If you think there's not enough show business in motor racing, the reason is that there are not enough Roger Penskes to go around.
The Grumman Corporation announced today it had begun acquisition talks with the Beech Aircraft Corporation, general aviation designer and builder.

A microfilm system that will vastly speed the tracking of crime suspects will be introduced into the Police Department on a citywide basis as a result of a secret, successful trial that has been going on in Queens since March.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-thecounter market declined yesterday in slightly stepped-up trading.
A United States District Court judge enjoined the Secret Service today from barring dissenters at public appearances of the President unless the president's personal safety was at stake.

A FILE ON DEATH. By Kenneth Giles. 192 pages. Walker. $5.95. A LIFE FOR A DEATH. By John Creasey (as Gordon Ashe). 185 pages. Holt, Rinehart and Winston. $4.95. Good mystery writers have always known that man himself is the greatest mystery of all, more baffling than the most labyrinthine plot.

We are being instructed these days by H. R. Haldeman to lift our eyes from the Watergate to the wider perspectives of the world, and with Premier Tanaka of Japan in Washington, the advice is better than its source.

A preliminary hearing will open Sept. 25 for 10 Palestinians held in Khartoum for the murder of two American diplomats and a Belgian envoy, the Sudanese Information Minister, Umar alHag Musa, said today.

WASHINGTON - In a three-week tour of American art collections, four representatives of Soviet Union museums are exploring the possibility of an unprecedented future exchange of art between the Soviet Union and the United States.

The outcome-4-1 in favor of Pittsburgh - didn't necessarily reflect a one-sided contest, but last night's game at Shea Stadium represented a clear example of two teams pursuing sharply contrasting courses.
The West German Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe today rejected a Bavarian government contention that the treaty between East Germany and West Germany was unconstitutional.

The Senate Watergate committee challenged, in terms of alarm and indignation, the testimony today of H. R. Haldeman about the contents of secret White House recordings of President Nixon's Watergate conversations.

Despite heavy pressure from the savings and loan industry, Congress will apparently not try to abolish for the time being the new high-interest "wild card" savings certificates with no interest ceiling offered since early this month by banks and thrift institutions.

Spokesmen for hockey and basketball told Congress today they could live with legislation intended to end blackouts of home sports games on local television. But Don Ruck, vice president of the National Hockey League, and William Alverson, president of the Milwaukee Bucks of the National Basketball Association, said they were opposed to the proposed legislation in principle.
Nearly two weeks after a military coup deposed the Afghan monarchy, the Government remains paralyzed, the streets are uneasily silent and the bazaars simmer with whispered gossip.
A 41-year-old man was convicted today on a charge of having driven while impaired by alcohol while tang a road test for a drivers license.

The American Embassy here has touched off a diplomatic incident by handing the Argentine Government a series of memorandums warning that new legislative bills about to be passed by the Peronist-controlled Congress will have a detrimental effect on foreign investment in Argentina.

" I drink 10 to 15 glasses of this water a day," said Charles Minowitz. "What are they talking about?" "They" are state health officials, and what they're talking about is the radium content of this Spa's fabled waters, whose supposed curative powers have been drawing visitors such as Mr. Minowitz for generations.

Two inmates who took advantage of a brief but violent riot in the Federal penitentiary to take four hostages and barricade themselves in the prison laundry released the hostages late tonight in return for a bargaining session with prison officials and nine specified inmates.

Governor Rockefeller's $3.5-billion bond plan for freezing transit fares .and building new subways and highways received final passage in the Legislature late tonight, and both houses then adjourned the special legislative session.
Since the cease-fire began in January the Saigon Government has forcibly moved thousands of Mekong Delta peasants out of areas frequented by the Vietcong.

Three men, one armed with a handgun, pushed their way into the Essex Refining Corporation yesterday morning, handcuffed the owner and an employee, and walked away pushing a rolling suitcase filled with $112,000 worth of gold and silver.
Unseeded John Bartlett of Australia upset top-seeded Arthur Ashe, the 1972 winner, 6-3, 2-6, 6-4, tonight in the first round of the Pro Tennis Classic at the Louisville Tennis Center.
Teams headed by Malcolm Brachman of Dallas and Bud Reinhold of Highland Park, Ill., clashed here this afternoon in the final of the spingold knockout team championship

Governor Rockefeller's $3.5-billion bond plan for freezing transit fares and building new subways and highways received final passage in the Legislature late tonight following a week of minor adjustments to attract a bipartisan show of strength.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 31--The New York Giants released rookies from Grambling, Iowa, Southern University and Rutgers today but held on to a free-agent tight end from Yankton College named Mark Herman.

Insurgent troops overran a village 50 miles north of Phnom Penh after Government reinforcements were stopped less than two miles away, military sources said today. Another village 35 miles northwest of the capital was reported under siege and the situation there described as demnerate.
The three national TV networks took different views today on whether the Federal Communications Commission should repeal its controversial prime-time access rule.

During the night the lightning had flashed, thunder had shaken the darkness and rain had poured down in awesome quantities. But now dawn had come at last, a hushed and peaceful dawn given special magic by a soft mist transformed to gold.

Breathes there a ballerina who would not like to do a pas de deux with Rudolf Nureyev? Yes, there does. She is Natglia Makarova who just finished dancing with Nureyev in "Swan Lake" in Paris. As both dancers were defectors at different times from the Soviet Union and the Kirov Ballet, their appearance together in Paris had been billed as an event

The SCM Corporation filed a $435-million antitrust suit yesterday against the Xerox Corportion, charging the giant of copier company with violating both the Sherman and the Clayton antitrust acts. It was the fifth such suit filed against Xerox in slightly more than a year.

Dr. Vera Butler Douthit, associate dean for student development at York College of the City University, died in Nairobi, Kenya, on Saturday while vacationing with her husband, Reginald, a research worker. She was 55 years old and lived at 35 West 93d Street.
The makers of Alka-Sltzeri have told the Government they are prepared to start warning consumers that the product should not be taken just to cure upset stomach.
The Senate passed tonight a new version of a farm bill after a Senate-House conference deadlocked and gave up on an effort to reach a compromise on an antistrike provision.

Following are excerpts from the transcript of testimony today by H. R. Haldeman, former White House chief of staff, on the 32d day of hearings on the Watergate case before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:
The Environmental Protection Agency, in the first regulatory action it has taken to cut noise pollution, proposed noise limits today for interstate trucks and buses.

Local school desegregation, rather than lowering the quality of education, has contributed substantially to its improvement in a number of communities, according to a study by the United States Commission on Civil Rights.
Representative Robert F. Drinan, Democrat of Massachusetts, introduced a resolution today calling for the impeachment of President Nixon "for high crimes and misdemeanors."

Since political campaigns are indispensable to selfgovernment and since campaign costs have to be paid by some source, the central question is not how to break the nexus between politics and money. Rather, it is how to make that connection clean and open.

A spokesman for the Exxon Corporation said yesterday that the company had not been served with a copy of the classaction antitrust suit filed in Brooklyn Federal Court on Monday against five oil companies including Exxon Corporation.

Although the attendance faltered for the second day in a row compared with last year's figures, racing at Saratoga today was first class. The 9,835 fans were impressed by the showing contributed by Onion of the Hobeau Farm, in the feature event of 6 1/2 furlongs.

A young woman testified at Ted Patrick's trial yesterday that she had been seized, separated from her child and held in a motel room for more than 10 days last October while Mr. Patrick and others tried unsuccessfully to deprogramm" her.
If you think there's not enough show business in motor racing, the reason is that there are not enough Roger Penskes to go around.
Combustion Engineering, Inc., reported yesterday receipt of an order valued at "close to $100-million" from the Westinghouse Electric. Corporation for 22 nuclear reactor pressure vessels.

" Israelis know how to laugh, but they don't generate any real humor of their own. It's one of the casualties of 25 years of war and tension. Even our victories have taken a toll in the national sense of humor. Mind you, I'm not complaining. I prefer it to losing."
A third McGuire will wear the uniform of the Knicks. Allie McGuire Jr., the son of the Marquette basketball coach and New York's thirdround draft choice, was signed yesterday.
A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that no out-of-state lawyers will be assigned to represent any of the defendants charged in connection with the Attica prison riot.

United Telecommunications, Inc., the nation's second largest independent (non-Bell) telephone company, announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Florida Telephone Corporation for stock valued at about $142million.

Incident at La Junta, by Oliver Lange (Stein Day, $6.95). An American girl trapped in a Mexican village by strange events. Lydia, or Love in Town, by Clare Darcy (Walker, $5.95). Romance in Regency England.

Nancy Baroody's War Dress, a nationally ranked foxchaser, and Ri-Arm Farm's Wintippit, a newcomer to the equine circuit, took commanding leads today in the two divisions of the junior working hunter competition at the Orange County horse show.

A 70-year-old Brooklyn woman was arrested at her home last night as a suspect in the poisoning last Sunday of two wolves. The woman, Pauline Hollinger, was taken into custody at her home, 1201 Avenue K, Brooklyn, where she lives with her two pet cats.

Joe CINCINNA Morgan and Tony Perez belted two-run homers in a four-run seventh inning, giving the Cincinnati Reds a 9-5 triumph over the Atlanta Braves tonight despite Henry Aaron's 701st career homer in the ninth.
Francis A. Raymaley, director of the State Agricultural Department's Division of Rural Resources, died today apparently of a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

The executive directors of the International Monetary Fund unanimously appointed today Dr. H. Johannes Witteveen of the Netherlands as the fund's new managing director to succeed Pierre-Paul Schweitzer of France.

The effort to relieve traffic congestion on the roadways at Kennedy International Airport will move forward this fall when construction starts on a five-story structure combining passenger terminals and parking facilities the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced yesterday.
Bond prices crumbled yesterday under the weight of two major financings, both indifferently received, while money rates continued to soar.

In the first of a series of hearings being conducted by the Public Service Commission, a half dozen speakers voiced strong opposition to a proposed 43 per cent increase in rates in parts of Nassau County by the Merrick Division of the New York Water Corporation.
A settlement has been reached in a Federal court suit brought against the state's 567 municipalities that could result in a marked decrease in the cost of public contracts.
An admitted prostitute and a jailed felon were convicted today by a Superior Court jury here of murdering Assemblyman Silvio J. Failla last Sept. 16.
The Congress was asked today to consider breaking off the American Telephone Telegraph Company from its equipment makers, the Western Electric Company, because of alleged anti-competitive practices.

Dr. Alfred Vogl, professor of clinical medicine at the New York University School of Medi cine and widely known for his discovery of advances of diuresis, died of an apparent heart attack in Selva, Italy, on Monday. He was 78 years old and lived at 145 East 84th Street.
Vice President Agnew assured some United States representatives abroad today that the nation's Government was being carried forward despite Watergate.

' Yes, we have no meat today," the man in the bloodstained white coat said as he pointed to the nearly-empty storage hooks he said were, normally filled to capacity with loins. "And we probably won't have any next week," he added.
A Government advisory committee recommended today a new code of "fair information practice," backed up by law, to protect the privacy of the individual in the age of the computer.

Even the two minnows, part of a scientific experiment, are having trouble getting used to life aboard Skylab. They keep swimming, pitched down, in tight little circles, apparently disoriented by the weightlessness of space.
A $9.6-million, two-year contract between Nassau County and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association was ratified by the police today by an 8-to-1 vote. The vote was 2,487 in favor and 302 opposed.

The stock market sold off sharply late yesterday afternoon shortly after newswires carried a report that a resolution calling for the impeachment of President Nixon had been introduced in the House of Representatives.
American and Canadian negotiators have reached agreement on new air routes to be divided among airlines of the two countries, informed sources said today.

The Soviet Union and its East European allies issued a fresh call tonight for completing the Conference on European Security and Cooperation by the end of 1973 and crowning it with an East-West summit meeting.
William T. Emmet, a retired securities analyst, died yesterday in Phelps Memorial Hospital, Tarrytown, N. Y. He was 36 years old and lived in Canaan, N. Y.

Scholars versed in the folkways of the common American playground director (homo infantum) have been fascinated by the reaction of the Amateur Athletic Union, the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the United States Olympic Committee and the National Rifle Association of America to a bill called the Amateur Athletic Act of 1973 that has been introduced by Senator John V. Tunney of California.

A number of the major wholesale beef houses serving New York City said yesterday they would close for the day today because "the remaining supplies of beef do not warrant a fiveday operation" this week. They said they aimed to "conserve beef on hand for their customers for weekend business."
Three girls and a youth in a stolen car were seized following a chase yesterday after they struck the wife of an African diplomat at West 79th Street and Riverside Drive, the police reported.

Former Representative J. Irving Whalley of Pennsylvania pleaded guilty today to charges of mail fraud and obstruction of justice. He faces a possible maximum sentence of 15 years in prison and $11,000 fine. No sentencing date was set.
Hard-line Protestants brought the first session of Northern Ireland's new Assembly to a disorderly close today, reinforcing their pledge to make the Assembly unworkable.

To the Editor: An interesting pattern is emerging from the Senate Watergate hearings. My very strong impression is that the tapes being sought by the committee, if released, would fail to incriminate either the President or his close associates in wrongdoing in the Watergate mess.

Olivier Giscard d'Estaing, president of a data services company called Compagnie International de Teleinformatique, said here yesterday that the Common Market should be able to achieve monetary union with full convertibility by 1980.
West German officials are scheduled to meet later this week to study results of an investigation into news reports charging that the American military engaged in illegal intelligence activities here.

Purcell McPhaul, who held about 50 police officers at bay with a shotgun for almost an hour from a basement on west 38th Street, Manhattan, Monday, was arraigned in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday, and held in lieu of $30,000 bail on charges of attempted murder, assault, reckless endangerment, resisting arrest and possession of a dangerous weapon.

Negotiators for the Government of Premier Souvanna Phouma and the Communistled Pathet Lao conferred again today on the details of their reported agreement for a coalition government. Informed sources said they worked out security arrangements for Vien. tiane, the administrative capital.

More than 100 state police officers, sheriff's deputies and conservation workers, aided by bloodhounds and helicopters, continued yesterday to search the Adirondacks Woodlands near Wells, N. Y., for the former convict sought in the murder Sunday of an 18-year-old camper.
A Federal judge dismissed a suit today by two black girls who say they were involuntarily sterilized. The actionr will not prevent refiling the suit against some of the defendants.

Despite assertions by President Nixon and some of his top aides that Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatric records were sought only to assist a "national security" investigation, some key figures in the White House intended to leak the confidential material to the press to discredit Dr. Ellsberg and damage his "image," according to sources familiar with the operation.

Gulf Western Industries, Inc., was asked last year to contribute "services" to President Nixon's campaign, company sources said yesterday. They said that the request had been made first by Herbert W. Kalmbach, then the President's personal lawyer, and later by William L. Safire, a special assistant to President Nixon and now a columnist for The New York Times.

President Nixon and Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan agreed this morning that the President would visit Japan within the next 18 months and that Emperor Hirohito would come to the United States during 1974.
Hyatt Robert von Dehn, founder of the Hyatt House hotel chain, died of a heart ailment in Pebble Beach on Saturday. He was 58 years old. He leaves his wife and two sons.
The PBW Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday it hopes to start a trading market in call options before the end of 1973.

Amid fresh charges of gerrymandering, the City Council late yesterday approved a reapportionment plan designed to make all City Council districts "compact, convenient and contiguous," as ordered by the state's Court of Appeals last May 3.
The guest list for tonight's state dinner at the White House for Japan's Premier, Kakuei Tanaka, was fairly routine, as state dinners go.

The top Federal environmental protection official in this area called yesterday for the suspension of the proposed fare increase on Port AuthorityTrans Hudson (PATH) trains, describing it as "unjust, unreasonable and unlawful."

Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, a member of the Senate Watergate committee, said today that he had gone on a vacation to the Caribbean with a Government contractor because the contractor was a friend of his.
Women prison inmates told a state legislative committee today they were a source of cheap labor for homeowners who wanted housecleaners and gardeners.

Julius Erving, probably pro basketball's most exciting player, is coming home to Long Island, where he grew up. The New York Nets have acquired Erving, the American Basketball Association's leading scorer, from the Virginia Squires.

The Oakland A's, struggling to retain their title in the American League West, picked up three players today for the stretch run, Vic Davalillo and Jesus Alou, outfielders and Mike Andrews, an infielder.
The Senate Armed Services Committee voted today to reduce military aid for South Vietnam and Laos to $952-million for the current fiscal year.
A Federal court refused today to rule on the constitutionality of New York's obscenity law, saying it was a matter for state courts to decide.
Dr. Arthur F. Wright, former chief of the obstetrical-gynecological service at Nassau Hospital, died yesterday in Southampton Hospital. He was 60 years- old and lived at 1 Devereux Place.

A policeman was stabbed yesterday as he attempted to quiet a disorderly man at Ninth Avenue and 52d Street, the police said, and another man was arrested for allegedly interfering in the arrest of the assailant.

The International Business Machines 'Corporation announced yesterday development of a new, larget-cappcity ,model of the IBM System/7 with enhanced communications and stand-alone programing capabilities.

SALISBURY; Rhodesia, July 13--Six members of the leading black political organization in Rhodesia have been arrested by the Rhodesian authorities during the last few days, according to Bishop Abel Muzorewa, leader of the African National Council.

Mortgage lending by the savings banks of New York State in June was the largest so far this year, but commitments to provide future mortgage financing declined, the Savings Banks Association of New York State reported yesterday.
A pair of important conclusions are emerging at high levels of the Federal Reserve Board. Both are, in a sense, pessimistic. But it can be argued that they are also realistic.
The Warner-Lambert Company increased earnings in the quarter and six months ended June 30 by 12 per cent to records for the periods, the company reported yesterday.

A top campaign aide to former Gov. Albert Brewer denied today knowledge of an alleged 400,000 contribution from President Nixon's campaign funds in 1970. Mr. Brewer was making a bid in 1970 to defeat Gov. George C. Wallace for the Democratic nominaion for Governor.

The Senate Watergate committee challenged with alarm and indignation 'the testimony of H. R. Haldeman, former White House chief of staff, about the contents of secret White House recordings of President Nixon's Watergate conversations. Senator Sam J. Ervin, the committee's chairman, declared that Mr. Haldeman's testimony was part of a "planned action" by the White House to "leak" a favorable version of the taped conversations.
Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor have instructed a New York lawyer to draw up papers for their divorce, a spokesman for the two film stars announced last night.
The'Soviet Union said today that its Antarctic supply ship Ob had reached open water after having been trapped in ice off the Antarctic Continent for three months.
The new 10-member Board of Elections voted yesterday to permit the registration of voters by volunteer registrars this summer.
If your daily traffic jam has lost its sting -- if those gas fumes in the tunnel or out there on the Long Island Expressway no longer intoxicate -- then try Interstate 684.
Beginning salary offers to this year's college graduates increased noticeably for the first time in four years, the College Placement Council reported yesterday.

A search for available parcels of land that may be available here for low-rent public housing is beginning as a result of the release of $13.7-million in Federal funds for construction of "scatter site" housing projects here.
" If Mrs. Housewife feels the meat shortage, so should the White House," says Bernard Goldstein. "They started the shortage and don't deserve any better treatment than anyone else."
H. R. Haldeman testified today that he had learned a number of details about several of the more controversial aspects of the Watergate affair long before they became public.
The House Armed Services Committee voted unanimously today to cite G. Gordon Liddy, a convicted Watergate conspirator, for contempt of Congress.
Iran has agreed to an American request that she take Canada's place on the four-nation ceasefire commission in South Vietnam, Administration officials said today.

During the last three years, plagued with rising costs and an inability to find qualified personnel in the inner city, New York Telephone has quietly moved parts of its directory assistance operations, for area code 212, out of New York City.
James P. Cullen, a vice president of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Robb, Peck, McCooey Co., Inc., died yesterday at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch.
A young East German army lieutenant defected by swimming 150 yards across the Elbe River..today, then changed his mind and voluntarily returned to East Germany.
WASHINGTON, July 31--Iran has agreed to an American request that she take Canada's place on the four-nation ceasefire commission in South Vietnam, Administration officials said today.

Three men, one armed with a handgun, pushed their way into the Essex Refining Corporation yesterday morning, handcuffed. the owner and an employee, and walked away pushing a rolling suitcase filled with $112,000 worth of gold and silver.
The referendum whereby President Ferdinand E. Marcos tested public feeling toward his martial-law regime in a two-day vote on Friday and Saturday was called "fictitious" today by a former Senator.

A Chinatown street fair, which began last Saturday with firecrackers and a dragon dance, is providing residents of the area with information and counseling on health, housing, education, the law and programs for the elderly.

Mayor Gerald Goldman of Passaic said today that the city needed $20-million in Federal funds to revitalize the economy of a city that was facing social and economic problems, including an outflow of industry.

The Board of Trustees of Yeshiva University expresses deepest condolences to Edy the Atlas and all members of the bereaved family on the passing of her beloved husband, honored as a Master Builder, and receptent of the MetroPolitan Award for the Advancement of Higher Education, a leader esteemed as a protagonist of the Judalc heritage and revered for his humanitarlanism.
Elijah Perry, who stepped down a month ago as City Council president while under indictment, will take office tomorrow as Camden's first state lobbyist.
The theft of a bicycle that had been donated to a small Catholic church for the use of a poor child was discovered yesterday.

A 41-year old man was convicted today on a charge of having driven while impaired by alcohol while taking a road test for a drivers license.

But could it be at least possible that the thing in the picture above, nutty-looking but no more so than the Wright brothers' contraption, is the real one? That it actually flew across the skies of New York a hundred years ago?

The executors for the estate of the late David Smith, an American sculptor who pioneered in the use of welded iron for sculpture, plan to change the dealership for his works from Marlborough Galleries to Knoedler Contemporary Arts, a new subsidiary of M. Knoedler Co.

The Winter Park Telephone Company, a Florida phone company with $19.5-million of revenues, sold 800,000 shares of common stock yesterday at $14.50 apiece. An underwriting syndicate headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith made the offering.

The latest mockery of an electoral process conducted by George Papadopoulos bears all the signs of a dangerous overreach. It seems that close to 80 per cent of Greeks have voted "yes," to grant the former colonel dictatorial powers over the land of democracy's birth, through at least 1981.
Heavy damage to the Alabama cotton crop has been blamed on the invasion of a pest known as the tarnished plant bug.
A former New York City policeman who has acknowledged conducting about 30 private investigations a year for the White House gave some details tonight on a few of them.

Chile's embattled Marxist Government is faced with a grave new challenge as a truck owners' strike threatens to para lyze the country. Shortages of food, gasoline and kerosene have reached serious proportions in this city of three million people. The capital is said to be receiving only 30 per cent of its normal supplies.

Etta James, involved with personal problems, has been away from recording for two years. Now she emerges again with "Etta James" (Chess Records CH 50042, $5.98) with power undimmed, a singer looking over her shoulder to the future.

The sex-film distributor found beaten and shot to death on Long Island Sunday had been "willing to talk" about reports of a mob take-over of his business, an assistant Manhattan district attorney said yesterday.

Mrs. Irene Langhorne Emory, the wife of John J. Emory, president of Thomas Emory's Sons, Inc., a real-estate company, and Sired chairman of Emory Industries, Inc., a chemicals producer, died yesterday of a stroke at her summer home in Isleboro, Me. She was 76 years old.

Wilbur Mausly Collins, who retired in 1958 as president of Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Ltd., and International, died yesterday at Nassau Hospital in Mineola. He was 80 years old and lived at 119 Stratford Ave.
An uncommonly thoughtprovoking documentary of the effect of burgeoning technology on three generations of Americans was shown last night over the National Broadcasting Company.

The high price of beef played a role yesterday in the rehabilitation of Bowne Park, in Flushing, Queens.

Pitchers with blazing fast balls still dominate softball around the country, but their importance has been dwindling with the advent of slow-pitch leagues. These leagues, which bar the speed boys, are continually growing on the national level and New Jersey is keeping pace with the trend.

Declaring there already is a 'significant surplus" of offstreet parking facilities in midown Manhattan, the Lindsay Administration announced yesterday proposals designed to curtail sharply the development of parking lots and garages in he area.

North Vietnam today accused the United States and South Vietnam of serious breaches of the Indochina peace accords. The electronic bugging of a union room in a plant of an American Motors subsidiary last year was acknowledged today by officials of the subsidiary.
Women prison inmates told a state legislative committee today that they were a source of cheap labor for homeowners who wanted housecleaners and gardeners.

The Environmental Protection Agency, in the first regulatory action it has taken to cut noise pollution, proposed noise limits today for interstate trucks and buses.

Week-long talks between India and Pakistan ended in Pakistan today apparently without any agreement on the basic disputes between the two countries. A joint statement said "certain issues" required further consideration and the discussions would be resumed in New Delhi Aug. 18.

A Delta Air Lines jetliner attempting to make an instrument landing in a thick morning fog crashed and burned at Logan International Airport here today. All but one of the 89 persons aboard were killed.

A number of the major wholesale beef houses serving New York City said yesterday they would close for the day today because "the remaining supplies of beef do not warrant a fiveday operation" this week. They said they aimed to "conserve beef on hand for their customers for weekend business."

U. S. Financial, Inc., which has called itself "the Sears Roebuck of housing," sought before a Federal bankruptcy judge today to escape being forced into receivership because of its rapidly mounting debts. They already exceed $260-million.
The American Motors Corporation today reported operating profits of $40.5-million for the first nine months of its 1973 fiscal year, highest for the period in 13 years.

The nation's largest steel maker, the United States Steel Corporation, reported yesterday new highs in sales for the second quarter and first half. But while production, shipments and net income for both periods soared above the like 1972 periods, all remained behind previous highs.

Walrus, the design studio and shop Susan Abbott and Terry Eisen have opened at 128 West 72d Street, takes its name from the project that started it all, a versatile pad that, in one of its uses resembles a walrus.

Senate Minority Leader J. Edward Crabiel or Middlesex County, who dropped out of the race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination to support Brendan T. Byrne, has decided to split $15,000 in unspent campaign funds between the Middlesex County Democratic organization and Mr. Byrne's campaign. Mr. Crabiel said he had received more than $51,000 and had spent $35,635 before he dropped his candidacy to support Mr. Byrne in last June's primary election.
The sprawling shipyard facilities of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, at Hudson and 13th Streets here, are benefiting from the dollar devaluation.

The International Herald Tribune, the English-language daily newspaper published in Paris, today raised its newstand price to 1.50 francs (approximately 37 cents) because of soaring inflation in France, a spokesman said.
New Jersey has decided to put off approval of any abortion clinics until the fall, and it least one physician await?? permission to open a clinic maintains that the delay is unreasonable.
Three out of four black law school graduates fail to pass bar examinations allowing them to practice, according to an official of a Negro attorneys organization.
The Spingold knockout team title was won here in the early hours of today by a quintet led by Bud Reinhold of Highland Park, Ill.

A 19-year-old art student with a high I.Q. who kept a detailed "official holdup record" crediting himself with 30 muggings in five months was sentenced yesterday as a youthful offender to a maximum of four years in a reformatory.

A fine of $150,000 a day was impose yesterday against the international Business Machines Corporation for its refusal to provide court-ordered documents in one of the most important antitrust cases in history.
From the Supreme Court of the United States has come an early warning signal that President Nixon's pretensions to unchecked executive power may be in for trouble at the bench.

The Skylab 2 astronauts, more alert and active, appeared today to be recovered from the motion sickness that had troubled them the first four days of their planned 59-day mission aboard the nation's orbiting space station.
The Internal Revenue Service announced today that it intended to start taxing some of the income received by political parties and committees, unless Congress or the courts told it not to.
A crowd estimated at 18,000 braved overcast and threatening skies to attend the reopening of the 36th annual Hill Cumorah Pageant last night.
Babe Ruth's career record of 714 home runs won't be broken by Hank Aaron until Sept. 30 at the earliest, a computer at Georgia State University insists.

The chief clerk of this city's Municipay Court--an original member of the ousted Kenny political machine--was indicted here today on bribery charges involving a "systematic" $5 kickback scheme on every bail bond sold to city prisoners.
Governor Cahill today signed into law a bill authorizing state cigarette tax agents to carry weapons and arrest cigarette smugglers.

AMERICAN CONFERENCE CLEVELAND-Released Rich Jackson, defensive end, and George Greenfield, Murray State running back. BALTIMORE-Acquired Ira Dean, Baylor detensive back, on waivers from Detroit. HOUSTON-Obtained James Ford, running back, from New Orleans in exchange for sixth and 10th-round 1974 draft choices on conditional basis subject to physical exam.

H. R. Haldeman's lawyer referred today to Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, as "that little Jap" and said later he saw nothing wrong with the comment, adding: "I wouldn't mind being called a little American."
Most Americans now favor mercy killing for people who have incurable diseases, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

Federal officials sifting the wreckage of a Delta Air Lines's DC-9 jetliner that crashed and burned yesterday in heavy fog at Logan International Airport here, killing all but one of the 89 persons aboard,

A 70-year-old Brooklyn woman, charged with poisoning two wolves, was ordered in Criminal Court yesterday to undergo psychiatric examination. The woman, Pauline Hollinger of 1201 Avenue K, pleaded not guilty to charges of burglary and criminal mischief. She had been arrested at her home the night before on the basis of information from an anonymous telephone caller who said he had witnessed the crime.
Cambodian troops began a new drive southwest of Phnom Penh today in an attempt to relieve the pressure of insurgent forces on the city's southern defense perimeter.
The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that a disciplinary panel had found Robert P. Teitelbaum, a registered representative of Jas, H. Oliphant Co., Inc., guilty of violating exchange rules.

Dr. William J. McGill, president of Columbia University, said yesterday that he regarded attempts to "kidnap" members of the conservative New Testament Missionary Fellowship as a threat to civil liberties.

The Food and Drug Administration took final action today on a subject that has caused nationwide debate and controversy for at least a decade the labeling, promotion and sales of vitamins and minerals.
Prince of Truth, appearing beaten when Windtex passed him on the last turn came on strongly again approaching the wire today to win the $27,325 Salvator Mile Handicap at Monmouth Park.
Mrs. Inge Werner Neumann Marcuse, wife of Prof. Herbert Marcuse, the political philosopher, died of cancer Tuesday in La Jolla, Calif., where they were living. She was 59 years old.

Dan Turpin looked up from the lamb chops on his butcher's block. "I know you're going away," he said, "and your daughter will be here alone. If she wants anything, tell her to give me a ring and ,1'll bring it round. We don't want her living on chips, do we?"

A last-minute decision by the American-owned Mediterranean Refining Company to keep operating in Lebanon today averted seizure of the company's assets by the Lebanese Government, a company spokesman said. Mederco, owned by the Mobil Oil and Caltex Companies, had shut down its operations at midnight at the Zahrani refinery near the south Lebanon port of Sidon.
Four men involved in the operation of a now-defunct medical center in Freeport, L. I., were arraigned yesterday on charges of raising $600,000 through the fraudulent sale of securities.

The French Government made public today its plan to settle the nearly-two-month old dispute between the management of the LIP Watch Manufacturing Company and its workers, who took over the factory and its production to protest the sale of the company to Swiss interests.

Walter Ulbricht, East German head of state, died today after having suffered a stroke on July 19. He was 80 years old. The veteran East German leader, known as the man who built the Berlin Wall in August, 1961, to seal off his Communist country from the West, was removed from the seat of power

The Senate approved today a compromise $20-billion highway bill that would eventually open part of the Highway Trust Fund for urban mass transit needs. The vote was 91 to 5 on the measure, which requires approval by the House before going to President Nixon.

Despite a broken throttle cable, this former Navy fleet tender, her crew of 20 Sea Scouts and a party of guests put out to sea this morning on a preliminary shakedown cruise from Caven Point, Jersey City, to the foot of Wall Street, Manhattan.

A teen-ager who reportedly concealed his true age and identity from the authorities was found hanged by his bedsheet yesterday in his cell at the city's House of Detention for Men on Rikers Island after writing a note disclaiming responsibility for the robbery that led to his jailing.

It had to happen, and yesterday it became official in New York for women to whistle at passing men: The first four women traffic policemen began working at four tough, midtown intersections.

Mindful of his bond referendum failure two years ago, Governor Rockefeller intends taking a lower profile in selling his new and larger $3.5-billion bond proposal approved by the Legislature last night.

James Earl Jones has the physical presence, power and emotional depth to play kings and giants. The problem has been for him to find roles that are large enough to challenge his sizable talent-although there have also been times, such as last summer, when he played Claudius to Stacy Keach's Hamlet, that he has made a lesser character achieve new importance.
The House agreed today to bar further "security" improvements on President Nixon's private homes at Key Biscayne, 'la., and San Clemente, Calif., withoutt specific Congressional approval.
