For many persons one of the largest assets in their prospective estates is a group life insurance policy. Amost every employs has a chance to buy "group term," as it is often called.

BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Aug. 1, 1973 Petition filed by; OAKWOOD INDUSTRIES INC., selling and distributing pipe, coatings and chemicals, at 31 West Prospect St., Nanuset, N.Y. Liabilities $68,896; assets $9,710. ISIDORE ROSENTHAL, shipping clerk, 1534 Selwyn Ave., Apt. 2 A, Bronx, N.Y. Liabilities $7,878; assets $966.

The Baltimore Orioles scored a 4-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians today. Mike Cuellar went the first five innings for Baltimore to earn his eighth victory against 11 defeats. Bob Reynolds hurled the last four for his fourth save.
Gen. Annibale Bergonzoli, who was decorated by the British for gallantry in World d War I and was captured by them in World War II, died at his home here yesterday. He was 89 years old.
SENATE WATERGATE HEARINGS TELEVISION Channels 2, 13, 31 live coverage starting at 9:30 A.M. Channels 13, 31, 50 on tape at 8 P.M. RADIO WBAI, WINS, WRVR, WCBS, and WNYC at 9:30 A.M.

C C/Bohrer, Inc., a subsidiary of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, has been awarded a $23.5-million contract for construction of additions to the Mill Creek waste water treatment plant in Cincinnati, Ohio. Construction is scheduled for completion in about 30 months.
Samuel Feingold, who was a Republican alderman under Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia in 1934-35, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 165 East 72d Street.
Opponents of the Greek Government asked the Supreme Court today to annul Sunday's referendum on the ground of large-scale official rigging and intimidation of voters.

A special Federal grand jury has been impaneled to investigate a possible "wholesale holdup of consumers" in the current shortage of beef in metropolitan area, United States Attorney Robert A. Morse announced yesterday.

Fernando Cosme thought he had no place to play organized baseball this summer. However, a friend told him about the Boriquen All-State division of the Athletic Federation of Spanish Leagues. "I want to be a major leaguer, so I have to play all the time," said the 18-year-old Cosme, a recent graduate of John Kennedy High School here, where he was voted most valuable player on the varsity team.

The 10-cent chocolate bar, as presently constituted, will in all likelihood be a thing of the past by 1974. The Nestle Company, Inc., said yesterday that it would offer a 15-cent bar, weighing about one-quarter ounce more, as soon as molds of the new size were completed.
Mrs. Irene Langhorne Gibson Emery, wife of John J. Emery, a director and retired chairman of Emery Industries Inc., in iCncinnati, died Monday at her summer home here. She was 76 years old.

A dozen private business and professional associations announced today that they had formed "a civic front" and indicating that its aim was to oust the Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

The Executive Council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said today that the failure of the Administration's economic stabilization program and the tight money policy of the Federal Reserve Board could lead to a recession.

The hearings on landmark designation of the houses at Fifth Avenue and 82d Street raise issues far beyond their individual architectural value. The controversy surrounding the buildings-whether a developer should be free to demolish them for a luxury apartment house or whether they should be preserved-is only the tip of an environmental iceberg.

A 17-year-old girl who was struck by a car here yesterday died of her injuries last night in a Syosset hospital, the Nassau County police reported. They identified the girl as Gloria McNally of 56 Briarcliff Road here.

A 24-year-old laborer was arrested last night when he attempted to ride a 13-foot alligator in a lake at the University of Florida. Curtis W. Reed had been warned twice previously by the police before he made his attempt before hundreds of spectators. Mr.

Despite a broken throttle cable, this former Navy fleet tender, her crew of 20 Sea Scouts and a party of guests put out to sea this morning on a preliminary shakedown cruise from Caven Point, Jersey City, to the foot of Wall Street, Manhattan.

The body of a woman who apparently witnessed the murder of a neighbor Sunday night was found yesterday in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, and an alarm was issued for her boyfriend in connection with both slaying, the police reported.

Stewart Mott, the 35-year-old bachelor philanthropist, rode down Fifth Avenue in a hansom cab yesterday, wearing a crown of laurel leaves. No, he was not celebrating making another million to go with the five he already has. He had just been named male National NonParent of the Year.

After a delay of one season, the first 13 Central Park tennis courts to be resurfaced were opened yesterday and dedicated in a characteristic fashion - two players quarreled over their right to a court.

Britain's big commercial banks raised their base lending rates by two full percentage points today to 10 per cent, the hightest level since 1914. In effect, most borrowers will now pay 12 per cent a year this loans in this country.

Inside the high wire fence, there are two basketball courts, in green cement with white lines. "That's the best basket, that one there," Julius Erving said, pointing to the nearest one. "That's where I play the most."
Mrs. Edward F. Cox confirmed today that her family had discussed the possibility of a Presidential resignation over Watergate, but she quoted her father as saying:
H.R. Haldeman acknowledged today that he had suggested this year that the White House "tie all 1972 demonstrations to McGovern and thus to the Democrats."
The chairman of the Holiday Magic cosmetic empire announced yesterday a complete about-face in its marketing practices in an effort to end legal attacks on the company by state and Federal officials.

ANDERSON-Bessle L. of Townsend Ave. Pelham, N.Y. on August 1, 1973. Beloved wife of the late John D. Anderson, devoted mother of Robert D. of Pelham and Mrs. (Betty) Floyd King of Orient, L.I. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Services at The Geo. T. Davis Memorial, 14 LeCount Pl, New Rochelle, N.Y. on Friday at 10:30 am. Friends may visit at the Memorial from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 pm on Thursday.
The big beef markets in the city were silent and still yesterday as most wholesale dealers shut down operations because of the shortage of beef.

Governor Rockefeller's proposed $3.5-billion transportation bond issue and its accompanying commitment for precedent- shattering mass-transit operating subsidies sailed to surprisingly easy passage in the windup hours of the State Legislature's special session at Albany.

Three young black women-two of whom have been sterilized-filed a class-action suit in United States District Court here yesterday to halt all Federally funded sterilizations and experimental birth control programs until national guidelines were established.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he would review standards for granting special parking privileges to the handicapped and seek to "shrink" designated midtown parking spots for cars of diplomats and the press.

Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz gave some encouragement today to beef processors who were meeting here to protest price ceilings, despite conflicting positions taken by the Cost of Living Council and the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.
New York State's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation today rejected the first application for a major development for second homes in the wild Adirondack Park.
Babe Ruth's career record of 714 home runs won't be broken by Hank Aaron until Sept. 30 at the earliest, a computer at Georgia State University insists.

Shadrach Woods, an architect and urban planner once associated with Le Corbusier, died Tuesday at his home, 465 West End Avenue. He was 50 years old.

A combination of happy circumstances may have accounted for the record turnout of about 110,000 people in the Sheep Meadow on Tuesday night for the New York Philharmonic's final free open-air program of the summer:

The Senate Watergate committee disclosed a 1972 White House memorandum warning of the existence of documents that could "directly involve the President" in the controversial settlement of antitrust actions against the International Telephone and Telegraph Company. The memorandum was from Charles W. Colson to H. R. Haldeman, who told the committee that he was "not familiar" with it. [Page 1 Col. 8; Text, P. 20.]

A 30-year-old man who had fired several shots at a neighbor was shot and killed last night by a special investigator from the Queens District Attorney's office who apparently happened upon the scene, the police said.

The State Bar of California confirmed today that a preliminary investigation was initiated in May into the actions of President Nixon and five other lawyers in California who have testified or been the subject of comments before the Senate Watergate committee.
Eleven European nations have agreed to go ahead with a space program that could launch European astronauts by 1980, sources said today after a European space conference.
It really didn't matter that the Mets failed to achieve their first double-header shutout since their legendary year of 1969; they came within one out of doing it.

The new management of U.S. Financial, Inc., said today it was preparing to "vigorously prosecute" several former officials of the company for alleged frauds that have brought the multimillion dollar conglomerate to the brink of bankruptcy.
Depressing economic and political news sent prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-market market sharply lower yesterday in continued slow trading.
In his 19th summer training camp, John Unitas is feeling his age, 40. He has water on the knee and an aching back.

What was once known as the Mozart Festival became the Mostly Mozart Festival five seasons ago, a hedge that makes it possible for Lincoln Center's summertime series to offer, as it did Tuesday night at Philharmonic Hall, a program of undiluted Bach.
H. R. aldeman testified today that ie had ordered a 1971 investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of Daniel Schorr, a Washington correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System.

An extremist Israeli group called the "Wrath of God" murdered a 30-year-old Arab in Norway last month in the mistaken belief that he was a leader of the Arab guerrilla group Black September, the Oslo newspaper Aftenposten said today.

The chief clerk of this city's Municipal Court-an original member of the ousted Kenny political machine-was indicted here today on bribery charges involving a "systematic" $5 kickback scheme on every bail bond sold to city prisoners.

A fine of $150,000 a day was imposed yesterday against the International Business Machines Corporation for its refusal to provide court-ordered documents in one of the most important antitrust cases in history.

As the golfers were saying here today, "There's a new boy in town." Jack Nicklaus has been the annual favorite in the $250,000 Westchester Classic, which begins tomorrow at the Westchester Country Club, but there's a genuine challenger here.

The Senate approved by a large majority today the nomination of William E. Colby as director of the Central Intelligence Agency but indicated that the new intelligence chief would undergo more Congressional scrutiny than any of his predecessors.
All day today the voices of a fugitive's wife and son boomed down from helicopters, urging the man to come out of the thick woods north and east of this small town and give himself up.

Hardly anyone connected with the Philadelphia Phillies expected Wayne Twitchell to become the bulwark of the National League club's pitching staff this season. In two previous campaigns with the Phillies,

Dr. Christos Demiris, a general practitioner and member of the staff of Doctors Hospital, in charge of residents, died, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 146 Mount Joy Avenue, on Friday. He was 49 years old.

State Insurance Commissioner Richard C. McDonough today approved rates for a new Blue Shield plan to give more coverage for medical and surgical expenses incurred by moderate-income individuals and families.

The award-winning series of National Geographic Society documentary specials will move to the television network of the American Broadcasting Company this season, with the first program to be shown Sept. 6 from 8 to 9 P.M.

Ernest A. Fitzgerald, the Pentagon employee who disclosed huge cost overruns on the production program for the C-5A-transport plane, was given "very low marks in loyalty" by a top White House aide, Senate Watergate investigators were told today.
Saratoga's reputation as a "graveyard of champions" received some costly new justification today when Riva Ridge was defeated by a $114.40 long shot.
Air bags will be offered as an option on some 1974 General Motors cars "around the first of the year," Ernest S. Starkman, vice president of G.M., told the Senate Commerce Committee today.

When oil meets a barrier, the men who profit from oil have shown themselves ruthless and resourceful in reaching their objective. There are environmental and legal barriers to the immediate exploitation of the oil lying below Alaska's North Slope, but the oil lobby in Washington is once again showing political muscle and ingenuity in getting its own way.
The stock market tumbled sharply yesterday and absorbed its broadest beating in six weeks as traders continued cashing in on the gains achieved in the strong rally that ran out of steam on Monday.

The Kennecott Copper Corportion announced yesterday several major management changes in its worldwide exploration activities. Chief among these are: C. Harry Burgess to vice president and assistant to the president, with Milton Stern, formerly with the Union Carbide Corporation, to succeed Mr. Burgess as vice president-exploration.
A State Supreme Court justice in Queens, admitting he might be violating the law, yesterday vacated the sentence of a woman prisoner because she has terminal cancer and has at most a year to live.

Grain and soybean futures traders were suddenly seized 'by a bad case of nerves yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade after bidding the markets up the daily limits at the openThe nervousness, a quite The nervousness, a quite common affliction when paper profits are heavy following a sustained run up in prices, created waves of moderate selling that left a ragged pattern at the close.
Sources close to a West German Government investigation say that it has so far turned up no evidence that American military intelligence has been tapping German civilian telephones illegally.
Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan asserted today that the United States was no longer able to solve the problems of the world alone and that other nations should not expect it to do so.

The United States Government obtained public subscriptions for just over half the $500-milion It sought to raise through an auction of 71/2 per cent bonds due in 20 years, the Treasury announced last night.
A Livingston College junior testified today that she had been manhandled by an arresting officer while she and another student were moving lounge furniture.

Two new sailors on leave hit town Tuesday night at the State Theater as American Ballet Theater presented "Fancy Free." David Coll and John Sowinski joined John Prinz to form the warmly harmonious trio of men on the make.

The Argentine Chamber of Deputies today passed new foreign-investment legislation that became a subject of controversy after disclosures earlier this week that the American Embassy had sought to influence the Government to soften its pending economic bills.
The Senate passed and sent back to the House today a bill that would provide a 10 per cent cost-of-living pension increase for elderly veterans and their widows.

The theory that President Nixon had the right to authorize "national security" wiretaps without a warrant, raised in behalf of John D. Ehrlichman in the Senate Watergate hearings, has been endorsed in a Federal District Court ruling here.
For some time the thinkers, dreamers and planners in cable television have been giving forth with seemingly blue-sky concepts.
A friend of Richard Neal's has seen the Houston Oilers' 1972 highlights film and there is no surprise ending.

President Salvador Allende Gossens today rejected the Opposition's demand to bring the military back into his Government, insisting that it was up lo the political parties to "avoid Ihe crumbling" of the nation's civic institutions.

The players came back from the dusty softball field late in the afternoon and 50 or 100 neighbors joined them. drifting by twos and threes out of the apartments and houses into the open heat.

Gaylord Perry of the Cleveland Indians could be called the Houdini of the major leagues. The famed magician was noted for his underwater escapes from a glass tank, though he was handcuffed and shackled in chains and irons.
Vincent Paul De Lazzero, board chairman of the Port Morris Tile and Terrazzo Corporation, died Friday at his home, 40 Sprague Road. He was 83 years old.

William S. Swingle, a director and former president of the National Foreign Trade Council, died today at his home after a long illness. He was 81 years old and had lived in Montclair, N.J.,
The West German Government reported today that it had tapped civilian telephone conversations in west Germany at the request of United States intelligence agencies.

Green Brook, swollen by heavy rains, overflowed its banks here today, leaving four persons dead, 80 families in temporary shelters after removal from their homes, several hundred automobiles destroyed or damaged and private and business property losses put at least $2-million.

Second-seeded Tom Okker and fifth-seeded Marty Riessen were upset today in the third round of the Pro Tennis Classic. Carlos Munoz of Spain ousted Okker of The Netherlands, 6-3, 6-4, and Ross Case defeated Riessen, of Chicago, 7-6, 6-4. The losses left only three seeded players in the tournament.

The city's Corporation Counsel said yesterday that the administrator of the new state antinarcotics program had appealed privately to the police not to make too many arrests under the program "to insure against flooding of present and new [court] parts."

The Nixon Administration said today. that the Cambodian Government, faced by an end of all American bombing support on Aug. 15, would continue to get from the United States all the economic, military and diplomatic assistance still possible under the law.

Harold Alexander Ley 3d, a leader in the travel industry, died Tuesday in the jetliner crash at Logan International Airport in Boston, in which 88 persons were killed. He was 34 years old and lived in Upper Montclair, N. J.
The Standard Oil Company of California is appealing to its employes and stockholders to foster the "aspirations of the Arab people" and "their efforts toward peace in the Middle East."

Controller Arthur Levitt announced today that tax collections for the state were running $163-million higher for the first four months of this fiscal year than a similar period last year and that "conditions continued to indicate that New York State will have a very good year."
The United States Embassy club will no longer accept dollars for dues, meals or drinks, club officials announced this week, carrying the dollar to what may be a new low.

In his 22 years in the major leagues, Willie Mays has socked 658 home runs that have traveled, perhaps, close to 50 miles. Last night, though, the Mets' 5-1 victory over Pittsburgh at Shea Stadium revolved around two singles by Mays one that bounced about 25 feet into the air and another that rolled about 30 feet along the ground.

In March and April of 1972, when Watergate was a household word only to those who lived there, the big issue was a suspicious coziness between the Nixon Administration and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. From this relationship came the dropping of an antitrust action against the mighty conglomerate and a convenient commitment of as much as $400,000 from I.T.T. to help pay for the Republican National Convention.
A torrential rainstorm killed at least seven persons in the metropolitan area yesterday and forced hundreds of families to leave their homes in dozens of towns in northern New Jersey.

The former head of the Central Intelligence Agency told the Senate Watergate committee today that he had to resist White House pressures in order to keep the agency clean of involvement in the Watergate cover-up.

Corporate documents that the White House feared would come to light last year disclose a well-orchestrated effort by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to enlist the aid of top Administration officials in blocking an antitrust suit against the company's merger with the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.

President Nixon has made good progress in his meetings here with Premier Tanaka of Japan in removing the serious misunderstandings of the last couple of years in the relations between Washington and Tokyo.

Sharpshooters with rifles stood on rooftops and in guard towers today at the Oklahoma State Penitentiary with orders to kill if necessary to prevent further bloodshed among 750 rebel prisoners in the yard below.
The New York Yankees, who threw lot of punches around Fen way Park yesterday, were absolutely punchless tonight as they absorbed a 10-0 mauling from theBoston Red Sox and left town in second place.

The 1972 White House memo regarding the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation that came to light in the Senate Watergate hearings yesterdayy produced numerous sharp reactions in Congress today.
A court hearing will be held Aug. 20 on efforts by a conservationist organization to stop operations at a fuel-processing plant at the Hanford atomic works.

ISTANBUL, Turkey -- As the ferryboat passes below the new bridge that spans the Bosporus here, the passengers look up with something like wonder and a silence falls over the boatdeck, packed with travelers on a summer day.
Daniel Pinzow, editor of the Editorial Index Department of The New York Times since 1971, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 288 West 238th Street, the Bronx. He was 46 years old.
A 15-year-old boy from Jamaica, Queens, was arrested yesterday and charged with the rape on July 26 of a 14-yearold girl who said her assailant had forced her into a driveway with a gun at her head.
SAIGON, South Vietnam -- In the crowded side entrance of one of Saigon's pagodas, the Minh Huong, a woman with a black birthmark on her right cheek sits telling fortunes.

Charles W. Colson, the former special counsel to the President, instructed another member of the White House staff to ask the Internal Revenue Service for the names of contributors to the National Council of Senior Citizens, according to a deposition filed today in United District Court here.
Jean-Pierre Melville, the film director, died of a heart attack today. He was 55 years old.

William "Scott" Kelly is a 44-year-old business executive who lives with his wife, Barbara, and three children in a Tudor-style stone house in this conservative Westchester County community. Both are registered Republicans.
Operators of fishing stations from Sandy Hook to Cape May yesterday were wondering what had happened to the bluefish. Few hungry choppers were being taken along the New Jersey coast.
More than 40 eighth grade boys who had been ordered to be fingerprinted tomorrow in connection with a murder investigation won a stay of the order today in State Supreme Court.

Luis Ayala, coach of the Chilean Davis Cup tennis team, seemed pleased today with the pairing for the first round of the American Zone finals. Dennis Ralston, captain of the United States team, was unconcerned.

Sales volume reported yesterday by the country's leadin chain store organizations indicated a continuation of the substantial gains registered in June. The large chains showed increases over July of 1972 ranging from 11.7 per cent to 23.3 per cent.

The House passed tonight a bill to license the construction of a trans-Alaska pipeline and to shield the project from further court challenges on environmental grounds.
Rosetta Pampanini, a lyric soprano who won fame with her interpretations of Puccini and Mascagni, died this morning at her home in Corbola, about 20 miles from here. She was 72 years old.

I have been measuring the pile of briefs concerning the proposed transmission line from Gilboa in Schoharie County to Leeds near Catskill in Greene County. The pile of paper measures seven and one-half inches; it weighs twelve pounds.
The East German Communists today opened their party newspaper, Neues Deutschland, to a young West German politician and his call for more freedom of travel and the exchange of ideas and information.
The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today reduced the liquidity requirement for members of the Federal Home Loan Bank System to 5.5 per cent from 6.5 per cent of savings and short-term borrowings.

G. Minot D'Arcy, an investment counselor, was one of the 88 victims of the crash of a jet plane at Logan International Airport in Boston on Tuesday. He was 43 years old and lived in Bristol, N. H., and New Canaan, Conn.

The Central Intelligence Agency's initial psychological assessment of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg concluded that he was motivated by "what he deemed a higher order of patriotism" in turning over the Pentagon papers to the press in 1971.

An angry station owner here finished giving away 4,000 gallons of gasoline to hard-pressed consumers this afternoon to satisfy an Internal Revenue Service judgment that he had overcharged his customers $1, 729 during the 60-day price freeze by illegally raising his prices 2 cents a gallon.

In a historic change of emphasis, the Police Department from now on will present a plaque and a $100 scholarship award for academic achievement to Police Academy graduates and eliminate the traditional marksmenship award of a revolver.

The America Radio Service Vietnam has discontinued verbatim covert age of the Watergate hearings because listeners wanted to hear more music, a spokesman for the United States defense attache's office said today.

Internal Revenue Service agents, finding violations of price ceilings, have ordered onthe-spot rollbacks in more than half of the Manhattan and Bronx beef-wholesaling establishments checked in "compliance sweeps" this week.
Henry A. Kissinger said tonight that Americans should not allow the Watergate scandal to diminish their support for an effective bipartisan foreign policy.

A number of students of the tax law say that capital gains ought to be taxed as heavily as wages. It is the liberal point of view and it was pressed by Senator George S. McGovern during his unsuccessful campaign for the Presidency.

A daily $150,000 fine against the International Business Machines Corporation was blocked temporarily yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals. Circuit Judge William Hughes Mulligan granted I.B.M. a stay of the extraordinary penalty until the corporations' appeal can be argued at a hearing here next Wednesday in the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
American Standard, Inc. realized a 41 per cent increase in second-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 12 per cent, making the half-year profit 70

New York Stock Exchange directors voted yesterday to suspend trading, effective immediately, in the common stock and 5 1/4 per cent convertible debentures of Memorex. These issues last traded On the exchange on July 6.
Stock prices declined yesterday for the fourth successive day, but reduced their losses in the final 90 minutes as volume remained modest on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Central Intelligence Agency's initial psychological assessment of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg concluded that he was motivated by "what he deemed a higher order of patriotism" in turning over the Pentagon papers to the press in 1971.
An inmate in a state prison has written a letter to the judge who sentenced him to three years. for selling and using drugs-and has thanked the judge.

The head of the National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday that his agency was "most impatient" for imposition of a Federal rule requiring planes to carry a device that would warn pilots when they flew dangerously close to the ground.
Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan came to New York yesterday, after two days of talks with President Nixon in Washington, to meet with prominent businessmen and other private citizens.

Ellsworth Bunker, the former United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, was nominated by President Nixon today to be an ambassador-at-large. Mr. Nixon also nominated Mr. Bunker's wife, Carol C. Laise, to be Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, a position that has been vacant since 1971.

Two black sprinters who left the United States track and field team that meets Africa this weekend reportedly have accused American officials of giving preferential treatment to their white teammates.

LONDON-You used to be able to tell a country by its cuisine--now I suspect its humor might provide a safer guide. Much of the humor in London and New York is admittedly identical, and many people in both cities feel perfectly at home with whatever brand of AngloAmerican humor comes along. And yet there can be wide and deep differences.
Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court agreed today to hear arguments on a request for an immediate halt to the United States bombing in Cambodia.
Yugoslavia's Ljubomir Ljubojevic settled for a draw today against Lian Ann Tan of Singapore, but maintained the lead in the world Interzonal Chess Tournament.

Skylab 2 ran into further trouble today with leaking steering rockets, and project officials ordered around-the-clock preparations of a rescue ship that may have to be dispatched to bring the three astronauts back from the nation's first orbiting space station.

America's entry in the fours with coxswain event at the world junior rowing championships was publicly lectured on sportsmanship today. The young men from Philadelphia's Vesper Boat Club, along with Coach Bob Madden, stood in silence before spectators while the international federation president, Thomi Keller of Switzerland, accused them of "making fools of their opponents."

Dr. Marta Rezler, assistant professor of Romance languages at HunterCollege and an expert on 18th-century French literature, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Syosset, L.I

South Side B South Side mainstream, the tough urban Chicago blues, arrived this week at Kenny's Castaways, East 84th Street, under the gentle patronage of Willie Dixon, bass player and composer of many classic Chicago-style blues.

Peter B. Bader, a deputy associate general counsel of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, died yesterday of leukemia in New York Hospital. He was 30 years old and lived at 2245 Randall Avenue, the Bronx.

CALCUTTA, India - To American and European filmgoers, Indian movies mean Satyajit Ray. To most Indians, however, the director's delicatey textured tapestries of Calcutta life and village families seem odd and unsettling.

Jack Krumpe has been stall-walking for almost a month, in anticipation of the Whitney Stakes on Saturday. And after that he'll be stall-walking for at least two more weeks, waiting for the Travers on Aug. 18.

Government leaders from the 32 Commonwealth countries, exhibiting a generally friendly mood, today opened a nine-day meeting that is scheduled to cover a broad range of social, economic and political issues.

President Nixon flew by helicopter today to his mountaintop retreat here for a weekend of rest and work. Gerald L, Warren the deputy White House press secretary, said the President was not accompanied by any members of his family or any of his key aides or advisers.
Rising prices and the relaxation of controls under Phase 4 will cost the city $30-million this fiscal year, according to Purchase Commissioner Marvin Gersten.

" Loops," according to the ads, shows and tells all about "one of America's most shocking subcultures," the one where you plunk in a quarter, hunch over a machine and hope for the best. Or worst. Which is it?
The Niagara Counly sheriff's narcotics officers arrested a Royalton man Tuesday and accused him of growing an estimated total of 5,000 marijuana plants on his property.

The Senate voted by a decisive 77-to-16 margin today to override President Nixon's veto of an emergency medical services bill designed to help prevent needless deaths of accident and heart attack victims.

Records of public funds spent on President Nixon's estate at San Clemente, Calif., show that Herbert W. Kalmbach, Mr. Nixon's former personal attorney, played a controlling role in plans for renovating the home.
WASHINGTON-I voted against the War Powers Bill of 1973 because its actual effect' would be to sanction for 123 days combat operations initiated solely by the President.
Jack Lesser, president of the Deborah Heart and Lung Center here, died today at the Einstein Medical Center in Philadelphia. He was 71 years old and lived in Wyncote, Pa.
A gallery of disarmingly original citizens-shown at play, pursuing novel avocations and making music makes up a rewarding documentary hour at 9 tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
At least 30 persons, many of them children, died last night when a flash fire swept a packed, multi-story entertainment center on this British holiday island.
Despite the possibility of a Presidential veto, the Senate voted 62 to 28 today to increase the minimum wage to $2.20 an hour for most workers by next July 1.

The Senate voted, 84 to 5, today to end the freeze on beef prices immediately to avert shortages. The action came in the form of an amendment to a minor and unrelated bill, and its ultimate fate in the House - and eventual acceptance by President Nixon - was highly uncertain.
A jury with an average age of 31 was empaneled today in the trial of the Gainesville 8, and Federal District Judge Winston E. Arnow immediately ordered them sequestered.

This market town was fast emptying today. By noon nearly all the houses were deserted and the shops shuttered and padlocked-the contents. and residents on their way to relative safety in Phnom Penh, about 10 miles to the northwest.

Alarmed about a 50 per cent drop in business following reports that water in five springs at the Saratoga Spa reservation contained radium levels exceeding Federal limits, the Saratoga Vichy Spring Company has begun a campaign to notify its customers about the source of Saratoga vichy.

Dr. L. Nelson Bell, immediate past moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. and father-in- law of the Rev. Billy Graham, died in his sleep today a few hours after addressing a mission conference.

Strong and generally unexpected demand for the new Treasury 71/2 per cent bonds ignited a furious rally in Government and corporate bonds yesterday, one of the most hectic sessions in years, traders declared.
A man arrested on a shoplifting charge and released without bail by Judge Bruce Wright of Bronx Criminal Court was discovered yesterday to be an escaped convict, a heroin seller and a bail jumper.

Gulf Western Industries, Inc. announced yesterday it had acquired 384,800 shares of the Bulova Watch Company, or slightly under 10 per cent of the 3,741,000 common shares outstanding of Bulova, in the open market in the last two years as "strictly an investment."
The Soviet Union broke a long silence on Watergate today, declaring that "former Government officials and White House staff members" had sworn that President Nixon was blameless.

George Meany, who remained neutral in the 1972 Presidential campaign, emphasized today his dissatisfaction and disillusionment with President Nixon and the performance of the Republican Administration.

Although the communique summing up the talks between President Nixon and Premier Tanaka of Japan has the ambiguity usual in such documents, Mr. Tanaka's visit should help to establish a more healthy relationship between the two countries.
A large bipartisan majority on the House Interior Committee gave tentative approval today to a proposal to impose strict Federal environmental standards on the strip, or surface, mining of coal.

The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly. one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

The youth who hanged himself in the Men's House of Detention on Rikers Island Wednesday was disclosed yesterday to have been 15 years old at the time of his arrest, too young to have been sent to any institutions of the city's Department of Correction.

The first round of the $250,000 Westchester golf classic was started twice today before it was officially washed out by rain. The halt was called at 9:30 A.M. at the Westchester Country Club when officials declared the course unplayable.

The kid nappers of J. Paul Getty 3d, 16-year-old grandson of the American oil magnate, who mysteriously disappeared in Rome almost a month ago, have asked for a $17-million ransom, the family lawyer here said tonight.
President Ferdinand E. Marcos today predicted an era of good relations with the United States and of steady progress for the Philippines.

Watkins Glen apart, Woodstock still has the magic name, and even Latin music is taking advantage of the vibrations. On Monday, Woodstock's Latin Festival takes place-at the Playhouse there-although it is primarily an excuse to film one of New York's top Latin bands, Eddie Palmieri's orchestra.

A man believed to be Robert Garrow-the fugitive wanted in the killing of an 18-year-old camper--was sighted in a clearing near here today and 175 state troopers and forest rangers converged on the area.
By a change in the vote of Senator Barry Goldwater, the Navy has apparently rescued its Trident missile-launching submarine from a deep budgetary cut by the Senate Armed Services Committee.
The Senate voted, 84 to 5, today to end the freeze on beef prices immediately to avert shortages.
A woman who executed what is thought to be the largest individual welfare fraud in the city was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to a prison term of up to three years.
The Women's New Jersey Golf Association's 54-hole championship became a 36-hole event today when rain washed out the scheduled second round.
Gaining more confidence with each workout, Clifton Davis believes he can make it with the New York Giants this year, possibly as the No I fullback.
Senator Daniel K. Inouye was saying "mahalo and aloha" today-but not to John J. Wilson, the lawyer who referred to him yesterday as a "little Jap."

The state grand jury in Trenton has indicted an Atlantic City detective on bribery charges in what law enforcement officials indicate may be the beginning of a major investigation of the police in the resort city. State law enforcement officials declined to comment on the scope of the investigation, but the state's Criminal Justice Director, Evan W. Jahos, said: "The investigation is continuing."
South Vietnam has no plans to intervene in the Cambodian fighting but may do so if Phnom Penh asks for help, a South Vietnam Government spokesman said today.

The Bank of China, which handles Peking's foreign currency transactions and recently established a correspondent relationship with the Chase Manhattan Bank, acted with uncharacteristic imprecision during the dollar crisis last month.

Smith, International, Inc., sold yesterday 1.5-million shares of common stock at $19.25 a share through an underwriting network managed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc. The company, which makes drilling equipment, had sales of $103.3-million and earnings of $5.95-million, or 90 cents a share, last year.

Just two days after the Walter E. Heller International Corporation consummated its purchase of Chicago's American National Bank, the financial holding company announced sweeping changes in its leadership.

More than 40 eighth-grade boys who had been ordered to be fingerprinted tomorrow in connection with a murder investigation in Elizabeth, N. J., won a stay of the order in the New Jersey Supreme Court. The court also ruled that the Appellate Division immediately hear the appeal of the order. A hearing has been scheduled for Tuesday.

Eastern Daylight time, the Skylab 2 astronauts waited for word on whether the steering-rocket oxidizer leak that had awakened them early signified a general difficulty that would mean they lacked a reliable spacecraft for returning to earth.
The first unit of a major regional shopping center opened here today when a 200,000square-foot Gertz department store officially began doing business.
Local lawmakers are preparing a 120-day ban on large musical concerts in Schuyler County, a measure designed to head off a repeat of the massive "Summer Jam" rock festival.
A torrential rainstorm killing at least five persons in the metropolitan area yesterday and forcing hundreds of families to leave their homes in dozens of towns in northern New Jersey.

Green Brook, swollen by heavy rains, overflowed its banks here today, leaving four persons dead, 80 families in temporary shelters after removal from their homes, several hundred automobiles destroyed or damaged and private and business property losses put at at least $2-million.
Governor Cahill today signed a bill that permits local governmental units to enter into joint contracts for services.

The United States dollar fluctuated on European money markets today, making small movements as traders marked time. The price of gold generally fell.

Felix Millan, who has been the most consistent Met day after day, was voted Met player of the month for July. The big news in the grain and soybean trade yesterday came after the close of the markets. It was then that the government reported sharply higher export bookings of American corn and soybeans and a slight dip in wheat sales.
Arrests and violence swept across the San Joaquin Valley today as the United Farm Workers Union pressed its strike against California table grape growers.
The armed forces have strongly opposed a Justice Department proposal to save draft evaders from jail by allowing them to join the services, Administration sources said today.

The Yankees skipped batting practice because of the rainy weather. In line with the faint trend noticed in baseball lately, however, they pass it up now about one day in four on the road .... Carl Yastrzemski, 0 for 9 in the first three games, held a private session of batting practice after the game Wednesday afternoon.

Internal Revenue Service agents, finding violations of price ceilings, have ordered onthe-spot rollbacks in more than half of the Manhattan and Bronx beef-wholesaling establishments checked in "compliance sweeps" this week.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market continued to decline yesterday in continued light trading.

Padre Cicero - an unfrocked priest who is said to have worked miracles, led an armed insurrection and protected bandits in the destitute backlands of northeastern Brazil at the turn of the century-is the center of a new controversy.

To the Editor: The testimony given on July 24 and 25 by Mr. Ehrlichman and by his counsel, Mr. Wilson, suggesting that legislation on national security matters made legal the burglary of the offices of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist is by far the most frightening, and enlightening, thing to come out of the Watergate hearings.

In the Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Cynthia Richards Rossbach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Rossbach of New York, became the bride of James Flood Stebbins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore E. Stebbins of Syosset, L. I.

Business loans continued to expand and interest rates to soar during the week ended Wednesday, according to Federal Reserve figures, heightening the probability of yet another rise in the rates banks charge for loans.

Joseph M. Healey, who became the first Democratic Mayor in this town's history in 1949 and held the post for 20 years, died Tuesday of heart and blood disorders in West Hudson Hospital. His age was 63, and he lived here at 244 Forest Street.

For several agonizing hours yesterday, it appeared that the Skylab 2 astronauts might be in more serious trouble than any American spacemen since the nervewracking flight around the moon of Apollo 13. Even though it finally proved unnecessary to order the three men back to earth immediately, two points did emerge with special clarity from this short-lived scare situation.
The American Broadcasting Company will televise the $100,000 winner-take-all tennis match between Bobby Riggs and Billie Jean King in prime evening viewing time Sept. 20 from the Houston Astrodome.

The form ran true at the silver anniversary show of the Perkiomen Valley Kennel Club today, when Dr. and Mrs. James A. Gribbin's Great Dane, Ch. Heidere's Kolyer Kimbayh, from Trenton, was named best in a field of 1,195 dogs on the grounds of the Chukker Valley Polo Club.

Nearly 100 operators of Mr. Softee ice cream trucks stayed away from their rounds in Queens and Nassau County Thursday and yesterday to protest what they said was a 16-cent-agallon price increase for their dairy mix.
Controller Abraham D. Beame invaded this Catskill resort area today for what he called a pleasant extension of his campaign for Mayor of New York City.

The way this season has gone for the Mets, anytime they can emerge from an evening's worth of injury problems with a 50-50 split they should be happy. And if they can add a victory to it, such as last night's 7-3 triumph over St. Louis, they should be deliriously overjoyed.

Devastated by flooding yesterday, for the second time in two years, residents of this Somerset County town of 21,000 asked, none too patiently today, how long it would take to get a flood-control project built.

Governor Rockefeller today signed into law nine bills passed by the Legislature during its special session, including the $3.5-billion transportation-bond measure and authorization for the State Banking Board to raise the interest ceiling on mortgage loans to as high as 3.5 per cent.

One man was critically hurt and four other persons suffered minor injuries yesterday when an explosion collapsed a two-and-a-half-story frame house at 619 East Third Street in Plainfield. The explosion at 7:15 A.M. blew out the side walls of the building, and the roof and upper level fell straight down before pitching forward onto a porch.

The New York Telephone Company yesterday named Alfred C. Partoll general attorney for regulatory matters. He succeeds Raymond F. Scully who was named a vice president of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania.
The State Department has invited a representative of the East German Government to open formal discussions here next week on establishing diplomatic relations.
Argentina, normally a major exporter of grain, was reliably reported yesterday to have issued tenders for foreign wheat in order to meet its export commitments.

The House Ways and Means Committee has recessed its sessions on President Nixon's trade bill until September, formally acknowledging there is no chance of completing the measure until after Congress's summer recess.

Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, stuck today to his view that additional restraints should be put on the economy if inflation is to be stopped and foreign confidence in the dollar restored.

Max I. Alimansky, who retired last year as manager of business and technical planning for the power distribution division of the General Electric Company, died Sunday in Boston. He was 67 years old and lived here in Lenox, Mass.

A 55-year-old physician was found bludgeoned to death and his 21-year-old nurse strangled in his office here yesterday. The police said robbery was the "apparent motive" in the double murder, even though the killer overlooked some $600 hidden in the doctor's sock.

The Justice Department reopened today its investigation of the shootings at Kent State University on May 4, 1970, in which Ohio National Guardsmen killed four students and wounded nine others during a campus protest against expansion of the Vietnam war into Cambodia.

State police bloodhounds picked up the fresh scent of Robert Garrow Sr. early this morning and followed the fugitive's trail through the dense woods for about a mile and a half, finally losing it in a creek near the Sacandaga River.

Governor Cahill asked President Nixon to declare six New Jersey counties a disaster area as their residents turned to the dreary task of mopping up after the flash floods that left six dead, three missing and caused millions of dollars of property damage.
Henry Aaron doesn't feel bad about stealing the spotlight from his Atlanta teammate, Darrell Evans, one of the National League's home run leaders. Actually, he believes he's doing Evans a service.
Congress gave final approval and sent to the White House today a bill prohibiting banks in 48 states from paying interlest on checking accounts.
Keena Rothhammer, from the Santa Clara Swim Club and Rick DeMont of the Marin Swim Club highlighted the opening of the Los Angeles invitational swim meet last night.

President Nixon proposed to Congress today legislation that would eventually bring major changes to the nation's banks and savings institutions and could lead to higher interest rates on consumer savings.
The death toll in the Isle of Man amusement center fire climbed to 46 tonight as five more bodies were found in the burned-out shell of the building.
The House gave final Congressional approval today to an increase in the minimum wage and a $20billion highway bill as Congress began a month-long recess.

Shell Canada, Ltd., announced yesterday at Toronto that, effective Monday, it would raise wholesale prices for motor gasolines, diesel and aviation fuels by two cents a gallon in the Atlantic Provinces, Quebec and Ontario, east of the Ottawa Valley.

William Ryan, chief of the Justice Department's Narcotics Section, ordered an investigation yesterday to determine if Braniff International played a role in the smuggling of cooaine aboard one of its planes last spring.

A coalition of Congressmen and lawyers demanded to day that the Justice Department seal its computer files on criminal offenders until it can impose new restrictions to protect individual rights.

A Federal judge denied today a request to remove temporarily the National Football League's suspension of Lance Rentzel, the Los Angeles Rams' wide receiver who is appealing a conviction for possessing marijuana.

Two black civil-rights groups in Buffalo and in Rochester have demanded the dismissal of all charges against the men accused of committing crimes during the 1971 rebellion at Attica state correctional facility.

The Vietcong Foreign Ministry has charged that Canada's delegation to the International Commission of Control and Supervision acted as a "cover" for United States truce violations in Vietnam, Hanoi's Vietnam News Agency said today in a broadcast monitored here.

A Federal judge rejected here yesterday attempts to make "class actions" out of three antitrust lawsuits challenging dual advertising rates charged by newspapers and other publications who deal both with direct advertisers and through agencies.

The crisis atmosphere at Mission Control eased today as tests showed that Skylab 2's Apollo ferry vehicle should be able to return the astronauts safely to earth with only two of the four sets of steering rockets in operation.

Anheuser-Busch, Inc., said today it would cease sale and production of Budweiser malt liquor effective Aug. 17 because of a recent labor disturbance and certain liquid supply shortages.

Most of the time there are no more than 700 persons in this 640-acre town in southwestern Montana. In fact, most of the time the townspeople are well outnumbered by the coyotes and bears that roam the surrounding pine forests or inspect the local garbage cans.

The United States dollar was mixed today as European money markets closed for the weekend following a day of fluctuation. In Paris, the financial dollar was quoted at 4.185 francs, up 1 1/2 centimes from Thursday, while the commercial dollar closed at 4.11 francs, up from Thursday's 4.105 francs.
The House refused today to dip into Treasury profits on sales of Eisenhower silver dollars to help support Eisenhower College in Seneca Falls, N.Y.

An American correspondent in Laos last spring described a battle in which Laotian Government and Communist Pathet Lao forces exchanged automatic-weapons fire furiously for five hours. When it was all over, it was discovered that the only casualties were two cows that had strayed into the battle area. "They didn't intend to kill us," explained one Government veteran, "So why should we kill them?"

The Government National Mortgage Association said today it would auction $228million of F.H.A.-insured home mortgages on Sept. 10.

A Federal judge ordered the Health, Education and Welfare Department today to release more than $52-million in impounded funds intended to establish community mental health centers. He said that the impoundment was unconstitutional.

Kevin P. Phillips and Albert Sindlinger report that a nationwide telephone survey has found that more Americans think "the drowning of Mary Jo Kopechne at Chappaquiddick" was "more morally reprehensible" than "the bugging of the Democratic National Committee" at Watergate.

Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board stuck tenaciously today to his view that additional restraints should be put on the economy if inflation is to be stopped and foreign confidence in the dol lar restored.
ARTS AND CRAFTS Fulton Street, except for fish, has not been much of a shopping area for many generations. But this weekend and next, you'll be able to go there and buy pottery.

Tom Gorman of Seattle broke the service of Jaime Fillol of Chile in the 32d game of the first set and de feated Fillol in the American Zone Davis Cup finals, 17-15 6-4, 4-6, 6-3. His victory gave the United States a 1-0 lead.

An official of the National Council of Churches testified in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday that there was nothing "bizarre" about the conservative New Testament Missionary Fellowship and that such groups were important for certain people who might otherwise turn to drugs or alcohol.
President Nixon, reaffirming that bombing in Cambodia would be terminated Aug. 15, warned today that the cutoff, imposed by Congress, could have "dangerous potential consequences" in Asia.

Leon J. Levitz, 58 years old, who resigned under fire as president of the Levitz Furniture Corporation in June, 1972, and left as a director three months later, has returned to the board of the company.

The First At Orlando Corporation, a bank-holding company, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Wilton Manors National Bank of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and its affiliate, the Lauderdale Beach Bank, through an exchange of stock valued at a maximum of $22.1-million.
The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., yesterday filed a complaint seeking an injunction against the playing and televising of the Bobby RiggsBillie Jean King $100,000 winner-take-all tennis match.

The season's worst trip for the Yankees continued to take on disastrous proportions tonight as they suffered a 7-to-2 loss to the rampaging Tigers in the opener of a four-game series.

Britain's Royal Ballet, in the last week of the current season, is absolutely packed. And not with tourists.

President Nixon appointed 14 members to the Commission on Financial Structure and Regulation June 16, 1970, and asked the new body to "improve the functioning of the private financial system." In short order the commission became known as the Hunt Commission, named for Reed O. Hunt, retired chief executive of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, who was appointed chairman earlier, on April 22.

The Senate Watergate committee began an investigation today of charges against its chief investigator, Carmine S. Bellino.

The Export Import Bank said today it would receive bids on Aug. 14 for $300-million in five-year debentures. The bidding had originally been scheduled for July 19 but was postponed to give investors adequate time to review a Treasury Department ruling on Domestic International Sales Corporations.

With the help of three field goals by Bobby Howfield, their Britishborn, soccer-style kicker, the New York Jets managed to turn back a determined Houston Oiler team, 16-13, before an Astrodome crowd of 45,775 tonight in the first preseason football game for both teams.
The Indian Government said today that China had shown "some indications" of a desire to establish normal relations with India.
Larry Gore, satirist, publicity man, contributor to Mad magazine and author of "Larry Gore's Thing" in Newsday from 1967 to 1972, died Wednesday of a heart attack after surgery, in London.
With painstaking care, the long pipes were lifted from the organ-set in the church choirloft and lowered to the men below.
Lured by the chance to make more money for less work, Mrs. Billie Jean King and John Newcombe have signed long-term contracts with World Team Tennis.
The National Restaurant Association, representing 400,000 eating places, said yesterday that beef was "flowing into black markets in many areas" as a result of price controls.
Byron Dexter, former managing editor of the quarterly Foreign Affairs, died at his home here last evening. He was 72 years old.
President Nixon is developing a new response on the Watergate scandal while spending the weekend at his retreat here, a White House spokesman said today.

A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and accused of terrorizing and shaking down the families of Chinese-Americans in Queens and Brooklyn. He usually demanded $500 payments of his victims, the police said.
Mrs. Alberta P. Locke, who taught the mentally retarded in the New York City school system for more than 50 years, died today at the age of 81.

The prosecutors and their first witness found themselves in a maze of contradictions this afternoon as testimony began in the trial of the Gainesville Eight.
William E. Siegel, since January senior vice chairman of Security Pacific National Bank, died Monday at his home in Pacific Palisades.

Earlier this week in Boston, despite the usual reports of dissension that only seem to make them play harder, the Red Sox took three of four games from the Yankees and knocked New York out of first place in the American League Eastern Division.

The University of Washington, Vesper Boat Club and Undine B.C. of Philadelphia crews are qualified to represent the United States in the European rowing championships scheduled for Moscow in September.

There were reported to be 600,000 people at the "Summer Jam" in Watkins Glen last weekend. It is a metaphysical number, of course. Nobody counted the hordes of young people that descended upon that tiny town, created historic traffic jams, heard the music, and then finally departed in all directions.

The task of rationalizing the crazy-quilt of pension protection that now covers public employes in this state has been left unfinished by the State Legislature. A new Communist offensive swept within three miles of the center of Phnom Penh today and Government troops began setting up roadblocks half a mile outside the city.

The Travelers Corporation yesterday reported record net income in the quarter and six months ended June 30. Second-quarter net income of $40.3-million, equal to 88 cents a share, increased 12 per cent from $36.1-million, or 78 cents a share, for the similar three months last year.

Thomas Lombardi a reputed crime figure sought by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on loan-sharking charges, voluntarily surrendered to Federal authorities yesterday and was later arraigned in Federal Court in Brooklyn where he pleaded not guilty and was released in $50.000 bond to await trial.

Tom Weiskopf is leading again. The $250,000 Westchester golf classic began today under cloudy skies following yesterday's first-round rainout and Weiskopf lost little time in asserting himself this afternoon with an eight-under-par 64 for a three-stroke lead.

Although geared for children, a street show put on Saturday afternoon at a Greenwich Village intersection by the Theater for the New City proved a pleasant diversion for all. Judging by the smiling reactions, the double-bill of two 30-minute plays scored a hit.

Miss Marjorie Susan Geller, a Ph.D. candidate at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, and John Claude McConnell, a fourth-year medical student there, were married here this afternoon.
Seven persons, four of them children, drowned when a car plunged into a creek near here, the state police said today. One youth survived.

Jolie Lentz is getting only a threeweek summer vacation this year, while most high school students across the country get three months, But then, most students don't get winter, spring and fall vacations either, and Jolie does.

India, with a population steadily in. creasing by 13 million a year, is reducing birth-control programs across the nation. The Government decision, part of a stringent economy campaign, means that plans to build family-planning and maternal-care centers in rural areas have been set aside.

WASHINGTON - All who have done it agree that it is nearly an impossible job, being the President's press secretary, but Ronald L. Ziegler, who does it for President Nixon, feels that he is perhaps under a special handicap. For he has to ride out the Watergate mess, which has made him the most controversial of the six men who have held the position since the Eisenhower years.

VIENNA - Last month, the first stage of the Conference on -Security and Cooperation in Europe was concluded in Helsinki. Although the conference has just passed its initial stage, the foreign ministers accepted a number of guiding principles for the future conduct of relations between the countries of Europe.

The largest privately owned undeveloped tract of land within 10 miles of New York City has been sold for residential development, ending a dispute over whether it should be developed as a park or as an apartment-and-office complex.

A Queens policeman who interrupted a liquor store holdup while off duty last July 14, shooting one of the holdup men and being wounded in a shootout with the gunmen, foiled another holdup in Queens late last night.

British troops fired rubber bullets today to disperse a crowd of 250 stonethrowing youths who broke away from a demonstration to attack an army and police post.
Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., won the singles championship in the $25,000 Buckeye tennis championships today for the second straight year.

Bobby Nichols became the surprise winner of the $250,000 Westchester Golf Classic today. Two tremendous putts, the first for an eagle to force a tie at the 72d hole and the other for a birdie at the first hole of a sudden-death playoff, enabled Nichols to walk away with the first prize of $50,000.
Religious services for more than 20,000 youths of 13 faiths or sects marked the fifth day of the National Scout Jamboree West today.

The city's Human Resources Administrator, Jule M. Sugarman, announced yesterday that Mayor Lindsay's goal of "zero growth" in the welfare rolls during fiscal 1972 had been surpassed. In fact, Mr. Sugarman declared, a furtheir drop of 7,441 in June-the ninth successive monthly decline-brought the number of welfare recipients in the city down to 1,198,179, from 1,270,475 at the start of the fiscal year on July 1, 1972.

Joel Achtenberg, 26 years old, of Kansas City, Mo., went on trial today for the second time for the burning of the R.O.T.C. building at Washington University during a campus demonstation in May, 1970. Mr. Achtenberg, a former student at the university, is one of six persons convicted under a Federal sabotage law for the burning.

President Nixon has been "toughing it out" for more than four months since, according to his own statement, he was told the facts about Watergate on March 21. H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman, his two principal aides, have now told their Version of events to the Senate Watergate Committee.

Interest rates continued their upward spiral yesterday under conditions of accelerating credit restraint. A sizable issue of Arizona school bonds failed to attract bids within the legal rate ceiling and it appeared that several issues of Governmentbacked tax-exempt notes would not draw bids today.

The Boston Red Sox scored four runs in the first inning and went on to a 5-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles in Memorial Stadium last night. A 27-year-old black man allegedly involved in the theft of a school bus was shot and killed in a struggle with an arresting police officer last night, touching off several hours of sporadic violence in the surrounding South Jamaica section of Queens.

Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League and the Los Angeles Rams were ordered today to show cause Aug. 22 for the suspension of the Rams' wide receiver, Lance Rentzel. Representative Elizabeth Holtzman, Democrat of Brooklyn, said today that she had filed a motion with the United States Supreme Court asking for action to stop the American bombing of Cambodia immediately.

A medium-sized earthquake measuring 4.7 on the Richter scale rolled down the coast of California from Santa Barbara to Orange County, southeast of Los Angeles this afternoon, but there were no immediate reports of injuries.
