India is courting a Malthusian disaster with the decision of the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi to sharply reduce spending for birth control. It must be conceded that India's ambitious and often pioneering family-planning efforts have thus far not been notably successful.
The Xerox Corporation announced today that it would open a factory in Dallas to employ 300 workers in addition to the engineering center the company recently opened here in leased space.

A dog, a cow and a man lay dead today in the middle of this village outside Phnom Penh. Cambodian troops celebrated around them, ignoring the villager and the dog but hacking chunks from the cow's carcass to cook for dinner or sell later.

An official of Dairymen Inc., a cooperative that contributed to President Nixon's 1972 campaign, has urged the President to turn over "memoranda or tapes relating to the 1971 dairy parity price," according to a letter released today.

In a parched field, a goat herder sifts the dry earth through his fingers in frustration. He talks about what is on the minds of this Mediterranean island nation's farmers and shepherds-the worst drought Cyprus has faced in a century.

The Nixon Administration announced today that it had m spent about $10-million for A Presidential security at San in Clemente, Calif.; Key Biscayne, Fla., and Grand Cay in the Bahamas, and at the places where the Nixon daughters have lived.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and Turbo Power and Marine Systems, Inc., a subsidiary of the United Aircraft Corporation, announced yesterday separate contracts totaling more than $125-million for gas turbine generator units.

The Mercer Arts Center, a Lilliputian-sized theater with the ambitions of a Lincoln Center, worked feverishly yesterday to salvage its "total theater environment for the young" from the rubble of the old Broadway Central Hotel, which collapsed Friday.
Winston Hill, looking like the world's biggest teddy bear while rolled under a blanket on a dormitory bed today, rejoined the Jets after refusing to play last Friday night.

The Nixon Administration announced today that it had spent. about $10-million for Presidential security at San Clemente, Calif.; Key Biscayne, Fla., and Grand Cay in the Bahamas, and at' the places where the Nixon daughters have lived.

Two Arab terrorists told the Greek security police today that they hurled hand grenades at the wrong line of passengers at Athens airport yesterday. The toll was three killed, two of them Americans, and 55 injured.
The United States Marine Corps today identified four nen killed Thursday when heir helicpoter crashed in mountains about 60 miles north of Naha.

Cambodia's deposed leader, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, said today that his supporters would refuse to negotiate with the United States while it continued aid to Phnom Penh or sent planes over Cambodia. He said he would accept nothing less than complete victory.

Gov. Thomas J. Meskill has confirmed the existence of a $65-million budget surplus the highest in Connecticut's history--for the 1972-73 fiscal year. Mr. Meskill announced over the weekend that no tax increase would be imposed next

In a stepped-up Federal drive, 19 beef wholesalers of 69 that were checked in the 14th Street and 135th Street market areas of Manhattan were served yesterday with notices of probable violation of beef-price ceilings.

L. Patrick Gray 3d testified today that he was mystified when President Nixon apparently paid no heed to a warning last year that White House aides were trying to "mortally wound" the President in the Watergate case.

As in the case of last month's hijacking of a Japanese airliner, major Palestinian guerrilla organizations have been quick to disavow any part in the latest lunatic outrage committed by two self-proclaimed members of the Black September terrorist group.

The Army's Eighth Infantry Division has ordered its intelligence service to begin a "coordinated counterdissidence effort" among the division's 13,000 troops, according to a copy of the plan made available to the press by a soldier who thinks it stifles political freedom.

A newsman who was at Kent State University in 1970 when four students were shot and killed said today that he had seen a man hand a pistol to the police and say: "I had to do it. They were trying to kill me."
The launching yesterday of the Soviet Union's third spaceship to Mars this year marks the beginning of the most ambitious effort yet to explore the distant planet.

Vice President Agnew announced last night that he had been informed that he was under investigation for possible violations of criminal law. In a terse, late-night statement issued through his press secretary, Marsh Thomson, the Vice President declared:
The Bank of Canada announced tonight that the bank rate was being increased by one-half of 1 per cent to 63/4 per cent, the fourth such increase since April.
Four-dollar wheat, the nightmare of flour millers and livestock feeders and the onceimpossible dream of the farmer, became a reality yesterday on Midwest grain exchanges.
HILAND, Wyo--The pretty young woman sat at her desk. She was confused. As she stared out the window, something stirred within her, something strange, something she had never before experienced.
An American bomb strike on a large Cambodian town this morning killed and wounded hundreds of people, mostly Government soldiers and their families.
The Health Department has listed 24 more food establishments as health-code violators and has served notice that failure to pass a third inspection later this month could result in orders to close.
Charles Alan Wright, the lanky Texan who will defend President Nixon in the -Watergate court cases, reacted strongly to the suggestion that he had come to the White House as a legal hired gun.

AARON-Isadore, devoted husband of Helen (nee Kastec). Dear brother of Sophip Gorson, Harry and Irving. Services today i0:30 A.M. at "The Riverside" Far Rockaway, L. I. AARON-Isidore. The Rabbis, Officers Trustees of Temple Beth El, Cedarhurst, N.Y. and its affiliates express deepest symPathy on the Passing of their member. We grieve with the family on their loss.
Unless he told you himself, you'd never believe that Allen Jerkens was a "sore loser." His bearing is one of pleasantness, the faint suggestion of a smile ever present on his lips.
Lawyers for the Florida promoter, Glenn W. Turner, today lost a bid for a stay in civil action until after his trial on criminal-mail-fraud charges.
The Penn Central Transporstation Company has petitioned the United States District Court here for authorization to buy 225 multi-level auto racks, the company announced today.

A federal jury convicted a former Chicago police sergeant yesterday of depriving two men of their civil rights by killing them. A convicted narcotics dealer also was found guilty of violating the civil rights law for hiring the sergeant to commit one of the murders.

Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan will visit Moscow in October, the Government in Tokyo announced. Mr. Tanaka returned home yesterday from a tour of the United States and talks with President Nixon. In Moscow, he is scheduled to talk with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader.

The Rev. T. E. Edmonson of the Sharon Primitive Baptist Church finished his homily yesterday. then turned to the congregation of his East Side storefront church and asked if anyone had anything to say.
The Pentagon confirmed today that a military aide to the former White House domestic adviser, John D. Ehrlichman, had been ordered promoted over the objections of the Army.

Four-dollar wheat, the nightmare of flour millers and livestock feeders and the once impossible dream of the farmer, became a reality yesterday on Midwest grain exchanges. For the first time in the nation's history, the price of a 60-pound bushel of wheat crossed the $4 level.
Bob Gibson will undergo surgery this week for a knee injury suffered last Saturday in New York and will be lost to the Cardinals for four to six weeks.
Ted Patrick -- who helped a father seize his son to try to get him away from a religious group -- was acquitted of unlawful imprisonment yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court.

PALERMO, Sicily--In the twelfthcentury Palazzo Reale where Norman kings once ruled, the president of the Sicilian Regional Assembly sits in remote splendor, glad to talk about the problems of the world instead of those at his doorstep.

8:05-10 A.M., WNCN. Mandolin Concerto in G, Hasse; Tournament Galop, Gottschalk; Concerto Grosso in D minor, Geminiani; Song of the Flea, Mussorgsky; Love for Three Oranges: Scherzo and March, Prokofiev; Symphony No. 4 in C minor, Schubert; Enigma Variations, Elgar; Fantasia on a Theme by Tallis, Vaughan Williams.
Fort Stamford is not noted in the annals of the Revolutionary War for deeds of bravery or for battles won and lost. According to a recently discovered book of daily accounts at the fort,

The Public Service Commis- days to sion of New York yesterday granted the Brooklyn Union Gas Company a $15.6-million rate increase. The added income will amount to nearly 9 per cent of the company's 1972 operating revenues of $175.2-million.
Stock prices on the American Stock Exchange in quiet trading yesterday closed slightly higher at 23.37, up 0.02, even though more individual issues showed decline than adances.

STEPHEN JONES, tuba, Federal Hall National Memorial, Wail and Broad Streets, 5.30 MUSIC FOR BRASS, Washington Square Park, 8 LA PUMA OPERA WORKSHOP, ill Douizettl's "Lucia di Lammermoor," Damrosch Park Lintotu Center, 7:30 MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL, Philharmonic Hall, 8. MUNICIPAL CONCERTS ORCHESTRA, McCarren Park, Driggs Avenue and Lorimrn Street, Brooklyn 8.30.

Chief Justice Warren E. Burger asked the organized bar today to consider a new screening procedure that would limit the number of appeals that losing parties could take above District Court, the lowest level of the Federal system.

The last railroad tunnel in Texas collapsed on a train during the weekend. Railroad officials said yesterday that $1million would be spent extracting the wreckage and, probably, turning the tunnel into a gorge.
Joseph (Newsboy) Moriarty, the reputed Hudson County numbers king, was sentenced today to three-and-one-half to five years in State Prison on his latest gambling conviction.

The United Aircraft Corporation's Turbo Power and Marine Systems subsidiary has obtained a $22-million order from the Florida Power Corporation, for a gas turbine powered generating complex with an output of 300.000 kilowatts.

Two of the Skylab 2 astronauts set endurance records in space "walking" today as they erected a new sunshade over their orbiting laboratory, changed film in the telescopes and performed other odd jobs in the vacuum of space.

Martin J. Hodas, described by the police as "the peep-show king" of New York City, was arrested here today and charged with illegal possession of a loaded gun after two shots were fired at an intruder in the bedroom of his $150,000 home early this morning.
Sale of copper scrap metal today was granted an exemption from the price freeze effective immediately, Cost of Living Council Director John T. Dunlop announced.
Guns and badges were given out yesterday to 15 men mosty blacks and Puerto Ricans-who are the first of a new type of policemen: the New York State Urban Park Patrolman.

A Queens dentist yesterday shot and critically wounded an alleged holdup man who made an appointment for a tooth extraction, showed up early with a butcher knife and threatened the life of a nurse in his demand for money.
The Federal Trade Commission announced today that makers of household detergents had voluntarily agreed to a unifrom label for their packages that would list the amount of phosphates in the product.

In the currently depressing climate of Washington it is particularly refreshing to note two first-class appointments to high Government posts. While Russell E. Train and William D. Ruckelshaus are both veterans of the Nixon Administration, they should bring it added strength in their new positions as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency and Deputy Attorney General, respectively.
The nation's biggest banks yesterday lifted their basic interest rate on loans to major corporations to 9 per cent, a record level set first last Friday by the Franklin National Bank.
The week-long search for a suspected killer in the Adirondacks broadened tonight when a man resembling the fugitive bought gas for a car stolen earlier today near the area of the manhunt.

An economic impact survey says it appears that Rhode Island will be able to withstand major cutbacks at its naval installations with little or no effect on unemployment and no net decline in retail sales.
A campaign was opened here today to convince consumers that middlemen and the increasing concentration of corporate power in the food industry are to blame for the surge in food prices.

To the Editor: David Rosenbaum's July 28 news report, "Witness Defends Spying in Campaign," concerns John Ehrlichman's concept of the investigation of morals (drinking, personal habits, etc.) of candidates. Senator Weicker seems shocked that such considerations should be taken into account in attempting to *assess the worth of political candidates in this country, fearing that elections would be "settled on the basis of candidates' private lives."

Amid mounting controversy over two brothers who were jailed after maintaining that they had robbed a Dublin bank on orders of British intelligence, the Defense Ministry denied tonight that the British authorities "were in any way connected with the bank raid in Dublin."

Griffin Crafts, who retired recently as chairman and president of the J. W. Wilson Glass Company of Linden, N.J., died yesterday in University Hospitaltal. He was 73 years old and lived at 220 East 19th Street.
A former security officer at Kent State University said that Terrence Norman was "gunhappy" but did not fire any shots on May 4, 1970, when four students were killed by National Guardsmen.

Chief Justice Warren E. Burger asked the organized bar today to consider a new screening procedure that would limit the number of appeals that losing parties could take above District Court, the lowest level of the Federal system.
The Common Market council has canceled a meeting of finance ministers that was to be held in The Hague, the Netherlands, on Sept. 3, a Belgian Finance Ministry spokesman said here today.

Greatly increased production costs and greater losses to in. vestors marked the Broadway and Off Broadway season that ended May 31. In a report made public yesterday by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, with whose office Broadway and Off Broadway productions financed with investors' money, are filed) losses amounted to $5,175,000.

An American bomb strike on a large Cambodian town killed and wounded hundreds of people, mostly soldiers and their families. The attack occurred at Neak Luong, 38 miles southeast of Phnom Penh. The American Embassy in Phnom Penh would say only that it had heard reports of an accidental bombing in Neak Luong. [Page 1, Column 1.]

The Government's key informer testified today that an antiwar veteran charged with plotting to disrupt the Republican National Convention in Miami Beach in 1972 told him he had organized "political assassination squads" armed by trading drugs for guns.

The N.A.A.C.P. announced yesterday that it had removed from office Lonnie C. King Jr., the president, and other officers of its Atlanta branch because of their failure to oppose a controversial school desegregation plan in that city.
An off-duty housing patrolman exchanged shots with gunman in a Bedford Stuyvesant bar yesterday to foil a holdup, the second time in three years he had been in a gun battle in the same bar.

President Nixon signed a law today that extends for three years the Federal Law Enforcement Assistance Administration with less cost and more flexibility for the states. The Federal cost will be $3.2billion. To qualify for funds, states will need to put up only

Japan's net long-term capital outflow reached staggering levels in the first few months of 1973 and there are clear signs of an unwinding of the speculative inflow of shortterm capital, the Organization for Economy Cooperation and Development said today in its annual review of the Japanese economy.
The United States dollar climbed to a three-week high against the West German mark today and gained against other European currencies, particularly the British pound.

" Let others spend their time dealing with the murky, small, unimportant, vicious little things. We will spend our time building a better world." President Nixon, July 31, 1973 "The pall of the Watergate, with all its revelations of misplaced loyalties, of strange measures of the unethical, of unusual doings in high places, and by lawyer after lawyer after lawyer, is upon us. It is something that necessarily touches us all, irrespective of political intention."

New executives of the Leadville Corporation in Colorado are in a bit of a quandary, and in a development that may or may not be related, the annual meeting has been put off until late September or early October.

Most contemporary artists, it sometimes seems, have become convinced that the world ends not with a bang or a whimper, but a snicker. That might help explain the recent rush being given to Petronius Arbiter, whose "Satyricon" is known to every college sophomore as the ultimate statement about late Roman decadence.

Things may be looking up for the New York Mets. They beat the division-leading St. Louis Cardinals, 6-5, yesterday at Shea Stadium for the second straight day with a performance not in keeping with their status as cellar dwellers in the National League East.

??ederal officials said today that indictments were expected within weeks in an investigation into bribery, extortion and tax fraud charges involving Vice President Agnew and some of his closest political and financial associates.
" Now is the time," Betty Furness, the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, said yesterday, "to put away the steak knives and get out the poultry shears and omelette pans."
Two of Britain's best-known passenger liners, the Carmania and the Franconia, are to be sold to the Panamanian associate of a New York company, the Cunard shipping line announced today.
Judge Robert F. Peckham of United States District Court in San Francisco upheld yesterday the Federal price ceilings on beef. He made his ruling in reiectine a bid by California

Behind the diplomatic incident caused by the United Statesl Embassy's memorandums to the Argentine Government crit icizing draft legislation on in vestments is the rising discontent and insecurity in the foreign business community.
A funeral mass for Fulgencio Batista, the former Cuban dictator overthrown in 1959 by Fidel Castro, was sung in a small chapel today, attended by more than 100 Cuban exiles and family members.

The Government is going after those who did not vote in last month's referendum, giving them till Sept. '8 to explain why they should not pay a fine or be jailed for one to six months, or be both fined and jailed.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers discussed Watergate today and said that the American system of financing political campaigns was so "rotten" that otherwise honorable men "can be corrupted by it."

The Yankees can't be certain whether they're home or still on the road. When they lost the first game of last night's double-header with Texas, 2-1, despite a bases-loaded, no-out situation in the ninth inning, they must have felt they were stiII wallowing in the depths of the disastrous trip on rich they lost nine of 11 games.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that the new State Racing and Wagering Board, which will oversee the operations of five state racing and betting commissions,
A grand jury indicted a prison guard yesterday on charges that he provided an inmate with the gun used for an escape attempt in which two muards were killed.

Delta Airlines and the Federal Aviation Administration reached today a temporary agreement for Delta to receive copies and transcripts of control tower tape recordings related to the jetliner crash at Logan Inter national Airport last Tuesday.
ABOARD THE TOPLESS, in Long Island Sound "Smell that?" asked David Griffin, shouting with excitement. "Like fresh-cut grass. It's blues."

Secretary of State William P. Rogers discussed Watergate today and said that the American system of financing political campaigns was so "rotten" that otherwise honorable men "can be corrupted by it."
Harwood S. Belding, a professor of environmental physiology at the University of Pittsburgh, died A yesterday at his home, 5818 Howe Street, He was 64 years old.
President Zulfikar All Bhulto will not run for President under Pakistan's new Constitution but will be nominated by the ruling People's party to e Prime Minister, it was announced today.

The International Rectifier Corporation announced today the Food and Drug Administration had approved the application of its Rachelle Laboratories subsidiary to market the pig-feed premix product, Chloracelle 250.

Byrnes-McCaffrey, a leading Chicago insurance broker, has merged with Bayly, Martin Fay, one of the nation's 10 largest commercial insurancebrokerage concerns, it was announced yesterday. Terms were not disclosed.

Over the last several months, the revelation of illegal and improper activities by former high officials of the Nixon Administration has shaken public confidence in the integrity of the Federal Government. These disclosures are of such a grave and far-reaching nature that even the impeachment of President Nixon has moved out of the realm of the unthinkable.
The top-seeded players in the $75,000 Western tennis championships, Ilie Nastase and Chris Evert. breezed to 6-1. 6-0 first-round triumphs tonight.

Seven years ago a young accountant decided he wanted something better than his $65-a-week job, so he took a position with Typhoon Industries, Inc., a New York area manufacturer of fences. Yesterday he bought the company.
The Atlanta Braves acquired Joe Niekro, a pitcher and the brother of Phil Nickro, who had a no-hitter last Sunday, on waivers from the Detroit Tigers today.

In a move to discourage the replacement of police at Hudson River crossings with civilians, the Port Authority police of New York and New Jersey released statistics today showing that more than 18,000 crimes were committed at Port Authority facilities in 1972.

The Eastside Playhouse, 334 East 74th Street, will be the new home, beginning next Tuesday, of "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," one of four shows at the Mercer Arts Center in the University Hotel, which collapsed last Friday.

Dr. Ernst Papanek, former executive director of the Wiltwyck School for Boys in Eso-, pus, N. Y., and later a professor of educational psychology at Queens College, died Sunday on a visit to Vienna. He was 73 years old and lived at West 64th Street.

Commissioner Theodore Karagheuzoff ordered yesterday that the Buildings Department inspect a citysupervised, middle - income cooperative apartment development in Brooklyn that has shown serious building defects although it was completed only six years ago.
A United States fighter-bomber struck a Government-held village today in another bombing error near the town where a misdirected American air strike yesterday left more than 400 casualties.

EAST BERLIN-Walter Felsenstein, the opera director, is not well known in America, outside of a limited circle of admirers who have seen his work in East Berlin or on one of his company's rare tours. Mr. Felsenstein's art does not travel very well.
The stillness of a lazy summer afternoon is pierced by angry words reverberating from a cluster of shady trees in Branch Brook Park Annex, but :here is no cause for alarm.

More than 800 oil spills occurred during the first six months of this year in the midAtlantic region, including more than 300 in the area of New York Harbor and its tributaries, according to a survey that has been made public by the Coast Guard.

Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that his Homicide Bureau had begun investigating the collapse last Friday of the old Broadway Central Hotel "to determine if there is any basis for criminal action."
A housing panel appointed by the President recommended today lifting current limits on Federal backing of mortgage loans to strengthen the Government's

Someone asked Frank Nero, who was elected to the City Council at 23 years old, elected Mayor at 24 and at 26 has been faced with a major disaster, what he planned to be when he is 30. "Probably old and tired, very tired," the youthful Mayor quipped.
Soaring soybean-export prices are turning Brazilian farmers from their usual crops needed on the home market.

New oil supplies will have to average 450,000 barrels a day higher in the second half of 1973 than they did in the first half if they are to meet demand, the Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday in its monthly Petroleum Situation publication.

Parks Commissioner Richard M. Clurman, accompanied by three aides, angrily confronted 10 members of a roving teenage gang--one wielding a bull whip--that was suspected of having just beaten a Parks Department employee, Monday afternoon, in a playground in St. Albans, Queens.

The Government named 10 American universities today to share equally in a $10-million educational project for Japanese studies, carrying out a plan announced by Premier Kakuei Tanaka in a joint communique after his meeting with President Nixon in Washington last week.
Irate bidders yesterday interrupted a city auction of 11 autos, seized from scofflaws who owed the city a total of $33,329 in unpaid parking fines, because they thought the procedure was a swindle.

The Communist German Democratic Republic and the international hierarchy of orthodox Communism today paid a farewell to Walter Ulbricht, the East German head of state who died last Wednesday of heart failure. He was 80 years old.

The United States has refused to accept the validity of Libya's expropriation last June of the American-owned Nelson Bunker Hunt Oil Company because it was carried out as an act of political reprisal against Washington, counter to "established principles of international law."

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he doubted he would campaign actively for State Senator John J. Marchi, the Republican candidate for Mayor, noting that in his role as Governor he was reluctant to involve himself in local partisan politics.

White House lawyers told a Federal district judge today that the courts had no power to force President Nixon to provide a grand jury with tape recordings of his conversations if he believed it was not in the public interest.

Four Federal or Congressional agencies are--or will soon be-investigating New York State's award of a $125,000 consulting contract to the Electronic Data Systems Corpration, Representative Benjanin S. Rosenthal told Governor Rockefeller yesterday.

The Battery Park City Authority named the developers yesterday for a sizable portion of the $1.1-billion development in Lower Manhattan and in the process revealed a physical design that differs from an earlier and much more innovative one.
The American Bar Association asked Congress today to create a tough new system for removing misbehaving or "disabled" judges from the Federal judiciary.

Ron Turcotte was something super today. The personable Canadian jockey registered five consecutive victories, the fifth on a filly with the most applicable name - Something Super.
A total of 155 black students of the University of Rhodesia, including five women, were arrested here today during a violent demonstration.

The opening of the giant new passenger terminal (Terminal A) at Newark International Airport today also involves the unveiling of an elaborate 14-mile system of access and service roads.

Two Arab terrorists who attacked Athens airport with hand grenades Sunday were changed today with "premeditated homicide of a particularly odious nature." In the event of conviction there is a mandatory death sentence.

Jack Nicklaus is a class guy who has stood alone for a decade as the finest golfer on earth, but because he is also the infidel dog who blasphemed by deposing Arnold Plainer, the rabble known as Arnie's Army made him a target of abuse for 10 years. Gene Tunney may have been the most grievously underrated fighter of all times;

After days of motion sickness, nights of mission-threatening malfunctions and hours outside rigging a new sunshade, the Skylab 2 astronauts were able to settle down today for the first time to business as usual.
Maxwell Arnold Kreindler, who was president of the famous "21" Club from 1947 to 1955, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 1016 Fifth; Avenue.

Does anyone remember Robert C. Odle Jr.? Mr. Odle, a one-time employe of the Committee for the Re-Election of the President, was the first man to rise in the white glare of the television lights in the Senate caucus room, to raise his right hand and swear to tell the truth to the seven Senators on the Watergate investigating committee and a network audience.

The national policy committee of the Jewish War Veterans called upon its members and friends today to "institute an immediate boycott of he products of Standard Oil of California and its subsidiaries."

Vice President Agnew and some of his closest personal, political and financial allies are under investigation by a Federal grand jury in Baltimore for alleged bribery, extortion and tax fraud involving 5 per cent kickbacks from Maryland contractors to Government officials.
William T. Brady, who was press relations chief for Consolidated Edison Company of New York from 1948 to his retirement in 1965, died yesterday at his home, 34 Gramercy Park. He was 72 years old.

Mrs. Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan, a guard-supervisor in Nazi death camps during World War II, was flown to West Germany Monday night to face trial on charges that she had killed a woman prisoner, helped in the hanging of a Jewish girl and selected more than 1,700 victims for the gas chambers.

The New York State Banking Board yesterday increased the legal interest-rate ceiling on home-mortgage loans to 8 per cent, effective Aug. 15, from 7.5 per cent. The new limit does not affect interest rates on existing mortgages. Harry W. Albright, Jr., State Superintendent of Banks, said the action was designed "to assure the continued availability of home-mortgage financing at reasonable rates to New Yorkers."
Nu Dimensions Figure Salons, Inc., will revise its advertising, contracts and sales techniques, under terms of an agreement with the city's Department of Consumer Affairs,

ASIMOV--Anna, of Long Beach, on Aug. 6, 1973, loving mother of Isaac, Stanley and Marcia Repanes; also is survived by seven grandchildren. Funeral arrangements private. BATEMAN--Grace Street. Aug. 5, 1973. Wife of the late Prof. Alan Bateman of 450 St. Ronan St., New Haven, Conn. Funeral service at Old Cemetery, East Haven, Conn. Wed., Aug. 8 at 2 P.M.
The surge in interest rates continued yesterday along a broad front, with a dramatic upward leap registered by Treasury bills.

Following are excerpts from a brief filed today in Federal District Court by attorneys for President Nixon in support of the President's refusal to obey a subpoena requiring him to give taperecordings of White House conversations and other documents to the Justice Department's special prosecutor, Archibald Cox:
Mayor Frank L. Rizzo said today that he was not using a special police unit to conduct "political espionage." He also promised to continue an investigation of official corruption.

The Federal Power Commission approved today an increase in the price of natural gas from the nation's largest producing area, a move that will more than double the price of gas flowng from wells that began producing within the last five gears.
Corn traders took their turn yesterday to bid up prices to an historic high-$3.01 1/4 for a bushel of 56 pounds on the Midwest exchanges. The price was for corn deliverable next month.

The owner and keeper of an eight-month-old dog pulled from the debris of the lod Broadway Central Hotel yesterday, came forward last night, identified the animal and gave him to the firemen who saved him as a reward.

The Battery Park City Authority named the developers yesterday for a sizable portion of the $1.1-billion development in Lower Manhattan and in the process revealed a physical design that differs from an earlier and much more innovative one.

Anthony Boiardo, a reputed Mafia leader whose case was severed from an extortion trial in 1970, after suffering a heart attack was examined today by a Governmentappointed doctor to determine if he was healthy enough to stand trial.

The Massachusetts House overrode Gov. Francis W. Sargent's veto of the school prayer bill today, 171 to 50. The Governor had rejected the measure, which adds the words "or prayer" to the present law that authorizes a moment's meditation at the start of each daily public school session.
Yankees vs. Texas Rangers. at Yankee Stadium. River Avenue and 161st Street. the Bronx. 2 P. M. (Radio-WMCA, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Dodgers, at Los Angeles. (Radio-WHN, 40:55 P.M.)

A single, brief rock-throwing incident by a roving band of youth marred an otherwise quiet evening in Jamaica, Queens last night, according to the police who patrolled the neighborhood where young black had rampaged Monday
The mostly Mozart concert at Philharmonic Hall Monday night was a mostly amiable affair with Alicia de Larrocha taking top honors for her poised, wholly delicious account of Mozart's "Coronation"

Fritz Peterson got kicked out of the Detroit Tigers' press box Monday night. While the Yankee pitcher was trying to chart pitches, he was asked for his press credentials. At a loss for words, Peterson showed his New York Raiders' card in a futile hope to remain.

Vincent Aloi, 40-year-old reputed chief of the Mafia's Colombo "family," was sentenced to up to seven years in prison yesterday for lying to a grand jury that investigated the slaying of rival gang leader, Joseph Gallo.

The Senate Watergate Committee unceremoniously completed the first phase of its inquiry into the Watergate case today after hearing a detailed defense of the Government's much-criticized original investigation.

Vice President Agnew and some of his closest personal, political and financial allies are under investigation by a Federal grand jury in Baltimore for alleged bribery, extortion and tax fraud involving 5 per cent kickbacks from Maryland contractors to Government officials. Indictments are expected within weeks, Federal officials said, but there was no indication that Mr. Agnew would be named. [Page 1, Column 8.]
The top-seeded players in the $75,000 Western tennis championships, The Nastase and Chris Evert. breezed to 6-1, 6-0 first-round triumphs tonight.

The Allis-Chalmers Corporation announced yesterday at Milwaukee that three Texas utilities awarded Allis-Chalmers Power Systems, Inc., a contract for two 1.15 million kilowatt nuclear steam turbine generators.
Wilbur Cooper, a lefthanded pitcher who won 20 or more games four times for the Pittsburgh Pirates in the early nineteen-twenties, died of a heart attack today at the age of 81.

The Federation of Economic Organizations (Keidanren) said today it had asked the Government and the Bank of Japan to ease the country's present rigorous exchange control in order that the yen may be used more extensively for trade settlement than at present.

Ecuador and a Texaco-Gulf consortium have signed a new concession contract which according to a Gulf spokesman here will give Ecuador close to 80 per cent of the gross profits of her petroleum exports.
The Atlanta Braves acquired Joe Niekro, a pitcher and the brother of Phil Niekro, who had a no-hitter last Sunday, on waivers from the Detroit Tigers today.

The Federal Power Commission approved today an increase in the price of natural gas from the nation's largest producing area, a move that will more than double the price of gas flowing from wells that began producing within the last five years.

Mrs. Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan, a guard-supervisor in Nazi death camps during World War II, was flown to West Germany Monday night to face trial on charges that she had killed a woman prisoner, helped in the hanging 'of a Jewish girl and selected more than 1,700 victims for the gas chambers.
Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, charged today that the Pentagon was letting subcontracts without adequate price and cost data, in violation of its own regulations.
Raymond H. White, a former telegrapher for The Associated Press, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 77 years old.

In 1947, after extensive public hearings, Minnesota's environmental watchdogs gave the Reserve Mining Company permission to use the pristine waters of Lake Superior as a dumping ground for thousands of tons of rocky waste each day.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthe-counter market finished slightly lower yesterday in continued slow trading.

Emile Puttemans of Belgium, holder of the world 5,000-meter record of 13 minutes 13 seconds, set the year's best time for the distance today in the August Track and Field Games in the Stockholm Stadium. The 26-year-old Belgian beat Dick Quax of New Zealand by 30 meters in 13:14.6.
Vice President Agnewv contemplated his legal situation and the effect of a criminal investigation on his political career in the privacy of his office next door to the White House today.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it was conducting a "preliminary" investigation of financial aspects of Senator George McGovern's 1972 Democratic presidential campaign here at the specific request of Archibald Cox, the special Watergate prosecutor.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday named the three public members to the city's newly created Rehabilitation Mortgage Insurance Corporation, which is expected to stimulate private participation in preserving and rehabilitating existing housing.

A 20-year-old fugitive convict with a long arrest record, who was released without bail last week by Criminal Court Judge Bruce Wright in the Bronx despite an assistant district attorney's protest, was seized early yesterday by the police in his sister's apartment.

Federal officials said today that indictments were expected within weeks in an investigation into bribery, extortion and tax fraud charges involving Vice President Agnew and some of his closest political and financial associates.

Fun and games are over for most of the Paris couture houses. They've settled down, in their fall collections, to do beautiful, elegant fashions for women who prefer to buy their clothes in posh salons rather than off plain pipe racks.

European money markets settled down to routine currency trading today, pricing the United States dollar and the British pound at almost unchanged levels.

Profits of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for the quarter and six months ended June 30, increased more than 11.5 per cent in both periods to record levels, according to yesterday's midyear report.

The New York Cultural Center on Columbus Circle has opened its best show in a long time, "Reality and Trompe-l'oeil by Franch New Real Painters." The four painters represented-Claude Yvel, Pierre Ducordeau, Henri Cadiou and Jean Malice-are newcomers to New York, but with listed prices going up to $14,000 they seem pretty sure of themselves.

Arlen D. Southern is a man who knows a thing or two about corporate advertising. At present, he's the vice president for corporate affairs at the I.U. International Corporation, where his responsibilities include such matters. Previously, he was director of corporate public relations and advertising at TRW, Inc., where he did much of the same.

A suit by Texasgulf, Inc., trying to stop the Canadian Development Corporation from gaining effective control of the Texas corporation, bogged down in a procedural morass today. The hearing was postponed until 11 a.m. tomorrow.

White House lawyers told a Federal district judge today that the courts had no power to force President Nixon to provide a grand jury with tape recordings of his conversations if he believed it was not in the public interest.

Dominick Dominick, Inc., announced yesterday that 17 of its branch offices would be sold to other firms. The New York Stock Exchange member firm announced plans recently to phase out its domestic retail brokerage business for competitive reasons.
The Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced today that it had discovered two more oil wells on its 2.9-million-acre contract area in the Amazon basin of Peru.

The United Nuclear Corporation announced yesterday execution of a letter of intent to sell its interest in the Gulf United Nuclear Fuels Corporation to the Gulf Oil Corporation. The agreement is subject to completion of a definitive contract and to approval of the boards of both companies.

Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that his Homicide Bureau had begun investigating the collapse last Friday of the old Broadway Central Hotel "to determine if there is any basis for criminal action."
Ten Cuban refugees who had crossed the Florida Straits through rough seas in a homemade 16-foot boat were taken into Key West yesterday by a Coast Guard cutter after their small outboard engine quit.
Mrs. Henrietta Robertson Hanley, widow of Joe R. Hanley, who was Lieutenant Governor under Thomas E, Dewey, died yesterday at a hospital, She was 93 years old.

An American enlisted man said today that it was he who disclosed Army intelligence activities in West Germany to the press, and that, if asked, he would testify before a Senate investigating committee about others he belives illegal.
Gulf Oil Canada, Ltd., raised its purchase price for Western Canadian crude oil today by 40 cents a barrel, retroactive to Aug. 1.
The stock market retreated slightly yesterday, as several recently-robust volative issues posted fairly substantial declines.

The map shows the principal turnoffs from major highways to the new terminal area and to the old terminal, which is being renamed North Terminal.
Senator John C. Stennis returned to his office today for the first time since he was shot down in a robbery in front of his home Jan. 30.

Marilyn Horne is an opera singer of amazing technical prodigality who nonetheless manages with alarming regularity to drive some of her admirers into a rage. The reason is that for all her gifts and ebullient personality, Miss Horne often falls short of what she could and should achieve.

Robert Garrow Sr., a fugitive who has eluded police for 10 days in the northern part of the state, visited his sister at 11:30 P.M. Monday night at her home in Mineville, N. Y., the state police said yesterday.

Total assets of the overseas branches of United States banks increased by 15 per cent or $10.4-billionin 1972, the Federal Reserve System reported today. At the end of 1972 total assets stood at $77.437-billion, compared with $67.054-billion at the end of 1971. The number of branches overseas of member banks increased by 50 to 627, the Reserve said.
Just in case the five members of the Babylon Town Board had forgotten the major decision they must make within 18 days, a crowd showed up for the monthly meeting today to remind them.

The Government delved into the marketing techniques of Glenn W. Turner's cosmetics concern today as it sought to prove its allegations that the controversial promoter had engaged in deceptive and misleading business practices.

The Government's star witness testified today that after he was unmasked as a Federal Bureau of Investigation informer, the alleged leader of a plot to disrupt the 1972 Republican National Convention took him to a clandestine meeting to discuss obtaining heavy weapons from right-wing Cubans and asked him to "fill a contract" for a gangland-style slaying.
The Government set the stage today for the end of the price freeze Monday and a probable early increase in many prices.
President Nixon broke a tie vote of the Tariff Commission today and ordered aid to former employes of a General Electric Company plant in Buffalo. The plant was closed last year.

But events this summer have demonstrated that work aimed at exploring the planets by instruments of the most diverse sort continues actively.

More than 28,000 gallons of oil were spilled into the inland and coastal waterways of New Jersey in 68 separate incidents luring the second quarter of 1973, according to a survey made public yesterday by the Coast Guard.
A United States fighter-bomber struck a Government-held village today in another bombing error near the town where a misdirected American air strike yesterday left more than 400 casualties.

Three of the four mayoral candidates have expressed reservations about the $3.5-billion transportation bond issue and said yesterday that they had not decided whether to campaign for it, although some of the proceeds are earmarked to save the 35-cent bus and subway fare.
Albert L. Kress, a management engineer who had been a vice president of ACF Industries, Inc., died Sunday at his home, 180 Springdale Road. He was 79 years old.

Attorneys, representing 60 people charged in connection with the 1971 Attica prison uprising, argued today that the list of witnesses who appeared before the grand jury investigating the disturbance should be made available to the defense.

The United States Attorney's office in New Jersey has begun an investigation of a nationwide chain of mail order houses selling allegedly worthless sex potions and miracle weight reducers.
Because 32 government leaders representing 800 million people might have quite a few enemies, the security problems of the current Commonwealth conference in this sedate capital have been enormous.
Governor Rockefeller appointed a State Advisory Committee on Mental Health today and designated former State Senator Dalwin J. Niles of Johnstown as chairman.

The Senate Watergate Committee unceremoniously completed the first phase of its inquiry into the Watergate case today after hearing a detailed defense of the Government's much-criticized original investigation.
Soaring interest rates have stirred up deep concern in Wall Street as a relatively short-run phenomenon that could deliver a knock-down punch to business generally and the stock market in particular.

Elise Brickner, 17 - year- old daughter of Rabbi Balfour Brigkner of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, was killed in a fall from a horse near Blois last Saturday, the police confirmed today.
An order barring a firm from dealing in commodity options in Nevada because of alleged misuse of at least $250,000 in customers' money has beer issued by Secretary of State William Swackhamer.

Hartford is ready to spend $27,000 for a lobbyist in Washington, Councilman George Levine said today. He said the city was expected to hire the Washington Consulting Group this month for $27,000 for 10 months' work.

A South Korean fishing captain was found guilty and fined $20,000 yesterday for fishing in United States waters off the coast of Alaska in mid-July. His fine brought to $100,000 the total in fines and penalties against the trawler Dong Bang 71 and Capt. Lee Nyohng Sik,
A suggestion by Tom Weiskopf to prevent overzealous amateur camera buffs from interfering with the contestants will he in effect here during the Professional Golfers' Association championship.

Police Chief Thomas J. Vaughan sent three policemen to this city's civic center construction site today during the lunch hour to keep an eye on construction workers accused of having subjected passing women to verbal abuse.

Harold S. Geneen, chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, has denied that he blamed Robert S. McNamara, a former Secretary of Defense, for the Vietnam war and the Edsel automobile.
Joe (Little Joe) Morgan has survived a fractured kneecap, strained knee ligaments and the lengthy inactivity of active military service during his 10-year major league baseball career.

The South Vietnamese command today reported the highest level of fighting across the country since mid-June. The command spokesman, Lieut. Col. Le Trun Hien, said, however, that although the number of incidents had risen, the intensity of the fighting remained comparatively low.
Ten persons, including patients in a doctor's office, were injured tonight when a bomb exploded outside a police station in the border town of Newry.
Charles J. Hardy Jr., a retired lawyer and former chairman and chief executive of ACF Industries, Inc., died Monday at Doctors Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 435 East 52d Street.

The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation announced yesterday plans for spending $1.1-billion on new power generating facilities by 1982.

Governor Cahill today gave the trustees of four bankrupt rail lines his recommendations for consolidating their freight operations as a means of reducing operating costs. But he received no commitments from any of the railroad officials.

The Netherlands raised the bank rate to 6 1/2 per cent from 6 per cent, effective tomorrow, the central bank said today.

When Congress voted five weeks ago to stop the bombing of Cambodia on Aug. 15, some members bitterly deplored the delayed cutoff date, arguing that the additional toll in Cambodian lives could not be morally justified. Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas made the same point last Saturday when he ordered a stay in the bombing-a stay promptly overruled by other members of the Court.

Miss Brenda Humstone Fox, daughter of Mrs. Alan Gordon of New York, South Laguna, Calif., and East Hampton, L. I., was married yesterday in a civil ceremony in Vienna to Peter Johannes Gall, son of Mrs. Maria Gall and Prof. Hannes Gall of Vienna.
Two high-speed turbotrains, built in France for service on Amtrak lines in tile Middle West, were unloaded from the freighter, Atlantic Cognac, at Port Elizabeth, N. J., yesterday.

Rennie Taylor, a former science writer for The Associated Press, died yesterday after a stroke. He was 77 years old. Mr. Taylor retired in 1961 to a fruit ranch he had owned since the nineteen-thirties near this Northern California cornmunity.
President Salvador Allende Gossens asked today for the retirement of two air force officers, and the right-wing press denounced the action as an attempt to "decapitate" the air force.

A Greek proposal that President George Papadopoulos of Greece mediate in the deepening conflict between President Makarios and Gen. George Grivas, the right-wing guerrilla leader, was welcomed today in Government circles.

Andrew J. Phelan, who retired as vice president and treasurer of Braniff International Airlines in March, died yesterday in Dallas. He was 65 years old and lived in Garden City, L. I.
John H. Lyons of 41-20 53d Street, Woodside, Queens, an insurance broker for 45 years, died Tuesday night in St. Charles Hospital, Port Jefferson, L. I. His age was 73.

The second quarter's dramatic upsurge in earnings may be a hard act to follow in the months ahead, the First National City Bank said yesterday. Earnings for the second quarter of 1973 climbed 29 per cent above year-ago levels and marked the biggest year-to-year increase for any quarter in 14 years, Citibank said.

Mrs. Margaret Holbrook Clark, widow of John Clark, president of the New York State Board of Law Examiners from 1921 to 1947, died today in a nursing home here. She was 95 years old.
A court order to stop the American bombing of Cambo. dia was overturned here yesterday by a 2-to-I decision of the United States Court of Appeals.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today suspended, pending further investigation, a 20-cent fare increase requested by PATH, the Port Authority-Trans Hudson rail commuter line between New York and New Jersey.
Gov. Ronald Reagan of California said today that Watergate lawbreakers should be brought to justice, but not as a "lynching" or a "witch hunt."

For the sixth consecutive month since the draft was discontinued, the Army failed in July to reach its recruiting goals, it was announced today. Thirty-five per cent of those who did sign up were black. This is almost three times the black proportion of the population.
The United States dollar dropped marginally today on most European money markets, while China and the Soviet Union both adjusted the exchange rates of their currencies.

A 50-year-old man being held for psychiatric observation before trial on a shoplifting charge hanged himself with a bedsheet from a bar in his cell at the Manhattan House of Detention yesterday morning.
John J. H. Tully,' purchasing agent for Brookhaven National Laboratory, died yesterday in Brookhaven Memorial Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 84 North Howells Point Road.

Passengers arriving at the new terminal at Newark International Airport, flown in across state and national boundaries today, landed in the middle of a territorial dispute between cab drivers from Essex and Union Counties.

Dr. David M. Brotman, founder, president, chief executive officer and principal shareholder of General Health Services, Inc., died, apparently of a heart attack, in his office today. He was 66 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

WASHINGTON--Like snow driven by a righteous wind, the evidence of Watergate continues to pile up, straining the limits of the nation's understanding and attention. And with it is a danger that the deeper lessons of this sordid affair will be buried under the drifts of details.

A 24-year-old Queens woman went to court yesterday to thank a judge for giving her an 18-month prison sentence. Pearl Counts of 116-72 197th Street, St. Albans, had pleaded guilty to passing forged checks for drug dealers. Criminal Court Judge John DiLeonardo, who could have sentenced her to up to 15 years, gave her an 18-month sentence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8-Vice President Agnew is suddenly contending with some of the same complex and controversial legal questions that have been taxing President Nixon and his lawyers for months.

The tourists come by the hundreds every day to stare at the ruins of Wounded Knee, trying to catch some hint of the 71 -day violent confrontation earlier this year between Indians and Federal marshals.
President Salvador Allende Gossens will bring members of the armed forces into his Cabinet in a move to put an end to the "state of sedition" that reigns in the country, it was announced today.

Marvin Gersten, the city's Purchase Commissioner, yesterday foresaw meat prices skyrocketing here - up to 40 per cent for the last half of August, compared with the outset of President Nixon's Phase 4 program in mid-July.
Eddie Condon's guitar was propped in front of his coffin yesterday afternoon as a tribute during a funeral service that drew about 150 friends and relatives.
The University of Wisconsin formally withdrew its financial support from Afro-American and Native American student centers on the Madison campus today.

Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, looking for solutions to the rising prices of food, took to the supermarket yesterday and later met with executives of some of the city's largest food chains--only to learn that everybody thought it was Washington's problem.

The British Petroleum Company and a Texas oilman, Nelson Bunker Hunt, filed a joint legal action yesterday in Houston charging the Coastal States Gas Producing Company with "unauthorized and improper lealings" in crude oil from Libya's Sarir field.

A teen-ager and a fugitive exconvict under indictment for a holdup-murder were accused today of a second slaying, committed a day later, possibly as a "thrill killing," according to state police investigators.

The National Broadcasting Company agreed yesterday to give the American Medical As-' sociation television air time to present its objections to an N. B. C. documentary on health care problems that the medical association has branded as "distorted" and unfair.

Mayor Lindsay, accompanied by his wife, will leave today for eight days in Colorado to attend two conferences. Tomorrow he will participate in the third Vail Symposium on the Urban Environment in Vail.
Prime Minister Heath of Britain told his fellow Commonwealth heads of government today that Uganda was guilty of "callous inhumanity" in her expulsion last year of more than 30,000 Asian residents.

Joe Orduna celebrated his 30th wedding anniversary today. Orduna has not been married for 30 years; he is only 25 years old. It's just that Orduna loves his wife and likes to celebrate a wedding "anniversary" every month.
Bob Sparks, a former jockey, singer and comic, caught a westerly wind today in an attempt to become the first trans-Atlantic balloonist.
Long Island Rail Road signalmen, in. response to a temporary restraining order, apparently ended their one-day sickin yesterday, according to a company spokesman.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y. -- The streets and alleys of this tiny Otsego County village are filled with vacationers who have come in search of the past-the past of James Fenimore Cooper, Wee Willie Keeler, Babe Ruth, quilting bees, blacksmiths, gaslights and trolley cars.

In the face of boorishness, the creative artist's only defense is taste and excellence. Natalia Makarova impaled her detractors with these twin esthetic darts and triumphed in American Ballet Theater's "Swan Lake" on Tuesday evening at the State Theater.

The Charlotte Police Department, facing a suit from persons ejected from a Billy Graham Day rally attended by President Nixon, has asked the United States District Court to hold the Secret Service and former White House chief of staff H. R. Haldeman responsible.

Passengers arriving at the new terminal at Newark International Airport, flown in across state and national boundaries today, landed in the middle of a territorial dispute between cab drivers from Essex and Union Counties.

A searing jelly-like substance hurled in a crowded Bronx courtroom by a man described as a disgruntled complainant against three suspected muggers sent at least 16 people to hospitals yesterday with what police called lye burns.

Ljubomir Ljubojevic barely clung to a half-point lead in the Interzonal tournament for world-championship aspirants after falling prey to a wild rook sacrifice by David Bronstein of the U.S.S.R. and going down to defeat on the black side of an Alekhine Defense in Round 11.

To the Editor: Confirmation that the California Bar Association has in fact undertaken a preliminary investigation into the actions of the President and other lawyers involved in the Watergate matter should serve as a spur to other bar associations--New York comes promptly to mind-to commence similar proceedings involving lawyers whose ethically questionable conduct has been established.

PARIS, Aug. 8 (Reuters)--Deputy Premier Nguyen Luu Vien of South Vietnam warned today that a Communist takeover in Phnom Penh would jeopardize the Vietnam peace accord and cause his Government to reconsider its attitude on talks with the Vietcong here concerning South Vietnam's political future.
Three decades after Pearl Harbor, Japanese traders are taking advantage of the devalued dollar by quietly buying up some of the highest priced chips in the bluechip game of thoroughbred breeding.
A Federal bankruptcy referee today prohibited courts from ordering Koscot Interplanetary Inc., to make payments in any civil actions while bankruptcy proceedings are pending.

The incredible flaws in the state's Draconian new drug laws have now been compounded by inexcusable neglect in preparing for their enforcement. Governor Rockefeller's original proposal for mandatory life terms for all drug pushers wove such an indis- Al criminate dragnet that it would have caught up even of occasional users of marijuana.
Bishop Kenneth W. Copeland, resident Bishop for the Houston Area of the United Methodist Church, died yesterday in Methodist Hospital, apparently of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.
Slam hands generally attract the attention of the bridge public, but for the tournament cognoscenti an insignificant part-score can be a source of delight.

A searing jelly-like substance hurled in a crowded Bronx courtroom by a man described as a disgruntled complainant against three suspected muggers sent at least 16 people to hospitals yesterday with what police called lye burns.

The film "Jesus Christ Superstar," which opened yesterday in three Manhattan and three New Jersey movie theaters, is, despite its guise as "a musical entertainment" comparable to "the antiSemitic Passion Play of Oberammergau," the American Jewish Committee charged yesterday at a press conference.

Gary Player of South Africa minimized today his chances of retaining his title in the Professional Golfers' Association championship that starts here tomorrow. Tom Weiskopf and Jack Nicklaus are rated cofavorites.
The destruction in this town from the accidental bombing on Monday is extensive. Big chunks of the center of town have been demolished, in. cluding two-story concrete buildings reinforced with steel.

Americans on the move may not realize the tax advantages available to them when they change jobs and go on to a new area-especially if they have not moved since 1969 when the tax allowances were liberalized.

SAN FRANCISCO--There is a new synthesis under way in psychology. It combines the scientific technology developed in the last century with ancient concepts and techniques of the traditions of the Middle and Far East. This is no idle philosophical movement, but a true translation of a most specialized and sometimes hidden knowledge with the empirical tradition of the West.
The bodies of eight young people, most of them individually wrapped in plastic and coated with lime, were unearthed here tonight, and the police were searching the area for more.
The state police blocked roads as far north as the Canadian border today and reinforced ground patrols around Witherbee in the effort to track down an elusive ex-convict wanted for murder.

A teen-ager and a fugitive exconvict under indictment for a holdup-murder were accused today of a second slaying, committed a day later, possibly as a "thrill killing," according to state police investigators.
The White House hopes to end all Government wage and price controls as soon as possible, perhaps by the end of the year, Nixon Administration officials said today.

-Margaret Carrol, a friend of Mary Jo Kopechne, filed suit in United States District Court yesterday contending that her telephone had been illegally wiretapped by former White House aides, Miss Kopechne drowned in 1969 in an automobile driven by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.
German officials said today that the investigations and trial of Mrs. Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan, who was extradited Monday from New York to face charges of Nazi war crimes, might take months.

Harlem Prep, the tuition-free school with a reputation for turning high-school dropouts into college graduates, will not reopen this fall unless the Board of Education agrees to take it over, the school's leading trustee said yesterday.

Levitz Furniture Corporation yesterday announced that its national headquarters would be moved from Pottstown, Pa., to Miami within the next sixty days. The company's national accounting operations will remain in Pottstown.

Peter Rennert of Great Neck L.I. upset one seeded player and extended another through three tough sets before being eliminated from the 16-year-old section of the Columbia tennis championships for juniors and boys yesterday at Baker Field.

The United States Court of Appeals yesterday reserved decision on an appeal by the Ininternational Business Machines Corporation of a contempt order in pretrial proceedings in the Justice Department's antitrust suit against the giant computer company.

A non-registered secondary offering of 250,000 common shares of Western Union Co. at $17.75 per share was sold out yesterday by Salomon Brothers and Oppenheimer Co. The company's stock closed unchanged at 18 on the New York Stock Exchange.

In accordance with an old Japanese custom that has acquired the force of an unwritten law here, the 114 Japan'ese passengers in the Japan Air Lines plane that was hijacked last month will each receive a "sympathy payment" of 500,000 yen (about $1,900) to compensate for their ordeal.

Bombers were active throughout the province during the day today. Meanwhile, a special police watch was mounted at all ports in Northern Ireland and Britain after threats of a bombing campaign in London from a small Roman Catholic extremist group called the Irish Citizens Army, security officials reported.

Joe Orduna celebrated his 30th wedding anniversary today. Orduna has not been martied for 30 years; he is only 25 years old. It's just that Orduna loves his wife and likes to celebrate a wedding "anniversary" every month.

Wellplaced Western and Communist diplomats said today that the Laotian Government here and the Communist-led Pathet Lao would sign a political and military agreement early next week and that a coalition government would be installed before the end of the month.

Youth was well represented on last night's program in the Festival of Contemporary Music here at Tanglewood, but the most vigorous and most adventurous work came from a delegate of the middle-aged party.
The Watergate investigation, permeating once hidden areas of the capital's social and political life. has focused new interest on an old subject: Congressional drinking.

The owner of the Mercer Arts Center told a board of inquiry yesterday that as early as January of this year he warned the proprietors of the old Broadway Central Hotel in downtown Manhattan and the New York City

Just about the only thing James Galanos doesn't like talking about is money. His clothes, he said, speak for themselves and one should look at them and not at price tags.
Vice President Agnew went on national television today to denounce as "damned lies" reports that he took kickbacks from government contractors in Maryland.

Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson announced today that as part of his effort to remove the Justice Department from politics, every department employe would henceforth be required to report any conversation about Justice Department matters with outside parties -- including Congressmen, their staffs and other governmental officials.

Unilever, N. V., and Unilever, Ltd., the twin companies that own or control more than 500 operating subsidiaries, includ ing the United States giant, the Lever Brothers Company, showed a combined increase of 23 per cent in second-quarter profits on a sales increase of 14 per cent, according to the semiannual report issued yesterday.
Edwin Tunis, an author and illustrator of children's books, died yesterday at the Greater Baltimore General Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in suburban Reisterstown.
Dr. Joseph Garland, physician and former editor or The New England Journal of Medicine, died Saturday at his home in suburban Chestnut Hill. He was 80 years old.

The case of seven antiwar veterans and a supporter on trial here for conspiring to disrupt the Republican National Convention is studded with a year-long series of occurrences that tie together figures in the Watergate scandal, undercover activities by informers and law enforcement agents, White House activities against political enemies and actions of the Justice Department's antiradical unit, the Internal Security Division.

Cheng Tzu-tsai, a 35-year-old dissident Taiwanese, was sentenced to a maximum of five years in Ossining State Correctional Facility yesterday for the attempted assassination of Chiang Kai-shek's son here three years ago.
Fifteen persons were killed by an explosion at the Arabian American Oil Company's refinery at Abqaiq, Saudi Arabia, it was disclosed today.

A Federal Court of Appeals overturned a lower-court order to stop the American bombing of Cambodia and cleared the way for the bombing to continue legally until Aug. 15, the cutoff date established by Congress. The appeals court, sitting in New York, voted 2 to 1 in overturning the order issued by Judge Orin G. Judd on July 25. That order had been stayed pending an appeal by the Government. [Page 1, Column 1.]

When Gene Michael first heard about the plans for a "Gene Michael night" at Yankee Stadium, his face flushed from embarrassment. "After all, aren't those things meant for the home run hitters?" asked the Yankees' smooth-fielding shortstop, whose career batting average hovers in the .220's. "At first, I was taken back when they came to me with the idea."

Bond prices rallied yesterday following weeks of virtually uninterrupted decline, with investors buying heavily from a $100-million issue of Illinois tax-exempts and $50-million of Gulf States Utilities Company bonds.
The price of a loaf of bread has gone up 1 to 4 cents for the consumer following announcements of price increases by three of the nationwide bakers.
Nine East Germans, among them five children, have escaped to West Berlin through a tunnel they dug secretly, it was disclosed here today.

The air attacne and an assistant air attache at the United States Embassy intervened yesterday to prevent a correspondent of The New York Times from flying to Neak Luong, the scene of an accidental American bombing, on a Cambodian Air Force helicopter.
George W. Jaques, a consulting partner in the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley McCloy, died Tuesday at his home, 2829 Bronson Road, Fairfield, Conn. He was 86 years old.

The Big Eight Conference dealt the University of Oklahoma football team, ranked No. 2 nationally in 1971 and 1972, a severe blow today by placing the Sooners on probation for two years for recruiting irregularities.
Vice President Agnew has always been a blunter, more direct man--at least in public-than his boss, President Nixon.
Five firebombs were hurled at separate targets near here today in incidents officials believe were connected with the continuing grape labor strife in the San Joaquin Valley.
Special State Prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari is investigating alleged criminal violations involving Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo, according to sources close to the investigation.
Four black residents of Westchester went to Federal Court today to challenge the legality of Government grants in the Town of New Castle on the grounds of discrimination.

As members of the Senate Watergate committee scattered wear ily toward their home states today, the committee's investigators began to study 7,573 pages of testimony in search of po tential cases of criminal perjury.

SHERBROOKE, Nova Scotia -- For mile upon mile toward the end of a thousand-mile automobile trip from Massachusetts, fog enveloped the rocky, cove-indented, tree-lined Atlantic Coast of Nova Scotia, but inspiring one to push on was the St. Mary's River, one of the province's best summer salmon streams.

The Concorde supersonic airliner will make its first visit to the United States next month with the twin objective of blunting American opposition and starting a sales drive.

Ljubomir Ljubojevic barely clung to a half-point lead in the Interzonal tournament for world-championship aspirants after falling prey to a wild rook sacrifice by David Bronstein of the U.S.S.R. and going down to defeat on the black side of an Alekhine Defense in Round 11.

Vilhelm Moberg, the novelist, was found dead near his summer home outside Stockholm today. He was 74 years old. His wife reported him missing earlier in the day, and the police found him, apparently drowned, in a dressing gown in the water.

The entire crew of 14 on the South African trawler Harvest Dealmar were feared drowned after the vessel was apparently involved in a collision with an unidentified tanker yesterday, the trawler's owners said here.

Kim Dae Jung, a self-exiled opponent of President Park Chung Hee of South Korea, was reported to have been abducted from his Tokyo hotel today by five unidentified Koreans.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation, despite its involvement in the Watergate scandal, is enjoying broad, but declining popularity, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

Former State Senator James M. Turner, Republican of Gloucester, testified for more than two hours before a state grand jury today in connection with an alleged plot to fix a parole for a state prison inmate.
Vice President Agnew is suddenly contending with some of the same complex and controversial legal questions that have been taxing President Nixon and his lawyers for months.
A race that recalls an event that is famous in the annals of Saratoga, the Jim Dandy, had its 10th running today.

The total number of reported serious crimes dropped last year for the first time in 17 years but violent crimes-murder, assault and rape-continued to rise, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

BEIRUT--Oil interests here speculate that the recent vetE by United States of the antiIsrael resolution in the United Nations may have placed in jeopardy a multimillion dollar development program by Aramco to increase oil production from Saudi Arabia.

The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market declined sharply yesterday in continued light trading. Brokers blamed the increasing higher interest rates for the weakness and predicted that more rate rises could be expected soon.
The Watergate special prosecution force confirmed today that it had shifted one of its men to strengthen its investigation of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
On the first pitch yesterday at Yankee Stadium, the Yankees lost Fritz Peterson. On the last pitch, they won the game.

Abraham Pletman, founder and chairman of the board of the Lafayette Radio Electronics Corporation of Syosset, L.I., died yesterday at his home, 2 Fifth Avenue, after a brief illness. He was 73 years old.

Attorney General Louis J Lefkowitz will move in court today or tomorrow to set aside last May's election of the community school board in Districl 17 in Central Brooklyn, sources in his office said yesterday.

The police were given sweeping powers of arrest under legislation approved today by President Arthur Chung. The legislation, passed by Parliament last night, was introduced by the government of Prime Minister Forbes Burnham "in the interests of state security and national harmony."

The man who made the most money at Monmouth Race Track today never bet a dime on a horse. Alexander Capps, 57 years old, of Camden, who won $1-million in the New Jerse?? lottery millionaire drawing held at the track, said he had no intention of risking $2 on any horse.

He has played the piano with small groups that toured the country and he liked that but now he has set himself up in business here and he calls himself Tom The Framer. That is because he frames pictures and he learned how to do it by working in a number of art galleries. Also, he studied at the Art Students League.

Investment trusts established for the four children of the late Samuel Bronfman, founder of the world's largest distiller, were disclosed yesterday to have joined a group of pur chasers making a tender offer to buy up to one million shares of Signal Companies, Inc., for $23 a share.
In the glass top of a pinball machine the figures start to materialize, like emanations from the mind of a player obsessed with a game that can only end in "TILT."

SERENE SCENES It's high August and hot. You're stuck in the city. For a quick escape to country vistas--waterfalls, lakes, forests, grist mills, mountains, streams--go direct to the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West at 77th Street (873-3400).
HARTFORD, Aug. 8-It is a typical American sidewalk scene--the construction workers drink their beer, eat their sandwiches and eye the women parading bv on their lunch hour.
Jon Matlack, who had been pitching well and losing much of this season, pitched brilliantly and won tonight as he fired a two-hitter in a 1-0 decision over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

Bill Freehan holds a Bachelor of Science degree in history from the University of Michigan. Yet in his chosen career of major league baseball, he has worn the "tools of ignorance" as catcher for the Detroit Tigers for 11 years.
The deletion of one word in a California state law has enabled five young women to become the first midshipwomen in the history of the 44-year-old California Maritime Academy.

The Federal Disaster Assistance Administration opened an office yesterday to receive applications for aid from victims of the flood last week. The administration said the one-stop center in the Somerset School, 303 Somerset Street, North Plainfield, would process requests for loans and temporary housing.

What with empty meat shelves and skyrocketing prices for almost everything else in the supermarket, housewives have little inclination these days to complicate their shopping problems by sitting in judgment on a farm labor dispute whose merits few even pretend to understand.
A Postal service program to encourage the use of airmail has failed and should be modified or curtailed, according to a report by the General Accounting Office.

Music and dogs go handin-hand at the home of Capt. and Mrs, Manuel Rodriguez. Mrs. Rodriguez, a former concert pianist, frequently is either at the keyboard or listening to concertos on her stereo record-plaver.

John Mooring, who was so unnerved in Houston last Friday when informed at the last minute he would be starting at the Jets' right tackle spot in place of Winston Hill, a holdout, still hasn't completely regained his poise.
Rumors of imminent demonetization of large denomination currency notes in India have flooded the banks with large bills and forced the Govern ment to issue repeated denials of any such plans.
