The International Monetary Fund said today it had cleared an arrangement under which The Sudan Government may draw up to $24-million Special Drawing Rights in foreign exchange during the next 12 months.

Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson announced today that as part of his effort to remove the Justice Department from politics, every department employee would henceforth be required to report any conversation about Justice Department matters with outside parties - including Congressmen, their staffs and other governmental officials.
Five firebombs were hurled at separate targets near here today in incidents officials believe were connected with the continuing grape labor strife in the San Joaquin Valley.

Bobby Lee Hunter, who fought his way to boxing fame while serving a prison sentence, was paroled yesterday. The 23-year-old flyweight won his freedom in a two-minute hearing before the South Carolina Probation and Parole Board after serving six years of an 18-year sentence for manslaughter.

A man between 55 and 60 years of age jumped off a Staten Island ferryboat last night about 200 yards off St. George, S.I., the police reported. He was still missing early this morning after extensive searches by the Coast Guard and the Police Department.

Handel's "Acis and Galatea" is a pastorial masque. Even though it may have been surrounded by elaborate stage machinery when first produced, it is one of Handel's more delicate and graceful pieces, full of murmuring felicities as well as such bravura coloratura arias as the basso's "Ruddier Than the Cherry" (the one bloodand-thunder piece of singing in the otherwise quiet work).
Harold Levine, president of Levine, Huntley, Schmidt, was watching television the other night (as a good adman should) when he saw a film clip on a news program that aroused his ire.
Henry Kearns, president of the United States ExportImport Bank since 1969, confirmed yesterday that he planned to resign and return to private business in southern California.
Connecticut's six-member Congressional delegation has submitted legislation calling for a study of and restructuring of rail service in the Northeast.
The Ladies Professional Golf Association's appeal in its law suit with Jane Blalock was disallowed Monday, a lawyer for the golfer announced yesterday.

A 50-year-old man being held for psychiatric observation before trial on a shoplifting charge hanged himself with a bedsheet from a bar in his cell at the Manhattan House of Detention yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON -- Suppose that during the trial of Daniel Ellsberg a friend or relation of Ellsberg's had had a little talk with the trial judge, William Matthew Byrne Jr. He asked whether Judge Byrne would be interested in a job paying $42,500 a year, good for life and carrying great influence and prestige in American life. He did not make a firm offer but indicated that he might later-after the trial.
The stock market, which traditionally abhors uncertainty, suffered a substantial decline yesterday in the face of uncertainties on the money-rate, economic and political fronts.
A 28-year old advertising copywriter at Macy's was stabbed to death at lunchtime yesterday in the entry of her Greenwich Village apartment building after she resisted an attempt to snatch her puse.

From mid1969 to February of 1971, at the direction of the President, the F.B.I. tapped the home telephones of 17 men four news -- men and 13 Government officials -- to find out why classified information had appeared in the press and to prevent future leaks.

Angelo DeCarlo, a one-time powerful New Jersey Mafia leader, failed to meet the Government's 10 A.M. deadline today to pay a $20,000 fine imposed when he was sentenced to a Federal penitentiary in 1970 for extortion. He contended that he had no assets.

The Department of Housing and Urban Development reported today that total applications nd construction starts under H.U.D.-Federal Housing Administration mortgage insurance programs were higher in June than in May but sharply below the level in June of last year.

Lawyers for Texasgulf, Inc., charged today that the Canadian Government--through its Canadian Development Corporation -- had conspired with that nation's largest mining company to attempt to take over Texasgulf.

The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered today an investigation of a proposal by Pan American World Airways that would tighten fare payment requirements during holiday periods for travelers in the mainland to Puerto Rico and Virgin Island routes.

Ireland's new Ambassador to the United States will be John Gerald Molloy, a 57year-old diplomat who was Dublin's man in London from 1964 to 1970. Since then he has been assistant secretary to the department of foreign affairs.
A court order to stop the American bombing of Cambodia was overturned here yesterday by a 2-to-1 decision of the United States Court of Appeals.

The Health Services Administration announced yesterday the names of 10 restaurants and food stores charged with violating the health code. If the reported violations are not corrected by the time of a final inspection, the places are subject to closing.

A stubborn sentiment among small farmers against the American-sponsored program to eradicate opium poppy planting in Turkey is being encouraged by the promises of local politicians that the ban will he repealed.

The nation's top economic planners have split into three camps of thought as grain prices again reached historic highs yesterday on Midwest exchanges. Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz held steadfast to his belief that a bumper harvest this autumn will check soaring food prices and said so again in a speech in Florida yesterday.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday announced formation of an interagency city task force to deal with the problem of sexual assaults.

Saudade of West Germany won the third race today in the Admiral's Cup series, Britain's premier yachting event, successfully holding off Prime Minister Edward Heath's Morning Cloud. The West German craft finished nearly three minutes ahead of the British yacht on corrected time for the 35-mile test in the Solent between the Isle of Wight and the English mainland.

Each weekday morning at 8:40, 41 Japanese teachers gather in underground seminar rooms at the Woodrow Wilson School for Public and International Affairs for another lesson in American life and language.
Governor Cahill signed a bill into law today that enables commercial and savings banks to open branch offices anywhere in the state.

The Interstate Commerce Commisston today suspended, pending further investigation, a 20-cent fare increase requested by PATH, the Port Authority-Trans Hudson rail commuter line between New York and New Jersey.

President Ferdinand E. Marcos acknowledged a serious shortage of rice and cereal in the Philippines today by ordering the military to take control of all cereal stocks and arrest all hoarders and price-manipulators.
The four stage productions of. the Mercer Arts Center forced out of their theaterworkshop site by the collapse of the Broadway Central Hotel have been relocated.
The state police blocked roads as far north as the Canadian border today and reinforced ground patrols around Witherbee in the effort to track down an elusive ex-convict wanted for murder.
John Alexander of Australia and Sharon Walsh of San Rafael, Calif., scored upsets in tonight's third round in the $75,000 Western tennis championships.

President Allende has evidently decided, for the second time in nine months, to bring high-ranking military officers into his Cabinet in an effort to arrest the slide toward chaos and civil war in Chile. Many Chilean democrats who have little in common with Dr. Allende's Popular Unity Government will nonetheless share the reservations of his Socialist party about this reliance on the armed forces to help resolve a political crisis.

Three veterans told the Senate Armed Services Committee today that while serving in Vietnam they participated either in the designation of North Vietnamese and Vietcong hospitals as bombing targets or in the actual destruction of them.
Alfred A. Knopf, one of the most prominent figures in American publishing, has stepped down as head of the publishing house he founded in 1915 to become its chairman emeritus.
Zhores A. Medvedev, well-known Soviet geneticist and dissident writer. has been deprived of his citizenship and told not to return to his homeland.

Vice President Agnew's reference at his news conference today to a tribe offer apparently referred o an incident in 1966 when he informed the press that he had teen offered a $200,000 campaign contribution by gambling interests in southern Maryland.
A 28-year-old advertising copywriter at Macy's was stabbed to death at lunchtime yesterday in the entry of her Greenwich Village apartment building after she resisted an attempt to snatch her purse.
The price of a loaf of bread has gone up 1 to 4 cents for the consumer following announcements of price increases by three of the nationwide bakers.

Richard Kisonak, former newspaper reporter, whose story of living with the knowledge of his terminal illness brought him wide attention last winter, died yesterday at a Lewiston hospital. He was 44 years old.

Five persons were injured yesterday when gas exploded in the basement of a Greenwich Village townhouse at 111 Bedford Street, near Christopher, causing extensive damage inside the three-story red brick building.

Angelo DeCarlo, a one-time powerful New Jersey Mafia leader, failed to meet the Government's 10 A.M. deadline today to pay a $20,000 fine imposed when he was sentenced to a Federal penitentiary in 1970 for extortion. He contended that he had no assets.

8:05-10 A.M., WNCN. String Trio No. 1 in B flat, Schubert; Symphony in D, Salieri; Tales of Hoffmann Overture, Offenbach; Introduction and Fandango, Boccherini; Symphony No, 2, Borodin; Symphony No. 83 in G minor. Haydn.
The Paragon Securities Company, a financially troubled bond house, has been placed in involuntary bankruptcy, it was disclosed yesterday.
Turkish authorities freed on $3,571 bail today an American woman jailed along with five other women and a man for eight months in Anatolia on hashish - smuggling charges.

The city received Federal Court permission yesterday to represent 200 to 300 localities throughout the United States in its civil antitrust action that charges the General Motors Corporation with monopolizing the sale of buses for municipal use.

"Everybody's wearing it," said Patricia Bugnet, a French student, strolling down the Avenue Montaigne in Paris last week. "It makes you look pretty."
Two divers cut into the hull of the sunken luxury liner Andrea Doria today in hopes of reaching the estimated $4-million worth of treasure they expected to find inside.

Jim Palmer says he will continue to wear a pair of faded, hand-me-down orange socks as long as he keeps winning. The Baltimore Orioles pitcher, on a seven-game winning streak, has another superstition -- his Watergate bug, one of 2,000 coins minted in the wake of the Watergate scandal.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday designated one of its senior officers, A. Gerdes Kuhbach, as its new acting executive director.

You would have thought Al Perra, the 59-year old boat steward at the Palisades Interstate Park's boat basin on the Hudson River had struck gold. His eyes gleamed with pleasure as he watched a truck deliver high-test gasoline.

The Administration fight against inflation will be predicated on elimination of controls and achieving a better balance between supply and demand, Frederick B. Dent, Secretary of Commerce said yesterday.

Earl Scruggs, who appears at the Schaefer Music Festival on Wednesday, figures that about 1960 he was stale. "Practically playing the same numbers every night and had been for the previous 15 years," he recalled last week.
The World Bank announced today it would lend $42-million of a total $65.9-million to help Tehran, Iran, relieve its traffic congestion by improving bus transport.

A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn signed an order yesterday at the request of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to show cause why the election of a community school board in the Crown Heights-Flatbush section should not be overturned because of fraud and a new election be called as soon as possible.
Maximilian Mintz, a retired tax accountant and lawyer, who was senior partner in the New York accounting firm of Pattterson, Teele Dennis until 1969, died Tuesday at the Washington Hospital Center.

To the Editor: It was with substantial agreement and great interest that I read your July 27 editorial concerning our judicial convention system. However, must we conclude that we should scrap the elective method and adopt some sort of appointment method?
The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $911-million, up 13 per cent from the year earlier $806-million.

It is 6:30 on a typical, sweltering midsummer Friday evening at chaotically crowded Penn Station. Amtrak's Train 184, the 6:10 to Boston is still stalled on Track 12. It is running late as usual, like the "crack" Merchants Limited before it.
Helen Reddy topped the bill at Wednesday's Schaefer Music Festival concert in Central Park with the builtin insurance of a new television series and a superhit, "I Am Woman," behind her.

Norman Lear, executive pro'ducer of the Columbia Broadcasting System television show "Maude," charged yesterday that "apparent pressure from anti-abortion forces" had driven away most of the potential commercial sponsorship for

Two hundred homosexuals marched on the West 20th Street police station last night to protest alleged police harassment. They came away with promises from the acting precinct commander to ease what he said had been "friction" between some homosexuals and individual officers.
Gold tumbled in Europe's financial centers today as the dollar continued to strengthen. At the same time, France announced a loosening of exchange controls that could further help the dollar.
H. Calvin Kuhl, pioneer radio and television producer and former vice president of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, died Tuesday at the age of 66.

The Pacific Northwest Bell Telephone Company yesterday said an executive committee of directors had approved a previously-announced offering of 6,220,199 additional common shares in a rights offering. The offering, to be made Sept. 4, provides holders with one right for each share held of record Aug. 20.
Gold issues turned lower while paper and other naturalresource groups showed some strength yesterday during a slow and downward-trending market.

Holly Hughes had his first big thrill in horse racing in 1916 when the colt he saddled, George Smith, won the Kentucky Derby. Since then the 85year-old trainer, who has been with the Sanford family, has had a succession of outstanding moments. But today he enjoyed a thrill second only to his 1916 Derby success.

A Consulting engineering company involved in the investigation of Vice President Agnew is also under inquiry in Florida. Speculators there made several hundred thousand dollars profit by taking options on land where an extension of a Florida turnpike was to be built at Miami.
Joseph F. Brown, a founder of the English-language newspaper Brazil Herald and an active member of Rio's American community for many years, died here yesterday. His age was 91.

The Lone Star Gas Company of Dallas and its former vice president, Edgar Allen Brown, denied today reports that Mr. Brown or the company had given a $150,000 contribution to President Nixon's re-elction campaign in 1972.
BROADWAY BEAUTY AND BARBER SUPPLY INC., sale at wholesale of beauty and barber supplies, 280 South Broadway, Yonkers, N.Y. Liabilities, $11,341; assets, none.

The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.
The biggest sale of oil and gas leases on state-owned land in a quarter of a century has been set for Oct. 2 by Land Commissioner Robert L. Armstrong.

"Although remarks made by others in conversations with the President may arguably be part of a criminal plan on their part, the President's participation in these conversations was in accordance with his constitutional duty to see that the laws are faithfully executed."
The Chicago Board of Trade was a scene of near bedlam yesterday as wheat buyers bid up all deliveries to limit highs for the ninth consecutive session a few minutes after the opening.
After winning seven classes in a row during two shows, Robin Ann Rost's Wigg's Bar finally was beaten today at the Sussex County horse show.

Argentina has settled into a period of deep confusion and inertia, in which even hardened politicians acknowledge that only one man, Juan Domingo Peron, appears to be in command of crucial decisions that will determine the political course of the country.
Governor Rockefeller made a strong and apparently successful appeal to Theodore W. Kheel yesterday to support the proposed $3.5-billion transportation bond issue.

By now, a sampling of tne Roundabout Theater has become one of the most rewarding Off Broadway treks in town. But this estimable repertory unit is marking time, in an interesting way in its double-bill of Strindberg's "Miss Julie" and Christopher Frank's "The Death of Lord
Orange County officials were directed today by the Clifornia Board of Equalization to examine the property tax assessment on President Nixon's seaside estate at San Clemente.

Mrs. Lucy Richardson Lythgoe, the widow of Albert M. Lythgoe, former curator of the department of Egyptology at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died today at a nursing home in Killingly. She was 94 years old and lived at Casa de Camno here.
The American Motors Corporation said today that it would seek Government approval for an average price increase of $55 on 1974 model cars.

When Joey Jackson was at New Mexico State, the college sports publicity director dreamed up the name "Mad Mountain" for him after a local Indian legend. Jackson, however, doesn't care about the nickname that much.
The Department of Agriculture lowered today its estimate of this year's grain production, and an official of the agency acknowledged that this would put new upward pressure on food prices.

The Japanese police have placed a watch on seaports and air terminals to forestall any attempt to smuggle a prominent South Korean politician, believed to have been abducted from his Tokyo hotel yesterday, out of the country.
Any artist whose ancestral tradition runs back through Thomas Rowlandson to William Hogarth has tough competition to face even if he doesn't mean to set himself up for comparison with his forebears.

It is rare that a serious bridge player can say to himself, likt two of the characters in "Ruddigore," that "It doesn't really matter, matter, matter, matter, matter." If he is playing rubber bridge, he has his cash positions to consider.

Lawyers for New York City went to Federal Court yesterday to challenge the state's investigation of the criminal justice system here. The challenge came in a suit filed by the City Corporation Counsel for Corrections Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm against the State Commission of Investigation.
The Evert sisters, top-seeded Chris and 15-year-old Jeanne, advanced to the semifinals of the $75,000 Western tennis championships today.

Six Greeks who have denied exploding bombs in Athens and plotting to overthrow the Government, were accused in testimony today of planning to execute Government officials and bomb public utilities and diplomatic cars.

The Royal Dutch-Shell Group of Companies attained an increase of 160.3 per cent in second-quarter net income on a sales gain of 24.5 per cent, the mid-year report disclosed yesterday. Half-year results were also significantly higher than a year earlier.

President Nixon "hit the ceiling" when he learned that Vice President Agnew was under investigation in an alleged Maryland kickback scheme and tried to talk Mr. Agnew out of holding a news conference, White House sources said today.

The years melted away tonight and there were Joe Louis and Max Schmeling surrounded by autograph seekers who were men in their 50's and 60's, some businessmen, some ex-boxers, all looking for autographs and a chance to shake the hand that shook the hand.

Winning numbers drawn on Aug. 9 were: NEW YORK 390498 Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.

A Federal commission, declaring that violent crimes "threaten the very existence of a humane and civilized society," proposed today that the possession of handguns be limited to the police and military personnel by 1983.
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that the difficulties confronting the nation were only a "passing phase" and that there was "no cause for panic."

Here is one cover-up the Administration admits to: From the spring of 1969 until this week, the White House and a variety of Federal agencies operated under what they term "a basic policy decision" to withhold information about all tax-funded improvements on the private residences of President Nixon.

James C. Bolton Jr., a Secret Service agent assigned last year to guard Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, the Democratic Presidential nominee, agreed to pass political information to the White House, according to a confidential memorandum cited tonight by The Washington Post.

"He who sows wind reaps storms," the Chilean Opposition likes to say in its own variation of the Biblical saying when referring to the troubled attempts of President Salvador Allende Gossens to bring socialism to this country.

The Senate Watergate committee filed suit in Federal District Court today to force President Nixon to make available the White House tapes the Senators believe may establish the truth about the political burglary and the subsequent cover-up.

Rough seas forced the Maryland marine police to call an early halt today to search operations for Dr. George A. Wiley, the former head of the National Welfare Rights Organization who is missing and presumed drowned in the Chesapeake Bay.
President Salvador Allende Gos sens announced the formation of a "Cabinet of National Se curity" today and gave it the mission of restoring economic and political order in the country.
Miss Mary Katherine Egan, president of the Springfield City Council, was married here this afternoon to U.S. Representative Edward Patrick Boland, also of Springfield.
Those were not flies that infested parts of Northern New Jersey by the millions last week. They were hyalopterus pruni.
Louis J. Haag, a certified public accountant and a partner in Touche Ross Co., died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, in Paris, where he had been on vacation. He lived in Valley Stream. L.I.
MILWAUKEE--Only a very inexperienced man would rush in at this point with a series of sweeping prescriptions to treat the deep-seated ills of our Government that have been disclosed by Watergate.

The United States Government allegedly withheld millions of dollars in foreign aid to Ecuador in 1971 and 1972 at the request of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, according to the Aug. 11 issue of Business Week magazine.

For several hours today, a small crowd of White Plains residents and a handful of utility company workmen watched as a 252-year-old house was moved from the path of a new highway to a hill overlooking the downtown rehabilitation project.
The Internal Revenue Service is abolishing a special division that for four years has investigated liberal and radical organizations and their sponsors for possible violations of tax law.
A multimillion dollar damage suit has been filed in United States District court against Nashville-based Genesco Inc., by a former principal stockholder alleging violation of Federal securities laws.

Vander Barbette, a worldrenowned trapeze artist of the nineteen-twenties and thirties, died Sunday at his home here He was 68 years old. Mr. Barbette leaves a sister, Mary Cahill, with whom he lived, and a half-brother, Sam Loving of Newton, Mass.

A dispute is simmering behind the scenes in the State Health Department over whether patients in hospitals, nursing homes and old-age homes should be told how clean - or dirty - the kitchens are in the institutions.
Henry A. Kissinger will not make his planned trip to Peking this month, diplomatic sources said here today.

A collective sigh and a television click could be heard across the land as the first phase of the Senate Watergate hearings ended. The public could again return to work in the afternoon and get a little shut-eye at night.
The Evert sisters, top-seeded Chris and 15-year-old Jeanne, advanced to the semifinals of the $75,000 Western tennis championships today.
LEE, Mass.--When Walter Terry, the new director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival,. first visited here in 1934, the outhouse on the premises was named "The New Yorker."
An assault and battery warrant was issued here today for a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent accused of assaulting a legal worker for the Wounded Knee defense committee Monday night.

The defense began today its efforts to crack the testimony of the Government's star witness, William W. Lemmer, in the trial of seven antiwar veterans and a supporter charged with plotting assault on the Republican National Convention with automatic weapons, slingshots and crossbows.

The agency of the Government most closely involved with home-mortgage finance today painted a grim picture of the current mortgage situation: interest rates of 9 per cent or more, money rushing out of the thrift institutions, which are the main mortgage lenders, and some danger of a drying up of mortgage money at any price.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday designated one of its senior officers, A. Gerdes Kuhbach, as its new acting executive director.

A worldwide survey by correspondents of The New York Times in the last week has indicated that although foreign leaders and public figures now seem to take the Watergate scandal more seriously than they did a few months ago, the affair has not so far cut deeply into their widespread support for Mr. Nixon's course in foreign policy.

LOW KEY The modest conceit that the Museum of Modern Art calls "Summergarden" will feature an hour of songs tonight and tomorrow night at about 8 o'clock in a two-guitar concert by Carl Rosenstock, a young folk singer and song writer, and Richard Levine.

Gary Adelman of Roslyn, L. I., upset Chris Sylvan of Fresno, Calif., 6-4, 6-4, then turned back Bob Glickman of Brooklyn, 6-1, 6-1, to reach the semifinals of the Columbia tennis championships for juniors and boys yesterday at Baker Field. Adelman was the only unseeded player to advance in the 18-year-old division.

Although the condition of the Skylab space station has stabilized and the orbiting astronauts are apparently out of any immediate danger, work goes on day and night at the space center here to be ready, just in case, for the first space rescue mission.
Dr. George Bugliarello, dean of engineering at the University of Illinois, Chicago Circle, will become the first president of the Polytechnic Institute of New York on Oct. 15.

Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, appeared yesterday to be osing his battle for immediate full union with Egypt. He was reliably reported to have bowed to Egyptian demands for a gradual procedure that would take years and could be abanloned before completion.
Continued concern by investors over rising interest rates and the inflationary spiral helped weaken prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market.

This is the time of the year when back-to-school marketeers begin rewing up for their full-scale onslaught on the nation's student body. So yesterday the Bic Pen Corporation unveiled a new fall campaign for its ballpoint and porous-point pens.
What this town has been hoping for recently is. somebody, anybody in power, who would stand up and give plain answers to hard questions, and Vice President Agnew has finally done it.
Lieut. Comdr. William M. Bowlin, U.S.N., retired who was Admiral Richard E. Byrd's personal navigator on his second Antarctic expedition, died Tuesday in his home here.

A 39-year-old heroin addict with a long history of arrests on rape, robbery and burglary charges was arraigned yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court on a homicide charge in the knife slaying of Roberta Block, a copywriter for Macy's, who apparently resisted a robbery attempt Monday afternoon in the hallway of her apartment building in Greenwich Village.
Gamblers dropped $804million at Nevada's legalized casinos during the last fiscal year a rise of 18.6 per cent over the previous year, the state announced yesterday.

The police said today that a 17-yearold high school dropout had told them that he and a 33-year-old man he later killed had been involved in more than 25 slaying. The bodies of 17 teen-agers have been uncovered in a rented boat shed here. Late today two more bodies were found near a lake development 120 miles to the northeast.

The General Motors' Corporation will build new assembly plants in Memphis, Tenn., and Oklahoma City, Okla., G.M. chairman Richard C. Gerstenberg said today.
The Federal Government will issue make-believe electronic paychecks to about 20,000 Air Force personnel this fall in a test aimed at reducing growing usage of paper checks.

The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the week totaled an estimated 16.1-billon ton-miles, 9.3 per cent above the corresponding week last year.
Eldridge Small apparently has convinced the New York Giants he can play cornerback better than he can catch passes. But the question is: Can he convince them enough to win a starting position?
Two pipe bombs were found yesterday at construction sites in Manhattan and in Brooklyn but police bomb squads were able to remove both bombs before they exploded.
The State Police late last night captured John W. Brown, the suspect wanted for the fatally stabbing of the Woodbine police chief and a gas station attendant.

Two dozen women disrupted traffic at East 181st Street and Crotona Avenue in the Bronx for 20 minutes yesterday afternoon to demand that a traffic signal or stop sign be installed at the intersection.

Domenico Savino, a composer and orchestra director, died in Doctors Hospital on Wednesday. He was 91 years old and lived at 320 West End Avenue.
FORT RILEY, Kan.--The platoon sang as it marched through the searing heat. The lieutenant colonel stopped, grinned and said, "Singing, we're getting somewhere with this outfit."

The United States Army command in Heidelberg, in its first official response to complaints from within its ranks about widespread activities by military intelligence, announced today that a program of "counterdissidence" by the Eighth Infantry Division had been "rescinded" because it was "inappropriate."
An oddly retrospective and conservative air has been dominating the Festival of Contemporary Music this week at Tanglewood. Last night's concert did nothing to change that atmosphere.

Whether or not Vice President Agnew is drawn further into the burgeoning scandal in his home state of Maryland, the Federal investigation of alleged kickbacks and bribery there will put the spotlight more fiercely than ever on the shocking way in which political campaigns are financed.

The National League president, Charles (Chub) Feeney, turned down today an appeal by Tim Foli of the Montreal Expos, the first ever in major league baseball, and suspended the infielder for three days because of a bumping incident in St. Louis on June 18.

Guy Kelcey, a pioneer traffic engineer and a founder of the international engineering firm of Edwards Kelcey in Newark, died today at his home here. He was 84 years old and lived at 739 Highland Avenue.
Governor Cahill issued an urgent appeal today to President Nixon and Federal officials for emergency aid to prevent a possible halt to freight and passenger rail service in New Jersey by the faill.
The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced a five-day suspension in trading of securities of the Coastal States Gas Producing Company of Houston, Tex.

With less than a month to go before the state's stringent narcotics law goes into effect, a city official who is coordinating implementation of the program here said yesterday that as many as 200 trial parts including judges and court personel - would be needed in New York City, rather than the 100 being projected for the entire state.

The voice of a "very seared" boy resumed broad. casting on a citizen's band frequency in the foothills of central New Mexico today.

Don Iverson, a 27-year-old Wisconsin professional playing his first major championship, and Al Geiberger, the 1966 winner, scored 67 in the first round of the Professional Golfers' Association championship today as the big names trailed.
The New Jersey Civil Rights Division announced an agreement today giving it the power to oversee faculty hiring at Rutgers University to prevent discrimination against minority groups and women.

Irene Hamar, a well-known sculptor and painter, who in private life was the wife of Henry P. de Vries, a noted international lawyer, died yesterday at University Hospital of complications following pneumonia.
At the bottom of a sheet of paper Milton Schaffner, an inspector for the city's Buildings Department, wrote in red pencil, "Hazardous."

Muhammad Ali is coming to New York this week to show a national television audience that his demountable jaw is practically as good as new. Not necessarily good as an instrument for measuring the kinetic energy in Ken Norton's fist (one half its mass times velocity squared), but useful for chomping collard greens, growing whiskers or framing the words, "I am the greatest."

The Chinese Communist party will convene its 10th national congress next week and use the occasion for the first outright denunciation of Lin Piao, the man named as Chairman Mao's successor by he last party congress in 1969, authoritative sources disclosed today.

In the city's first major layoffs in the current beef shortage, 700 workers are being furloughed tonight with closing of 25 to 30 meat companies and reduced operations by others, according to Butchers Local 174.

Thousands of shoppers thronged the new two-level, air-conditioned Staten Island Mall in the New Springville section yesterday after the formal opening of the nineblock-long complex of stores and businesses.
Allan L. Fletcher, a medical writer, editor and publisher, died of cancer yesterday at University Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 206 Lakeview Avenue, Leonia, N.J.

Archie O. Joslin, a director and former president of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., a leading manufacturer of textiles, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 25 West 54th Street.

The United States Army command in Heidelberg, in its first official response to complaints from within its ranks about widespread activities by military intelligence, announced today that a program of "counterdissidence" by the Eighth Infantry Division had been "rescinded" because it was "inappropriate."
Donald Peers, a popular singer here during the late nineteen-forties and early fifties, died in a Brighton nursing home today. He was 64 years old.
John Meier, a witness before the grand jury that indicted Clifford Irving as the author of a fraudulent Howard Hughes autobiography, was arrested today on tax-violation charges.
A rescue vessel plucked an American balloonist, Bob Sparks, out of the Atlantic today after thunderstorms forced him to abandon a flight to Europe, a Canadian military spokesman said.
Benjamin Mandel, who specialized in research into Communism for the Federal Government, died here yesterday. He was 82 years old.

The White House disavowed today any intention of imposing a mandatory fuel allocation program in "the foreseeable future" but issued an implicit warning to the oil industry by publishing a tentative mandatory plan.
American air strikes killed Cambodian Government soldiers and civilians in at least five bombing accidents in the last two weeks, Cambodian military sources said today.
Representative Ogden R. Reid greeted a group of Jewish emigrants from the Soviet Union at the railroad station in Vienna yesterday.
Despite Mayor Lindsay's orders for stepped-up building inspections following the collapse of the old Broadway Central Hotel, city officials say the move will do little to avert future collapses.
France's overall gold and convertible reserves rose by 53 million francs (roughly $12.6million) in July to 47.1 billion francs (about $11.2 billion), the Finance Ministry said today.

VicePresident Agnew flew off, on vacation today to Frank Sinatra's oasis in the California desert, assured by voters' telegrams and political friends that his news conference yesterday on the criminal investigation involving him had made the best of an awkward situation.
Two representatives of the East German Government conferred today with State Department officials on procedures for negotiating diplomatic relations.

Former Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird specifically approved falsified reporting of the Nixon Administration's secret B-52 raids in Cambodia in 1969, a highly classified Pentagon memorandum showed today.
The Department of Agriculture lowered today its estimate of this year's grain production, and an official of the agency acknowledged that this would put new upward pressure on food prices.

Bill Sharp, a rookie outfielder, hit his third home run of the season with two out in the ninth inning to carry the Chicago White Sox to a 5-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers in Tiger Stadium last night.

A 29-year-old man was stabbed to death last night in his apartment at 330 Third Avenue near 24th Street, the police reported. His body was found amid broken lamps and general disarray at 10 P.M., about two hours after the victim had been seen by neighbors entering the biulding with a male companion.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 205.2 from 195.1 last week.

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced today it is enlarging its tanker fleet by 40 per cent to bring more crude oil to market. The expansion will raise the fleet to 3,6 million deadweight tons. The company is buying four and chartering three tankers that can haul enough crude in one voyage to keep all Indiana Standard's 10 domestic refineries operating a full week.

Policemen today arrested the second-ranking member of the anti-Governmentguerrilla movement led by Gen. George Grivas, who has sworn to overthrow Archbishop Makarios, the President of Cyprus.

Mrs. Carl Chadsey Jr. or the host club, the defending champion, and Mrs. Thomas J. Hory of Winged Foot, won today's semifinal matches in the 48th annual Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association championship over the 5.775-yard, par-36, 37 - 73 Round Hill Club course.

Governor Rockefeller made a strong and apparently successful appeal to Theodore W. Kheel yesterday to support the proposed $3.5-billion transportation bond issue. A 16-year-old boy and several friends set out this morning to break the world record for the longest nonrepetitious keyboard composition by playing nonstop a computer-written 100-hour piece composed solely of all 40,320 possible permutations of the C major scale.

The Senate Watergate committee filed suit in Federal District Court today to force President Nixon to make available the White House tapes the Senators believe may establish the truth about the political burglary and the subsequent cover-up.

Governor Rockefeller yesterday defended the computer company of H. Ross Perot, the Texas multi-millionaire, and ordered an investigation of "the motivation behind" recent allegations against the company and its $125,000 contract to study computerization of the state's welfare systems.

Former Justice Arthur J. Goldberg recommended today that other former Supreme Court Justices listen to White House tape recordings on Watergate and determine which portions should be given to investigators.

Corporate bond prices extended Wednesday's gains yesterday in moderately active trading. Dealers attributed the improvement, which found prices for secondary issues firm at the opening and closing slightly below their highs for the day, to the absence of new offerings.

The Skylab astronauts were requested today by Mission Control to share their filet mignon with two spiders named Arabella and Anita so that they can keep up their two months of spinning webs in weightlessness.
President Nixon worked today in the seclusion of his mountaintop retreat on the public response he will make to developments in the Watergate case.

Robert B. McKay, chairman of the city's Board of Correction, yesterday cited the case of "Rudolph D." to illustrate his criticism that defendants encountered long delays in awaiting trial in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

A band concert in the village square is a time-honored summer event almost everywhere in the Western world, and on Tuesday night New York had a special and not always pleasant variation on the theme. The concert took place in a square, all right (Washington), and in a village of sorts (Greenwich), but the music was anything but the usual summer fare.

Residents of this borough of 2,600 population filed into the American Legion Hall tonight to mourn their police chief, Phillip De Santis, who was slain last Monday while trying to arrest a murder suspect.

Former Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird specifically approved falsified reporting of the Nixon Administration's secret B-52 raids in Cambodia in 1969, a highly classified Pentagon memorandum showed today.
A Soviet dissident writer has accused Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany of creating a new Munich by his policy of reconciliation with the Soviet Union.
There are restaurants in Rome where waiters toss the fettucine with golden forks and spoons. These days, they have good reason.

The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor was authorized by Superior Court Judge Herman Michaels in Newark yesterday to resume an investigation of what it has contended are erroneous reports of airline cargo thefts at the three jetports in the metropolitan area.
The Consolidated Edison Company said demand for electricity passed the eight million kilowatt mark for the first time in its history yesterday.

AREA A--Bluefishing remains thin on the entire New Jersey shore, with the general report that there are no blues on the surf and very few outside. One compensation for the area's fishermen is a good run of fluke near Spring Lake.

The Justice Department filed suit today against the nation's two largest tire manufacturers--Goodyear and Firestone--charging that each company separately tried to gain a monopoly of the direct sales of tires to consumers.
American air strikes killed Cambodian Government soldiers and civilians in at least five bombing accidents in the last two weeks, Cambodian military sources said today.

Demonstrating that old precept, he who lives by the 1-0 game dies by the 1-0 game, the New York Mets lost to the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight and moved on to San Francisco for the next stop of their final California tour of the year.

William M. Kunstler and five legal colleagues entered today a second defense motion for mistrial in the Fountain Valley mass ?? The jury has deliberated seven days. Judge Warren H. Young denied a mistrial petition in United States District Court earlier this week.
The third and fourth known victims of the collapse of the old Broadway Central Hotel were pulled yesterday from beneath the brick, plaster and wood wreckage of the former city landmark.

Justice William 0. Douglas of the Supreme Court granted bail today to the so-called Fort Worth Five, a group of Irishborn New Yorkers jailed in Texas since January for refusing to answer a Federal grand jury's questions about illegal gun purchases.
More than 70 people were believed killed when their bus fell into a deep irrigation canal.

Depositors withdrew $600-million out of the nation's savings banks last month, the biggest monthly outflow on record, their industry association reported yesterday. Interest credited to savings accounts last month totaled $175million, producing a net decrease in deposits of $425-million, also a record.
Five dollars may not go very far these days but Peter Westbrook has stretched it all the way from this city's ghetto to the World University Games in Moscow.
East Germany served notice today that it would take action "at the appropriate time" on the vulnerable Berlin transit routes fait a mounting flow of refugees to the West.

In a savage batting demonstration that must have made such former sluggers as Bill Dickey and Moose Skowron think of their playing days when Yankee Stadium's tenants lived up to the name Bronx Bombers, New York defeated the Oakland A's 109, last night.

New England Telephone Telegraph Company yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a rights offering of 6,500,000 common shares on the basis of one share for each six shares held on Sept. 7. The company's stock closed at 32 1/2, down 1/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

The 10th Festival of Contemporary Music at the Berkshire Music Center came to a close last night with an orchestral concert that demonstrated at length how little terseness has come to be valued in some influential composing circles.

It took nearly a quarter of a century, but Charles F. Brannan was a happy man today. It was Mr. Brannan, as Secretary of Agriculture under President Truman who first proposed in 1949 the radically different method of supporting farm income that finally reached fruition in the farm bill signed today.
The Gulf Oil Corporation said yesterday that it had contribute $100,000 in corporate funds to President Nixon's reelection campaign. Such contributions are illegal under Federal law.
President Nixon signed today legislation establishing a fouryear farm program with a new method of subsidizing the main crops.

Government sources said today that Argentina had agreed to ship Uruguay 60,000 tons of wheat despite her own shortage of the cereal. The first Argentine shipment of some 7,500 tons is expected next Monday, the sources said.
Reggie Smith, Boston's controversial outfielder, left Fenway Park last night in the second inning of a game with the California Angels after he had a run-in with fans.

Family, friends and the Air Force paid final tribute today to Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker. In a 15-minute memorial service, about 100 persons listened to a eulogy that praised Mr. Rickenbacker as a man "with deep faith and conviction in all respects of life."

He was called a waddie, a buckaroo or an ranahan. He lived with cattle for weeks at a time. He had no radio, no television and no pickup truck. A saddle was his home, his pillow and his prized possession.
The Skylab 2 astronauts photographed a "truly spectacular" solar eruption of gaseous material today on their first day off in two weeks.

Professional truck drivers are "faced with the dilemma of whether to risk their lives and safety or their livelihood" when confronted with the prospect of driving a vehicle that is in hazardous condition, the Professional Drivers Council charged.

Some early-morning frantic buying of wheat petered out yesterday in the first half hour of trading once prices had jumped the daily limit. With no sellers willing to do business, buying orders remained unfilled for a million bushels or more.
Debbie Austin of Oneida, N. Y., played through heavy wind today for a three-under-par 70 and took the first-round lead in the $30,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.
Prices declined on a broad front yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market.
Dr. Robert K. Cutter, chairman of the board of Cutter Laboratories, Inc., pharmaceutical manufacturers, died here Thursday after a brief illness. His age was 75.

BLUE MOUNTAIN LAKE, N. Y.-A "swarm" of small earthquakes that began to rattle-without damage-this Adirondack resort area a couple of weeks ago has provoked some mild unease among the cottage and motel owners but undisguised enthusiasm among a small band of geologists who have rushed in to turn the wooded area into a huge outdoor laboratory.

An attorney for Dr. Daniel Ellsberg has chided the Senate Watergate committee for failing to challenge what he called "totally false and slanderous" testimony by the former White House aide, John D. Ehrlichman, suggesting that Dr. Ellsberg delivered copies of the Pentagon papers to the Soviet Embassy.
A bank guard was seriously wounded yesterday during a blazing exchange of gunfire in the second holdup of the day in the same bank branch.
Lillian Roxon, an authority on rock music and one of the leading chroniclers of its culture and personalities, died Thursday from the effects of an asthma attack. She was 40 years old.

Many of the nation's biggest banks yesterday raised their prime interest rate from 9 to 9 1/4 per cent, a record. The First National City Bank led the move in raising its base, or minimum, rate on large business loans,

Richard Henry Pratt, architect, landscape designer and author, died at his home this morning after a long illness. He was 81 years old. Mr. Pratt was architectural editor for The Ladies Home Journal for 26 years, from 1936 until his retirement in 1962.

All 55 of thee city's kosher meat markets will be closed next week in protest over "exorbitant price increases" in poultry, veal and lamb because of unavailability of kosher beef caused by the price ceiling.

Jersey's economy will produce a record $50-billion gross state product this year despite a stubborn high 7 per cent unemployment rate, according to Ronald M. Heymann, State Labor and industry Commissioner.

Chileans went serenely about their usual occupations as life appeared almost normal on this sunny winter's day and a grizzled fruit hawker said, "I hope everything's going to be all right, now that the military have taken over."
Barnet Grossman, retired real estate broker and former clothing manufacturer, died yesterday in Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 96 years old and lived at 5001 15th Avenue, Brooklyn.

Greg Larson, who has been in one spot long enough to make critical appraisals, today called the current offensive line for the New York Giants, "the strongest since I've been here."

Cambodian insurgents disguised as refugees slipped into the grounds of Phnom Penh's radio transmitting station today and damaged one of its two generators, reducing its emergency electric power capacity by about half.

This weekend may mark the last appearance of Willie Mays in San Francisco as an active player, just as his pinch-hitting appearance in Los Angeles Thursday night may have been his farewell to Dodger Stadium. Willie batted for Jerry Koosman, leading off the ninth, and grounded out.
The Commonwealth heads of government ended nine days of deliberation here today with a statement supporting majority rule in Rhodesia and expressing "intense concern" about the situation there.
In a dramatic switch of role, the Kashmiri Moslem leader, Sheik Mohammed Abdullah, has announced that he will enter Indian national politics "to serve the entire country" instead of only Kashmir.

The Athens special military court early today imposed 18year and 15-year prison sentences on two of the six royalists on trial for exploding bombs and conspiring against the army-backed Government. The four other defendants received lighter sentences.

Federal investigators subpoenaed today the records of Vice President Agnew's two-year administration as Governor of Maryland and "any and all" financial records dealing with his campaign for the governorship.

On Aug. 2, Patrick J. Buchanan, special consultant to President Nixon, wrote an article on the Op-Ed Page of The Times in which he spoke sharply about the critics of the Administration. He said that "the Watergate crowd cannot hold a candle to its principal accusers in politics and the press."
Chaudhri Fazal Elahi, former speaker of the National Assembly, was named President of Pakistan by the Legislature today.

The Washington office of Senator Jacob K. Javits disclosed yesterday that he had asked for police protection last month after the murder outside Washington of an Israeli diplomat, Col. Yosef Alon.

The death of 10 persons last December in the collision of two airplanes at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport was attributed yesterday to " "failure of the traffic control system to insure separation of aircraft during a period of restricted visibility."
Gasoline , heating oil and other petroleum products will remain under rigid price controls for in indefinite period, the Nixon Administration announced today.
The Cragwood Stable, with the superb assistance of Jorge Velasquez, took both ends of the Bernard Baruch Handicap today.

Israel announced this morning that her air force had intercepted a Middle East Airlines jetliner outside of Beirut last night and forced the plane to fly to a military airfield in Israel. But a military spokesman later conceded that the wrong plane had been seized.

Commissioner Bob Carlson of the American Basketball Association said here yesterday the A.B.A. and National Basketball Association had been authorized by a Federal court order to seek a new merger agreement without Congressional approval. Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo was relieved of his judicial assignment yesterday following his indictment Thursday on charges of perjury and obstruction of governmental administration.

The automobile industry's annual slowdown for its modelyear change-over caused United States auto production to fall by nearly 53,000 units this week, according to Automotive News.
Two French airlines, Air France and U.T.A., announced today that they were halting passenger flights into Cambodia as a safety precaution.
Andy (The Flea) Provan scored three goals tonight as the Eastern Division champion Philadelphia Atoms beat the St. Louis Stars, 5-1.

The order of the Interstate Commerce Commission temporarily suspending a 20-cent fare increase by PATH, the Port Authority Trans-Hudson commuter rail link between New York and New Jersey, provides something more than relief from the runaway cost of living for PATH riders.

Theodore W. Kheel declared yesterday his support for Governor Rockefeller's proposed $3.5-billion transportation bond issue and said he would campaign for it as part of a threepoint transportation program.

A network of roads the Communists have been energetically building in South Vietnam since the American bombing halt in January now stretches over 250 miles from the North Vietnamese border to the central part of the country, American intelligence officials say.

A funeral service for Roberta Herbert, a copywriter for Macy's who was stabbed Wednesday afternoon in the hallway of her apartment building at 494 Hudson Street, in Greenwich Village, while resisting a robbery attempt, will take place in Miami tomorrow.

The series of regional strikes against Canada's railroads continued today as 20,000 workers walked off their jobs in Ontario and another 7,000 were ordered out in British Columbia, Alberta and the Northwest Territories.

The Justice Department filed suit today charging the school district of Omaha, Neb., with maintaining racially segregated schools in violation of the law.

The roar that shook the suburbs tonight wasn't a cheer for a 1:57 4/5 mile that equaled Roosevelt Raceways track record. It was, simply, an audible sigh of relief when the photo showed the heavily favored Sir Dalrae had won the $50,000 pace.

President Nixon signed legislation today extending authority for the Federal Housing Administration to grant lowinterest loans at least until Oct. 1 to ease the current squeeze on home mortgage money.

Donald F. Tucker of Neptune, a former prison guard, has been chosen as the first permanent ombudsmen for the New Jersey penal system. A prisons spokesman said today that Mr. Tucker, 54 years old, would take over the post on Sept. 1.
Greg Larson, who has been in one spot long enough to qualify as a critic, today called the current offensive line for the New York Giants, "the strongest since I've been here."

Thursday night's Mostly Mozart concert was appealingly schizophrenic: early Handel, in genial, old-shoe comfort, followed by late Mozart, ardent and commanding.

To the Editor: President Nixon's claim on almost all public occasions is that "world peace" is his major objective. This now requires, according to his letter of Aug. 3 to Congress, renewed bombing in Cambodia after the cut-off date of Aug. 15.

AN unofficial and very casual survey of midtown New York restaurants during the last week indicates that more people are toting their leftovers home in doggy bags. Better than all of Washington's explanations about the objectives of Phases 1 through 4, this observation describes an actual accomplishment. New York City has practically run out of beef.

Stock prices continued to decline last week in the face of credit-tightening moves by the Federal Reserve Board and spiraling money rates. The Dow-Jones industrial average fell 16% points to finish at 892.38, its lowest closing level in four weeks. A small gain on Monday was the only advancing session during the last two weeks as measured by the blue-chip Dow.

A derelict houseboat burned for more than four hours off a Breezy Point jetty in the Rockaways, Queens, near Rockaway Point last night-too far from shore for the police, too close to shore for the Coast Guard and in seas too rough for the Fire Department's marine unit to do anything about it.

A three-run homer by Tito Fuentes off Ray Sadecki and Ron Bryant's six-hit pitching for his 17th victory were the main elements today in a 4-1 decision the San Francisco Giants scored over the New York Mets.
On this first weekend for the new terminal at Newark International Airport, a computerized schedule board listed identical flights under "arrivals" and "departures."
Grebo, Yoruba, Ibo and Amharic were being spoken in the crowded confines of the People Center of the American Museum of Natural History yesterday afternoon.

What happened to Hank Borowy in 1945 could make many modem major league pitchers shudder. Borowy had a 10-5 won-lost record with the New York Yankees in July, but found himself on the waiver list. Eventually, he was plucked by Chicago and pitched the Cubs into the World Series.
Betty Burfeindt gained eight strokes on the leader, Dehhie Austin, with a course-record-tying 68 today to win the $30,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament with a 54-hole total of 212.
President Zulfikar-Ali Bhutto was tonight elected Prime Minister by a vote of 160 to 28 in the National Assembly. Mr. Bhutto has been President since the end of the war with India in December, 1971.

Elaborate changes have been made around the property storerooms of the New York Police Department these days - changes prompted by the department's own disclosure last December that millions of dollars' worth of heroin and cocaine, including evidence seized in the famous "French Connection" case, had vanished from its custody.
In a few hours now Americans will no longer be killing people in Indochina, or destroying their land. After eight years, the bombing is to stop.

Steve Mizerak, a teacher from Woodbridge, N. J., survived a strong challenge by Luther (Wimpy) Lassiter today to win his fourth straight United States Open pocket billiards-championship. Mizerak, unbeaten in the double-elimination tourney, lost a marathon match that started last night and lasted more than 4 1/2 hours, 150-110, in 22 innings. This meant game 2 of the series would decide the championship.
The number of narcotics addicts on the city's welfare rolls was reported yesterday to have been cut in half in 18 months--from a peak of 32,000 at the start of 1972 to 15,674 last June.
United States planes continued heavy bombing around the Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh, yesterday, three days before the bombing was to be cut off by Congressional action.
Norm Cash Day yesterday was a success for everybody except the 38-year-old first baseman who has worn a Detroit Tiger uniform for 14 seasons.
South Vietnam appears unlikely to intervene militarily on behalf of the Cambo dian Government, informed official sources say.
The West Berlin Supreme Court has ruled that a teen-age girl alleged to have killed her father in East Germany should be handed back to the East German authorities to stand trial.
Delegates from 10 mostly poor African countries met here for two days last week to ponder whether their 12-year-old economic union could and should survive and prosper.
For the first time since 1966, Soviet trotting horses will be racing in the New York area later this month.

The United States Gypsum Company announced yesterday that it had offered to pay $28million to plaintiffs as its share in a class action antitrust suit against major gypsum wallboard makers.

Many states and the Federal Government have various scholarship and loan programs that provide for some forgiveness of repayment if a student fulfills certain requirements such as training for a much needed profession or settling in areas where there is a lack of certain skills.
The whites who rule it call the territory South-West Africa. To the blacks who want to govern it and to the United Nations it is Namibia. A resident of any race is likely to call it just South-West.

The United States national soccer team, with seven American-born players in its line-up for the first time, defeated the national team of Poland, 1-0, yesterday on a goal by Al Trost of the St. Louis Stars of the North American Soccer League.

The active search for a small boy believed lost in New Mexico was ended today. The boy's voice had been heard pleading for help over citizens band radios for five days, but the police said the calls probably were a hoax.

While the picnickers and their sons and wives sported on the grass inside the walls of Green Haven Correctional Facility, other inmates who had not been invited peered through the chain-link fence at the rare burst of gaiety.
The South Vietnamese command today reported continued heavy clashes with Communist troops in the Central Highlands, the adjacent coastal lowlands and the Mekong Delta, below Saigon.
PEKING-India wishes to normalize relations with China. China wishes to normalize relations with India. But two years of Indian diplomatic efforts have left the two Governments as far apart as ever.

Re-entry problems face not only astronauts, but also the fruit growers of the United States. They are up in arms against new safety regulations for farm laborers proposed under the Occupational Safety and Health Act (OSHA) that would set strict standards for farm workers entering orchards that have been sprayed with organophosphorous pesticides.
The last time Joan Crawford traveled with a trunk was in 1955, when she was a passenger aboard the Andrea Doria. "Thats not what sunk the ship," she said. "That didn't happen until the next year."

Almost 2,000 Roman Catholic worshipers, mostly CroatianAmericans, held a religious procession on the West Side yesterday morning to celebrate the presence of the Pilgrim Virgin statue of Our Lady of Fatima in the Archdiocese of New York.
The Security Council will meet tomorrow in an urgent session to debate Israel's attempt to seize Palestinian guerrilla leaders by intercepting an Arab jetliner and forcing it to land in Israel.

Alexander and Betty Bennett were shepherding two children and a shopping cart through a supermarket in the Carrick section of Pittsburgh, an aging neighborhood of modest homes and hard-working people, the kind of place where words such as patriotism and law and order still hold deep meaning.

The Occidental Petroleum Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had received $135-million in cash from the Libyan Government as partial corn pensation for the nationalization of a 51 per cent interest in its Libyan oil assets.
As a boyhood golfer Jack Nicklaus set his goal to be the best in the world. That meant equaling the record of his idol, the late Bobby Jones, who won 13 major championships.
Parents of two young boys, both believed to be among 23 murder victims, contend that the police ignored their sons' disappearance and listed at least seven other missing youths as runaways.

The State Commission on Cultural Resources has proposed a broad program of selfhelp and public assistance to ease the employment and financial problems of many of the state's 50,000 artists and writers.
The body of Sir Moses Montefiore, father of modern Jewish settlement here, will be returned to Jerusalem a century after his death, the Israeli Government said today.

What race team can play it so cool that its crewmen can polish the car and replace a scraped identification number between heats? Mark Donohue's crew, of course. And what race driver can run second most of the way and then win with a showboat finish? Again, Donohue.

A 54-year-old Harlem jeweler was fatally wounded by two armed young men during a holdup of his store shortly after 6 P.M. yesterday. The victim, Edgar Collins of 519 West 141st Street, was alone when the two men, about 20 years old, entered the store at 108 West 125th Street.
Frank Zverina, a Czechoslovak writer and translator who was active in the Czech resistance during the Nazi occupation of his country, died Sunday at St. Barnabas Hospital, the Bronx. His age was 53.

Gunmen and soldiers exchanged fire in two separate incidents in Belfast early today, the army said. In Londonderry an army patrol asserted that it had fired on and hit a gunman near the Roman Catholic Creggan district.

The Justice Department asked the Federal District Court today to dismiss a suit against President Nixon's chief of staff, Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., who remained on the active Army payroll for two months while working at the White House.
Only a little over one-half of the food establishments inspected since the state began compiling reports under a new Sanitary Code last December have passed the examinations.

Vice. President Agnew's staff advisers here believe he will turn over his personal financial papers, as requested by Federal prosecutors, probably this week, Marsh Thompson, Mr. Agnew's press secretary, said today.
Lem Barney blocked an extra-point attempt with 1 minute 18 seconds left to give the Detroit Lions a 17-16 victory over the Kansas City Chiefs in a National Football League exhibition game tonight.
MARGAREE FORKS, Nova Scotia--While fleeing the rain-swollen St. Mary's River northeast to another Atlantic salmon stream, the Margaree, my spirits soared as a rift appeared in the heavy clouds.
Harry A. Pearson, director of research for the Sonotone Corportion in Elmsford, and an expert on amplifiers and hearing aids, died yesterday of cancer at White Plains Hospital.

About 40 employes of the Newark Housing Authority, carrying signs and chanting slogans, picketed the authority's offices Monday to protest plans to lay off some 100 administrative workers. The pickets, members of Local 305 of the Building Service Employes International, were served last Friday with notices of the layoff. The authority said the workers were being laid off for financial reasons.
The publicly reported wealth of Vice President Agnew has increased by $112,000 over the last seven years, according to statements issued by Mr. Agnew over the years.

Two of Representative Herman Badillo's political inner circle-the small group that met at his apartment after he lost the Democratic mayoral runoff and discussed whether he should try again as an independent-came out publicly yesterday for the man who won the runoff, Controller Abraham D. Beame.

The Penn Central Transportation Company obtained a $17.7million emergency loan from the Federal Railroad Administration today but the road's trustees insisted that without really massive Federal aid by Oct. 31 that they must begin making plans for going out of the railroad business.

United States District Court Judge Leo Brewster freed the Fort Worth Five today on bonds totaling $50,000. Judge Brewster conducted the brief hearing in his courtroom moments after the five IrishAmericans, all New Yorkers, were brought here from a Federal penitentiary at Seagoville, Tex., near Dallas.

The Federal Drug Enforcement Administration began action today to dismiss six narcotics agents who took part in two narcotics raids in Illinois last April that have resulted in a Federal grand jury investigation.

Six years ago, the flying career of a bald and bouncy 45year-old Northeast Airlines captain, Joseph E. Burrell, was interrupted by illness. A chronic tremor in his left thumb was diagnosed as a symptom of Parkinson's disease. He was grounded and went on sick leave.

The newsprint shortage tightened yesterday as the three mills of a large Canadian producer, the Price Company of St. Anne, Quebec, were struck by 1,800 workers. The union has not made public its demands, but the company has offered increases of 20 to 23 cents an hour retroactive to May 1.
The Federal Reserve Board raised its discount rate today from 7 to 7 1/2 per cent, the highest in history.

GREENWICH, Conn. -A man's home may be his castle. But how many castles feel like home? To the John Butler Hortons, theirs does. And once the couple's friends have inspected the turreted one-story pile of Connecticut stone, such banal queries as "Where are the cannons?" cease.
The prosecution said today that it would not carry out a court order to send a girl fugitive back to East Germany until the European Court of Justice had heard her appeal.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers plans to meet with envoys from the other Southeast Asia Treaty Organization members in New York next month to put stress on the nonmilitary aspects of the 19-yearold organization as a way of keeping it alive, State Department officials said today.

The Commodity Exchange Authority has charged the Louis Dreyfus Corporation, a wheat exporter, with willfully filing inaccurate reports during last year's massive wheat sale to the Soviet Union, the authority announced today.
The stock market, continuing its unsettled course, greeted the start of Phase 4 of the Nixon price stabilization program yesterday with a substantial decline.

With last year's surprise success, "Fritz the Cat," and his current box-office hit, "Heavy Traffic," Ralph Bakshi, the aggressive young creator of both X-rated animated features, has shaken up the loony-tuney cartoon world with dissonant melodies that are not for children.
If the wine runs short at the Mexican mission, guests can blame the uncorking of yet another campaign against parking violations that claimed the wine truck as an early victim.

The price of gold dipped below the $100 mark in unofficial London markets for the first time in three months today while the dollar traded inconclusively on European exchanges following considerable gains last week.

LONDON-A year or so ago Trevor Nunn, the young artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company, conceived the idea of staging all of Shakespeare's Roman plays as a sequence, showing, if you like, the rise, decline and fall of the Roman Empire.

Morgan, Stanley Co., the investment banking concern, was reported here today to have taken an interest in the outcome of the $290-million Canadian tender offer to United States stockholders for 10 million shares of Texasgulf, Inc.

Wallace Read McGill, former producer and director of the "Bell Telephone Hour" on radio, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 67. Mr. McGill conducted the program, which became known as the Great Artist Series, from 1942 to 1958.
A Spanish Caravelle airliner exploded and crashed near this northwestern port today and airline officials said that all 79 passengers and six crew members aboard had been killed.

Not surprisingly, a somewhat similar problem has developed with respect to burglar alarms, now that an increasing number of these signal systems are being installed in private homes by security-minded families. False alarms have become a costly drain on police manpower.
A robbery suspect was set free by a Criminal Court judge yesterday, a week after he was mistakenly arrested on a warrant issued for a man with an almost identical name who lived at the same address.
Total business inventories rose by $2.6-billion in June, the largest monthly increase on record, the Commerce Department reported today.

In their first confrontation in the New Jersey campaign for Governor, Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. and former Superior Court Judge Brendan T. Byrne disagreed today on applying environmental protection to highway construction projects.
Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and her 15-year-old sister Jeanne advanced today to the second round of the women's United States clay court tennis championship.
The Franklin National Bank has agreed to a consent order issued by the Securities Exchange Commission in a proceedings involving the Susquehanna Corporation, a spokesman for the bank said yesterday.

Construction of the Jersey Central Power Light Company's 1.14- million- kilowatt atomic-powered generating station here was delayed when members of the,'local Planning Board tonight tabled the company's request for siteplan approval.

Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas and his wife arrived in Hong Kong, on their way to China, where, the jurist said, he would like to meet Chinese leaders, or Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the exiled Chief of State of Cambodia, or both, Justice Douglas said in an airport interview that "I would enjoy meeting with the leaders of the People's Republic of China and with Sihanouk, but it is not in our plans."

The Food and Drug Administration ordered all drug companies today to submit lists of products containing Trichloroethane and proposed rigid restrictions on future use of the chemical, which has been linked to the deaths of 21 persons Who inhaled it from aerosol cough remedies.

Higher prices were announced yesterday for automobiles and the steel used to manufacture a variety of consumer products as the Nixon Administration's 60-day price freeze gave way to a more relaxed Phase 4.
Earl B. Wilson Sr., who was called to Washington as a $1-a-year man by President Franklin D. Roosevelt to acquire and ration sugar during World War II, died today at the age of 82.
President Ferdinand E. Marcos appealed again today to Philippine Moslems to cooperate with the Government, pledging to use his martial-law powers to develop their homelands in Mindanao.
Steel production for the week ended Aug. 11 declined by 1.4 per cent to 2,771,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Maurice Stokes has been dead for three years, but pro basketball players, old and new, won't let his memory fade. His fight for life is being recalled in the film, "Maurie," and tonight the annual charity game that bears his name at Kutsher's Country Club in Monticello, N. Y.

The North American Soccer League semifinal playoffs begin tomorrow night with the New York Cosmos meeting the Dallas Tornado in Dallas and continue Saturday night in Philadelphia where the Atoms take on the Toronto Metros. Each playoff is a one-game series.

David Kennedy, the 17-yearold son of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, and five other young people were injured this afternoon when a jeep driven by David's brother, Joseph, 21, overturned on a highway six miles east of here.

Huntington Hartford yesterday won a preliminary injunction in New York State Supreme Court to block financial transactions he claimed would strip him of his holdings in Paradise Island, a vacation resort in the Bahamas.

The letter from James H. Lavenson, president of the Plaza, begins: "I'm 53 years old and fat. In addition, I'm in lousy shape physically." Between that confession and the signature is a sales pitch for a spa the hotel plans to open in the fall (annual membership $500).
Joe L. Brown, general manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, walked into a scheduled news conference at his office tonight just as two television lights blew out.

For the first time since 1962, Rod Laver will represent Australia in Davis Cup competition this year. The four-time Wimbledon champion notified Neale Fraser by telephone from his home in California that he hoped to go to Melbourne for the semi-final round against Czechoslovakia in November.
Trucks carrying the first tomato shipments of the season are unloading tons of the vegetables at the Campbell Soup Company here, and though the harvest is late, the price is not soaring.
