RCA Institutes, an electronics school with 12,500 students that opened 64 years ago as the Marconi Institute, is scheduled to close. "Like other nonsubsidized organizations," said a spokesman, "the institute has been faced with the increasingly serious problem of rising costs.

Following is a summary by Archibald Cox, the special Watergate prosecutor, of the legal brief filed by Mr. Cox in connection with his suit to compel President Nixon to provide a grand jury with recordings of White House conversations and related documents:

Archibald Cox, the Watergate special prosecutor, argued today that President Nixon could not be "a proper judge" of whether the public interest requires his making tape recordings of White House conversations available to a grand jury investigation.

Douglas Richards Kennedy, television and motion picture character actor, died Friday at the age of 55. Mr. Kennedy's TV credits inclouded roles in "Wagon Train," "Big Valley," "Bonanza," "Lassie" and "Perry Mason."

The grotesque scale of values that guided the bombing of Cambodia, with all its callousness and deceit, was never more bluntly revealed than in last week's testimony by Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, explaining why a double system of accounting was set up to hide from Congress and the American people the fact that B-52's were raining death and devastation on a neutral nation.

The Control Data Corporation announced last night that preliminary discussions had taken place for it to manage and maintain, but not own, leased peripheral computer equipment presently installed by the Memorex Corporation.
Battle lines were 'drawn quickly for Sunday's GiantsJets exhibition when Coach Alex Webster said yesterday that "we'll go with No. 1 people."
The officials who run the drug programs administered by the city's Addiction Services Agency reacted angrily yesterday to charges of inefficiency and corruption made by Controller Abraham D. Beame.
President Nixon signed today a $23-billion highway bill that permits for the first time a share of the Federal Highway Trust Fund to be used by the cities for mass transit.

Mrs. Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge, last surviving child of the financier William Rockefeller and the widow of Marcellus Hartley Dodge, chairman of the Renmington Arms Company, died today at her home, Giralda Farms. She was 91 years old.
The United States lost a top gymnast because of emergency surgery and, finally managed to cut through Soviet red tape at the World University Games today.

Herod the Great would have loved it. In celebration of Israel's 25th anniversary, 450 international guests nibbled stuffed vine leaves under the stars, watched Rudolf Nureyev dance in the Herodian Amphitheatre later at Caesarea and sang "Hello, Golda, well hello, Golda . . ." to Israel's Premier at a torchlit party in the 2,000-year-old Herodian citadel of Jerusalem.

Charles Phelps Cushing, photographer, photographers' agent and writer, whose interest in Americana led him to photograph more than 500 Main Streets, died yesterday at his home, 2440 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx. His age was 88.

Talking Picture of the Elmendorf interests won the $29,375 Adirondack today before a crowd of 16,667. Braulio Baeza rode the Kentucky - bred daughter of Speak John, who had the margin of a head over In Hot Pursuit, racing in the silks ofOgden Mills Phipps.

THE PREACHERS. By James Morris. 418 pages. St. Martin's Press. Illustrated by Tom Huffman. $8.95. James Morris is an Insomniac who solved the problem of what to do in the wee hours of the morning by building himself a powerful radio receiver and tuning in to Fundamentalist preachers, mostly from the right wing.

Israeli and Egyptian naval craft exchanged fire today in the Gulf of Suez. The Israelis said they had hit and disabled a 110-ton patrol boat of the Castro class in the encounter, the first naval engagement between the two countries since the cease-fire went into effect three years ago.
Kratt Foods, a subsidiary of Kraftco Corporation, announced today temporary allocation of cheese products to its retail food service and industrial customers.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers plans to meet with envoys from the other Southeast Asia Treaty Organization members in New York next month to put stress on the nonmilitary aspects of the 19-yearold organization as a way of keeping it alive, State Department officials said today.
The officials who run the drug programs administered by the city's Addiction Services Agency reacted angrily yesterday to charges of inefficiency and corruption made by Controller Abraham D. Beame.
Lime Rodney, a Swedish filly with a reputation as an exceptional sprinter, has been entered in the $150,000 Roosevelt International Trot, increasing the list of starters for the Aug. 25 race to five.
Jack Nicklaus, once, again the king, and Tom Weiskopf, who figures the pressure may finally be off, plan to take it a little easy the rast of the year.
An unexploded pipe bomb, the 10th such device found at a construction site in the city this year, was discovered yesterday morning in Brooklyn.
The treasury ana me Federal Reserve Banks are holding about $80-million worth of Government savings bonds unclaimed by servicemen and others who bought them, the General Accounting Office says.
John W. Dean 3d was named by the prosecution yesterday as a co-conspirator in the criminal case of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell in Federal Court here.
Mrs. Mary Sargent Ladd Abreu and Baron Bernard d'Anglejan-Chatillon, both of Paris, were married in the First Congreational Church here today. The Rev. Malcolm D. Kilborn performed the ceremony.

An upturn in the nationwide slaughter of cattle appears to have developed for the first time since a squeeze that began July 18, when President Nixon kept price ceilings on beef while removing them from all other foods.
The Bohack Corporation has left Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester with the sale of seven supermarkets of which privately owned Sloan Supermarket Stores took possession last Saturday night.

The Swiss team championship of the Greater New York Bridge Association ended Sunday night at the New York Hilton in a victory for a Precision sextet: Michael and Gail Moss, Amalya Kearse, Steve Altman, all of New York, Anne-Marie Sporing of Wayne, N. J., and Tom Smith of Greenwich Conn.

John D. Ehrlichman charged today that the work of the Senate Watergate committee was "destructive." The President's former domestic adviser said that the committee members had forged ahead with "what they consider to be in the national interest" even though the inquiry may violate "the rights of individuals."

Despite an over-all lull in fighting in Cambodia today, military sources reported the loss of an important market town 48 miles northeast of here. American planes continued heavy attacks all around Phnom Penh with two days remaining until the scheduled cutoff of the bombing.

More than 25 C.B.S. affiliate stations have declined to carry reruns of two episodes of "Maude" dealing with abortion, the first of which is scheduled on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network tonight.

The National Medical Association, the professional organization representing the nation's 6,000 black doctors, must take a more active role in national politics if current gains made in health services for the poor are to be maintained, a Government official said yesterday.

In their first confrontation in the New Jersey campaign for Governor, Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. and former Superior Court Judge Brendan T. Byrne disagreed today on applying environmental, protection to highway construction projects.
Six years ago, John Stanton, patient number 1142 at Meadow View Hospital, the Hudson County mental institution on County Road here, died a natural death.
Median household income in the United States rose to $9,700 last year, an increase of about 7.4 per cent from that of the previous year, the Commerce Department said today.

Ettore Zappi, whom District Attorney William Cahl of Nassau County has described as the No. 2 man in the crime "family" of Carlo Gambino, was arrested at his home here this morning as a fugitive from justice in California.

The Canadian Government, moving against the steepest increases in the cost of living that this country has known since the Korean war, imposed temporary controls tonight on the export of beef and pork.

The harvested lavender is heaped high on the floor of the Fragonard perfume factory and the sweet smell from the stills floats through the town, a drowsy, beautiful aerie stacked high on the hills behind Cannes and the French Riviera.
Dr. John D. Corbit Jr., director of the obstetrics and gynecology division of Lankenau Hospital since 1964 and professor of gynecology at Jefferson Medical College, died Friday at the hospital.
Kim Dae Jung, the former South Korean Opposition leader who was mysteriously abducted from a Tokyo hotel last Wednesday, was abruptly freed and returned to his home here last night in good health.
Final settlement of the nationwide gypsum wallboard case, the largest private price fixing antitrust case in history, was announced today, subject to court approval.

Carl O. Kamp, Jr., whose resignation as a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board becomes effective Wednesday, has been elected president of the regional Federal Home Loan Bank of Atlanta, succeeding John A. Fogarty, 65 years old, who is retiring at the end of this month.
Maneuvering sideways and upside down, two Skylab 2 astronauts flitted about their space station today with a jet-propelled backback.

The cost of roast-beef dinners and chicken dinners for a family of four in the metropolitan area has increased more than 17 per cent in a year-triple the 5.4 per cent rise in an average factory production worker's hourly earnings in that time.

A gang of youths who call themselves the Jollie Stompers and who have been praised by the police for their good behavior held up and shot two men early yesterday in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.
The H. H. Robertson Company reports its West German subsidiary, Robertson Bauelemente, G.m.b.H., will close its building products manufacturing plant at Hitdorf, West Germany, by the end of year.

The North American Soccer League semifinal playoffs begin tomorrow night with the New York Cosmos meeting the Dallas Tornado in Dallas and continue Saturday night in Philadelphia where the Atoms take on the Toronto Metros. Each playoff is a one-game series.

The Collins Day Group, Inc., the leading dealer in commodity options, is negotiating to sell its nationwide operation, according to industry sources. The name of the prospective buyer could not be ascertained yesterday.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-thecounter market fell sharply yesterday in continued light trading.
Chester Griswold Burden, a retired vice president of the Commercial Cable Company, died Aug. 6 in Bad Gastein, Austria, where he was on vacation. He lived at 1220 Park Avenue.

The Arab states asked the Security Council today to meet its responsibilities and face up to the "arrogant challenge" of the Israelis and their continued "defiance of the United Nations and international law."

Despite reports of a blazing argument between Manager Bill Virdon and Richie Hebner, the third baseman, and the hair curlers of Dock Ellis, The Pittsburgh Pirates are making a steady run at the flag in the National League's Eastern Division.

Chief Justice Warren E. Burger again denied today an application to call a special term of the Supreme Court to consider the constitutionality of United States bombing of Cambodia. It was his second such action in five days.

A prestigious national panel studying crime in the United States has made the most far-reaching recommendation yet for reducing the heavy toll in murder and crime that results from the indiscriminate availability of handguns.

A special offering of 241,700 shares of Coleman Company common at 19 1/2 per share was made yesterday by Bear Stearns Co. The company's stock closed at 19 1/2, down 1/4 on the American Stock Exchange.
Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities.

With Roy White hitting home runs from different sides of the plate. on two consecutive times at bat, the Yankees grabbed a 6-0 lead over California after two innings last night and spent the rest of the evening looking over their shoulders.

Construction of the Jersey Central Power Light Company's 1.14-million-kilowatt atomic-powered generating station here was delayed when members of the local Planning Board tonight tabled the company's request for siteplan approvals.

To the Editor: As a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee and a sponsor of legislation regarding the United States' commitment to NATO, I have noted with deep interest numerous news articles concerning Congressional hearings on NATO troop levels.
The Canadian Government, moving against the steepest increases in the cost of living that this country has known since the Korean war, imposed controls tonight on the export of beef and pork.
The 48 Admiral's Cup contenders from 16 nations reached the Fastnet rock today with 260 miles to go in the finale of the four-race series to decide world supremacy in ocean racing.
George C. Thayer, the author of numerou's books and articles on political subjects, died today at Georgetown University Hospital here. He was 39 years old and lived here.

The jury in the Gainesville Eight trial has expressed fears that its telephones are being tapped. But Federal District Judge Winston E. Arnow, disclosing in court this afternoon that he had asked the telephone company to check the jurors' home lines, told them there was "no indication of electronic surveillance."

Two Registered Nurses who filed charges of sex discrimination when they were transferred from the ambulance squad to in hospital service at the Jersey City Medical Center last, year apparently have won a point and lost $3,000 a year.
Cornelius M. O'Shea, chief horticulturist of the city's Department of Parks, died yesterday in La Guardia Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 46-10 61st Street, Woodside, Queens.

After growing for three years as a sales promotion agency, Halpern/McDevitt, Inc., took the plunge about a year ago and moved head on into advertising. For Daniel J. Halpern, Nancy J. McDevitt and their associates, the results have been largely satisfying.

Vice President Agnew's staff advisers here believe he will turn over his personal financial papers, as requested by Federal prosecutors, probably this week, Marsh Thompson, Mr. Agnew's press secretary, said today.
Kim Dae Jung, the former South Korean Opposition leader who was mysteriously abducted from a Tokyo hotal last Wednesday, was abruptly freed and returned to his home here last night in good health.
He had been a Jet only a few days when Richard Neal first heard about the game against the Giants, an annual crusade that will be staged next Sunday at New Haven.
Special court-martial was ordered today for 56 navy officers charged with attempted mutiny during an abortive attempt in May to hijack the fleet and blackmail the Greek Government to give up power.

The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a fraud suit today against Marasol Properties and four other companies, charging that the means that they are using to sell condominiums constitutes an illegal sale of securities.
Jorge Ahumada of Argentina floored Ray Anderson, of Youngstown, Ohio, two times last night and was awarded the victory after the eighth round of the scheduled 10-round bout at the Felt Forum.
The Chrysler Corporation's forge plant here resumed production of essential parts today as workers ended a wildcat srike over allegedly unsafe working conditions.
A young mother, strolling in Chicago's Grant Park with her husband and child, was stabbed to death today when she paused to enter a washroom.

Five men were sentenced today to life imprisonment for the murders of eight persons last fall at a luxurious golf course here. The sentences -- eight consecutive life terms for each defendant - produced bedlam in the courtroom.
The Symphony of the New World, which begins its eighth season this fall, has appointed Everett Lee as musical director.

A dispute over who legally owns $800,000 worth of art treasures and artifacts from three South American nations -- and not theft- is the reason for the disappearance of the artwork from two Manhattan warehouses on Friday, the police reported yesterday.

The Aviation Consumer Action Project asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to formulate "reasonable rules" to make the airlines more responsive to passengers' baggage problems.

Police Chief Herman Short defended today department policies of handling runaway juveniles against criticism of some of the parents whose children are believed to have been victims in the mass killings here.

Dresser Industries, Inc., achieved record sales and earnwings in the quarter and nine months ended July 31, reflecting the increased results of the industrial specialties group, according to the company's re-ort issued yesterday.

Despite a general lull in fighting in Cambodia, military sources reported the loss of Skoun, an important market town 35 miles northeast of Phnom Penh, and American planes continued heavy attacks around Phnom Penh two days before the United States bombing will stop under Congressional order. Protestant leaders in this country and abroad have become concerned about the arrest of several South Korean clergymen six weeks ago on charges of anti-Government activities.

" Everytime you ship one of your animals by air, you ship with your heart in your mouth," says Mrs. Stanley A. Davis, a dachshund breeder in Hopkinton. N.H.

A Sikh was fined $35 today for refusing, on account of his religion, to wear a crash helmet while motorcycling. Mohan Hartung Singh was the first Sikh to be prosecuted under a law that obliges motorcyclists to wear helmets.

Helen Teschemacher, who was a teacher in the old city of Brooklyn before its consolidation as part of New York City, died at the age of 99 in the Villa Maria Nursing Home.

Space officials said today that the Skylab 2 crew would be permitted to complete their record 59-day space mission. A rescue craft, if needed, will not be launched before Sept. 25.

A Chrysler automobile stamping plant was shut down here today after two plant security men were assaulted when a discharged employee closed a framing department by sitting on an assembly line. A number of workers remained in the closed plant.

The south African Government today deported the American secretary of an Anglican bishop it had previously exiled. Ann Lowell, a 32-year-old employe of the prelate in Boston, arrived in South Africa a few days ago, intending to spend about six weeks in the country.
Residents of the small homes that circle the Washine Division chemical plant, where seven workmen were injured in a morning explosion, expressed fear, anger and frustration today.
The British bookmaking concern of Ladbrokes and Company, Ltd., began offering today what it described as "fairly strong" odds that President Nixon would survive the Watergate scandal.

A Los Angeles doctor has reported finding a high rate of irregular fetal heartbeat during the labor of poor mothers who appeared healthy. The rate of such fetal distress was almost as high as that for mothers whose medical histories indicated a high risk of complication in pregnancy.

On the final day of United States bombing in Cambodia, 60 persons-including the antiwar activists the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan and his brother Jeromewere arrested today as they knelt and prayed at the White House in a protest against the raids.
The British cruise ship Canberra, which ran aground last month off Granada, West Indies, ran aground here tonight.

A 28-year-old high school teacher who applied for a pistol permit and invited license bureau policemen into his apartment to discuss his application ended up in the 24th Precinct station house yesterday afternoon, booked on several charges of violating local gun laws.

Prof. David J. Sargent of Medford, Mass., has been named dean of the Suffolk University School of Law in Boston. The appointment of the 41year-old faculty member was announced by President Thomas Fulham.
The national police seized a watch factory from striking workers today, provoking a test of strength that could lead to labor turmoil across France.
The American dollar jumped to a six-week peak today. Gold fell $7 an ounce to a three-month low.

Two military tribunals have been assigned to try 10 persons, including prominent Filipinos and three Americans, on charges of attempting to kill Presiident Ferdinand E. Marcos, informed sources said today.

Thieves at Cornell University in Ithaca, N. Y., stole 63 rifles, 11 handguns, three telescopic sights, five bayonets and a grenade launcher from two R.O.T.C. storage areas on the campus. The loss, from a third-floor room and a small cinderblock building, both in Barton Hall, was discovered by the campus police.

A polyester fiber plant with an initial capacity of 250 million pounds will be erected near Charleston, S. C., E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday. The plant, which will produce both filament and staple polyester fiber, is scheduled for completion in late 1975.

The Westchester County sheriff's office yesterday reported the indictment and arrest of a New Rochelle physician accused of having sold prescriptions for dangerous drugs, such as barbiturates, at $15 apiece without examining the "patients," who turned out to be undercover agents.
Fred Gipson, the author of "Hound-Dog Man," "Old Yeller" and other- adventure stories written for both children and adults, died this morning at his ranch home near here. He was 65 years old.

Top-seeded Alex Mayer, arriving at 2 A.M. on a 24-hour flight from Lebanon, began his quest for the Pennsylvania grass tennis championship with 6-1 6-3 victory over Tom Kriess of Los Angeles today at the Merion Cricket Club.

A State Department spokesman called the kidnapping of Kim Dae Jung a "deplorable incident" today and voiced hope that authorities in South Korea would find and punish those responsible for the abduction of the Opposition political leader.

Two members of the jury that convicted five young blacks yesterday of eight killings at a luxurious golf club here last fall said today in notarized statements that they had been pressured into reaching the guilty verdict.
Mrs. Charles A. Halleck, wife of the former House Republican leader, drowned yesterday when she fell from a boat into the Madison River. while fishing with her husband.

Earnings and the rate of return for the 65 major United States railroads improved in both the second quarter of this year and for the year that ended June 30, according to a report issued today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Televised harness races whose numbers-game format could produce cheering such as "C'mon 5-0-6" are being considered by the Offtrack Betting Corporation.

The White House said today that President Nixon "is interested in making sure that all appropriate steps are taken" by Federal investigators who are looking into allegations against Vice President Agnew.

Samuel Landfair Rosenberry, a senior partner in the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley McCloy, died here of cancer yesterday at his summer home. His age was 70 and lived at 135 East 71st Street, New York.
Auxiliary Bishop Jeremiah F. Minihan of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston died today while on vacation in Dublin. His age was 70.

Since Ruby Braff, that engaging elf from Boston, came to New York with his cornet almost 20 years ago, he has led an essentially underground existence despite consistent critical acclaim for his warm-toned, melodic and imaginatively swinging playing. But there are indications that 1973 maybe Ruby's year of emergence.

Two tape recordings of conversations between a suspended policeman accused of selling $35 worth of marijuana and the undercover police officer who allegedly bought the marijuana were played in court yesterday.
Elmer Wayne Henley and David Owen Brooks, who confessed they had participated in a homosexual's sextorture slaying of 27 boys, were indicted for murder today by a Harris County grand jury.

BURLINGTON, Vt.--The Watergate affair has been outrageously exploited by both the American press and the Congress. It all adds up to a vicious political stunt, an anti-Nixon vendetta which is utterly appalling in its depth of hatred and recrimination.

It was the middle of August, 22 years ago, when the New York Giants, trailing the Brooklyn Dodgers by 13 games, began the devouring rush that brought these tribal enemies to the season's end in a dead heat and set up the playoff that Bobby Thomson won with a home run bigger than any of Babe Ruth's 714, bigger even than Henry Aaron's 715th will be to anybody except Henry.

Kim Dae Jung, the South Korea Opposition leader who disappeared suddenly in Tokyo six days ago, said tonight his abduction had all the marks of careful planning, skilled execution and close monitoring by those in charge.

To the Editor: The matter of the Presidential tapes sounds like the story of the man in the alleyway who taps you on the shoulder and offers to sell you a hot watch. You know it was wrong of him to steal the watch; it's wrong if you buy the watch but oh, what a cheap ??argain.

A spokesman for the Catholic Communications Foundation has called the decision of the Columbia Broadcasting System to rerun two episodes of the situation comedy "Maude" dealing with abortion "a willful insult to the American televiewer."

Reginald Palmer Vincent, a vice president of the First National City Bank, who retired four years ago after 40 years of service, died at the Mary Fletcher Hospital, Burlington, Vt., where he was taken from his summer home in Glen Burnie, N. Y. His age was 69.
In performing Mozart, two opposing temptations must be resisted. On one hand, whether early or late, his music must not he romanticized and poured into the 19th-century expressive mold; on the other,

Transportation officials in the metropolitan area began detailed planning yesterday for t using the funds in the $23-billion federal highway-mass transit bill and said the money would buy new highways, new g buses and some new masstransit facilities.

A damage suit of more than $2million has been filed in United States District Court in Tampa, Fla., against The New York Times by ComCorp, Clevelandbased publishers of the Polk Shopper's Shopping News, Lakeland. Fla.

BURIED ALIVE; THE BIOGRAPHY OF JANIS JOPLIN. By Myra Friedman. 333 pages, Illustrated Morrow. $7.95. A friend of mine dislikes swimming on beaches where there are lifeguards. "I reserve the right," he says, "to drown myself if I choose."

Controller Abraham D. Beame called yesterday for a graduated scale of fees for applicants for more than one long gun and a tightening of the fiscal practices of the city's Firearms Control Board, which issues long-gun permits.

Three dives have been made into the midAtlantic canyon where the world's surface is being torn apart and born anew. For the first time human eyes have gazed directly on the evidence for this process beneath the sea.
Financially troubled Royal Inns of America, Inc., will start paying its debts at thel end of this month, ending a five-month moratorium, it was announced today.

Seven men were. injured and at least two others were missing after an explosion rocked a chemical plant near busy Route 46 here today. Five of the injured were in critical condition at Hackensack Hospital last night, but all were expected to live.

The Justice Department, in two separate lawsuits filed today, charged the police departments of Chicago and Buffalo with discriminating in employment against blacks, Spanish-surnamed persons and women.
The trickle of price increase that began Monday when the Nixon Administration's price. freeze gave way to Phase swelled to a steady stream yes terday.

The United Steelworkers of America and the nation's three largest aluminum producers today reached a landmark agreement that is expected to forestall "feast and famine" cycles of production and assure labor peace until the summer of 1977.

Charles D. Breitel, associate judge of the state Curt of Ap- T peals and Republican-Liberal h candidate for chief judge, was endorsed yesterday by Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, a Democrat running for Mayor on the Liberal line.
Mrs. Patricia McCullough Wenk of Darien was married here this evening to Robb M. DeGraff, an advertising manager with E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in Wilmington, Del.
Iran has been accepted as a member of the International Commission of Control and Supervision in Vietnam, the Iranian Ambassador, Ardeshir Zahedi, said today.

Jeb Stuart Magruder, former deputy director of President Nixon's 1972 campaign corn mittee, will plead guilty tomorrow to one count of conspiracy to obstruct justice for his in volvement in the Watergate scandal, C.B.S. News reported last night.
Three men standing on a Bronx sidewalk were injured by shots fired from a passing car last night, according to the police, who said the vehicle roared away after the shooting.
Cambodian commander of a key road junction city that fell to insurgent troops two days ago has been arrested and jailed, the high command said today.
A soldier identified as a rebel who defected to the Cambodian Government side said today that six months of intense American bombings in Cambodia has inflicted little damage on insurgent troops.
When The Times asked me to report on what's being said in my barnyard about Watergate, I immediately sought an audience with the goose. She is sore at me at the moment but is always willing to talk.

Hans Christian Andersen's Ugly Duckling, one of the most popular statues in Central Park, was stolen from its granite base last week, and an intensive search by detectives and Parks Department personnel has so far failed to find it.
The supply of newsprint for newspapers in the United States is currently tight and likely to become more so, according to industry and newspaper sources.
Mayor Frank L. Rizzo reported today he was "baffled" at learning he had failed a lie detector test on a local political dispute. The results were disclosed in The Daily News, sponsor of the tests.

Unsecured creditors and worker shareholders of the Rolls-Royce Company, which encountered financial difficulties in 1971 and left shareholders and creditors little hope of recouping their money, will receive payments totaling more than $66-million, it was announced today.

Thieves at Cornell University in Ithaca, N. Y., stole 63 rifles, 11 handguns, three telescopic sights, five bayonets and a grenade launcher from two R.O.T.C. storage areas on the campus. The loss, from a third-floor room and a small cinderblock building, both in Barton Hall, was discovered by the campus police. The Ithaca police and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation joined in an inquiry.

Married couples who not only live together, but work together too, seem to be on the increase as more women become involved in careers. Obviously, being together almost constantly raises some special questions. How, for example, do the couples decide who does what at work? And, since they both work, who does what at home? Do they feel competitive? Do they ever need to get away from one another?

The police on this resort island said today they were continuing their investigation of an accident yesterday in which an auto driven by Joseph P. Kennedy 3d overturned on a country road, injuring his younger brother David and five young women.

Residents of the small homes that circle the Washine Division chemical plant, where seven workmen were injured in a morning explosion, expressed fear, anger and frustration today.

Kenneth G. Southard, a vice He president of Kenyon Eckhardt Inc., New York advertising agency, died Sunday at Lenox Hospital after a brief illness. He was 36 years old and lived in Port Washington, L. I.
About 250 young people from a variety of radical political groups demonstrated last night on 34th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues against American policies in Indochina.

A Brooklyn grand jury decided yesterday that the marraige of John Ryall and Leslie Chernak was not made by angels but was conceived in a Long Island apartment and financed by a holdup of the bank where Leslie's sister worked as a teller.

As the nation waited for President Nixon's latest statement on the Watergate scandal, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday that his popularity had plummeted to the lowest point for any American President in 20 years.

Visits to most of the country's major national parks have declined this summer, in what park officials see as the first strong evidence that many Americans have changed their 1973 vacation plans because of threats of a gasoline shortage.
Sparked by her victory Sunday over Mrs. Billie Jean King, the Wimbledon champion, Mrs. Margaret Court is eager for the United States Open tennis championships at Forest Hills.
A suspect who the police said was on probation after serving a term for rape was charged today with murdering a 17-year-old girl near her family's wooded, rural home in East Amwell.
The jury-selection process in Erie County has been challenged by an organization representing some prisoners accused of having committed crimes during the Attica prison riot.
Sparked by her victory Sunday over Mrs. Billie Jean King, the Wimbledon champion, Mrs. Margaret Court is eager for the United States Open tennis championships at Forest Hills.

City officials announced yesterday that additional police officers would be stationed in Greenwich Village bececause of the knife slaying of a young woman in the area last week and complaints by residents that an influx of outsiders was disrupting the neighborhood.

The Fort Worth Five returned to New York yesterday after being released for the second time from a Texas jail where they were being held for refusing to tell a grand jury about an alleged gun deal with the Irish Republican Army.

Vice President Agnew offered today to answer questions personally and open his records to the United States Attorney here who is investigating allegations of extortion, bribery, tax fraud and conspiracy that allegedly took place when Mr. Agnew was Governor of Maryland.
Americans are continuing to buy new cars in record numbers. Sales reports for Aug. 1-10 showed deliveries of an estimated 200,463 cars, up 3.1 per cent from 194,377 in the same period last year.

The Federal Reserve Board approved today the acquisition of G.A.C. Finance, Inc., of Allentown, Pa., by the BankAmerica Corporation. holding company parent of the Bank of America, largely in order to "avoid the collapse" of the acquired company.

Cats living in the same household with another cat suffering from a lymph cancer caused by the feline leukemia virus run a large risk of being infected and developing cancer, researchers here and in Boston have reported.

Two Big American yachts slipped away from nearly 300 challengers in the Fastnet race today and appeared to have the ocean classic between them as they neared the finish. The 61-foot Sorcery, ineligible to win the Admiral's Cup because she is one foot over the specifications, was sighted passing Wolf Rock, 65 miles from the finish. She is owned by Jim French Baldwin of Locust Valley, L. I.

Charles D. Breitel, associate judge of the state Curt of Appeals and Republican-Liberal candidate for chief judge, was endorsed yesterday by Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, a Democrat running for Mayor on the Liberal line.
The Norwegian Government today expelled an Israeli Embassy security officer accused of hiding two Israeli fugitives wanted in the slaying of a Moroccan.
The qualifying medalist, Mrs. Kaye Potter of Louisville, Ky., was beaten as match play began today in the United States women's amateur golf championship at the Montclair Golf Club.

Johnny Unitas, who led the Baltimore Colts at quarterback for 17 seasons, has sued that National Football League club for $725,000 on charges of malicious breach of contract. Unitas, now with the San Diego Chargers,

Facing their sixth straight left-handed starting pitcher, the Yankees pointed up again last night the fallacy in opposing managers' thinking that it's better to start southpaws than right-handers against the predominantly left-handed hitting team.
The Procter Gamble Company raised its net profit for the fourth fiscal quarter by 5.4 per cent, according to the company's annual report issued yesterday.
" America Goes Public" will be the theme of a seven-hour national telethon Sept. 15 designed to wipe out the Democratic party's $3-million debt left over from the 1968 Presidential campaign.

Juan Per6n's acceptance of his party's nomination for President of Argentina was hardly in doubt. What has surprised many Argentines and shocked thousands of Mr. Peron's loyal supporters is his announced decision to go into the election next month with his third wife as his vice-presidential running mate.
Mrs. Etta Rehahn Polchinski, who had sung in opera as a soloist with the Metropolitan Opera Company and over radio station WOR in New York, died Loday at her home, 39 Cypress Street. Her age was 78.

A 5-year-old boy and a middle-aged man were killed here this morning when a car driven by a man on his way to court to answer a drunken driver charge mounted the curb at a busy intersection and smashed into a group of pedestrians.
The qualifying medalist, Mrs. Kaye Potter of Louisville, Ky., was beaten as match play began today in the United States women's amateur golf championship at the Montclair Golf Club.
Some key short-term interest rates again reached new peaks yesterday even while the rest of the credit markets were extending an equilibrium level reached last week.
President Nixon has the "greatest respect" for Helmut Sonnenfeldt and hopes he will be confirmed as Treasury Under Secretary, the White House said today.
At least 750 pounds of frozen fish were destroyed when the brakes of a tractortrailer caught fire on Interstate 84, the state police reported.

The conspiracy trial of the Gainesville Eight, now in its third week, was delayed today when a juror became ill. The defendants, eight antiwar veterans, are accused of plotting to disrupt the 1972 Republican National Convention.
President Salvador Allende Gossens' new civil-military Government ordered strong measures today to curb the wave of terrorism in Chile.
Dade County Circuit Judge Jack Turner was acquitted here today of a bribery charge by a jury that had deliberated less than one hour.

Dr. Sidney Smedresman, a a physician who had also been a supervising school physician for 20 years, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 147-43 77th Road, Kew Garden Hills, Queens. He was 62 years old.

The Southland Corporation has agreed not to choose product lines offered in its 7-Eleven convenience stores on the basis of how much suppliers buy from Southland's other subsidiaries, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

The Maryland Society of Professional Engineers today named a committee to investigate reports of kickbacks by engineers to Maryland politicians, and the chairman of the committee said that a preliminary check indicated that "apparently there is something in here."

Partly because of the new system of floating currency exchange rates and partly because of some real improvement, two measures of the United States balance of international payments showed dramatic improvement in the second quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

Noting that many of the victims of the Houston mass murders were runaway boys, Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, says he plans a series of meetings with juvenile authorities from around the country on the problem of runaways.
President Nixon plans to hold a news conference at San Clemente, Calif., after he goes there next week, the White House said today.

The United States has proposed an international law that would protect underwater oil and mining investments from the kind of contract breaking that Arab producing countries have recently been inflicting on American companies.
Mrs. Alberta Hogue Miller, the wife of Otto N. Miller, board chairman of the Standard Oil Company of California, died last evening at her home here. She was 62 years old.

Bob Rosburg, a member of the Tournament Players Division Policy Board of the Professional Golfers' Association, the unit that directs and conducts the $8.2-million tour, has been suspended "for conduct unbecoming a professional golfer." Unless Rosburg appeals, the suspension will keep him out of the next three tournaments, staring with the $200,000 U.S.I. event this week. .
Thomas F. Galvin, the Republican candidate for City Council President, was assured yesterday of a second line on the ballot when the Conservative party also named him as its candidate.
With some wonder and awe, you sit and watch the Chamber Theater of the Manhattan Theater Club, that thriving uptown unit, revive "Waiting for Lefty."
The Tariff Commission ruled unanimously today that imports of aluminum ingot from Canada, though sold at "less than fair value," are not injuring the domestic aluminum industry.

The Waterfront Commission charged yesterday that 15 watchmen hired from a private security agency to guard cargoes in the New York Harbor had conspired with their employer to over bill 15 pier companies and shipping lines of at least $63,000 in 1971. The watchmen were ordered to appear at a commission hearing on Sept. 5 to answer the charges. .

Young Americans for Freedom, the young conservative group that generally finds the Republican party too far to the left, opened its annual convention here today with its members seemingly undecided about President Nixon's involvement in the Watergate case.

Doberman pinschers and horses have played leading roles in the lives of Frank and Eleanor D'Amico of Glen Cove, L. I. "For me, It all started 20 years ago when Ellie and I were married," said Frank.
The Newburgh City Board of Education voted unanimously tonight to reject a school integration proposal by the State Education Commissioner, Ewald B. Nyquist.
Federal Judge Lee P. Gagliardi said yesterday that the trial of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans would start on Sept. 11.

Former Senator James M. Turner, Republican of Gloucester, was indicted today by the statewide grand jury on charges of having accepted a bribe to try to arrange an early parole for a convicted bookmaker.

"Either get right or get out--the choice is yours." Richard Oritz yelled at two youngsters trying to push each other into the pool at the first state park in New York City. "We'll stay, we'll stay," the youngsters answered as they hurried away from the water's edge.

Before Congress finally called a halt this week, the United States dropped 7.4 million tons of bombs on Indochina over a nine-year period, more than three times the amount of explosives dropped by American planes during World War II. A half-million tons thundered down on the peaceful countryside of Cambodia, devastating a nation of peasants whose overwhelming desire was to be left a1one and in peace.
Alive or dead in the daily double, harness-racing fans apparently would rather take their chances on that form of wager than on a pair of quinellas.
The United States dollar paused briefly in its recovery today before resuming the rise that has already taken it to a twomonth peak.

While Representatives Edward I. Koch was meeting with the police yesterday to discuss the problems of increased crime in Greenwich Village, thieves were ransacking his apartment in Washington. The Manhattan Democrat's neighbors reported that a television set and some clothing had probably been stolen.

Dr. Dorothy Stepat De Van, who spent 35 years on the Hunter College teaching staff and was chairman of the department of home economics from 1965 to 1968, died Monday at her home, 4960 Broadway. She was 57 years old.
Senator Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota, said to-day that the military was so top-heavy with high-ranking officers that its grade structure was shaped like a balloon rather than a pyramid.

The Justice Department told a Federal judge today that it intended to appeal his order to turn over several Presidential documents on a controversial milk-price support increase for which the White House has claimed executive privilege.
Soviet fans derisively whistled the Israeli team all around huge Lenin Stadium tonight during opening ceremonies for the seventh World University Games.

The average cost of feeding a family of four in the city shot up 3.9 per cent during the first week of August to $56.54, up $2.13 from the week before, the Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.

Plainclothes members of the police anticrime patrol shot and killed a man yesterday after he opened fire on the two officers who had followed him into a second-floor beauty salon on a usually sedate East Side street.

Jeb Stuart Magruder, the only Watergate insider so far to testify directly that former Attorney General John N. Mitchell approved the bugging and break-in plot in advance, was given a lie-detector test by the prosecution and passed, according to reliable sources.
Investors played a waiting game on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The index closed unchanged at 22.97, with 386 stocks declining and 324 showing gains.
Carlyle H. Black, who retired in 1952 as chairman of the American Can Company, died yesterday in a Stamford nursing home. He was 86 years old and lived at 84 Ferris Hill Road.

A center to house memorabilia of Abraham Lincoln will be built on the campus of Lincoln Memorial University for $1-million. The school said that the Kentucky Fried Chicken magnate, Col. Harlan Sanders, had given $500,000 toward the project. The rest of the money will be raised by the school.

Would you like your goldfish or your favorite plant in bed with you? Just ask Bennett Janssen to design a bed for you. Mr. Janssen, who builds as well as designs furniture, recently made a bed for a client that incorporates a goldfish tank at the foot of the bed, with a miniature fig tree in the headboard.

Two union officials were indicted yesterday in Federal Court and charged with demanding a $500 payoff from a contractor working on the site of the old Hotel New Yorker at 34th Street and Eighth Avenue.
A 30-hour sit-in by workers at a Chrysler automobile stamping plant here ended today when the police arrested two of the protesters on charges of assaulting two plant security men.

The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy agreed today to stay on as president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference after the board of directors rejected his resignation.
Vice President Agnew called on Americans tonight to support President Nixon in carrying on his job.
The fourth-seeded chess player in the United States Open chess championship was almost upset early today by a blind chess player officially rated far below him.
A 64-year-old man who the police said, had a "minor record" of bookmaking arrests was beaten to death in the kitchen of his home in Maspeth, Queens, early yesterday morning.
The Security Council voted unanimously this afternoon to condemn Israel for intercepting a Lebanese commercial airliner last week and forcing the plane to land in Israel.
Borough officials said today they planned to prevent any further manufacturing in a chemical plant where seven persons were injured in an explosion and fire yesterday.

The state of Michigan sued an oil company and a driller today for $1,265,000 in damages it attributed to natural gas eruptions that forced the evacuation of the northern Michigan hamlet of Williamsburg in April and undermined buildings there.

Champing on the stub of a cigar and mulling over another loss, Ralph Houk, the Yankees' manager, said yesterday: "We haven't played good defensive ball. Our defense just hasn't been up to par for the last three of four weeks."

Kyle Rote Jr.'s goal in the 17th minute gave the Dallas Tornado a 1-0 victory over the New York Cosmos tonight in the North American Soccer League's semifinal playoff. The game was played at Texas Stadium before 9,009 fans.
A July 29 editorial complains that the Highway Trust Fund "compromise" reached by the House-Senate conferees is a major victory for the highway lobby.
The Environmental Protection Agency filed a suit today under the national Clean Air Act against two United States Steel Corporation facilitise in Gary, Ind.

The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.
A State Appeals Court, ruled today that 22 eighth-grade boys who had been fighting a court order to be fingerprinted in a murder investigation must comply.

Walter A. Moore, who retired in 1967 as vice president and director of marketing for the Best Foods Division of C. P. C. International, Inc., died Wednesday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 67 years old and lived at 24 Merrilon Avenue in Garden City. L.I.

With only 39 games left to play, the Yankees left New York last night for two critical weeks in the West. They were only two games out of first place, but they hit the road with the unsettling knowledge that they ranked among the worst travelers in baseball.

John M. Greene. legislative correspondent for The Long Island Press and a newspaperman for more than half a century, died yesterday in the Albany Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived in Rockville Centre, L.I.

As recently as three decades ago, forty thousand or more Americans died of tuberculosis each year, victims of what was then still one of mankind's major enemies among the infectious diseases. By the mid-nineteenfifties, however, the annual number of tuberculosis deaths in this country was down to ten thousand and it has continued to decline ever since.

The police yesterday reported the arrest of three men who they said belonged to a gang responsible for 10 bank holdups on the East Side in the last two months. The loot of the robberies totaled $40,400 and helped to finance the $100a-day narcotics habits of two of the suspects, the police said.
Mrs. Anne Quast Sander of Seattle, a three-time champion, and little-known Carol Semple of Sewickley, Pa., gained the final of the 73rd United States Women's Amateur golf championship here today.

George Papadopoulos, the former artillery colonel who seized power in Greece six years ago, today took the oath as the country's first President and ,promised an amnesty for some 300 political prisoners, including the man who' tried to kill him in 1968.

Operations returned to normal at the Stauffer Chemical Company plant today, one day after a cloud of noxious gas escaped from a tank and drifted down the California coast, sending 38 persons to the hospital.
Miss Tracy Nan Tasihman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Malcolm Tashman of New York and Stamford, was married this afternoon to David Alan Kalson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Kalson of Pittsburgh.

Cesar Chavez, president of the United Farm Workers, and hundreds of his followers will begin a three-day fast here tomorrow in what was termed an effort to demonstrate once again "our commitment to nonviolence" after recent antistrike activity and the death last week of two members of Mr. Chavez's union and injuries to many others.

TOWSON, Md., Aug. 19--Sitting on an iron lawn chair under the huge tulip tree in her backyard on Chesapeake Avenue, Mrs. Arthur G. Turner sipped iced tea and said nothing mean about the corruption and rumors of corruption in this Baltimore suburb.

Brew Moore, an American jazz' musician, died here this morning at Municipal Hospital, where he was taken Friday night after a fall on a staircase at the Tivoli Gardens amusement park. He was 49 years old.
The soft winds that pushed across the clear blue water of the Caribbean woke the Crusans here today to an island that has changed again.

The owner of Stuyvesant Town has announced that it may sell the giant Manhattan housing project next year when a 25-year-old tax-relief agreement with the city expires. In letters to its tenants, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the owner, said that it might sell the project to a private investor or to the tenants if they formed a cooperative or condominium.

Robert M. McKiernan, presi dent of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said yesterday that if the Police Department continued to seek recruits from lists of the Housing and Transit Authorities police, he would go to court to stop the action.
PARIS-As it does every summer, France's cultural activity has shifted to the South. From Marseilles to Nice, some remarkable artistic events are taking place.

In the wake of Watergate, it is clearer than ever that the health of the electoral process depends on the vigilant involvement of all citizens. Too many residents of New York City remain unregistered and thus ineligible to vote.

The special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, and his staff have been seeking to find out why 13 "politically sensitive" documents essential to a Justice Department inquiry into possible perjury by high Government officials and officers of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation were withheld from the department's Criminal Division during the 1972 Presidential campaign.

Paced by Roland Matthes, East Germany beat the defending champion, the Soviet Union, by 18 points today to win the men's European Cup swimming championships for the second time in four years. East Germany, which also won in 1969, took seven of 14 events at Friesen Stadium in East Berlin.

Criminal prosecutions have severely hurt the Mafia in New York City in the last year, and Federal and local law-enforcement officials are talking cautiously for the first time about a day when crippling blows may be dealt the underworld here.

Mother Mary Anna Dillon, a former superior general of the Congregation of the Infant Jesus of Brooklyn, a religious order popularly known as the Nursing Sisters of the Sick Poor, died Saturday at St. Joseph's Villa, Rockville Centre, L. I. Her age was 81.

As everyone, including the losers had expected, the doubles team of Stan Smith and Eric van Dillen gave the United States a 2-1 lead today in the Davis Cup interzone final by beating the Rumanian pair of Ilie Nastase and lonel Santieu, 6-2, 7-5, 6-2.

District Attorney Jim Garrison goes on trial in Federal Court here tomorrow, accused of taking payoffs to protect illegal gambling. Six of his alleged accomplices are reported ready to testify against him.

LAWRENCE, L. I., Aug. 19--Miss Jean Katherine Baldridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Connell Baldridge, was married here today to Benjamin Stephen Bilus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Bilus of Plainfield, N.J., in her parents' garden. The ceremony was performed by Acting Village Justice Leonard Lazarus.

The marriage of Miss Patricia Sue Schenkel, who graduated in May from Smith College, to Michael Keith Marshall, a 1973 graduate of Oklahoma State' University, took place here yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Nathan I. Perilman performed the ceremony at the Regency.

Two weeks ago, a group of young Peronists hovered around a television set in their living room to view the party convention that unanimously selected Juan Domingo Per6n and his wife, Isabel, as their presidential and vice-presidential candidates.

At the Community Synagogue of Sands Point this afternoon, Dr. Linda Faith Pessar and Dr. Richard B. T. Cowan, residents at the Psychiatric Institute of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York, were married by Rabbi Martin S. Rozenberg.
B. T. Fitzpatrick, a lawyer who was a Federal housing export and principal architect of the National Housing Act of 1949, died today of pneumonia. He was 66 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

The canoe was missing from the infield lake behind the tote board today, having been carted away for repainting in the colors of Mrs. Patricia Blass. For the next 365 days, as Saratoga's sacred tradition dictates, the old skiff will display the colors of the owner of the Travers Stakes winner.
Norman Mailer experienced a most unusual kind of day here yesterday. Everything went right.
The Yankees received their first look tonight at their new first baseman and their first right-handed pitching opponent in 10 games. In both cases, they liked what they saw.

Herbert Mullin was convicted today of killing 10 persons, including a woman and her two small sons. Mullin, 26 years old, was found guilty on two counts of first-degree murder and eight counts of second-degree murder, and he was found sane on all 10 counts.

The city's public-school children will lose one meal of meat--probably a hamburger-from their weekly lunch fare next month because of rapidly rising wholesale prices and spreading shortages, officials of the Bureau of School Lunches said yesterday.

Miss Janet Sue Sharenow and Martin Jay Albert were married this afternoon in Temple Israel of Great Neck. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz of the Hillcrest (Queens)Jewish Center and Cantor Benjamin' Siegel of Temple Israel officiated.

The Economic Stabilization Office of the Internal Revenue Service in Newark ordered 39 wholesalers, retailers and meat packers to reduce beef prices. An I.R.S. spokesman said the 39, with improperly high prices, were among 209 places investigated last week. The spokesman said the 39 immediately complied with the order to reduce prices, thereby avoiding a possible $2,500 fine.

Mrs. Barbara Green FitzGeraid, founder and director of the Children's Hearing and Speech Center in Washington, and the widow of Desmond FitzGerald, a former deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, died Saturday of cancer in Memorial Hospital. She was 53 years old and lived in Washington.

Cleveland scored two touchdowns within 12 seconds in the third quarter and Frank Pitts scored on two spectacular plays to lead the Browns to a 24-6 preseason football victory over the Cincinnati.Bengals today.

A 35-mile race was the highlight yesterday of the first Harlem Bicycle Championship, a series of races that sponsors hope will be an annual event.

W. E. Hutton Co. announced yesterday it had acquired the retail sales operations and customer accounts of Newburger, Loeb Co.,

A New York department store is selling well-worn blue jeans for $15 a pair, about $6 or $7 more than the price of new, unworn blue jeans. Here is wealth to stagger the mind of Croesus. A nation so rich it will pay others to wear out its pants for it.

The United States Department of Labor has been accused of threatening to deny Federal assistance to contracts here that contain the city's fair-employment requirements.
An exiled Laotian Air Force general who tried to overthrow the Government here today died after a small plane he was flying was shot down near the end of the airport runway.
Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today, in discussing the Watergate scandal, that the United States must not become "so obsessed with security matters that laws are freely violated."
Employes of the United Mine Workers' welfare fund, negotiating their first contract as an independent union, went on strike today in a dispute over pension funding.
Until Sunday morning, only one team, the Dallas Tornado, stood between the Philadelphia Atoms and the championship of the North American Soccer League. But by noon, there were two teams.

The Connecticut Citizen Research Group said today that New Haven was wasting nearly $2-milllion on parks programs no one knew anything about, a Horticulture department that Plants no gardens, and parks too neglected to be used.

A man claiming to be an inspector for the city's Health Department, described as "extremely good-looking" and "a fast-talker" in both Italian and English, is being sought in Brooklyn after shaking down at least 17 shopkeepers for $15 to $125 each since June.
The Chilean Government held last-ditch talks with transport leaders today to try to find a solution to the truckers' strike before it snowballed into a national catastrophe.

Bob Foster will defend his world lightheavy weight boxing title for a record 11th time tomorrow night when he meets Pierre Fourie of South Africa in a bout contrasting Fourie's speed with Foster's power.
E. Howard Hunt Jr., a convicted Watergate conspirator, says his lawyer withdrew from his case at the urging of the special prosecutor, Archibald Cox.
Two Skylab 2 astronauts became plumbers today, using stethoscopes and soapy water in an unsuccessful search for leaks in two systems aboard the orbiting space station.
At 1:01 P.M. yesterday, a doctor on the Lower East Side picked up his phone, dialed 911 - the emergency number - and reported that a patient in his office had suffered cardiac arrest.
Broadway, this city's main street, has. been decked with banners matching the blue and white silks of the Meadow Stable since several weeks before the current meeting began.

A sharp decline in the number of customer complaints to the State Public Service Commission about the New York Telephone Company's service during the last three years, particularly in the New York City area, was reported yesterday by the state agency.
A new rabies vaccine has been developed that is expected to reduce greatly the number of deaths from that dread disease, particularly in less developed areas.

Who is the average person? The U.S. Supreme Court, in its recent rulings on pornography, has commissioned that person to decide for the rest of us that a work (a) "taken as a whole appeals to the prurient interest," (b) "in a patently offensive way," and (c) "lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value." Susan Brownmiller (Op-Ed page, Aug. 6) applauds the decision.

To the Editor: The pathetic element in President Nixon's Watergate address is not in his failure to refute charges against him or to remove the doubt they have created. It is rather in his inability to assess the depth and significance of the crisis Watergate has created for the republic.

The United States captured its first two gold medals of the World University Games today but the Soviet Union continued its domination on its home field by winning five events on the final day of track and field competition.

Two of the nation's largest retailers, Sears, Roebuck Co., and the S. S. Kresge Company, posted their highest sales and earnings for any quarter on record except the Christmas period, according to mid-year statements issued yesterday.

Fuqua Industries, Inc., said yesterday it would accept all shares tendered in exchange for its $15 principal amount of 9 1/2 per cent subordinated debentures during the 10-day proration period since the offer became effective Aug. 7. The company said "over 200,000" shares were tendered based on preliminary information.

The bargaining organization for teachers of the Houston Independent School District voted last night to strike today on the opening of school over the school board's refusal to grant a $.l00-a-year pay increase.
Mel Stottlemyre continued tonight having as much trouble winning as Charlie Brown's baseball team, and the Yankees continued skidding closer to that club's level.

Mike Belkin of Toronto, playing his first competitive tennis in six months, upset ninth-seeded Adriano Panatta of Italy, 6-4, 6-3, today in the first round of the $100,000 Canadian open tennis championships.

Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, in angry and combative tones, told approximately 75 Central Ward residents demanding better cleanup efforts in their area that he would not be intimidated by their demonstrations and protests.

President Nixon, speaking to a friendly audience of war veterans in New Orleans, defended his ordering of the secret bombing of Cambodia in 1969 and said it had been "absolutely necessary" to save American lives and move the war in Southeast Asia to the negotiating table.
Steel production for the week ended Aug. 18 rose 0.4 per cent to 2,781,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market finished lower yesterday in slower trading. Brokers attributed the decline to news that some major banks had risked the prime lending rate to 9% per cent, from 9 1/4 per cent and that the dollar had weakened in foreign exchange markets.

Efforts to resolve the political deadlock on the subcontinent have abruptly focused on the fate of the dispossessed non-Bengali community in Bangladesh.

The stock market plodded through another declining session yesterday in the slowest trading so far this year. The Dow-Jones industrial average skidded 4.44 points and closed at 867.40, a new low for 1973.

Dr. Charles Cramer, head of the department of medicine of Flushing Hospital and Medical Center since 1953 and former president of its medical board, died Saturday in the hospital. He was 67. years old and lived at 33-16 157th Street, Flushing, Queens.
Ike and Tina Turner's familiar Revue-by now, since it is more or less unchanged, very familiar-closed at Soul at the Center '73 series at Philharmonic Hall on Sunday evening.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the Soviet Union's successful flighttesting of a new missile system had made it a matter of "greater urgency" than before for Washington and Moscow to carry out their pledge to reach a treaty putting limits on offensive strategic weapons by the end of 1974.

For the last two weeks of this muggy summer, 8-year-old and 9year-old boys have been learning to play football while, only a few yards away, girls of the same age have been learning to be cheerleaders for the Farmingdale Hawks.

The Minnesota Twins went into the last of the ninth inning at Baltimore's Memorial Stadium last night, leading, 3-1. What happened in the next few minutes is a perfect example of the old cliche, "the game is not over until the last out."

Gaylord Perry, the Indians' controversial pitcher who won the American League's Cy Young Award last year, is available for trade if the proper offer is made, according to Phil Seghi, the Cleveland general manager.
Dr. Frederick H. Frost, a pioneer in the paper- processing industry, died today at a hospital here. He was 71 years old.

The first of the legal confrontations over President Nixon's attitudes toward the Watergate conspiracy will be joined in earnest tomorrow. Opposing lawyers representing the President and the special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, are to present oral arguments on whether Mr. Nixon should or should not be required to produce tape-recorded evidence sought for criminal prosecutions.

China has bought at least 755,000 bales of United States cotton for delivery through next summer, far more than government officials would confirm a few weeks ago, an Agriculture Department report showed today.

Chicken and pork prices tumbled in the metropolitan area yesterday, a drop attributed varyingly to consumer resistance to previous high prices and to the possibility that hoarders had filled their home freezers and gone out of the market for a while.
Mayor Lindsay signedlegislation yesterday officially renaming Welfare Island as Franklin D, Roosevelt Island, This was the fifth time the 147-acre tract in the East River had been renamed.

The Government said yesterday it would hold public hearings this month on the steel and automobile price increases that were announced last week at the end of the Nixon Administration's 60-day price freeze.

A 35-year-old Air Force sergeant has been charged with espionage for allegedly trying to pass secret military documents to a Russian agent in New York City last month, the Defense Department said today.
Brenda became the season's second hurricane today, aiming its 75-mile-an-hour winds at the Mexican coast southeast of Vera Cruz, the National Hurricane Center reported.

This time he has at least been specific enough to make it acutely embarrassing for himself should he fall to keep to his timetable.
Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today, in discussing the Watergate scandal, that the United States must not become "so obsessed with security matters that laws are freely violated."
Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities.

The Central Intelligence Agency is about to undergo its firs major organizational change in 10 years, high officials dis closed today. One agency operation facin reorganization is the top-leve Office of National Estimate which consists of 10 executive and 20 staff members.

With the opening of school less than a month away, a number of school districts around the state are planning a vigorous crackdown on truancy this year.

A fireman saved a 4-year-old girl by reaching down from the roof of a four-story building and taking the child from the arms of her cousin. Fire Department officials said that Henry Gmelin, a five-year department veteran, was on the roof of 850 Bedford Avenue in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn when he heard cries coming from the fourth-floor apartment directly below him.
The Ford Foundation has awarded a grant of $1.5-million to Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival for the organization's multiple operation.

Governor Cahill signed an agreement with the Federal Government today to provide about $5-million to repair public facilities damaged by floods in Somerset, Essex, Middlesex and Union Counties earlier this month.
Israeli authorities sent a $1,666 bill to the Paris office of Lebanon's Middle East Airlines yesterday for the costs of handling a jetliner forced to land at the Tel Aviv airport by an Arab hijacker.

So few passersby on an August Sunday are Frenchmen and so many are tourists prepared for anything that the transformation of the Galeries Lafayette yesterday drew little attention.

Benjamin J. Darling, a past president of the Hudson County Bar Association, died Saturday in the Hudson Manor Nursing Home in North Bergen. He was 94 years old.

Campaigning together for the first time, the three Democratic candidates for citywide office-nominated in separate, free-for-all primaries-accepted a union's endorsement and a $25,000 check from its political action fund yesterday.

United States businesses, which increased their capital expenditures 2 per cent abroad last year compared with 1971, plan to raise them by $52-billion in the next three years, McGraw-Hill said yesterday. Federal District Judge William B. Jones ruled today that the White House does not have to comply with his order to turn over several documents until an appeals court rules on President Nixon's claims of executive privilege.

Red Kelly, a former defenseman and center with the Detroit Red Wings and Toronto Maple Leafs, has been named Toronto coach, the National Hockey League club announced tonight.

Joseph P. Kennedy 3d, oldest son of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, was convicted today of negligent driving that resulted in an accident that at least temporarily paralyzed a teen-age girl. He was fined $100.

West Germany's negotiations to establish diplomatic relations with Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Bulgaria have hit a snag on the thorny problem of Bonn's relationship with West Berlin, according to West German officials and Eastern European sources.

A $54 - million declaratory judgment against American Export Industries, Inc., and several of its directors and officers, was asked for yesterday in a suit filed here in Federal District court by the Independent Investor Protective League.

An all-male jury in Special Narcotics Part of State Supreme Court reported late last night that it was unable to reach a verdict in the case of a suspended Brooklyn police officer accused of selling marijuana to a fellow officer. Justice Alfred M. Ascione then declared a mistrial at 11:40 P.M.
The cost of New York City's contracts with outside consultants has risen to $172.5-million a year, compared with a $8-million annual level at the end of Mayor Robert F. Wagner's administration.

The first of the city's new civilian traffic controllers will take to midtown intersections next Monday to free traffic police officers for crime-fighting duties. This was announced yesterday as Mayor Lindsay signed into law a bill creating a 500man civilian traffic - control force.
The Federal Reserve Board opened the way today for a decision later this year on the controversial question of whether bank holding companies should be allowed to own savings and loan associations.

David Selden, president of the American Federation of Teachers, told the union's annual convention today that "the opportunity for teacher unity is at hand" in the forthcoming merger talks between the federation and the rival National Education Association.

The New Jersey Legislature will return for a special one-day session Sept. 10 to enact emergency legislation providing for an additional $25-million in unemployment compensation benefits and to act on some anticipated gubernatorial appointments.

The 25th annual National Amputee Golf Association championship opens tomorrow at the Fiddler's Elbow Country Club with the qualifying round of 18 holes. For the first time it is an open tournament. There will be money prizes since some golfers are now professionals.

The Consumer Product Safety Commission declared today three aerosol spray adhesives an "imminent hazard" to public health because of their possible link to genetic damage Retail sales of the products were banned.

An officer of Motorola, Inc., explaining his company's extraordinary plan to sell American-made color television sets in Japan, conceded today that the United States could not. produce color sets more cheaply than Japan.

Mutual fund sales in July exceeded redemptions for the first time since January, 1972, the Investment Company Institute reported today. Sales of mutual funds in the month totaled $363.7-million and redemptions were $356.6million, for a sales net of $7.1million.
The Western Union Corporation announced yesterday that it was cutting back its capital spending program for 1974 by about $75-million and releasing about 1,000 employes.
The Secret Service continued today to press its investigation of what was described as a "very serious, very large" conspiracy by "nonmentals"...
Electrohome, Ltd., has purchased the electronic-circuit manufacturing operations at Niagara-onthe-Lake, Ont., of Textron, Inc., Providence, R. I. The plant employs about 30 persons.

Secretary General Waldheim announced his schedule today for a 10-day visit to Israel and four neighboring Arab countries, beginning Monday in Syria.

Rising interest rates and increasing inflation continued to depress prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in over-the-counter trading. Many of the nation's banks yesterday raised their prime lending rate to 9 1/2 per cent from 9 1/4 per cent.
A top farm official in the Nixon Administration said today that further controls on United States exports of soybeans and other crops were not likely.

New developments in electronics were announced yesterday by the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation and the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation.

A spokesman for the Giant Stores Corporation, based here, said today the company had sold three of its Maine stores to King's Department Stores, Inc. They are in Biddeford, Sanford and South Portland.

Maurice J. Williams, the special American coordinator for relief to six drought-stricken West African countries, said today that famine had been averted in the area but that a critical 60-day period. was ahead.

The marriage of Miss Margaret E. Fleder to Robert A. Feinman, a news commentator for radio station KOPO in Tucson, Ariz., took place here this afternoon.
In Christ Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Claudia LaMotte became the bride of Dana Eagle Hull. The Rev. David Hoag performed the ceremony.

Shoppers can expect to pay between a cent and 2 cents more for a quart of milk early next month in the metropolitan tristate region, dairy industry spokesmen said yesterday.

The new United States Consumer Product Safety Commission urged users of the Little Wonder TV Antenna today to unplug and disconnect it immediately to avoid possible electrocution.

Selling pressure intensified in the stock market yesterday and prices again tumbled to new lows for the year. The Dow-Jones Industrial average dropped 9.56 points and closed at 857.84 -- its lowest closing level since Dec. 14, 1971.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday told critics and defenders of the plan to reapportion the City Council that he would decide some time this week whether to sign or veto the bill.
New orders for durable goods declined $310-million in July following an increase of $567million in June, the Commerce Department reported today.
