All these years, the British have had their old school ties-snob emblems by which the happy few who went to the best schools could recognize each other. Americans have college ties, of course, but they haven't made a great fuss over them.

An Italian haberdasher from Mexico City was charged in a Federal indictment unsealed in Brooklyn yesterday with being the pivotal figure in the flow of $132-million worth of heroin from France to major dealers in the United States and Canada.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., announced yesterday that the Brown Williamson Tobacco Corporation, which recently acquired 93 per cent of Gimbel's stock through a tender offer at $23 a share, had proposed a merger between Gimbel and a wholly owned subsidiary of the tobacco company.

Vice President Agnew has every right to complain that his constitutional rights are being violated by leaks attributed to "Justice Department sources" on allegations supposedly made against him in the current Federal investigation into possible bribery, extortion, tax fraud and conspiracy while Mr. Agnew was Governor of Maryland.

Five reputed organized-crime figures who were indicted last March 28 on charges of having bilked 30 wholesale food distributors out of $50,000 in a so-called "bustout" scheme were indicted again yesterday
Unseeded Eddie Dibbs of Miami, showing an excellent return of serve and sharp passing shots, upset Stan Smith, 7-6, 7-5, in the first round of the $100,000 Canadian open tennis tournament today.

The key figure in a state investigation of alleged municipal corruption in Atlantic City appeared under armed guard in Trenton to go before a state grand jury. The witness, Lee Cohn, an Atlantic City hotel owner, waited outside the jury room most of the day with a bodyguard of four armed plainclothes state policemen before appearing for an hour before the grand jury.

About 2,500 dockers took the day off yesterday at Port Newark and Port Elizabeth for the funeral of one of their union leaders. The action slowed work on about 12 cargo vessels, although the men returned to their jobs at night.

The now-expired price freeze slowed the rise in consumer prices last month but did not stop it, the Labor Department disclosed today. Food prices, in particular, failed to respond completely to the freeze, which ended for food July 18.
A group of Russians clashed today with about 20 Soviet Jews who had rooted for the Israeli basketball team at the World University Games here.
The Cambodian Government appealed to Congress and the American people today to abide by "the moral obligation" of the United States to help

A group of prominent Democrats, including former judges of the state and Federal courts, yesterday endorsed Judge Charles D. Breitel, RepublicanLiberal candidate for chief judge of the State Court of Appeals.

The chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission pledged today to support Governor Cahill's efforts to reduce freight losses on bankrupt rail lines operating in New Jersey through consolidation of facilities and services.

John Milner, who describes himself as "a much more aggressive hitter this year," singled to center with two out in the ninth inning last night to drive in Wayne Garrett from second with the run that enabled the Mets to beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 2-1, at Shea Stadium.
Vice President Agnew accused members of the Justice Department today of an effort "to indict me in the press" and called for an investigation to expose the Federal investigators responsible.

The city sued in Federal Court yesterday seeking to force Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz to certify a national beef shortage and thus bring into play a new law requiring President Nixon to take "appropriate action."
Rescue workers extinguished today a fire that had blocked efforts to reach two men trapped in a copper mine last Friday.
Representative John B. Anderson, a Republican with a safe district and an independent mind, is the kind of man colleagues will look to for signals when Congress reconvenes next month.
To the Editor: Your "Hot Line to Boston" editorial of Aug. 10 is the typical "damn the railroads" gut reaction of the United States press in most situations.

Prince Norodom Sihanouk, describing President Nixon as a liar, denied tonight that while Cambodia's Chief of State he had ever acquiesced in the secret bombing of Cambodia as contended by the President in a New Orleans speech yesterday.
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi entered the talks between Indian and Pakistani officials today in an attempt to resolve the political deadlock on the Subcontinent.
A group of Russians clashed today with about 20 Soviet Jews who had rooted for the Israeli basketball team at the World University Games here.

Is the Kremlin seeking to erect a new iron curtain to isolate its subjects from the outside world as efficaciously as was done in the Stalin era? The possibility may seem absurd in a period of much-publicized detente when Moscow begs for multimillion-dollar Western loans, puts out the red carpet for European and American businessmen, and shuns propaganda exploitation of Watergate as a means of showing its high regard for President Nixon.

Dr. Leslie C. Peacock, 43year-old president of the Crocker National Bank-the 14th largest bank in the country, is going to leave banking and California and go back to his native Texas and build up a ranch.
The Jets' scouting reports on Burgess Owens said he would "play immediately." But nobody expected the No. 1 draft choice to be a starter at strong safety after the third preseason game.
The world lightheavyweight champion, Bob Foster, reacted angrily to what he believed to be a racial slur at the weigh-in for his title defense tonight against Pierrie Fourie of South Africa.
To the motorists who slowed to a crawl as they drove by, the swarm of people arguing around a string of parked cars looked as if they were debating a massive fender-bender.
A seven-member State Department team plans to leave for East Berlin sometime this week for talks on the possible establishment of diplomatic relations, the department said today.
How far left can young zealots in Chancellor Willy Brandt's Social Democratic party take West Germany? The question is often asked by his opponents and by critical foreigners, and it is getting
With eggs selling for a dollar a dozen these days, this hardly seems like the time to start dropping them from the roof of a nine-story building.

Marty Piraino, 50year-old bowler from Syracuse, N.Y., missed a perfect game by one pin yesterday, but his 299 was more than enough to take first place and the $6,000 prize in the $55,000 Columbia open bowling tournament.
Miss Roberta Downs of New York was married in a civil ceremony at a friend's home here yesterday to Count Bernard Claret de La Touche of La Gatinaliere, Chatellerauth, France, and Paris.
The 11 crew members of the experimental raft Acali began five days of isolation today for medical and psychological tests.
The New York Giants sweetened Randy Johnson's incentives as a quarterback today. In what he described as a "gentlemanly" meeting with Coach Alex Webster and Wellington Mara,
The United Auto Workers picked the Chrysler Corporation today as the member of the automotive "big three" that must come to terms on a new contract or face a strike.
United States Air Force guards standing watch over nuclear-armed fighter-bombers opened fire late last week on unidentified persons near the plane's compound, it was disclosed today.
Acknowledging the results of a poll that showed him unable to win, Representative Herman Badillo said yesterday that he would not file as an independent candidate for Mayor of New York City.

In his news conference Monday, Secretary of State Rogers voiced an attitude about freedom and national security that could have spared the Nixon Administration and the nation untold pain and humiliation had it been official policy. Mr. Rogers did not directly disagree with what the President has said recently in this area; but the differences in priority, emphasis and approach were unmistakable.
Warren Archibaid didn't expect -- and didn't get -- a car for being selected as most valuable player in the North American Soccer League.

The Government-owned Canada Development Corporation disclosed today that more than $225-million of Texasgulf, Inc. stock had been tendered in response to its offer to buy 10 million shares of the giant mining company at a price of $29 a share.
The White House made available today to the Watergate special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, files on the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

After 24 years of coaching football at Syracuse, Ben Schwartzwalder had his first losing season last year, five victories and six losses. Steve Dolce, Syracuse's starting middle linebacker from West Orange, N.J., took it personally.

Leaning on a railing at the water's edge on Roosevelt Island, formerly Welfare Island, watching a tanker steam northward towards Hellgate, a visitor could be excused for dreaming for a moment that he, too, was afloat.

All cause of heavy pollution from human waste may be open by Thursday, a beach official said today. Mrs. Carmen Federici, a spokesman for the Federation of Beaches, which operates 18 private beaches on the bay, said the pollution level is receding.

A seriously ill patient was rushed from New Haven to Mt. Sinai Hospital here in less than an hour by Coast Guard helicopter last night so he could be placed in Mt. Sinai's hyperbaric chamber to prevent the spread of gangrene.
Mrs. Muriel G. Bernard, wife of Dr. Canute C. Bernard, a surgeon here, died Monday of cancer at Jamaica Hospital in Queens. She was 52 years old.

The television industry, following two years of declining profits that began with the general economic slump of 1970, rebounded dramatically last year, according to a Federal Communications Commission report issued yesterday.

A young, paroled ex-convict pleaded guilty yesterday to the murder of an 86-year-old homeless man in the rectory of a midtown Roman Catholic church, and he described how the killing occurred last September.

A Manhattan State Supreme Court justice ordered the state's Department of Social Services to pay some 10,000 hospitalized Medicaid patients--who receive Social Security--an estimated $240,000 for their personal expenses. The money represents $4 a month for each person. The $4 had been added to Social Security benefits last year by Congress.

BALE-Ethel Beloved wife of Louis devoted mother of Linda Rosenthal Joan Bayern Cherished grandmother, dear sister of Harry Jack Shana Shirley Goldfarb Services today 12 noon at "The Riverside" Bronx, 179 St. Grand Concourse.

The marriage of Mrs. Laura G. Ross to James J. Ross took 'place here last evening at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Rand, stepfather and mother of the bride. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony.
The Jets' scouting reports on Burgess Owens said he would "play immediately." But nobody expected the No. 1 draft choice to be a starter at strong safety after the third preseason game.

The New York Giants sweetened Randy Johnson's incentives as a quarterback today. In what he described as a "gentlemanly" meeting with Coach Alex Webster and Wellington Mara, the club president, the 28-year-old Johnson said the Giants had altered his contract and "made the situation very attractive for me to stay -- both financially and for the future."
About the only thing that Economists, businessmen and investorss agree about these lays is that they are playing with a deck full of strange cards and jokers. As Paul Valdry,

The prices of nearby wheat futures again soared to historic highs today on the Chicago Board of Trade. The nearest delivery, September, rose the daily permissible limit of 20 cents to close at $5.28 for a 60-pound bushel.

Court papers made public yesterday said that Victor Chernyshev, first secretary of the Soviet Embassy in Washington, was the Russian official who met Air Force Sgt. James D. Wood in an alleged espionagerendezvous here July 21.

Melvin R. Laird acknowledged today that the Watergate scandals had damaged President Nixon's legislative proposals in Congress. But he said the White House now had hopes of early passage of some major Administration bills, notably special revenue sharing for education, which has been considered dead.
The Britannica Encyclopedia of American Art, a onevolume work devoted to the subject, will be published by Simon Schuster 'on Oct. 31. Containing 1,100 entries.

Alfred Hitchcock Presents-Stories to be Read with the Lights On (Random House, $7.95). Thirtyseven stories of murder and suspense. A Life, by Wright Morris (Harper Row, $5.95. An 82-year-old man reminisces.

Mrs. Aloncita Johnson Flood, an executive with the City Manpower and Development Agency and the wife of Roger W. Flood, retired executive and commissioner of the City Housing Authority, died Sunday in Sydenham Hospital.
STREET FESTIVAL The Lower East Side Street Festival, which opens today about noon, is a polyglot--and if you eat enough of the foods offered, possibly also a polyglut--affair.

Lincoln Center will become a film buff's paradise for two weeks when the New York Film Festival begins its 11th year on Sept. 28 with a batch of new movies by such directors as Joseph Losev, Francois Truffaut and Satyajit Ray.

A non registered secondary offering of 375,000 common shares of ITE Imperial Corporation at 16 3/4 per share by Salomon Brothers was reported oversubscribed yesterday. The company's stock closed at 16 3/4, up 1/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Pert Cathy Carr, Olympic gold medalist and world record-holder, paced United States swimmers to three gold medals today in the World University Games and the United States men's and women's basketball teams continued winning streaks.

City detectives raided a Gramercy Park apartment last night and arrested five suspects on narcotics charges, including a 25-year-old woman who, the police said, is a secretary to Parks Commissioner Richard M. Clurman.

A large contingent of New York enthusiasts journeyed to France in. June for the first Monte Carlo Bridge Festival, and returned full of praise for the organization of Jean-Michel Boulenger and the direction of Harold Franklin.

Nine years ago, Edo de Waart was one of six firstprize winners in the Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting competition here, and he subsequently led the New York Philharmonic several times as Leonard Bernstein's assistant.
Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident physicist, declared today that Western reconciliation with Moscow on Soviet terms posed a serious threat to the world.

Japan's wholesale price index soared in the first 10 days of this month, according to the Bank of Japan. The index for the period was 16.6 per cent higher than a year earlier, the bank said in a statement today.
Several members of the rebel force that attempted a coup early yesterday have been executed by the Laotian Army, and there will "no trials" for the rest of the prisoners, the Government said today.

Riva Ridge performed an act of mercy today for Lucien Laurin, if not for the many favorite players among the 17,917 fans who had established him the odds-on choice against five rivals in the 1 1/8-mile feature event.

Patrick H. Hoy, special assistant to the president and formerly a vice chairman and executive vice president of Penn Dixie Industries, Inc., died today of cancer at the Michael Reese Hospital. He was 59 years old.
A virtual national trapshooting unknown won the class AA championship in the opening of the 74th annual Grand American trapshooting tournament yesterday.

Long-haired, bearded, some wearing faded dungarees, carrying chipped sticks, dulled skates, polo-shirtedthey took to the ice yesterday for the once-in-a-lifetime, chance to get a major-league hockey tryout.

Personal checks totaling $3,500 cashed by Police Officer Robert Cameric a few days before his disappearance last Wednesday were returned by the bank marked "insufficient funds," a Police Department spokesman said yesterday.
Stax Records, a major soul music label, uncovered a $406,737 kickback scheme involving two of its employes nearly two years ago but never reported it to Federal authorities, a Government brief filed

Argentina's new Government has forbidden foreign news agencies to supply newspapers throughout the country with local Argentine news. The decree was signed by interim President Raul Lastiri, a Peronist.
William R. Baird, the abortion advocate, has been named as an unpaid consultant to Mayor Lindsay's Office for Veterans Action.

Roberta Kantor, a 28-yearold former editor in chief of the newspaper at the Bronx campus of Hunter College, and the man she lived with, 41-year-old Gerald DeSantis, were found dead from apparent narcotics overdoses Monday in a lower East Side apartment, the police said.
How does one convey the seemingly paradoxical picture of a city whose rhythm of life continues though enemy forces are only 10 miles away?

The wife of a man being sought on a Federal warrant for threatening President Nixon's life went into the ruggged mountains near here today in an attempt to find her husband and convince him to surrender.

" Do you have a room for tonight?" the rumpled father asks wearily. "For how many?" the desk clerk responds knowingly. Out in the car a rumpled mother, three rumpled children and a rumpled dog watch intently.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Aug. 14.
LONDON--In the summer of 1968 Ford's sewing machinists brought Ford's Dagenham plant to a halt They were demanding the right to operate machines which gave them access to the more highly paid grades.

The Skylab 2 crew photographed a giant bubble in the sun's outer atmosphere today, Scientists here termed it the most significant solar event in this mission, which is aimed at delving into the mysteries of the earth's nearest star.
Jack L. Begon, the American Broadcasting Company newsman who turned up here yesterday after having been missing for 29 days, was taken from a clinic to a prison today.

The third annual Community/Street Theater Festival, which opened yesterday in Lincoln Center Plaza, expects to set records for audience and number of performances during the next two weeks, despite the dampening effects of increasing logistical problems and a drastically reduced budget.
The dollar resumed its climb on most major European money markets today after an unexplained decline over the two previous trading sessions.
The Greek Government opened the gates of its prisons today to free hundreds of jailed political enemies, after a general amnesty proclaimed Sunday by President George Papadopoulos.
The Mexican Goverment announced the arrest last night of two men charged with last May's kidnapping of a United States Consul General, Terrance G. Leonhardy.
The Secret Service continued today to press its investigation of what was described as a "very serious, very large" conspiracy by "nonmentals" to assassinate President Nixon

The president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Frank E. Fitzsimmons, repudiated today contracts his field agents negotiated with 30 California grape growers during teamster peace talks with Cesar Chavez of the United Farm Workers.
In defending their glut of reruns, the networks argue that viewers have a chance to see programs they may have missed the first time around.
A 17-year-old youth was stabbed to death and another youth was wounded in a gang fight on a Brooklyn street early yesterday morning, the police reported.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's second largest tire producer (after Goodyear), increased its earnings by 25 per cent in the third fiscal quarter and by 24 per cent in the nine-month period.
Several members of the rebel force that attempted a coup early yesterday have been executed by the Laotian Army, and there will "no trials" for the rest of the prisoners, the Government said today.

A 28-year-old former editor in chief of the newspaper of Hunter College's Bronx campus and the 41-year-old man she was living with were found dead from apparent narcotics overdoses in their Lower East Side apartment Monday evening, the police reported yesterday.

Raymond J. O'Connor, chairman of the board of the Contract Plating Company and a trustee of the American Shakespear Theater and Festival, which he helped bring to Stratford, died Friday at a fishing lodge in Gagnon, Quebec. His age was 78.

Ronald Harvey, a prime suspect in two murders in Cherry Hill, N. J., and seven in Washington, failed to appear for an extradition hearing today, and an assistant United States attorney testified that he had "disappeared."
Gertrude Boatwright Claytor, a poet who won the Poetry Society of America's annual award in 1932, died today. She was 83 years old.
Wilbur Marks, president of the Poseidon Scientific Corporation, which does oceanographic work for the Navy, died today at his home in Dix Hills. His age was 45.
The outer defense perimeter of the former imperial city of Hue came under heavy sustained shelling by Communist gunners last night, the South Vietnamese military command said today.
The third annual Community/Street Theater Festival .had a brilliant opening at -- Lincoln Center yesterdayfloodlit by a hot sun and ornamented by a vivid cross section of who's who in New York.

NEW HAVEN--Those who place the ultimate blame for Watergate on Richard Nixon's childhood go back too far. Those who place it in the tendency of White House power to corrupt don't go back far enough.

Personal checks totaling $3,500 cashed by Police Officer Robert Cameric a few days before his disappearance last Wednesday were returned by the bank marked "insufficient funds," a Police Departmtnt spokesman said yesterday.

" Soul-Train," the black music-dance television program--a sort of "American Blackstand" -- modified itself from its Channel 5 image and reappeared at the Apollo Theater on Monday, in the shape of three soul-music groups and six dancers from the show.

A Government informer, a onetime chief confidant of the alleged ringleader of a plot to disrupt the Republican National Convention last summer, testified today that the only plans he knew of were in a letter urging peaceful demonstrations with some provisions for "self-defense."

Londonderry's coroner accused the British Army today of "unadulterated murder" of the 13 men shot to death Jan. 30, 1972, known here as "Bloody Sunday." He was holding an inquest on the men killed by troops during a rally of Roman Catholics.
The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange dropped by 2,181,894 shares to 17,959,611 shares in the month ended Aug. 15.
The Penn Central Transportation Company reported yesterday a net loss for July of $22.3-million and a net loss of $105.4-million for the first seven months of this year.
On a vacation trip to Moscow last week, Robert Abrams, the Bronx Borough President, sometimes felt he had never left the political circuit at home.
Fifteen explosive devices were found in department stores and the mail today in what appeared to be a new campaign by sympathizers of the Irish Republican Army.
Senator Charles S. Percy, on a tour of the Indian subcontinent, said today that the Watergate scandal had damaged the foreign policy of the United States.
Senior United States sources said today that the military situation in Cambodia had improved substantially but warned of a new battle for the capital.
A state grand jury today indicted for conspiracy several members of a committee that organized a testimonial dinner for Vice President Agnew last year.
" A pregnant employee may now continue working as long as she feels able to perform her duties," Mrs. Ersa H. Poston, president of the State Civil Service Commission,

Evidence is mounting that the decision of the Federal Reserve Board and other agencies in early July to raise the ceilings on interest rates that banks and thrift institutions can pay to savers is having a result that nobody in the Government wanted-a switch of funds out of the savings institutions into commercial banks.
Krzysztof Penderecki, the Polish avant-garde composer, has gone through a curious roller-coaster ride as far as his international reputation is concerned.
Yields for fourmonth commitments to purchase mortgages climbed sharply at the Federal National Mortgage Association's auction, Fannie Mae said today.
Amid the 500,000 gallons of water in the Royals Stadium $750,00 fountain spectacular, the Yankees continued drowning tonight in the Eastern Division title race.

National Football League teams no longer need the protection of television blackouts of home games, a House committee concluded today. The Special Investigations subcommittee of the House Commerce committee recommended that Congress ban blackouts when tickets for regular home season games are sold out before the season opens. It also said Congress should limit the area of any blackouts allowed.

A crowd of about 500 people besieged a police station on the Lower East Side for more than two hours yesterday demanding that the police turn over to them a man they believed to be the slayer of four young boys.

In the last three months of this year, motorists using the lower stretches of the West Side Highway will have to get used to massive disruption of their normal traffic patterns while the city installs a new paving of pre-cast concrete blocks in place of a potholed surface pocked with scores of huge metal repair plates.
The White House made available today to the Watergate special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, files on the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

On the night of July 17, 1973, a double-header was played at Yankee Stadium. Baseball followers will concur that nothing extraordinary transpired on that occasion. A good Yankee ball club twice defeated a Minnesota Twins team as listless as the first two sentences.
Vice President Agnew accused members of the Justice Department today of an effort "to indict me in the press" and called for an investigation to expose the Federal investigators responsible.

Following are a transcript of Vice President Agnew's broadcast news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times, and the text of a statement later by Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson:...
Edmund Whiting, architect and hospital planner, died at his home here on Saturday. He was 62 years old.
United Air Lines, whose advertising has long talked about "the friendly skies," is going to get downright unfriendly to Europe in a forthcoming campaign promoting skiing in the American West.
Mrs. Julia Owsley Wilkins, wife of Fraser Wilkins, former Ambassador to Cyprus and inspector general of the Foreign Service, died yesterday in Georgetown University Hospital. She was 59 years old.
The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia-has set detailed rules that the Government must follow if it wants to withhold information under the Freedom of Information Act.
Nearly 300 opponents of abortion demonstrated last night outside the Columbia Broadcasting System's headquarters to protest a controversial segment of the "Maude" television comedy series.
Hundreds of additional firefighters from around the country were pulled into the effort to control 20 major forest fires in five Western states yesterday.

Routine Federal Bu reau of Investigation chocks of petitions bearing the names of minority party members in Washington state have been pictured by an official of one such group as evidence of the Government's "Watergate mentality."

The television industry, following two years of declining profits that began with the general economic slump of 1970, rebounded dramatically last year, according to a Federal Communications Commission report issued yesterday.

An aggressive young conservative Republican, State Senator Robert E. Bauman, tonight won the nation's first contested postWatergate election for a seat in the House of Representatives, defeating a 60-year-old old-line Democrat, Frederick C. Malkus, also a Maryland State Senator.

At the rate things are going, it appears likely that that plain, old-fashioned ailment, the backache, will be the most common leveler of Americans in about three years, replacing the common cold. The gloomy projection comes from the National Center for Health Statistics, which estimates that 7,000,000 persons are being treated for it right now and that 2,000,000 new cases will be added each year.

A crowd of about 500 people besieged a police station on the Lower East Side for more than two hours yesterday demanding that the police turn over to them a man they believed to be the slayer of four young boys.
A Federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit that accused the city of racial discrimination in refusing to approve a controversial housing project.
A 24-year-old Queens woman, a senior clerk with the New York Telephone Company, was beaten yesterday by five fellow employes in the Canal Stteet station of the BMT, Transit Authority police said.
Three pedestrians were in jured at the lunch hour yesterday when a car jumped a curb at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street and crashed into a gift shop's display window.

Glenn W. Turner, the Florida businessman, who was forced to surrender two Cadillacs in a bankruptcy court order, today got permission to rent a truck from his Orlando-based cosmetics concern, Koscot Interplanetary Inc.
Gordon Jeffery, foreign editor of The London Daily Mirror, died today from injuries he suffered when he was hit by a car. He was 41 years old.
The South Vietnamese Government signed oil exploration contracts worth $16.6million initially today with three of four major companies granted permission to seek petroleum in the South China Sea.

A Government mediator and workers of the bankrupt Lip watchmaking factory in eastern France agreed today to resume talks in an attempt to end the country's worst industrial conflict of the year. Government officials said Henri Giraud, a veteran troubleshooter for labor conflicts, has been given a free hand by Industry Minister Jean Charbonnel to make a deal restoring peace on the labor front before French workers return from vacations late this month.
It was one of those mornings that Nature designed expressly for breakfast on the clubhouse terrace at Saratoga, fresh as the blueberry muffins themselves, cool and dewy like the Hand melons.

Everybody in the trade says racing needs to be simplified so that the public can understand it. And now look: the new management of Ontario (Calif.) Motor Speedway has devised a qualifying procedure that would boggle the mind of a tax lawyer.

The now-expired price freeze slowed the rise in consumer prices last month but did not stop it, the Labor Department disclosed today. Food prices, in particular, failed to respond completely to the freeze, which ended for food July 18.
Major banks that had not raised their prime rates on Monday when the First National Bank of Chicago led a move to a record 9 1/2 per cent joined the parade yesterday, making the level industrywide.

The White House brushed aside today an incident in New Orleans yesterday in which President Nixon shoved his press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, attributing it to the confusion of a day in which plans were changed because of a reported threat n the President's life.
The Seoul District Criminal Court opened the trial of two Presbyterian clergymen and two other South koreans today on charges of attempting to overthrow the Government by force.
Bob Foster, the- light-heavyweight champion, pumped hundreds of left jabs to the bloody face of his South African challenger, Pierre Fourie, and retained his title tonight with a 15round decision.

The Navy said today that it had overpaid the Lockheed Shipbuilding and Construction Company of Seattle for a dozen ships by $42.24-million, but had agreed to postpone getting its money back until Lockheed appeals.

Opponents of the proposed New York City Convention and Exhibition Center, planned for mid-Manhattan's West Side, charged yesterday that traffic to and from the center would snarl traffic in already overburdened streets and create massive air-pollution and noise problems.

Backed by former Interior Secretary Stewart L. Udall, an association representing all the communities on Fire Island asked yesterday for an injunction to halt all commercial development on the island because, it says, the fragile barrier beach is being destroyed.
The Greek Government today completed the release of about 350 political prisoners under the amnesty granted by President George Papadopoulos.

A Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn said he was "favorably disposed" toward an application by a group of Orthodox Jews for a permanent order restraining the city Board of Elections and the state from holding voter registration on Oct. 9, 10 and 13. But the justice, Anthony J. DiGiovanna, added that he was reserving decision on the case.
The Civil Aeronautics Board was told today that it could not bar cuts in trans-Atlantic air fares proposed by foreign carriers. The ruling was made by the United States Court of Appeals

Pope Paul VI today advocated a return to traditional Latin and Gregorian chants in the Roman Catholic liturgy. "Many have asked that in all nations the Latin and Gregorian chants of the Gloria, the Credo, the Sanctus and the Agnus Dei be preserved," he said during a general audience at his summer residence near here.

Edwin M. Gaudet, who was accused of threatening President Nixon's life last week in New Orleans, surrendered to Federal and local officers today after almost two days of hiding in the rugged mountains of northern New Mexico.

New England Electric System yesterday said directors had voted to sell late this year up to 1,250,000 additional common shares to underwriters through selective bidding. The company's stock closed unchanged at 22 1/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Baltimore Orioles won their 10th straight game last night, beating the Minnesota Twins, 4-3, in Baltimore. Brooks Robinson cleared the loaded bases with a twoout single in the first inning that drew the Orioles even at 3-3.

The Russians won three of six swimming events at the World University Games today. The big surprise was the defeat of 18-year-old Cathy Carr, America's world record-holder, in the 100meter breaststroke, her best event.

William P. Rogers does not anger easily, but he was undoubtedly stung when he was described publicly by Senator Stuart Symington as "the laughing stock of the cocktail-party circuit" on the ground that Henry A. Kissinger was already "Secretary of State in all but title. "

Five Connecticut locals of the plumbers union and a statewide association of mechanical contractors yesterday announced agreement on a new two-year contract providing for a lower hourly rate for work on residential housing than on commercial and industrial construction.
The Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday that it had raised the price thatit pays for sour and intermediate crude oil in West Texas and New Mexico by 15 cents.

Last February Mike Bartolotta, a 24-year-old Brooklyn salesman, failed to qualify for the Transit Authority Police because he was threequarters of an inch shorter than the requirement of 5 feet 7 inches.
Following are the texts of Secretary of State William P. Rogers's letter of resignation, dated Aug. 16, and President Nixon's acceptance on Aug. 20:
The Federal Communications Commission ruled today that the Alger Hiss case was no longer a controversy of public importance subject to equaltime provisions of its fairness doctrine.
Prices continued to retreat yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and the overthe-counter market in slow trading.
A company in Princeton stole $10 apiece from 30,000 people across the country by promising free gifts and cash for written opinions about products,
Judge Charles D. Breitel called last night for the spending of "enormous sums" to determine the cause of the "crime explosion" that has taken place in the state.
The state has taken action to combat an outbreak of Eastern equine encephalomyelitis that has killed more than 40 horses in New Hampshire and in Massachusetts.
Weather: Partly sunny today fair, seasonable tonight and tomorrow. Temp. range: today 60-78; Wed. 65-74. Temp.-Hum. Index yesterday 70. Full U.S. report on Page 74.
Heavy rains caused postponement of the United States men's amateur tennis championship program at the Meadow Club today. The third-round matches were rescheduled for tomorrow.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today denied a request by Government lawyers to throw out a major portion of evidence offeared by the Penn Central Railroad in support of its plan to cease operations by the first of the year.

The incessant din of the subway trains assails the senses. Wheels grind out minute particles of steel dust into the stale air. Anonymous faces bob in and out of focus as the rush-hour crowds surge through a nether world where the sun never shines. For those who patrol daily the 231 miles of New York City subways, the transit policeman's lot is not a cushy one.
Two Pennsylvania men have been charged with fraudulent misrepresentation for allegedly using high-pressure selling tactics to obtain advertisements for booklets purporting to promote child safety.

Lee Trevino, claiming he's "an overworked Mexican," plans to cut his appearances on the pro golf tour to 20 weeks next year. "I've worked enough for 10 men in the last six years," he said yesterday. "I'm not going to work this hard again. I've played in something like 30 tournaments a year since I came on the tour."

Still showing a kind of late-summer madness, the Mets gave it the old magic last night before 25,442 customers in Shea. Stadium when they scored two runs with two down in the ninth inning and defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers again. 4-3.

President Nixon said today that he and his family would prefer to be able to do without Secret Service protection, or at least to make do with less of it. But it seems unlikely that the President's wishes will prevail.

The Canadian-New Jersey exchange diving meet, to be held Sunday at the Mountainside community pool, represents more than competition between youngsters from two countries. It has captured all the goodwill that was expected when the meet was initiated nine years ago.
A Hamilton County grand jury, called to consider the case of Robert Garrow Sr., who has been accused of murder, handed up eight sealed indictments against two persons yesterday.

Her reading of the role at Jacob's Pillow last night was modestly successful.

George R. Vila, chairman of Uniroyal, has warned that, unless the national energy supply situation begins to improve soon, the rubber industry may face reductions or shutdowns in operations.
A Rockland County grand jury today returned a 15count indictment against a 24year-old man charged with killing two police officers with his car while under the influence of drugs and alcohol.

In an effort to get better performance from his top commanders, Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley announced yesterday that effective immediately all those above the rank of captain would be subject to reappointment every year and would have to earn that reappointment. The highest civil service rank in the Police Department is captain.

Morrison-Knudson Company, Inc., announced yesterday that it had been awarded a $9.8million contract by the Army for construction of four buildings to house communications equipment and offices at Fort Belvoir, Va.
An off-duty United States marshal and a bar manager ,were shot and seriously wounded in a Brooklyn bar early yesterday morning by two gunmen who held up the bar, the police reported.

Daise E. Terry, former editorial office manager of The New Yorker magazine, died Monday at the age of 89. Miss Terry, who served with Herbert Hoover in relief work in Europe after World War I, joined the magazine as a secretary in 1929.

Richard O. Simpson, chairman of the new Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission, said today that he was prepared to seek a ban on all or some cigarettes if, as expected, an examination confirms the surgeon general's findings in recent years on the hazardous nature of cigarette smoking.

Citing harassment suffered by the Israeli basketball team and its Soviet Jewish fans at the World University Games, the American Jewish Congress urged American athletes yesterday not to participate in sports events in the Soviet Union.
It was Be Kind to Ilie Nastase Day, and the Rumanian tennis star conceded yesterday he would like to change the image that has earned him the nickname of Nasty.
Governor Cahill, who inherited a $300-million budget deficit when he took office nearly four years ago, could leave his successor a surplus exceeding $200-million.

Volume gains in its department stores and Venture Stores discount chain contributed to the record sales and earnings of the May Department Stores Company in the quarter and six months ended Aug. 4, according to yesterday's midyear report.

Four hundred Greenwich Village residents, alarmed by two murders in an eight-day period this month, demonstrated in front of the Sixth Precinct police station last night, demanding more foot patrolmen and new laws to clear the Village of drug pushers and users.

Seven prominent Maryland Republicans, all friends or supporters of Vice President Agnew, were identified by the state prosecutor here today as members of a committee indicted yesterday for conspiracy to conceal a $49,900 contribution to an Agnew testimonial last year.

The incident-ridden basketball series at the World University Games erupted into another clash today as Cuban and United States players came to blows with less than two minutes remaining in their game.
Federal designation of a bowling pin coating as a possible cause of cancer has led to unemployment for 47 persons in this north country village.

Ludi Claire, who only this week joined the cast of Neil Simon's "The Prisoner of Second Avenue," taking over the role of Gabriel Dell's sister from Ruth Mannings, is collaborating on a musical version of Shaw's "Major Barbara"' with Jule Styne, the composer.

A Government witness gave damaging testimony today against eight persons accused of plotting to disrupt the 1972 Republican National Convention, but then seemed to reverse part of his testimony on crossexamination.
The Federal Government warned today of a possible safety defect in 2.5 million passenger cars built by the Chrysler Corporation.
John Riggins, the New York Jets' leading rusher last season and this year's leading holdout, showed up at camp at 7:15 o'clock tonight.

Pressed by rising costs and shifting student tastes, a small but growing number of colleges across the country are discarding the old nine-month school year for something that promises more money and more flexibility-the 12-month campus.

President Nixon announced today that he had accepted with "personal regret" the resignation'of William P. Rogers as Secretary of State and would nominate Henry A. Kissinger, the White House adviser on national security, to take over the senior Cabinet position.

Statements today by several members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee indicated that Henry A. Kissinger might face far tougher questioning in hearings on his nomination as Secretary of State than was initially indicated.
A tobacco-state Representative said today he would offer an amendment to the Hazardous Substances Act to prevent the Consumer Products Safety Commission from trying to ban cigarettes.
The nation's stock exchanges, symbols of wealth and power in the world of finance, are having trouble earning money themselves.

An investigation into complaints about some literature supporting Controller Abraham D. Beame in the Democratic mayoral runoff has concluded that some were unjustified and that there was no existing law to cover others, District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx said yesterday.
Dr. C. Holman Lovell, one of the oldest practicing physicians in Brooklyn, died Wednesday at his home, 418 Hancock Street, Brooklyn. He was 81 years old.

Nine persons described as the top echelon of the Black Liberation Army were indicted in Brooklyn yesterday on charges ranging from murder and attempted murder to robbery, grand larceny and possession of guns.
The price of gold fell briefly under $100 an ounce today for the second time since May. The United States dollar's value rose nearly everywhere.

Steven Anthony Cropper, the six-year-old boy who was found murdered and mutilated last Friday on a building roof, was buried yesterday after funeral services at the DeWitt Reformed Church on the Lower East Side.
William Nafash, chief projectionist at Radio City Music Hall, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Wednesday evening ?? route to his home in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. He was 69 years old.

In this region of Cambodia, where rice fields and jungle are strewn with the superb ruins of the 12th-century Angkor civilization, the recent American bombing halt has had no effect so far, for the war here had long been in virtual suspense.

A murder suspect was briefly allowed to see her week-old son for the first time Tuesday night, thanks to the intervention of a judge. But the baby was taken from her following the mother's return yesterday to Tioga County Jail in Owego.

President Nixon seriously misstated the issue of the secret Cambodian bombing of 1969-70 in his address to the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention in New Orleans. The question is not the one he posed: "How could the United States make a secret attack on tiny Cambodia?" The real question is: How could Mr. Nixon break faith with the American people two months after taking office?
A Vietcong spokesman said today that five European newsmen who were missing yesterday in a Vietcong zone north of Saigon were safe and being well treated.

To the Editor: In a recent letter, scientist-astronauts Joseph Allen and Karl Henize seemed to focus more on my personal credibility than on the issues I raised in my June Op-Ed article on space priorities. I regret this approach because I feel it clouds the substance of our disagreement.
A Federal judge declared unconstitutional today an Air Force regulation requiring servicemen to obtain permission from their commanders before they can collect signatures for a petition.

Nearly 20,000 persons who were either retired or were still working but had accumulated advance pension benefits lost $48.7-million last year when their companies terminated private pension plans, according to a report to President Nixon.

Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the dissident author, disclosed today that he had been barred from living legally in Moscow. He used the occasion for an angry attack on the Soviet Union's residence controls as a "demeaning system that probably does not exist even in the colonial countries."

Alan King should, I suppose, get some kind of credit for trying. Wearing the hat of 'executive producer, the come-dian has obviously given considerable time and effort to a series called "The Corner Bar." Produced in New York

Don Kessinger's 10th-inning single with two out drove in Randy Hundley from third, giving the Chicago Cubs a 4-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today. It was Chicago's third straight and fifth in the last six games.
Ilie Nastase was upset by Onny Parun, 6-4, 1-6, 6-2, in the second round of the $30,000 Eastern grass-court tennis championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.

Esmark, Inc., formerly Swift Co., which operates the nation's largest meat-packing business, increased its profits substantially in the three and nine months ended July 31, despite ceilings, shortages and boycotts, according to a report issued yesterday.

Forget all those sweaters and tweeds filling the racks of stores around town. Summer is not yet over. Some people have a late-summer vacation ahead of them. And others want some new duds for the big Labor Day weekend. Well, no need to settle for picked-over markdowns.

Henry A. Kissinger, newly nominated to be Secretary of State, pledged to carry out a more open foreign policy in which Congress, the State Department and private citizens would have a stronger voice. Speaking at a news conference on the lawn of the Western White House, he said he would work through Congress for a nonpartisan policy, now that the United States was out of the Vietnam war. President Salvador Allende Gossens's experiment of Socialism in Democracy is threatened by intensified opposition that has taken the form of strikes, sabotage, street violence and now, Congressional denunciation.
A History of Croatia, by Stephen Gazi (Philosophical Library, $11.95). Closing Time, by Norman O. Brown (Random House, $5.95). Commentary on the ideas of Giambattista Vico and James Joyce.

The South Korean Government today told Yomiuri Shimbun, one of Japan's leading daily newspapers, that its bureau here would be closed and its correspondents expelled unless it retracted a report it published this morning on the kidnapping from Tokyo to Seoul of Kim Dae Jung.
A former leading Opposition senator who was arrested 11 months ago has been charged with subversion and murder.

The Gannett Company, Inc., has announced agreement in principle to acquire three daily newspapers in Springfield, Mo., and Muskogee, Okla., and their broadcast affiliates in common stock transactions totaling $33.4-million.

A team of unhurried gunmen invaded the lobby of the sedate Crovdon Hotel on 86th Street near Fifth Avenue early yesterday, subdued seven persons, including the jazz musician, Maynard Ferguson, and made off with an estimated total of $100,000 in cash and jewels.
The new 10-member Board of Elections, bogged down in political infighting, has failed repeatedly to elect board officials it should have chosen at its first meeting on July 16.
The Nastase was upset by Onny Parun, 6-4, 1-6, 6-2, in the second round of the $30,000 Eastern grasscourt tennis championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.

The city's Housing and Development Administration yielded yesterday to the demand of the owner-tenants of the Lindsay Park middle-income cooperative in Brooklyn to replace the original management board representing the sponsor with one representing the residents.

The Cubans said they were sorry and were given a mild reprimand for attacking their United States rivals in a World University Games basketball contest yesterday.
The huge profit gains reported by American corporations so far this year represent largely "phantom profits," the Morgan Guaranty Survey says in its August edition, to be published today.

Secretary General Waldheim appealed to governments and relief agencies today to assist Pakistan, a country stricken by devastating floods. He said that the floods had destroyed $250-million in crops and left five million people homeless.

Though plagued by delays from political in-fighting, racial strife, lawsuits and administrative red tape, this city appears on the verge of a breakthrough in an area that is anathema to most suburban towns-public housing.
Federal agents and the New Orleans police are investigating a report, as yet unconfirmed, that two black extremists plotted to kill President Nixon, according to sources close to the investigation.
The Signal Companies, Inc., announced yesterday a third successful exploratory well, which it said confirmed the Thistle Field in the British Sector of the North Sea as a major commercial oil field.

A 9 P.M. to 6 A.M. curfew for youths 18 years old and younger went into effect here tonight, and Mayor Henry R. Cioffi was so pleased with the community's peaceful response that he declared that the curfew would end at 6 A.M. tomorrow.
Miss Cathy L. Robinowitz and Andrew E. Randall, 1973 graduates of Bradley University, were married in the garden of the Rye Town Hilton this afternoon by Rabbi Samuel Silver.

Miss Linda Kay Schwartz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Schwartz of Roslyn, was married this evening to Philip Reed Carlson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Carlson of Toledo, Ohio. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony at the Old Westbury Country Club.

The major international agreements governing the world oil market are coming apart under the pressure of price instability for crude oil and the political drive by Middle East producing countries for greater control over their oil.

That old Mets' magic didn't quite make it last night in Shea Stadium as the Los Angeles Dodgers scored a 5-4 victory and prevented a three-game sweep by the most successful last-place team in baseball.

The New York State Banking Department moved yesterday to curb excessively tight credit restrictions for home mortgages with an announcement that it would monitor the terms that various lending institutions are requiring for such loans.

Cesar Chavez, president of the United Farm Workers Union, appealed to an audience of union teachers today to support his struggle with California grape growers and with the teamsters' union, a struggle he said was far from over despite conciliatory moves by the national teamster leadership.
The number of Greek political prisoners freed under a broad amnesty granted Sunday by President George Papadopoulos rose to some 300 today.

A clean-shaven John Riggins, sporting a "Mohawkstyle" hairdo, put in his first appearance at the New York Jets' training camp at Hofstra University last night and today tried to explain what turned him into a salary holdout.
The Securities and Exchange Commission today filed fraud charges against Glen-Arden Commodities, Inc., in connection with the sale of Scotch whisky investment contracts.
Robert D. Swensen, manager of the operational division of the Communications Satellite Corportion, Washington, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 40 years old.

Government investigators now believe that as many as 15 or 20 of the names on a White House master list of campaign contributors may represent illegal cash donations from corporations, according to sources close to the investigation. The sources said these donations totaled up to $1.5-million.
An American scientist who just returned from a 19-day inspection trip to North Vietnam said yesterday that he was "embarrassed and saddened and numbed" by the bomb damage there.

The Canada Development Corporation announced yesterday that it will not accept tenders for more than 10 million shares of Texasgulf, Inc. common stock in response to its offer to purchase Texasgulf shares at $29 a share in cash.
Secretary of State-designate Henry A. Kissinger struck just the right note yesterday with his promise to conduct a more open, bipartisan foreign policy "in full and new partnership with Congress."

It was so serene as the sunlight filtered through the trees near the International Barn this morning that it was jolting to hear a special policeman say, "That damned horse is the meanest animal I ever saw."

Informed Justice Department sources disclosed today that what one of them called "illegal and unlawful" burglaries by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had taken place in this country over a 30-year period that began under the Administration of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and ended in 1966.

William N. Cross, president of the New York State Fire Fighters Association from 1944 to 1968 died today in Faxton Hospital. He was 66 years old.

Researchers in Cambridge, England, are investigating one of the most basic elements of the life process: the "switching system" that, in all living cells, regulates the flow of information needed for their function.
A Harris County grand jury returned four new indictments today against two youths charged in the sex-torture slayings case in which 27 bodies have been recovered.

A Federal grand jury that has been looking into the affairs of a number of officials, including Vice President Agnew, today indicted N. Dale Anderson, the executive of suburban Baltimore County, on 39 counts centering on bribery, extortion and conspiracy.
Ending a 12-session losing streak, prices on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday despite relatively slow trading. Prices in the over-the-counter market also showed a gain.

A Superior Court judge rejected today Lance Rentzel's request for an injunction ending the Los Angeles Ram wide receiver's National FootLeague suspension for conduct detrimental to the league. Judge David A. Thomas made the decision after considering arguments over the application for a preliminary injunction that were presented yesterday.

Dan Pastorini threw a 31yard touchdown pass to Fred Willis with 1 minute 12 seconds to play tonight as the Houston Oilers earned a 27-24 exhibition football victory over the Dallas Cowboys, ending a 14-game losing streak.
United States swimmers scored a sweep of the five events today and the fightshaken men's basketball team gained the final in the Americans' finest day at the World University Games.
Herbert J. Wagner, former commander of the New Jersey Air Force Reserve, died yesterday in Point Pleasant Hospital. He was 56 years old.

Mike Ryan is a girl. Mary Elizabeth Ryan of Laurel, Md., to be exact. Nobody on the race track calls her by any other name than Mike, and most people know her because she's the assistant to Johnny Campo in the task of training 43 horses now cn the grounds.

Ten armed members of the American Indian Movement took over the State Department of Public Instruction offices yesterday but surrendered peacefully and were arrested after law enforcement officers threatened a showdown.

Bond prices, again reversing course, rose sharply in an active credit-market session dominated by successful offerings of two new corporate and taxexempt issues and the prospect of strong bidding today on 83/8 per cent Treasury notes.

Jim Montgomery of the Badger Dolphins from Madison, Wis., captured the 200-meter free-style race with a meet-record time of 1 minute 53.698 seconds at the national Amateur Athletic Union swimming championship tonight.

Chuck Rayner, a goalie, and Doug Harvey, a defenseman, were among five men inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame yesterday in Toronto. Rayner, one of the most popular players ever to play for the New York Rangers, spent 10 years in the National Hockey League, two with the old New York Americans.

A public offering of 200,000 common shares of Michigan Gas Utilities Company at $14.25 a share was announced yesterday by Kidder, Peabody Co. The company's stock closed unchanged at 14 1/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Board of Public Utility Commissioners conceded today that the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company did not have to give it 45 days' notice on dividend payments that Bell made to the parent American Telephone Telegraph Company.
Dave Stockton said that spike marks on the putting greens had both helped and hurt him as he scored a 67 today and shared the lead in the $100,000 Liggett Myers golf tournament.

For the last 10 years the summer slogan among distance runners along north shore areas of New Jersey has been, "See you at Takanasse." Each Monday evening since 1964, from early June through late August, the Shore Athletic Club has conducted a series of running and walking events at the quiet, shoreside lake in the West End section of this Monmouth County community.
Dr. Margaret Blenkner, a leader in the field of gerontology, died last Friday. She was 64 years old.
At least six more record companies have received subpoenas this month from the Federal grand jury in Newark that is investigating allegations of payola.

The National Cash Register Company and the Control Data Corporation announced yesterday the formation of the CDCNCR Advanced Systems Laboratory to conduct joint design of future computer central processing units.

Representative Mario Biaggi has given private assurances to at least three of the city's Democratic county chairmen that he will not make a "serious run" for Mayor, even though he is the Conservative party nominee.

A former Brooklyn police detective who was indicted with another detective last December on bribery charges arising from the electronic bugging of an alleged Mafia meeting place in a Canarsie junkyard won reinstatement to the police force yesterday pending a departmental trial.
The stock market staged a technical rebound yesterday and turned in its best performance in almost a month as stocks made a broad advance in continued light trading.
Three physicists from Peking attended the opening session of a two-day international physics conference here today.
President Nixon's affirmation of confidence yesterday in Vice President Agnew has not eased the tension between their two offices.

Maybe it was more than their need for an experienced tight end that made the New York Giants pick up 33-yearold Gary Ballman on waivers from the Philadelphia Eagles during the offseason.

The Yankee body, barely breathing, arrived in Oakland yesterday and it was in such miserable shape the thought of keeping it alive seemed to be cruel and agonizing punishment for the people who give life and sustenance to that body.

Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson disclosed today that a full-scale' internal investigation of the Department of Justice was being conducted to determine if its personnel had leaked information to the press about a Federal investigation involving Vice Presdent Agnew.
John Beers of Canada won the high jump today at 7 feet 3 1/2 inches in an international meet and set a Canadian record. He also defeated the world recordholder, Dwight Stones of the United States..

Don Kessinger's 10th-inning single with two out drove in Randy Hundley from third, giving the Chicago Cubs a 4-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today. It was Chicago's third straight and fifth in the last six games.
Taxi drivers are going to be ensconced in comfortable bucket seats and enclosed in bulletproof metal and glass cabins in fleet-operated cabs, according to a new city mandate.
The auto industry today reported an 11.4 per cent jump in sales to a record 207,555 cars in the Aug. 11-20 period, up from 186,270 in the comparable period a year ago.

Federated Department Stores Inc., which includes in its nationwide department store chain Bloomingdale's and Abraham Straus here, rang up record sales and earnings in the quarter and six months ended July 29.
Revenue agents today investigated a reported wine fraud involving false labeling of 1.9 million bottles of red Bordeaux wine, French newspapers said.
Railway stations in London became the latest targets for a bomb attack and bombing threats tonight after four days in which bombs had been planted in department stores.

John E. Herlihy Jr., a broken with E. F. Hutton Co. and former advertising manager for Newsweek International in New York and London, died Wednes day in New York Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived ?? 252 East 61st Street.

A new group was reported today to be competing with Robert H. Abplanalp, the millionaire industrialist, for control of the all-but-dormant Sullivan County International Airport.

The New York Public Library has returned an apparently lost book to circulation. Its 76-year-old scholarly journal, The Bulletin, has resumed publication after being suspended in December, 1971, in the wake of the library's financial crises.
The writer of the following article, a member of the staff of The New York Times who was born in Hong Kong, recently completed a 13-day private visit to China.
Consummers continued to pull the rug from under livestock and egg prices on the big Midwest exchanges today and once again all cattle, hog and broiler futures dropped their daily permissile limits.

Bjorn Borg, the 16-year-old Swede, and unheralded Ivan Molina of Columbia played the matches of their lives today to sideline Ken Rosewall and Rod Laver in the $100,000 Canadian open tennis tournament.

Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier whose extradition to the United States was rejected by the courts here, said in an interview published today that he believed his presence in the United States would aggravate the Watergate case.

The Association of American Railroads today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.1 billion ton-miles; 6-5 per cent above the corresponding week last year.

The city school system reversed itself yesterday and said it would provide "the same proportion of meat meals" in its lunch program as last year four a week in most schools, three in others - instead of eliminating one a week as announced last Sunday.
Jerome Kretchmer, former Environmental Protection Administrator, yesterday endorsed Jacob D. Fuchsberg, the Democcatic nominee, for election as chief judge of the State Court of Appeals.
Among the actions of the delegates to the American Legion convention in Honolulu was a resolution denouncing "persons for their actions and for their verbal attacks upon our prisoners of war."

Billy Talbert, the tournament director of the United States Open tennis championship, exuded optimism yesterday at the draw for the tournament, which begins Wednesday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.
Environmentalists asked a Federal Court here today to enjoin temporarily construction of a 25,000 car-parking lot at the proposed Hackensack Meadowlands sports complex.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 209.5 from 213.2 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 120.4 on Aug. 22, 1972.

A newsprint shortage caused by a strike at Canadian paper mills has forced some newspapers to reduce the size of their papers and others to reduce the waste of paper, according to a survey by United Press International.

The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

The city's Schools Chancellor, Irving Anker, upheld yesterday the ouster of Claude L. Huntley as acting principal of an intermediate school in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. Mr. Huntley was removed by Community School Board 14.

The Boothe Computer Corporation yesterday asked the American Stock Exchange and the Pacific Stock Exchange to halt trading in the company's common stock and its 5 3/4 convertible subordinated debentures.

A senior Air Force officer said today that the accidental bombing that killed 137 Cambodians in the town of Neak Luong on Aug. 6 was due primarily to the failure of the B-52's radarnavigator to throw a single switch.

Dr. Eleanor Bernert Sheldon, president of the Social Science Research Council of New York, has been named the first woman director of the First National City Corporation, and of its chief subsidiary, the First National City Bank.

Even in the usual sleepy season of summer reruns and tryouts, the television networks and stations are finding that the pressure groups never rest. C.B.S. has had more than its share this year of boycott campaigns started by would-be censors among its viewers.
The Kawasaki Steel Corporation of Japan said today it planned to build a small steel plant in the United States.
The Government published today a monumental, computerized compilation of the names of some 70,000 persons who contributed or lent $79.1-million to all candidates in the 1972 Presidential campaign.

The General Accounting Office reported to Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, today that an Air Force general had spent $670,000 in public funds to convert his aircraft into a plush executive jet.

Dr. Henry Alexander Davidson, psychiatrist and author, died today at his home, 276 Prospect Street. He was 68 years old.

Government troops have recaptured three positions important to the defense of the provincial capital of Kompong Speu and Phnom Penh's highway to the sea, the Cambodian military command reported yesterday.

Angelo DeCarlo paid the first installment of a $20,000 fine yesterday when his wife appeared in Federal Court and presented a check for $2,000. A judge had ordered the reputed Mafia leader to pay the fine or be returned to prison.
Canada's seasonally adjusted exports in July rose 4 per cent to $2,068-billion from June's $1.986-billion, up 35 per cent from a sear earlier, Statistics Canada said in a preliminary statement today.
Federal prosecutors disclosed here yesterday that they were investigating at least two cases involving "some evidence of possible criminal conduct by state court judges."
State auditors have disallowed $3.8-million of $10.1-million in claims made by the city's Addiction Services Agency, according to a report yesterday by State Controller Arthur Levitt.
A Pakistani spokesman said today that officials were "trying hard to reach the stage where an agreement can be worked out" on the problems arising from the Indian-Pakistani war of 1971.

A team of unhurried gunmen invaded the lobby of the sedate Croydon Hotel 86th Street off Fifth Avenue early yesterday, subdued seven persons, including the jazz musician Maynard Ferguson, and made off with loot estimated at $100,000 in cash and jewels.

Informed Justice Department sources disclosed today that what one of them called "illegal and unlawful" burglaries by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had taken place in this country over a 30-year period that began under the Administration of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and ended in 1966.

Dr. Rolf L. Bolin, a marine biologist and a professor of marine biology and oceanography at Stanford University from 1930 to 1966, died of cancer last evening at Monterey Peninsula Community Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived here.

John G. Jackson Jr., counsel to the law firm of Jackson, Nash, Brophy, Barringer Brooks, of which he was a former senior partner, died Wednesday in Community Hospital, Glen Cove, L. I. He was 63 years old and lived on Cedar Ridge Road in Locust Valley, L. I.
Credit conditions tightened and growth in the money supply slowed in the week ended Wednesday, data released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.
An official of the Massachusetts Mental Health Department has decided to stop feeding the names of patients confined at state institutions into a corn puter bank in Orangeburg, N.Y.

Representative Mario Biaggi has given private assurances to at least three of the city's Democratic county chairmen that he will not make a "serious run" for Mayor, even though he is the Conservative party nominee.
Firefighters won their sixday battle yesterday with the most stubborn of the forest fires raging in the West by handdigging 30 miles of line around a blaze near Lake Tahoe in California.
Communist troops fired more than 300 mortar shells into Government positions guarding the former imperial capital of Hue, the South Vietnamese command said today.

Lunchtime strollers stood raptly silent in front of the New York Public Library yesterday as a lean, whitefaced figure clad in black from neck to toe plastered an imaginary wall, tugged on a nonexistent rope and drove a phantom automobile up the library steps.

White House aides, convinced that President Nixon came through "with flying colors" at his first meeting with reporters in five months, indicated today that he might hold another news conference in a few days.

The Government, in a move to encourage commercial banks to make mortgage loans, told banks today that they no longer have to limit mortgage interests rates to mid-April levels. The go-ahead to lend at rates equivalent to effective yields on mortgages insured or guaranteed by the Government was given by the Committee on Interest and Dividends. On April 16, in an effort to keep interest rates

Henry A. Kissinger, newly nominated to be Secretary of State, pledged today to carry out a more open foreign policy in which Congress, the State Department and private citizens would have a stronger voice.
A police undercover agent told a jury here today how he infiltrated the Vietnam Veterans Against the War.

Six proposals that could shape the future of Hudson County's scandal - ridden Meadowview Hospital as well as lead to increased Federal and state aid were presented to the County Board of Freeholders today by the Hospital's planning commission.

Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley yesterday unveiled a "master plan" for improving the Police Department, giving high priority to new anti-corruption measures, faster police response to emergency calls from the public and the recruitment of more minoritygroup members as policemen.

The National Energy Board has confirmed that a natural gas export price increase under a contract between Westcoast Transmission, Ltd., of Vancouver and a United States concern is acceptable, a board official said today.

The Federal Reserve said today its board of governors voted to amend regulation "Q" effective Sept. 10, to impose early withdrawal penalties on any changes in either the maturity or interest rate on existing certificates of deposit.
The Veterans of Foreign Wars have overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to allow women to join their organization. A bylaw to this effect
Skylab 2's astronauts, preparing for a four-hour space "walk" tomorrow, rehearsed today the installation of instruments needed to keep their ship sailing on a true course through space.

Henry A. Kissinger, newly nominated to be Secretary of State, pledged today to carry out a more open foreign policy in which Congress, the State Department and private citizens would have a stronger voice.
The owner-manager of a midtown welfare hotel was arrested yesterday on fraud charges involving the illegal cashing of more than $6,000 in public-assistance checks.
