" They're walking billboards," said Barry Reifler. He was bragging about the ubiquitous plastic tote bags-with molded handles, reinforced handles or draw strings-that display advertising messages of one sort or another. His company, Uniflex, Inc., produces over 40 million of them each year.

Karen Magnussen, who won the world figure skating championship last March in Czechoslovakia, made her local professional debut Wednesday night at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I.
A 28-year-old man, walking home from a shopping trip with his wife, was shot to death on a street in Jamaica, Queens, last evening by one of two holdup men, the police reported.
After completing a tabulation of registrations, school officials say enrollment in the Memphis system, which faces widescale busing for desegregation on Monday, is down by 20,000 to 30,000 pupils.

William R. Baird, the birth-control advocate, attempted unsuccessfully yesterday to see Mayor Lindsay at City Hall for an explanation of the "shortest political career in history." Mr. Baird, who said he had been appointed on Tuesday as a consultant on abortion and birth control to the Mayor's Office for Veterans Action, found he had been let go from the nonsalaried advisory position the next day.
A considerable literature on the Precision System has grown up during the four years since it first made its impact in the 1969 world championship.

BELGRADE-The strengthening of the role of Europe is most frequently explained by its prosperity and its high level of technology. In most instances such explanations are made with Western Europe in mind.
Henry A. Kissinger's nomination as Secretary of State was welcomed in Jerusalem today.
The Atomic Energy Commission disclosed today that it was investigating a possible "fuel densification" problem in 10 of the nation's 34 operating atomic plants.
A banner with the words "women power" was raised over the public gallery of the American Stock Exchange yesterday by a dozen members of the New York chapter of the National Organization for Women.

The State Department today reiterated its opposition to changes in the status of Israeli-occupied Arab territory in the wake of an Israeli Labor party plan for public and private purchases of Arab lands. The Department spokesman, Paul J. Hare, was asked at a news briefing to comment on
" I go to dif: ferent wilderness places every year," said Mrs. Mary Muhihausen, a widow from Huntington, L.I., who spent last summer on a five-week camping trip in Nepal.

A man indicted on a murder charge, who had been released on bail last week after spending a year in prison awaiting trial, was being sought yesterday by the police for allegedly attacking one of the witnesses against him and threatening "to get" others who say they saw him stab to death a robbery victim two years ago.
Masuo Araki, former education minister and a member of the ruling Liberal Democratic party in the House of Representatives, died tonight of a heart attack. He was 74 years old.

A Federal judge today struck down regulations prohibiting newsmen from interviewing prisoners in Federal custody, saying that such regulations violated the newspaper's rights under the First Amendment.

South Jamaica children were playing at a street party yesterday less than 20 yards from the spot where 28-year-old Eugene Dantzler was shot and killed Thursday evening as he and his wife were taking a short cut to their home.
The Atomic Energy Commission ordered 10 nuclear power plants in various areas today to limit their operations and cut back power levels pending further studies.
Domestic auto makers' stepped up the flow of 1974 models almost 50 per cent this week despite a parts shortage that held Chrysler to the production of just a few thousand cars.
A Federal judge has dropped the Republican National Committee and its chairman from a damage suit at the request of the antiwar activist who filed the suit.

John A. B. Fisher, 62, has been elected chairman of the American Totalisator Company, a subsidiary of the General Instrument Corporation. James H. Pierce, 43, a vice president from the Servmation Corporation, has been named to succeed Mr. Fisher as president of AmTote.

A 39-year-old former convict was arraigned in the criminal part of State Supreme Court in Manhattan in the stabbing murder of a young woman in the hallway of her Greenwich Village apartment house earlier this month. Hosie S. Turner of 330 West 36th Street pleaded not guilty to a charge of killing Roberta Herbert. Justice Andrew Tyler continued him without bail for a hearing on Sept. 13.

A man indicted on a murder charge, who had been released on bail last week after spending a year in prison awaiting trial, was being sought yesterday by the police for allegedly attacking one of the witnesses against him and threatening "to get" others who say they saw him stab to death a robbery victim two years ago.

A Federal judge ruled today that the Government's Phase 4 regulations on most gasoline sold at the pump could not go into effect when the present extended freeze on retail gasoline prices expires Aug. 31.
Japan today postponed an important meeting of Japanese and South Korean Cabinet ministers to register public displeasure over the abduction of a South Korean Opposition leader from Tokyo.

Faced with drastically curtailed supplies of their most important offering--beef--restaurants in the metropolitan area are trying to make do in a variety of ways, adding surcharges to beef dishes on the menu, creating new non-beef dishes, even deliberately running out of beef in the belief that it is not worth the...
The possibility of tight cotton supplies later this year and the current absence of export controls spurred buying of cotton futures by the trade and commission houses yesterday.

A nationwide walkout of railway workers began last night in Canada and management and union leaders met with a federal mediator today in an effort to reach a settlement.
The president of B'nai B'rith sharply criticized the White House freeze on Federal housing subsidies today, describing it as "having crippled construction" of low-rent housing for the elderly poor.

South Vietnamese units withstood a series of shelling attacks, brief firefights and mine traps during the 24-hour period ended at noon today, the military command said. It said 38 Government soldiers and 19 Communist soldiers were killed in the fighting. Six civilians were also reported killed.

Representative Edward I. Koch asserted yesterday that a hotel just down the block from Carnegie Hall has more than 70 welfare families and is collecting rent of more than $1,600 a month each from some of these families.

TOKYO--After almost eight years of marriage to a member of a distinguished Japanese family, Mrs. Joan McCullough Itoh now easily kneels in the tradition of a good Japanese wife and almost touches the tatami-matted floor with her forehead when guests come to their house.

Not since some local dentists were accused of wholesaling marijuana has a local scandal set so many Boulderites afire. Corruption in politics is one thing, they say, but cheating at the Soapbox Derby is almost an affront to the flag.
John Hencken of the Santa Clara, Calif., Swim Club set a world record tonight in the men's 200-meter breast-stroke event in the National Amateur Athletic Union championships.

By pleading guilty to destruction of evidence, a Long Island used-car dealer who was also suspected of dealing in heroin, wound up yesterday with a $4,000 profit and the memory of the "best vacation" he ever had - all at Government expense.

Charles W. Bray 3d has resigned as the State Department's spokesman because he does not want to work for Henry A. Kissinger if Mr. Kissinger is confirmed by the Senate as Secretary of State, a reliable source reported today.

Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, the Liberal party candidate for Mayor, yesterday urged the use of sound management procedures in the criminal courts to permit more efficient handling of cases and to speed their priorities.

Bail for two women and a man arrested in a drug raid last Tuesday was reduced from $4-million to $25,000 yesterday after a chemical analysis showed the confiscated narcotics to be neither heroin nor cocaine.
Othello, the chestnut prince of Soviet horses, was unveiled this morning at Roosevelt Raceway, and one American groom turned to a friend and asked, "Would you bet this horse?"

Avenging last summer's defeat at the Munich Olympics, the young United States men's basketball team stunned the Soviet Union, 75-67, today and American swimmers added five gold medals in the dramatic conclusion of the World University Games.

Food prices continue to hold the principal attention of most consumers, but there are other subjects of im portance that should not be lost sight of. Some of these received attention recently at the convention of the Con summer Federation of America in Milwaukee.
Ken Germann, the athletic director at Columbia University for the last five years, was named yesterday commissioner of the Southern Conference.
Twelve law enforcement officers were indicted by a Federal grand jury today in connection with a series of mistaken drug raids in southwestern Illinois last April.
The United States announced an agreement with Thailand today for the start of a phased withdrawal of American forces and aircraft from Thailand.

Gilbert Shaw, founder and president of Polymers, Inc., a synthetic-fiber manufacturer in Middlebury, died Wednesday at the age of 60. He was stricken while vacationing at his summer home in Charlotte and died in a Burlington hospital.
Clarence J. Henry, a retired justice of the State Supreme Court, died yesterday in Strong Memorial Hospital. He was 70 years old.

This morning the Skylab 2 astronauts will pass the mark set by their predecessors of Skylab 1 and become participants in the longest manned-space mission in history. Perhaps even more remarkable is the whole change of atmosphere and attitude about this mission: Little is heard now of earlier fears that a rescue rocket might have to be sent up next month to bring back the three spacemen.

Two young men who told the police they were sons of the late William V.S. Tubman, the President of Liberia who died in 1971, have been arrested here on a charge of criminal possession of a dangerous drug, a felony punishable by up to 15 years in prison.

Francis A. Byrne Sr., father of Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate for Governor, died today at Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 86 years old. The staff for the candidate said his campaign schedule had been canceled until Sept. 2.

The stock market yesterday tried its best but failed to hold on to Thursday's rally. Prices opened higher with the Dow-Jones industrial average up 3.84 at 11 A.M. and the New York Stock Exchange index ahead 0.09.
The Quaker Oats Company yesterday reported record sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended June 30.
The Dolly Madison Ice Cream Company has been ordered by a Federal bankruptcy judge to suspend operations, effective today. day.
Another wave of strikes, involving the shutdown of shops and transportation, was reported today in nine of Chile's provinces. In Santiago, the capital, the doctors continued their stoppage.
Rich Glover may play the most important football game in his career Sunday afternoon when the Giants face the Pittsburgh Steelers at Yankee Stadium.
Prices showed little change yesterday in quiet trading on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market.
Commissioner Joseph C. Dey of the Tournament Players Division of the Professional Golfers' Association, one of the leading executives in golf, indicated today he might retire.
An animal lover has invented an invisible method of fencing pets in. Richard M. Peck of Allentown, Pa., was granted Patent 3,753,421 this week for his electrical apparatus, called Sta-Put.
Evonne Goolagong and Mrs. Helga Masthoff advanced to the final of the $100,000 Canadian open tennis tournament today.
The interest ceiling on veterans Administration and Federal Housing Administration home-loan guarantees was raised today from 7 3/4 per cent to 8 1/2 per cent, effective tomorrow.

Federal appeals court ruled today that former State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan may be sued for civil damages in connection with the slaying of two Black Panther party leaders during a police raid four years ago.

Christ Episcopal Church was the setting here tonight for the marriage of Miss Ellen Christie Schramm, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. John C. Schramm of Redding, to Sherwin Cathcart Day, composer and pianist. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William L. Day of Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Randall C. Giddings performed the ceremony.

The United States ExportImport Bank and the Wells Fargo Bank of San Francisco joined in an agreement yesterday to lend Mexico $54.18million as part of the financing for that country's first nuclear power plant.

The latest bond market rally picked up momentum yesterday as the Treasury and corporate sectors raced ahead to gains of as much as a point. Once again, professional activity dominated the session although permanent investors continued to step in to commit long-term funds.

Representative Edward I. Koch said that more than 70 welfare families were living in the Great Northern Hotel near Carnegie Hall on 57th Street and that the hotel was collecting more than $1,600 a month from some of the families.

J. C. Snead led the $100,000 Liggett Myers open today with a six-under-par 136 for 36 holes and gained one of the eight places in tomorrow's $150,000 United States match-play championship.
A day-care center in nearby Rosenhayn for children of migrant and local seasonal farm workers closed today for lack of funds.
The most critical negotiations on a peace settlement in Laos are now taking place, not between the Vientiane Government and the Pathet Lao, but within the Vientiane Government itself.
Bob Griese directed Miami to an early lead tonight and the Dophins defeated the Los Angelss Rams, 17-14 in a National Football League preseason game.

The city has started a campaign to persuade residents not to use the 911 emergency number unless it is absolutely necessary.

Scotland Yard officially blamed elements of the outlawed Irish Republican Army today for a series of explosive devices plaguing London this week. A letter bomb sent to the Stock Exchange in London's financial district injured two people this morning, the first victims of the devices.

Three high- ranking Foreign Service officers, including a key assistant to Henry A. Kissinger during the Vietnam peace talks in Paris, were among 13 Government officials whose telephones were tapped on President Nixon's authority between 1969 and 1971, according to sources familiar with the operation.

Miss Janice Carolyn Dolan, daughter of Mrs. Harry B. Seng of Livingston and John F. Dolan of Miami, was married here this afternoon to William Thomas Cunningham Jr., widower, and son of Mr. and Mrs. Cunningham of Chatham.
Japanese automobile manufacturers are facing possible production cuts as a result of a shortage of steel and other raw materials, industry officials said today.
Edward Trudeau Thomas, dean of admissions of Hofstra College (now University) from 1946 to 1961, died here yesterday. He was 71 years. old and lived in Princeton.

Secretary General Waldheim asked today for a $513.4-million budget to cover United Nations expenses in the coming two years, and said that dollar devaluation and inflation in the United States had increased the costs of running the organization.
Othello, the chestnut prince of Soviet horses, was unveiled this morning at Roosevelt Raceway, and one American groom turned to a friend and asked, "Would you bet this horse?"
Nineteen states have revived the death penalty since it was struck down by the Supreme Court, saving 600 persons from execution.

Two long-time police officers were indicted yesterday on charges that they lied to a Staten Island special grand jury about knowledge of a "sergeants club," which, according to law-enforcement sources, has extorted close to $26,000 from merchants in the 120th precinct since 1966.

The selection of New York City as the site for a Sept. 24 public hearing on a proposed fare increase on PATH trans-Hudson tube trains was assailed by numerous New Jersey political and business leaders yesterday. Senator Clifford P. Case joined with community leaders served by the bistate commuter line in deploring the decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Mrs. Susan R. Simon of Hartsdale, N. Y. was married here this afternoon to Herbert S. Adler, a first vice president and treasurer of E. M. Warburg, Pincus Co., Inc., investment bankers in New York, and a general partner of Lionel L. Pincus Co. Rabbi Elihu Schagrin performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

Close to 6.5 million foreigners, including substantial numbers of Western Europeans, will have basked under the hot Spanish sun this month, but Spain is starting to have second thoughts about the invasion she has so successfully promoted.
An armed man who attempted to hold up a busy bank on Park Avenue during lunchtime yesterday was surprised and subdued by a customer trained in unarmed combat.
A court battle is under way here to determine who will serve as executor of the estate of one of the nation's richest women, Mrs. Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge.

Hawaiian Electric Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with an offering of 600,000 common shares and $16million in first mortgage bonds due 2003 both for sale. through Dillon Read and Dean Witter. The company's stock closed at 251/4, down 1/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Senator Alan Bible, Democrat of Nevada, will announce Tuesday that he will not run for re-election next year, sources close to him confirmed tonight. The Nevada Senator, 63 years old, has been bothered by high blood presssore.

The Mets recaptured the magic again last night when they defeated the San Francisco Giants, 1-0, on a 10thinning single by Felix Millan that settled a tingling pitcher's standoff between Jerry Koosman and Juan Marichal.
The Nebraska Parole Board recommended today that Caril Ann Fugate, who accompanied her boy friend Charles Starkweather on a killing rampage 15 years ago, be considered for parole.

Kale L., beloved mother of Raphael Barr, devoted grandmother of Kathy, Richard and Michael. Cherished greatgrandmother of Derek. Services Sunday, August 26, 2:30 P.M. at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Family will receive at chapel Saturday eve after 7 P.M.

The city's Thin Blue Line is thinner still. New Yorkers are now reaping a whirlwind of crime and fear-of-crime sown some months ago through a policy of police force attrition that left the force dangerously undermanned.

Purchase Commissioner Marvin Gersten voiced "anger" at the high cost of pork, chicken and turkey in bids offered to the cityyesterday, and he said his buying of cattle on the hoof was making it cheaper to serve beef sirloin than the pork loin that had been an alternative.

A recent Florida Supreme Court decision "has applied to newspapers for the first time a type of government control that has long hung over the heads of broadcast journalists," according to Julian Goodman, president of the National Broadcasting Company.

The American Federation of Teachers ended its annual convention here today with a strong endorsement by delegates of their leadership's forthcoming merger talks with the National Education Association but with contrasting views of the outlook for merger expressed by its two top officers.

Oakland took two more strides toward another American League pennant, and the New York Yankees one more big stride away from one, in a 5-1 victory the A's scored tonight in the opener of a three-game series.
The United States jumped off to a 2-0 lead in the Wightman Cup tennis competition tonight as Chris Evert whipped Virginia Wade, 6-4, 6-2, and Patti Hogan defeated Varonica Burton, 6-4, 6-3.
Scotland Yard officially blamed elements of the outlawed Irish Republican Army today for a series of explosive devices plaguing London this week.
Assemblyman Kenneth A. Gewertz, Democrat of Gloucester, said today he had filed suit to force public disclosure by the Ethics Committee of confidential reports on state legislators.

The Republican mayoral campaign of State Senator John J. Marchi came to the Hamptons tonight with a lavish splash of the money and high society that each summer finds its way from New York City 100 miles eastward to this seaside resort.

Vinny Giles and Dick Siderowf won their matches today and contributed to a near-sweep in foursome play but the United States gained only a onepoint lead over Britain in the 24th Walker Cup amateur golf matches.
The Japanese Government decided today to remove export controls from 20 major items, many of which compete vigorously in the American market.
The disclosure in France this week of what could prove to be a major wine scandal was greeted with considerable caution in the French press.
John Hencken of the Santa Clara, Calif., Swim Club set a world record tonight in the men's 200-meter breast-stroke event in the National Amateur Athletic Union championships.
George P. Shultz, the Treasury Secretary, warned the public today to expect an "astounding" increase in the wholesale price index for August.
Cattle herdsmen in many parts of the drought-stricken region below the Sahara are returning to their villages and waterholes now that the summer rains have started and the grasses are growing.
Mouse embryos are being frozen and stockpiled at the Jackson Laboratories in Bar Harbor, Me., to test the feasiability of their being stored for long periods.
The King of Afghanistan, Mohammad Zahir Shah, announced his abdication in a statement issued by the Afghan Embassy in Rome. The King was deposed last month while he was visiting Italy.
A police stake-out unit arrested five men and recoved $75,000 worth of stolen merchandise last night after following three of the men from a holdup in the garment district to a nearby loft.
The United States announced an agreement with Thailand today for the start of a phased withdrawal of American forces and aircraft from Thailand.

Edwin J. Lukas, a former director of national affairs for the American Jewish Committee and an early exponent of the involvement of Jews in the civil rights movement, died Wednesday at a convalescent home in nearby Kentfield. He was 71 years old.
Rescuers said today: that they had "no idea"' how much debris remained between them and two copper miners trapped for more than a week in a tunnel 1,300 feet underground.

Charges against five of the seven black defendants in the Brauhaus murder trial have been dismissed. Federal Judge Almeric Christian first dropped charges against Glenn Williams at the request of Assistant United States Attorney Paul Lynch.
Another wave of strikes, involving the shutdown of shops and transportation, was reported today in nine of Chile's provinces. In Santiago, the capital, the doctors continued their stoppage.

A Federal judge ruled today that the Government's Phase 4 regulations on most gasoline sold at the pump could not go into effect when the present extended freeze on retail gasoline prices expires Aug. 31.
A court battle is under way here to determine who will serve as executor of the estate of one of the nation's richest women, Mrs. Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge.

News correspondents stationed in or visiting Cambodia were summoned to the Information Ministry today for a warning that "measures"-presumably expulsion-would be taken against those found guilty of "exaggerated or false" reporting.
Dr. Arthur Bookman, an internist and specialist on diabetes who practiced for 56 years, died Thursday at his home, 33 East 70th Street. He was 96 years old.

Otis Chandler, pub fisher of the Los Angeles Times, yesterday charged that the Securities and Exchange Commission had inflicted "maximum and gratuitous damage" on him in its civil suit against a northern California company on which Chandler served as a director.

The split between police groups widened yesterday as leaders of the State Police Conference and the Housing and transit t Patrolmen's Benevolent Associations attacked Robert M. McKiernan, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association; which represents city police officers.
Mary Mills fired a fourunder-par 67 today and gained a three-stroke lead in the opening round of the National Jewish Hospital open at the 6,330-yard Green Gables Country Club course.
The Administration is considering a proposal to Impose a tax on new cars that use large quantities of gasoline, Eric Zausner, Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Interior, said today.

The wife of an owner of a team in the National Football League is a witch. On three occasions she has applied her powers to field goals, willing that two go awry and one be true. "I don't like to do it too often," she said. "But I know I can."

A Pan American World Airways guidebook to New York City that's been on bookstore shelves for more than a year became a best seller yesterday after disclosure that it contained a guide to the city's prostitutes.
Bruce Brown, an American police officer, ducked inside the slashing arc of the club aimed at his head and jammed a short metal wand against his Japanese assailant's jugular with both hands.

Avenging last summer's defeat at the Munich Olympics, the young United States men's basketball team stunned the Soviet Union, 75-67, today and American swimmers added five gold medals in the dramatic conclusion of the World University Games.

The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the author's judgment of quality of comparable establishments, Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

A 20 per cent decline in the annual rate of housing starts in the second half of this year is forecast in the semiannual survey issued yesterday by Advance Mortgage Company, a subsidiary of. the First National City Corporation. The survey expects 1973 starts to fall below two million, a decline of about 16 per cent from the almost 2.4-million level of 1972.
Emanuel Scheyer, who retired in 1955 as design engineer for the New York City Transit Authority, died Thursday at his home, 1717 Avenue N, Brooklyn. He was 88 years old.
Khmer Rouge insurgents shelled Phnom Penh's Pochentong military and international airport just before dawn today for the first time since the United States bombing halt 10 days ago.
Saudi Arabia's diplomatic influence as a pivotal country in the Middle East is increasing along with her growing economic importance as the world's leading oil exporter.

The United States announced an agreement with Thailand for the start of a phased withdrawal of American forces and aircraft from Thailand. A joint statement, issued in Washington and in Bangkok, said that the United States would take "immediate steps" to withdraw 3,550 servicemen and more than 100 aircraft.

When most golfers think of changes in their favorite game over the years, they think of equipment modifications, the influence of women on the game and the way the rich man's sport has become a recreation for millions.
A gunman today held four hostages in a bank for a second day and said that the standoff was the fault of the police who had barged in while he was robbing the bank.

A plastic jungle of ultrabright trees and flowers has swallowed up the city's information center in Times Square. It is hard to suggest that the center's conversion into an outsized fruit salad defiles the area since Times Square long ago sank into a state of squalor that defies worsening.

Dr. N. Edd Miller, president of the University of Nevada at Reno, announced yesterday that he was resigning to become president of the University of Maine at Portland-Gorham.

Sheik Mohammed Abdulian, the Lion of Kashmir, is seeking a dominant role among India's Moslem minority. Less than two weeks after the 68-year-old leader announced dramatically that he would enter national politics, he has sought to cement his power among India's 60 million Moslems.

Chile's Marxist President Salvador Allende Gossens, who was elected to power in September, 1970, has survived a series of upheavals that would have broken a less resistant leader.

Trading activity in the stock market early last week shriveled in the August heat. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange declined amid a general lethargy that was not surprising for the period prior to Labor Day. Ulster's agony became London's terror last week as the war between the Irish Republican Army and the British Government took a brutal turn. It is not surprising that much of India's art, music, and literature is concerned with the monsoon. Paintings depict people on rooftops, looking eagerly at the dark clouds billowing out from over the horizon, with flocks of herons flying in front. Of the many melodies of Indian music, Raga Malhar is the most popular, because it brings to mind distant echoes of the sound of thunder and the pitter-patter of raindrops.

NEWARK - The Newark Fresh Air Fund is sending out an urgent request for donations so that its camping program will not he curtailed. The fund director, Gwen Bright, announced last week that a goal of $50,000 will not he reached by this year's deadline unless concerned citizens took immediate action in the form of donations.

Some are now passing themselves off as nationals of another country, especially when traveling in confined circumstances, such as a compartment in a European train.

Jose da Costa, a senior member of the faculty of the New England Conservatory of Music in Boston since 1938, died yesterday at his home here. He was 75 years old.

MOON CAKE FESTIVAL - The Chinese in Hong Kong celebrate the Mid-Autumn Festival, also known as the Moon Cake Festival, on Sept. 11. That evening the hillsides of Hong Kong will appear to be swarming with fireflies as thousands of children parade around the Crown Colony carrying paper lanterns with a candle or a small battery-powered light inside and munching moon cakes under a full moon.

Shoppers returning shaken from the supermarket will be astonished to learn from Herbert Stein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, that they are generally better off than they were a year ago. Mr. Stein bases his contention on Government statistics showing that, after adjustments for price increases, per capita disposable personal income was 5 per cent higher in the second quarter of 1973 than a year earlier.

The laissez-faire, do-your-own-thing, protest movement of a few years back has left its mark. Nobody's pushing anybody into any kind of a uniform. Nobody dares. There are suggestions: sweater coats, bloused-top dresses, voluminous capes, straighter pants. But the "thou shalt wear white gloves" attitude has faded away. Still, there's a general feeling that everybody is ready to look prettier and neater again, that faded blue jeans will not take you everywhere.

MORRISTOWN Here in Morris County, two children were killed when struck by a car driven by a man who, the police felt, was obviously under the influence of drugs. But it took four hours to find a doctor who was willing to administer a blood test.
Lilac Hill raced to a twolength victory today in the fifth running of the $57,650 Cotillion Handicap at Liberty Bell Park.

Larry Gravestock of Amarillo, Tex., won the overall championship of the 74th annual Grand American trapshooting tournament today. He broke 938 of 1,000 targets during the six days of cornpetition.

WASHINGTON -- Every minute a new case of cancer is discovered in the United States. The disease is taking a fearful toll, causing the deaths of 350,000 Americans yearly. Only heart disease is a greater killer. The rate at which cancer is developing in the American population has increased slightly in the past generation, dropping in women but rising in men.

Bick Long of Madison, N. C.. finished with a one-over-par 38-35--73 yesterday to win the 25th National Amputee Golf Association championship at the Fiddler's Elbow Country Club.

Rogers C. B. Morton, Secretary of the Interior, and Gov. William A. Egan announced yesterday that construction of the proposed 789 - mile trans - Alaska pipeline would be supervised by a joint Federal-state commission.

Three men were killed today by an explosion in a garage in the Cliftonville area of north Belfast. Hugh Porter, a 33-year-old Englishman, became the first four-time champion of professional pursuit bicycling today. Porter was timed in 6 minutes 2.97 seconds over the 5,000 meters (about 31/8 miles), almost 10 seconds faster than Rene Pijnen of The Nether. lands.

More than 90 per cent of the Chrysler Corporation employes represented by the United Automobile Workers have voted to authorize a strike, the union said today. The-vote today is routine and gives little indication of whether a strike is likely.

In his new post as Secretary of State, Henry A. Kissinger may find it necessary to take a fresh look at his conception of detente with the Soviet Union. It envisions that increasing relations between American and Soviet citizens will build mutual trust, with benefits for both countries.

Lou Brock and Little Joe Morgan, two of baseball's speed kings, stole and slugged their way into the major league record books yesterday during a Cincinnati's 4-I victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

Despite another vigorous rally during the final two trading sessions last week, the dominant professional view of interest rate prospects remains basically unchanged: interest rates are headed higher, perhaps to new 1973 peaks.

During the spate of fall fashion openings on Seventh Avenue, a pretty blond model showed up so often on the runways that some members of the audience thought they were seeing double. They were.

Thomas Frederick Waghorn, purchasing agent for Booz Allen Hamilton, Inc., management consultants, died Saturday in Astoria General Hospital in Queens. He lived at 31-15 21st Avenue, Long Island city, Queens.

The Skylab 2 astronauts passed the halfway point of their planned 59-day mission early today as the crew of the orbiting space station began its 430th trip around the earth. The milestone came after the spacemen went to bed last night, ending a busy day of 'battery tests and scientific experiments.
Secretary General Waldheim declared today in his annual message that the necessity for international cooperation "has never been so great or so urgent."

The old question of "What's in a name?" can be answered by the Carling Brewing Company with one word: "Profits." Last year, with sales slumping Carling executives decided they needed "premium" beer to capitalize on the trend of sales into slightly higher priced brands.
Lucille Corcos, a painter and illustrator, died of a heart attack yesterday in Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern. She was 64 years old and lived here with her husband, Edgar Levy.

Family after family gave up and moved out, turning the high, rolling plains of eastern Colorado into a vast and eerie cemetery of abandoned homesteads, rotting houses, brokendown barns and creaky windmills.

The American Film Theatre, a new effort to create a national theater on film, gets under way this fall after two years of planning. Beginning next month, the big advertising push for this unique project will also get under way.
Dr. Francis Lane Childs, who retired in 1954 as Winklev Professor of Anglo-Saxon and English Language and Literature at Dartmouth College, died today. He was 88 years old and lived here.

Howard William Calkins, former chairman of Albert Frank-Guenther Law, Inc., national advertising and public relations agency with headquarters in New York, died yesterday at his home, 81 Cayuga Road, Crestwood. His age was 71.
Captain Cool, also known as Mark Donohue, succeeded in making 95degree heat seem comfortable today as he breezed away with the Road America Can-Am.

A 23-year-old Bronx woman was charged yesterday with homicide in the death of her 6-year-old son, who had been thrown off the roof of 1541 Shakespeare Avenue in the Morisania section, the police said.

A stubborn, two-alarm fire in a six-story Bronx apartment house yesterday afternoon sent three persons, including 2-month-old twins, to the hospital and felled 14 firemen, who suffered smoke inhalation and heat exhaustion.

To seek out the causes of hurricanes, typhoons and the tropical "heat engines" that drive much of the world's weather, about 35 nations are engaged in the most elaborate and ambitious international scientific experiment ever undertaken.

A rail transit line rather than an interstate highway should be built along Manhattan's Hudson shorefront to replace the dilapidated West Side Highway, according to Theodore W. Kheel, a persistent critic of transportation plans for the city.

A 34-year-old Brooklyn gra cer was slain early yesterday outside his home in the Bush wick section by two gunnmer on whom he had opened fire a short time earlier when they robbed him of $500 outside hil store nearby, according to the police.
Pope Paul VI today denounced a film, "The Loves of Jesus Christ," that is to be produced in Denmark, as an "ignoble and blasphemous outrage."

Miss Alison Rose Cohen, daughter of Dean and Mrs. Henry Cohen of New York, and Gay Head, Mass., was married here this afternoon to Donald S. Abelson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold D. Abelson of Roslyn Heights, L.I., Hubbardton, Vt. and Queenstown, New Zealand.

Miss Jocelyn Edelston, daughter of Mrs. Henry Jacobs of New York and Towson, Md., and the late Joseph Edelston of Chicago, was married here this afternoon to Robert Krim, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Krim of Newton Centre. Rabbi Roland Gittelsohn performed the ceremony in his study. A reception was held at the Krim home.

The members of the International Air Transport Association, 76 of the world's major airlines, have agreed in principle to create a unit of account to take the place of the dollar and the pound sterling as a base for the calculation and compensation of international passenger and freight rates, the I.A.T.A. announced' today.

This morning at 7:30 or a little later, a handful of top executives of the First National Bank of Chicago met for about a half hour to discuss what the prime rate should be. The 'prime' is the interest rate charged by commercial banks on loans to their best customers.
Toni Okker of the Netherlands defeated Manuel Orantes of Spain, 6-3, 6-2, 6-1, today in the final of the $100,000 Canadian open tennis tournament.

John Chapman failed in an effort to win two harness racing stakes races, worth $280,000, in less than 20 hours when he finished fifth with J. R. Skipper in the $130,000 Prix d'Ete at Blue Bonnet Raceway.

A runaway teen-aged girl with a serious blood ailment was on the way home with her boyfriend today, with a promise that their parents would no longer object to their marriage. Sheryl McDonald, 17, years old, and Kevin Dodd, 16, last seen Monday, were found early today by a ranger in Elijah Clark State park in Georgia.

Senator Peter H. Dominick, a member of the Armed Services Committee and the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy, called on the Administration today to undertake "at once" a program for the maximum development of energy resources to reduce dependence on overseas oil supplies, particularly those in the Middle East.

To the Editor: I have read with interest the press' recent attempts to understand the increasing number of suicides in the New York City prison system. There can be no simple answer to this problem, for each suicide seems to point to a different problem within the prisons, the courts, the hospital prison wards or at times the very structure of our society.

A man and three girls were injured today when a bomb exploded in an automobile near a packed Roman Catholic church. The bombing, in Ballycastle, County Antrim, 60 miles north of here, occurred only minutes before 800 worshippers would have been streaming out of St. Patrick's Church at the end of the service.

The marriage of Miss Deborah Greene to John Hurtman Fulford 3d, son of Mrs. Fulford Jr. and the late Mr. Fulford, took place here this afternoon. Rabbi Edward D. Kiner performed the ceremony in the garden at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Greene, parents of the bride.

The United States retained the Wightman Cup today with Chris Evert gaining the decisive point in the seven-match British-American tennis series for women. She then watched as her 15-year-old sister, Jeanne, and Patti Hogan won the final doubles match.
Ron Bryant, a grown man who keeps a teddy bear in the dugout for luck, became the National League's first 20-game winner yesterday in a 5-4 San Francisco Giant decision over the Mets.

Genetics, the reigning queen of the life sciences for the last generation, seems to have lost her glitter. This was the impression that emerged as 2,700 specialists from all over the world prepared to head home this week after a major 10-day congress of genetics here.

Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, flew here at midnight yesterday in an apparent effort to apply pressure to reluctant Egypt for last-minute acceptance of his plans for a union between the two countries.

The Chicago Bears defeated the Buffalo Bills, 13-10, today in a National Football League preseason game that ended in a fight. With six seconds remaining, Dennis Shaw of the Bills it J. D. Hill with a 15-yard pass.
American Airlines has agreed to discontinue advertisements found misleading by the State Attorney General. The airline, while not admitting any viola tion of law, paid the state $1,000 in costs.

Roberto Thieme, secretary general of the Fatherland and Liberty movement, and 10 other rightists were arrested in a stylish restaurant this morning.

Richard Greene in the Knickerbocker class and Cecil Akre in the Sunfish captured the major trophies today as Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's 41st annual Race Week finished scheduled five-day regatta.
Five field goals by Pete Gogolak and two touchdown returns on interceptions helped the New York Giants to a 29-24 exhibition victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers yesterday at Yankee Stadium.

GOLDEN MEADOW One of the largest and loveliest of the city's parks is Flushing Meadow-Corona Park, a great expanse of green divided by a series of long arboreal walks, far too good to leave to Queensfolk alone. It belongs to everybody, but it is often underused, which gives its sweeping lawns some of the look of a vast private manor.

Harold H. Levin, a partner in the law firm of Proskauer Rose Goetz Mendelsohn and a past president and chairman of the 92d Street Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Association, died yesterday at his home, 138 East 78th Street. He was 73 years old.

Sandra Palmer, unshaken by an inconsistent putting game, calmly sank a 20-foot birdie putt on the 18th green today for a three-under-par 68 and a one-stroke victory in the second annual National Jewish Hospital open.

Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, the selfstyled "toughest cop in America" who took office 18 months ago and quickly established a reputation rivaling that of Chicago's Mayor Daley as the most powerful big-city mayor in the country, now finds himself at a crisis point in his short but flamboyant political career.

The marriage of Miss Linda Sue Dalton to John Russell MacGregor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Woodrow MacGregor of Holden, Mass., took place here this afternoon. Cantor David Bendict performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Philip B. Dalton, parents of the bride.

The Taxi and Limousine Commission has inched forward in trying to bring a safer, more comfortable taxicab to the streets of New York. Chairman Michael J. Lazar of the commission displayed the other day a prototype of the new vehicle scheduled to become standard by 1975. Smaller than a Checker taxicab, it offers utterly inadequate improvement over the cramped quarters too often given passengers today.

John Schroeder brought a golf championship to a tennis family today. The 27year-old son of Ted Schroeder, who won the Wimbledon title in 1949 and the United States crown in 1942, became the United States match-play champion at golf.

An underground group calling itself "Black October," which says it has killed two heroin dealers here, issued a public "last warning" this weekend that it "would kill others." The Baltimore Sun said the group delivered a statement to the newspaper, saying that the murder of drug pushers appeared to be the only way of ridding Negro areas of Baltimore of heroin.

The death toll in the Pakistani floods was reported today to be more than 2,300 as the swollen Indus River coursed southward through heavily populated districts. More than 15 million people have been made homeless since the river waters started overflowing their banks in Punjab and Sind Provinces two weeks ago after heavy rains.

New York's peach crop is being decimated by "X" disease. At a time when the corn is as high as an elephant's eye, when tomatoes are bursting with redness and the first early apples of the year are being picked, up and down the mid-Hudson Valley peach trees are dying.

Part of a bluegrass legend came to New York on Thursday: Charlie Monroe, older brother and onetime partner of Bill Monroe, who is widely acclaimed as "the father of bluegrass."

Don Tyson, chairman and chief executive officer of Tyson Foods, Inc:, had a chapel specially built in his garden for the marriage this evening of his 17-year old daughter, Carla, to her high school classmate, Charles Howard, who is 18.

Sixteen of the nation's best 3-year-old trotters were entered today in the richest Hambletonian stake in the 48-year history of the classic. The two favorites, Arnie Almahurst and Knightly Way, drew starting positions 1 and 2, respectively, for the $144,710 race at the Du Quoin State Fair on Wednesday.
Frederick H. Robinson, who retired in 1968 as board chairman of Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 70.

The 53d anniversary of women's suffrage passed in quiet, even discreet, observance yesterday. In Seneca Falls, N.Y., the birthplace of women's rights, there was an elaborate ceremony to induct the first 20 members of the new Women's Hall of Fame.

Time magazine said yesterday that a key witness against Vice President Agnew in an investigation of an alleged kick-back scandal had taken a lie detector test. Time said the test had sown that the witness, Jerome Wolff, "told the truth about delivering funds extorted from contractors to Agnew."

South Vietnamese voters went dutifully to the polls yesterday in a largely predetermined Senate election that has given President Nguyen Van Thieu a firm grasp on the legislature at the expense of his dwindling legal opposition.

The Transit Authority is starting an experimental "culture loop" bus route this Saturday to run 17 miles through midtown and upper Manhattan with all-day, multiride tickets costing $1.

The Unity Securities Corporation, a Beverly Hills brokerdealer firm, has been accused in a Securities and Exchange Commission complaint of fraudulently manipulating the stock of Orecraft, Inc., a Utah corporation with its principal place of business in suburban Woodland Hills.

Two prominent dissidents who are being tried on charges of sub. version continued to offer willing testimony today, according to Tass, the official press agency. At the same time the controlled Soviet media began to give wide internal publicity to the case.
The 128-country International Civil Aviation Organization started a conference here today to consider proposals for new agreements to curb hijackings.

What do you do when you discover that a lot of the purchasers of your product are former customers who strayed and have since returned to the fold? If you're Volkswagen, you use it as an advertising theme.

The initial zeal shown by the city's new civilian traffic control agents offers encouraging promise of a return to the good old days when traffic cops monitored their intersections with energy and determination. Not for many years, since the Police Department allowed that useful directorial skill to atrophy,

To the Editor: When you live abroad and return to New York you discover that everyone seems very knowing and clever about the hard drug scene. Cute words like rip-off make stealing sound sexy. Chic people have learned to say horse for heroin and OD for overdose.
The first necessity of a circus, when it comes to a place, is to make itself known. That is exactly what the circus that hit town yesterday did, but instead of staging a circus parade,
A Federal appeals court ruled today that bankrupt rail lines must obtain the permission of regulatory agencies to terminate passenger service.

Eddie Condon, who died early this month, was more celebrated for his talking than for his guitar playing. In the late nineteen-twenties and during the thirties, he used his acerbic wit to get jobs for his friends and himself.

An investigation of a possible conspiracy to kill President Nixon is still alive, a Secret Service source in Washington said today. The source held out the possibility that arrests might yet be made. "We just don't want to speculate," he said.

The American Bankers Association said today that a national survey it conducted showed that banks have increased their interest rates for savers without draining funds from other financial institutions. The president of the A.B.A., Eugene H. Adams, said the association polled the 110 bankers who made up the A.B.A.'s governing council.

No matter how you count it-and there are several ways to do so--yesterday's pollen count reached an all-season high, causing itchy eyes, runny noses and sneezing for the thousands of hay-fever sufferers in the metropolitan area.

Recent developments on both sides of the Arab-Israeli conflict compound the already formidable task facing United Nations Secretary General Waldheim in his current, on-the-scene search for a new Middle East peace formula.

Skyrocketing interest rates pose a serious threat to the nation's thrift institutions-the mutual savings banks and the savings and loan associations-which have the bulk of their assets tied up in long-term residential mortgages.

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, has decided to cut short the second and third phases of the Senate Watergate Committee's public hearings so that the committee will have more time to prepare its final report.

India and Pakistan signed an agreement clearing the way for the release of most of the Pakistani prisoners held in India and for settlement of other problems arising from their war of December, 1971. The accord also provides a procedure for Pakistani recognition of Bangladesh. [Page 1, Columns 7-8.]
The Westvaco Corporation, a leading producer of paper, packaging and chemicals, reported yesterday record results for the quarter and nine months ended July 31.

For Ken Buchanan, former lightweight champion of the world, Saturday's fight against Edwin (Chu Chu) Malave in the Felt Forum is just an exercise to keep him fit for his real rival-Roberto Duran, the current champion.

Chris Evert, who holds grass in the same high esteem other girls have for poison ivy, is practicing on the clipped lawns of the Longwood Cricket Club here for the United States Open tennis championships

To passengers at the front of the IRT Flushing-bound train as it headed into the long downgrade for the trip under the East River yesterday afternoon, the sudden collapse of the tunnel masonry seemed like an avalanche hitting their car.

Japan further tightened credit today by raising the official discount rate and bank reserve requirement ratios. Monetary officials said the twin move was a determined effort to curb accelerating prices and dampen inflation.

The "Directory of Key Government Personnel," Hill Knowlton's pocket-size biennial listing of who's who In high places in Washington, has finally made its appearance-several months after the normal publication date. As the public relations firm discreetly notes in a press release accompanying the latest edition: "Although delayed by well-publicized developments that held up naming some key Government officials . . ."

The Agriculture Department will drop a program that provided supplementary subsidized milk for children in 86,000 schools unless Congress agrees to provide more money, a department official said today.

The nation's manufacturers in the last two weeks have experienced the strongest surge of price increases for the materials they buy since the Nixon Administration's original Phase I price freeze ended in 1971, according to a survey of 250 companies.

L. James Evans, a senior vice president and director of the Technicon Corporation, makers of chemical and analytical instruments here, died in his sleep yesterday while visiting friends in Greenwich, Conn. He was 58 years old and lived at 57 Forest Avenue, Rye.

One man died and 1,000 passengers were trapped in 115-degree heat and heavy smoke yesterday after an archway in the ancient Flushing line tunnel under the East River collapsed on the first car of a Queens-bound IRT train.

For Ken Buchanan, former lightweight champion of the world, Saturday's fight against Edwin (Chu Chu) Malave in the Felt Forum is just an exercise to keep him fit for his real rival-Roberto Duran, the current champion.

North Korea threatened yesterday to break off its talks with South Korea unless the South replaced some of its delegates. The North Koreans charged that the delegates in question were responsible for the abduction of a South Korean opposition leader from Tokyo to Seoul early this month.
Yancey (Yank) Durham, manager of the former heavyweight boxing champion, Joe Frazier, suffered a stroke today and was listed in very critical condition at Temple University Hospital.

Another American League pitcher joined the spitball confessional line Monday behind Jim Merritt of the Texas Rangers. A Boston Red Sox pitcher, Bill Lee, boldly declared that he, too, had thrown spitballs and said that if the American League president, Joe Cronin, was going to issue fines for spitballs, he should fine everyone who threw them.
The four domestic automobile manufacturers urged the Government today to let them charge the public an additional $1.25-billion for 1974 model cars and trucks.
In the wake of the letter-bomb explosion at the British Embassy yesterday, the United States Government disclosed today that it had stepped up antiterrorist measures here and abroad.

The State Judicial Conference accused the city and the state yesterday of having failed to give adequate psychiatric help to hundreds of troubled New York City youngsters and of often having refused to give any psychiatric care to the children who need it most.
Gov. Daniel J. Evans of Washington announced today a coalition of state, county and city obbyists to promote budgetary

The New York Dance Festival, which would have begun its 12th season this weekend, has been forced to cancel be-, cause of insufficient funding.' The director of the festival, Donald Saddler, announced the cancellation yesterday.

A loose bolt caused an amusement ride accident that fatally injured a teen-aged girl on Long Island last month, Commissioner Louis J. Levine of the Labor Department reported yesterday. Mr. Levine said that a departmental hearing had determined that the loosening of the bolt caused the door of the passenger cage on the ride to open. The two passengers were thrown out.

A pair of carefully manicured patches of green in Watsessing Park here represent the last outpost in North Jersey of the ancient sport of lawn bowling. Each weekday some 15 to 20 devotees can be observed tossing the "jack" past the "hogline," then carefully rolling three or four bowls apiece as close as possible to the target. On weekends the numbers double or triple as the younger, working folks join in.

The Board of Education, reversing an earlier decision by School Chancellor Irving Anker, yesterday rescinded a scheduled Brooklyn high school zoning change that had touched off parent boycotts and demonstations last spring.

Trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday was slightly higher than the day before when it had fallen to the lowest level in almost seven years. Volume reached 1,527,855 shares compared with 1,320,000 on Monday.

The name is familiar, and so is the position - Peter Revson on the pole for next Sunday's running of the California 500 at Ontario Motor Speedway. Jerry Grant, who sat on the pole of the 1972 race, is in the second spot of the front row.
Two of the highest officials attacked and purged during the Cultural Revolution have joined the growing list of important Chinese Communists who have been rehabilitated.

The hardships caused on both sides of the border by the Canadian railroad strike are a harsh reminder of the degree to which the United States and Canadian economies are interlocked. The disruption of Canada's rail lifeline also underscores the remarkable self-restraint unions in this country have been showing in the face of skyrocketing living costs as against the normally less militant labor movements of other lands.
New Jersey has been found to have the "most vigorously enforced" air-pollution laws and regulations of seven states assessed by a General Accounting Office study.
Stock prices rose yesterday morning, declined in the afternoon and then showed enough strength in the last 45 minutes of trading to finish with a small advance.
The dollar moved fractionally higher in world money markets today, partly reflecting higher interest rates in the United States and Japan but mostly continuing the dollar's general upward trend.
Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, in a rare and bluntly outspoken interview with two Western newsmen, has declared that his life has been threatened. The Nobel Prize novelist,

Ray Nitschke fighting tears not nearly so well as he fought National Football League blockers for 15 years, announced today his retirement from the Green Bay Packers and insisted he had only one regret. "I have no complaints and no hard feelings. I'm just glad to have been a Packer," the former all-pro middle linebacker told the long anticipated news conference held at the club's Lambeau Field Office.

Leopold Blumka, a prominent dealer and collector of medieval and Renaissance objects, who continued a tradition here established by his great-grandfather in Vienna, died yesterday at his home, 941 Park Avenue.

The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday it planned an offering of an unspecified number of additional shares and would be filing a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission soon. The company's stock was down 3/4 at 89 1/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Government's composite index of "leading indicators" of the economy continued its sustained rise in July, the Commerce Department reported today on the basis of preliminary figures.
The Beatrice Foods Company announced yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of the Samsonite Corporation, the luggage maker. The deal had been pending since last April.
The worst flood in Pakistan's 26-year-old history left a trail of shattered villages, ruined crops and homeless families today as it surged toward the southeastern city of Hyderbad.

Many shaky game contracts become easier to play if the bidding has marked all the missing high-card strength with a particular opponent. In the diagramed deal from the recent Summer Nationals in Washington, South took full advantage of the information available to him, and brought off a play technically known as a "partial elimination."

India and Pakistan signed an agreement clearing the way for the release of most of the Pakistani prisoners held in India and for settlement of other problems arising from their war of December, 1971. The accord also provides a procedure for Pakistani recognition of Bangladesh. [Page 1, Columns 7-8.

Reason and understanding prevailed yesterday and the United States Open tennis championships will start their $227,200 run today in Forest Hills, Queens, with little else to worry about than who plays whom.
A Flying Tiger Lines air freighter left here today for Japan carrying 131 head of beef cattle for sale at more than $11 a pound.

For nearly 200 years the Morrow family has farmed the land of Sussex County producing milk for the market. Now, William Morrow, owner of the 280-acre family farm near here, is planning to sell his land to a speculator and move to Iowa to raise corn and soybeans.

Heavy fighting, with growing casualties on both sides, spread along Route 4 southwest of Phnom Penh today as Government forces sought to reopen the overland link to Kompong Som, Cambodia's only seaport.

February, 1936, to August, 1945: The rapid rise, brief triumph and cataclysmic fall of the military government in Japan is the subject of Hirumichi Horikawa's "The Militarists," which opened yesterday at the Elgin Theater.

The nation's manufacturers MEXICO CITY, in the last two weeks have experienced the strongest surge of price increases for the materials they buy since the Nixon Administration's original Phase 1 price freeze ended in 1971, according to a survey of 250 companies.
Amid jeers, shouts and applause, the final arguments were heard yesterday on proposals for the New York Telephone Company to charge for information calls in the state.

Three counselors at a boys camp operated near here by a New York City church group, were arrested last night and charged with robbing a service station of $750 while the attendant was repairing a flat tire on their car.

Sixty-nine police officers were promoted to higher ranks in ceremonies at the Police Academy yesterday, and for the first time in department history the promotion orders of the four highest ranking among them said their appointments were good for only "a period of 365 days."

Another key witness in the Federal investigation of the possible role of a number of officials, including Vice President Agnew, in kickbacks from Maryland contractors was reported today to be cooperating with the United States Attorney's office here in return for preferential treatment.

A predawn earthquake ripped through the center of Mexico today, devastating towns and villages in the country's worst disaster in modern history. Nearly 500 persons were reported dead and more than 1,000 injured.
Samuel I. Newhouse, who tried for 13 years to gain control of The Denver Post, sold his 18.5 per cent interest today for $4.78-million, attorneys for The. Post announced.

Another key witness in the Federal investigation of the possible role of a number of officials, including Vice President Agnew, in kickbacks from Maryland contractors was reported today to be cooperating with the United States Attorney's office here in return for preferential treatment.
A new $125-million Pennsylvania financing drew a lackluster response from investors yesterday that brought to a halt a recent rising tendency for the prices of tax-exempt bonds.

Emory Swank, the United States' Ambassador to Cambodia since 1970, will end his tour here and return to the United States next week, an embassy spokesman said today. Mr. Swank's successor has not yet been nominated by the White House.

The ruling body of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, citing the "worsening plight" of 100,000 Russian Jews who have applied for emigration visas, appealed to the Nixon Administration today to use its influence with the Soviet authorities to expedite

Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, in a rare and bluntly outspoken interview with two Western newsmen, has declared that his life has been threatened. The Nobel Prize novelist, whose writings are banned in his homeland, added that if he was imprisoned or killed, "the main part of my works will be published."

Three counselors at a boys camp operated near here by a New York City church group, were arrested last night and charged with robbing a service station of $750 while the attendant was repairing a flat tire on their car.
Robert W. Dowling, who took part in many civic and business enterprises in the lifestream of New York City, died at his home in the Pierre Hotel yesterday after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

The Rev. Carl McIntire, a Fundamentalist minister, said yesterday that a "pirate" radio ship that he had commissioned was scheduled to take up position off Cape May today and begin broadcasting by the end of the week.

A former champion, Bill Campbell, the British Amateur champion, Dick Siderowf and William Hyndman 3d advanced to the second round of the 73d United States Amateur golf championship today with impressive victories in the first round.

After all the painful increases in food prices and the official warnings of "astounding" new increases ahead, it is at least moderately encouraging to note that in the last two weeks the trend of wholesale food prices in the major American commodities exchanges has been downward -substantially so.

LOS ANGELES-From the time he was 8 years old, the whole country watched him grow up on television. And 10 years ago, when the daughter:of an all-America football star and an actress married him, she too entered the fishbowl existence that the children of celebrities either enjoy or simply must endure.
John Riggins, the New York Jets' holdout fullback and leading rusher last year, packed his gear today and walked out of training camp.
Joe Namath has sued Sports Illustrated for $2.2-million, charging that the magazine maligned him and deprived him of income.

The new Attorney General of the United States, Elliot L. Richardson, is an elegant man of elaborate, almost ostentatious serenity, and you could never tell by watching him these days that he is under more pressure now than ever before in his varied service to the Federal Government.
The United States Military Academy has rewritten its book of regulations, replacing decades of accumulated restrictions with a simplified code emphasizing self-discipline.
Baseball tradition demands that a player come to bat the same inning in which he has made a fine play and swat a home run.
Forty members of the prestigious Soviet Academy of Sciences today called on Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist, to cease his public criticism of the Kremlin's domestic and foreign policies.
A 23-year-old truck driver fled from a Federal courtroom in Brooklyn after he was sentenced to six months in prison for theft yesterday, but he was quickly captured by a deputy marshal.
New York sweltered through its hotlest day of the year yesterday, and the city consumed more electricity than ever before although Consolidated Edison was forced to cut the voltage by 5 per cent.

The Federal and Ontario governments have filed a petition in the Supreme Court of New Brunswick seeking to liquidate I.O.S. Ltd., a worldwide mutual fund group that has its head office in Fredericton, N. B.
Yancey (Yank) Durham, manager of the former heavyweight boxing champion, Joe Frazier, suffered a stroke today and was listed in very critical condition at Temple University Hospital.
The legendary Turk went door-knocking here today and the New York Giants cut five players.

Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court gave judges general advice on remaining independent of politics. Justice Marshall, addressing the World Law Through Peace Conference at Abidjan, Ivory Coast, said that "when judges watch the election returns, they squander the only power they have."

India and Pakistan signed an agreement here today clearing the way for the release of most of the 90,000 Pakistani prisoners held in India and for settlement of other problems arising from their war in December, 1971.
The North Vietnamese have violated peace accords by transforming the former United States base at Khe Sanh in South Vietnam into a major military complex, Pentagon officials say.

The city's public-school supervisors and administrators have voted, by a better than 2-to-1 margin, to accept a new con- r tract with the Board of Educa- a tion that will give them higher salaries and other benefits, along with eight additional working days a year.
Bill Rohinson, who failed to impress the New York Yankees in three seasons in New York, has found a new life in Philadelphia after waystops in Tucson. Ariz., and Eugene, Ore.

The Civil Aeronautics Board voted yesterday to ask a Federal court in Washington to stay the implementation of a decision invalidating the agreement by which virtually all scheduled airlines charge the same fare for trans-Atlantic flights.
" Now it's a horse race," a $2 bettor conceded yesterday at Belmont Park after learning that the $250,000 Marlboro Cup here on Sept. 15 would have a field of at least eight.
A $3-billion program to build electric generating stations for northern Ohio and western Pennsylvania was announced yesterday by a group of five utilities serving the areas.

President Nixon is "not just a lame duck, he is a wounded duck," said Representative Howard W. Robison, a Republican with 15 years in the House. Among his upstate New York constituents more than four out of 12 who answered a Robison questionnaire favored Mr. Nixon's resignation or removal.

Governor Rockefeller has agreed to campaign in New Jersey next month for the Republican candidate for Governor in the first of a series of cross-country political forays that informed Republicans in New York said were calculated to establish him as a candidate for the Presidency in 1976.

Two retail store clerks and a manager were convicted of having sold forbidden items in Ocean City on Sundayhandbag and a hibachi barbecue. Mrs. Joyce Ray, manager of Brooks Discount Store, and Debby Smith and Tony R. Pritz were fined $225 each and given suspended 10-day jail terms.
Hank Aaron hit the 706th home run of his career tonight, a 375-foot drive in the first inning, but the Chicago Cubs beat the Atlanta Braves. 9-6.
A tornado swept an area along the Massachusetts-New York border today and the police said that it killed four persons and injured 31.

Man Killed in Fall at Station Robert E. Philpot, a sales executive for the Columbia Broadcasting system, was killed yesterday when he fell off the Scarsdale railroad station platform and was hit by an express train. Mr. Philpot,

A tractor-trailer collided with a Penn Central passenger train here today, derailing the locomotive. The truck driver suffered critical injuries, and the locomotive fireman was less seriously injured.

Fats and vitamins. These days people concerned about nutrition frequently think they have to nearly eliminate the former while they take massive doses of the latter. Much is known about how fats and vitamins work in the body but neither is yet a cut and dried nutritional issue.

Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations arrived here from Syria today on the second stop of his tour of the Middle East, whose situation he termed "one of the most dangerous and explosive" in the world.

One man died and 1,000 passengers were trapped in 115-degree heat and heavy smoke yesterday after an archway in the ancient Flushing line tunnel under the East River collapsed on the first car of a Queens-bound IRT train.

This afternoon, wire service reporters began staking out President Nixon's home in San Clemente to be on hand in the event the President should decide to go to the beach or take a drive on the Freeway, as he frequently does.

The Consumer Product Safety Commission, prompted by concern over possible genetic damage and birth defects, banned nine more aerosol spray adhesives today. The action brought to 13 the number of brands of the product banned since last week.

Abbie Hoffman, the antiwar activist, Yippie and defendant in the Chicago Seven conspiracy trial, was arrested last night along with three other persons and charged with selling three pounds of cocaine to two undercover narcotic agents for $36,000.
The United States Military Academy has rewritten its book of regulations, replacing decades of accumulated restrictions with a simplified code emphasizing self-discipline.

A former champion, Bill Campbell, the British Amateur champion, Dick Siderowf and William Hyndman 3d advanced to the second round of the 73d United States Amateur golf championship today with impressive victories in the first round.
A 64-year-old city Health Department dentist was arrested yesterday on charges of sexually abusing and verbally harassing four female patients aged 11 O 18 years old.

The titular head of Eastern Orthodox Christianity delivered a message to the World Council of Churches today reaffirming his church's commitment to the organized ecumenical movement but urging council leaders to avoid preoccupation with "socio-political aims."
Vice Admiral Thomas H. Binford, holder of many citations, including the Navy Cross, the Silver Star and the Legion of Merit, died yesterday in Balboa Naval Hospital. He was 77 years old.
A British businessman was kidnapped near here last night and his captors, who police sources said could be Argentine guerrillas, have demanded a ransom equivalent to $ -million.

Sixteen of the foremost trotting horses in the country were ready to go to the post here tomorrow in the 48th Hambletonian. But behind the serene setting in the cornfields of southern Illinois, a historic fight was being waged over the future site of harness racing's most prestigious event.
A lifetime in the military has transformed one of France's most authentic heroes and distinguished generals into a man of nonviolence.
LONDON--Far and away the biggest events of this city's musical summer have been the two complete cycles of Wagner's "Ring of the Nibelung" put on by the Sadler's Wells company at the Coliseum.

The office of Maurice H. Nadjari, New York State's special prosecutor, announced the indictments of seven present and former New York policemen - including five sergeants - in an investigation that is seeking to determine the extent of payoffs by city contractors.

India and Pakistan signed an agreement here today clearing the way for the release of most of the 90,000 Pakistani prisoners held in India and for settlement of other problems arising from their war in December, 1971.

The city's Purchase Department said yesterday tat it had received "encouraging" bids on chickens from major producers in the East. "The bids are lower than those of the wholesalers with whom we have been dealing," Deputy Commissioner Michael L. Vallon said "We will decide tomorrow which we will accept."

Democratic leaders in the 13th District are considering a not-unwilling Bill Bradley, the Princeton-educated basketball star, as a Congressional candidate, a Morris County Democratic leader said today.

Malyarov, First Deputy Prosecutor General of the Soviet Union, whose post as the nation's second-ranking law enforcement official corresponds roughly to that of the Deputy Attorney General in the United States.

Governor Rockefeller has agreed to campaign in New Jersey next month for the Republican candidate for Governor in the first of a series of cross-country political forays that informed Republicans in New York said were calculated to establish him as a candidate for the Presidency in 1976.
On the evening of the sixth day of their imprisonment in a bank vault, the four hostages of a gunman and his companion were freed without injury last night, and their captors surrendered meekly.
The Midwest Stock Exchange said today that it had a proift of $291,400 on revenues of $12.3-million in the first seven moths of this year.

President Salvador Allende Gossens reshuffled his Cabinet today and again included military leaders in key ministerial posts in an attempt to cope more effectively with a wave of crippling strikes and terrorism.

President Ferdinand Marcos yesterday ordered a reinvestigation into charges of subversion and illegal possession of firearms against former Senator Benigno S. Aquino. He said the Government wanted "to demonstrate utmost fairness. impartiality and objectivity on the prosecution of charges against the accused."

The uncle of the 14-year-old disqualified winner of this year's All-American Soapbox Derby said today that he had suggested and sanctioned the use of an electromagnetic cheating device in his nephew's car. He said it was needed for a winning chance in the face of wholesale cheating by other participants in the Akron, Ohio, event.
As the American economic boom goes into its late-phase paroxyms, astonishment steals over the faces of economists, businessmen and even Nixon Administration officials.

Two news items struck the Midwest commodities exchange yesterday after the close of markets in which virtually all grain, soybean and livestock futures prices dropped by their respective daily permissible limits. The first item was a report of the worst outbreak of the dreaded hoof and mouth disease in Europe since 1964.
Amid jeers, shouts and applause, the final arguments were heard yesterday on proposals for the New York Telephone Company to charge for information calls in the state.

Murray Chotiner, a long time political associate of President Nixon, confirmed today that he had hired Seymour K. Freidin, a journalist, for $1,000 a week, to supply intelligence on Democratic candidates to the Nixon campaign.

Carina (Ninu) de Narvaez, 16-year-old daughter of Dr. Felix de Narvaez, adjunct associate professor at New York University School of Medicine, and of Mrs. Cynthia Delafield de Narvaez of Sarasota, Fla,, died after a long illness yesterday in University Hospital, where her father is an attending pathologist.
