An official of the Penn Central Company said today he did not think there would be a problem in getting cash to keep the financially troubled railroad running.

A predawn earthquake ripped through the center of Mexico today, devastating towns and villages in the country's worst disaster in modern history. More than 500 persons were reported dead and more than 1,000 injured.
The City Council voted yesterday to ask the State Court of Appeals for an extension beyond Saturday to remap the district boundaries for the Council.

Seven present and former New York policemen-including five sergeants-have been indicted in an investigation that is seeking to determine the extent of payoffs by city contractors, the office of special state prosecutor, Maurice N. Nadjari, announced yesterday.

The Suffolk County Legislature today approved a broad series of consumerprotection measures including strict regulations on pyramidingg" corporations in the county, prohibitions against unfair trade practices and the establishment of a Department of Consumer Affairs headed by a commissioner with subpoena powers.

The last two of seven defendants in this island's second recent multiple murder trial were found not guilty today on charges of have ing killed two men and wounding a third in an armed attack last Nov. 7 on a local restaurant.

The Chrysler Corporation, designated by the United Auto Workers as the "target" company for 1973 contract talks with the auto makers, made its first formal offer to the union today: an annual increase of 3 per cent in basic wages plus higher pension and life-insurance benefits.

Gregory Battcock, associate professor of fine arts at William Paterson College in New Jersey, is the new editor of Arts Magazine. His appointment was announced here by Alvin Demick, publisher of the 47-year-old publication,
New York sweltered through its hottest day of the year yesterday, and the city consumed more electricity than ever before although Consolidated Edison was forced to cut the voltage by 5 per cent.
The New Jersey Turnpike Authority announced today it would not renew its contract with the Howard Johnson's Restaurants, which operated exclusively on the superhighway for 22 years.

Members of Parliament were hurrying back to Ottawa today to legislate an end to the five-day-old rail strike that has halted virtually every train in the country, just as the economic effects of the dispute were beginning to reach average Canadians.
With helicopters patrolling overhead, soldiers' guns bristling from roofs, and crowds held well back, Prime Minister Heath began a two-day visit to Northern Ireland today.

With three days remaining before the state's stringnet new narcotics law takes effect, the city's Addiction Services Agency yesterday announced a "marathon" campaign to register as many addicts as possible in drug rehabilitation programs.

The Hoerner Waldorf Corporation said yesterday that it had asked the Montana State Department of Health and Environmental Sciences for permission to construct a $40-million expansion of its paper mill at Missoula, Montana.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, once the major political force in the Liberal party in New York City, endorsed the three-candidate citywide Democratic ticket yesterday and promised to raise "in excess of $50,000" for the campaign.
West German Chancellor Willy Brandt today appealed to West Germans not to demand exaggerated wage increases or raise prices in a way that could threaten the Government's anti-inflationary program.

Secretary of Statedesignate Henry A. Kissinger has canceled a planned September trip to Europe, the Western White House said today. Mr. Kissinger had accepted an invitation to address a nongovernment group, the Atlantic Treaty Organization, in Brussels on Sept. 10.

Samuel W. Ireland, who in 1920 founded the Ireland Coffee Company, a wholesaler serving hotels and restaurants in the Delaware Valley, died Monday in Atlantic City Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived here.
Stocks advanced on a broad front yesterday in the heaviest trading since July 26. It was the market's third consecutive advance.

The New York Mets found themselves sitting on a lofty plateau last night as they finally climbed out of the Eastern Division cellar and into fifth place with a 3-0 victory over the San Diego Padres at Shea Stadium.
The Police Department yesterday issued a memorandum to all field commanders to reduce the overtime police officers incur in accompanying to the courts the people they arrest following crimes.

The peace accord achieved by India, Pakistan and Bangladesh after more than fourteen months of on-and-off negotiations represents a triumph of pragmatism over passion in a region where the seeds of emotional conflict are as bitter and deeply rooted as anywhere on earth.
A 30-year-old man was indicted by a grand jury in the Bronx yesterday on charges of sexually abusing a 5-year-old boy in a park there last week.
Cambodian troops trying to reopen Phnom Penh's supply routes were thrown back today despite the use of fighter-bombers, artillery and armored personnel carriers.
Defense motions to block the trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans were rejected yesterday by Federal District Judge Lee P. Gagliardi.
Long Beach city officials said today they intended to enact local rent-stabilization legislation that would basically prohibit rent increases in excess of any increases in the Consumer Price Index.

The sudden upsurge in news of dissidence from Moscow has brought into sharp focus the Soviet leaders' determination to pursue their policy of improved relations with the West without giving an inch to domestic pressures for liberal reforms.

President Nixon was ordered today by Judge John J. Sirica to make tape recordings of White House conversations involving the Watergate case available to him for a decision on their use by a grand jury.
The White House said today that President Nixon would not comply with Judge John J. Sirica's order to turn over his Watergate tape recordings to the court.

Going home from work on the city's subways is a daily ordeal even under normal summer conditions of sweltering heat in ill-ventilated tunnels and overcrowded cars. Any mishap, and particularly any accident involving fire and smoke, quickly turns this poorly maintained transportation system into a terrifying trap for thousands of helpless passengers.
A minisubmarine manned by two Britons was trapped today deep in the Atlantic Ocean about 150 miles southwest of this southwest Irish city, the vessel's owners reported.
Pakistan's worst flood crested tonight near the southern cities of Hyderabad and Kotri, amid signs that waters were ebbing elsewhere across the stricken country.

The lights went out around Shea Stadium tonight, airconditioners in an area covering 180,000 homes shut off, the video portion of the broadcast on local television went out, but the game between the San Diego Padres and New York Mets proceeded without interruption despite the power failure.

Given the many difficulties involved in producing Mozart's "The Ahduction From the Seraglio," it must be said that the New York Lyric Opera managed pretty well in most respects with its presentation of the work at the Universalist Church, Central Park West at 76th Street.

Howard Johnson's dominance of toll-road restaurant operations may be starting to wane with the announcement that the New Jersey Turnpike Authority is terminating its 22-year relationship with the chain.

Forage carried the silks of William Haggin Perry to victory in the Stymie Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. But the performance was completely different from the way Stymie used to run.

Another Jet cut came today and Gary Hammond survived. He's still around, not because he is a wide receiver or punt return man or a quarterback, but because he can be all three, and Coach Weeb Ewbank likes having versatile players around.
Five European newsmen returned from a Vietcong zone north of Saigon in good health today after spending a week watching the life and activities of the Vietnamese Communists.
A cholera outbreak in the Naples area and some suspect cases of severe gastrointestinal disorders elsewhere in Italy have touched off an infection scare.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, today reported the raising of $22.3million this year-the largest sum raised in its 61 year history-to maintain and enlarge its network of medical and social services in Israel and to carry out projects in the United States.
Sixty picketing members of the United Farm Workers Union were arrested and several persons were injured today when the strikers and sheriff's deputies clashed at a Gallo Brothers vineyard.
Though this is a land untouched by the attitudes and values of permissive society, "The Pill" is widely used in China.
A leader of the Salute to Ted Agnew Night committee, a Republican fund-raising group indicted here for violations of Maryland election law, pleaded not guilty on behalf of the committee today.

The price of gold rose sharply while the value of the dollar fell on European money markets today. Dealers said the gold market remained fairly quiet in terms of the size and number of deals, but the gold price jumped further than the corresponding fall of the dollar appeared to indicate.
A United States bankruptcy referee today abandoned attempts to form a creditors' committee to negotiate settlement of $26-million in debts filed against Koscot Interplane-tary, Inc.
President Nixon's lawyers charged today that the Senate Watergate committee had conducted a "criminal investigation and trial" that exceeded the authority granted to Congress by the Constitution.
One of two dissidents being tried on charges of subversion was reportedly linked in testimony to day to the publication of an underground news bulletin that ceased to appear after his arrest.

A fire engine speeds down a New York City street. When it stops, a short, portly man with a black Fedora jumps off and starts speaking rapidly in a high-pitched voice. And in his final words, he declaims, "Us Little Guys Fight Back."

The collapse of an "archaic duct structure, the only one of its kind" in the subway system, caused Tuesday's fatal accident in the East River Flushing line tunnel, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday.

Some 81 per cent of the companies surveyed this month by the National Association of Purchasing Management said they were not curtailing their investment plans, despite historically high interest rates.

To give a bit of cold comfort, it was just as hot in New York in an older day as it has been all this week. "Hot" had a different meaning though, in those years. All you had to endure half a century ago was the temperature, not the triumph of technology.

Eight beef wholesalers and processors in New Jersey were accused of having violated Federal beef price rules yesterday but over-all compliance around the state has been good, the Internal Revenue Service said.

Even the losers were hot yesterday as the $227,000 United States Open tennis championships opened in temperatures that reached 94 degrees. Food prices dropped sharply In the city last week, the second decline in two weeks, the Consumer Affairs Department reported yesterday.

United States private and Government assets abroad rose substantially against last year but the rise in liabilities was greater, meaning a drop in the net "international investment position" of the nation, the Commerce Department reported today. This net position was put at $50.6-billion at the end of 1972, down from $57.6-billion at the end of 1971.

Susan Agnew, 25-year-old daughter of the Vice President, cut short a tour of duty on the hospital ship Hope earlier this week after the police apparently learned from informants of a threat against her life.

Judging from the overflow audience that Chamber Music at the Guggenheim attracted to the museum's subterranean hall on Tuesday night, the brief summer festival of music and dance might easily bear expansion.
Special Prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari's office disclosed yesterday that it was investigating an alleged conspiracy to pay a $50,000 bribe to a State Supreme Court justice.

Peter Ottley, president of a union that represents 20,000 hotel and hospital maintenance and service employes in the metropolitan area, was indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of embezzling more than $186,000 in union funds.
Phil Regan, a retired singer and actor, was sentenced today to an indefinite prison term on two counts of bribing a county supervisor. He could serve a maximum of 14 years.

A coalition of native American organizations announced today that they had filed the first class-action civil rights complaint with the Justice Department's newly created Office of Indian Rights, charging 32 Federal agencies with employment discrimination.

Theodore H. White is so awesomely diligent a reporter, so accomplished a political analyst, so engaging a person that criticizing him seems like sacrilege. But someone did eventually say that the emperor had no clothes, and it is time for someone to say that White has written a bad book.
Gen. George Grivas, the Cypriote underground leader tonight rejected a Greek Government call for him to give up his armed struggle in Cyprus.

Candidates should appeal to reason and logic when they address a well-educated audience, but a less-educated crowd can be dealt with "on an emotional and graphic level," according to the 1973 Democratic state party election manual.

A businessman who admitted helping his nephew cheat to win the National Soapbox Derby was charged in juvenile court today with contributing to the delinquency of a minor. No charges were brought against the boy.

Abbie Hoffman, the "Chicago Seven" defendant who friends said has withdrawn from radical politics into more personal expressions, was ordered held in $200,000 bail yesterday for allegedly selling three pounds of cocaine to undercover policemen.

In what might be seen as an exchange of traditional roles, Frank Umont, an American League umpire, apologized earlier this month to A1 Worthington for the abusive language he directed toward the Minnesota Twins' pitching coach during a game in Oakland.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, in another move to check the sharp decline in availability of mortgage money for home buyers, decided today to allow savings and loan associations to offer more large certificates of deposit-those of $100,000 or more with no interest ceiling.
Dennis Clark of Seattle inched into the lead of the Mallory Cup competition today in the North American sailing championships.

Republican voter support for Vice President Agnew for the party's Presidential nomination in 1976 has fallen sharply in the wake of disclosures that Mr. Agnew is the target of a Federal investigation, the Gallup Poll said yesterday.

The Coast Guard reported today that an oil slick had been sighted in the Atlantic offshore from Neptune Beach east of here. A Coast Guard spokesman said the slick was about 500 yards long and 25 yards wide. He said it was "sliding along the shoreline" as it moved southward, depositing heavy oil along the beaches.

A United States citizen who identified himself as a top aide to the President of Zambia was held on $250,000 bond today on charges of being an unregistered foreign agent and possessing hugging devices.

The New Jersey Coalition for Fair Broadcasting, a public interest group that includes some of the state's governmental leaders, accused New York television stations today of failing to live up to agreements"binding" them to increase news and public affairs coverage of northern New Jersey.

President Nixon was ordered today by Judge John J. Sirica to make tape recordings of White House conversations involving the Watergate case available to him for a decision on their use by a grand jury.
The Agriculture Department announced today a program designed to increase 1974 harvests of livestock feed grains at least 6 per cent over this year's level.

EXTREMES A kind of see-the-poor-as-J. P. Morgansaw-them tour is one of the more piquant services available to the well-heeled New Yorker or tourist who likes his sightseeing limousined, and who has a spare $50 to shell out for five hours of New York.
As the case of the Gainesville Eight neared the jury, the Government released to the defense today 44 pages of documents concerning its star informer.

The diplomatic breach between Japan and South Korea widened today as the Seoul Government delivered to Tokyo what Japanese officials considered an unsatisfactory report on the abduction of a Korean opposition leader here three weeks ago.
There wasn't too much of a problem about clothes at last night's opening performance of the New York City Opera's fall season. In this weather nobody was going to be wearing furs; that was for sure.
The two convicted robbers who held four hostages in a bank vault for more than five days were charged today on a number of counts. Other charges, possibly including rape, remain in abeyance.
The National Transportation Safety Board, despite the Nixon Administration's opposition, has urged Congress to establish it as "a completely independent agency."
Nolan Ryan really showed the New York Yankees something last night. It was the Game thing he had been showing lots of people the last two years: sensational pitching.

Officials of the Japanese National Educational Television Network cheerfully expect to lose money on their promotion of the heavyweight championship bout between George Foreman and Joe (King) Roman, the Puerto Rican challenger, this week.

Litton Industries, Inc., West Coast electronics, office equipment and industrial products maker, announced yesterday a sharp recovery in profits for the fiscal year ended July 31. West German officials expect Chancellor Willy Brandt to postpone-perhaps for months-the trip he planned to make to Prague next Thursday to establish diplomatic relations with Czechoslovakia, unless there is a lastminute round of negotiations to settle difficulties over Bonn's right to represent West Berlin.

The Canadian Parliament convened today to legislate an end to a nationwide railroad strike, with the Government and the Opposition leaders all trying to make maximum political capital out of the special session.
The heat wave is beginning to take its toll on the health of New Yorkers, especially the very old, the very young and those who live without airconditioning.
A. I. Goldberg, an Associated Press correspondent in Europe during and after World War II and later A.P. correspondent in Moscow, died today at the age of 69.

Mrs. Diane Wilcox Lohr, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Wilcox of Lake Forest, Ill., was married here last evening to JeanPierre Radley, son of Pauline Trigere, the fashion designer, and Lazar Radley of Kansas City.

The Lockheed Propulsion Company submitted to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration today a proposal to develop, manufacture and test large solid rocket boosters for the space shuttle vehicle at plants in Louisiana and Mississippi.

Ian Anderson, flute player, singer and leader of Jethro Tull and a performer given to standing on one leg while he plays, is a hard man to satisfy. As part of the Tull group's American tour, he packed Madison Square Garden twice this week,
The 25nition disarmament conference ended its 1973 session today with some members charging that it had reached a state of complete paralysis.

Federal prosecutors urged a District Judge here yesterday to deter white-collar crimes by imposing "substantial punishment" on a business executive described as the leader of "the largest criminal stock fraud ever prosecuted."
A fight between north Camden youths and the police mushroomed into a five-hour looting spree that was put down early this morning by a barrage of tear gas.
James W. McCord Jr., a convicted Watergate conspirator, ended his college lecture tour tonight after his second appearance.
The dollar reversed an early downward trend on European money markets today and closed the day fractionally higher. Gold prices declined.

Residents of the Jackson Heights and Corona sections of Queens reported yesterday the loss of thousands of dollars in spoiled food as the result of being without power for more than 15 hours on Wednesday.

Interest rates apparently have been pushed high enough to discourage some business borrowers, figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York seemed to show.

The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the holding company that owns the bank of the same name, announced yesterday it had reached a tentative agreement to acquire the Ritter Financial Corporation in a share exchange involving about $28.4-million.

MENTONE, Tex.-For just about everybody, Mentone, Tex., is only a 40 mile-anhour speed zone on the way to somewhere else. But for a handful of chickens, uncounted cats, a few dogs, a pack of coyotes and 43 persons, Mentone, Tex., is home.
Mao Tse-tung, Chou En-lai and other experienced leaders sit with a former textile worker, a minority representative and a farmer in a new ruling Politburo announced in Peking today.
TAIPEI, Taiwan - It is likely that few Taiwanese, apart from sophisticated residents of the bigger cities, initiated any special activity on Aug. 19, the 21st day of the seventh moon.

Mildred Catharine Smith, for more than 30 years co-editor and later editor in chief of Publishers' Weekly, and director and secretary of the R. R. Bowker Company, publisher of the book dealers' trade journal, died yesterday. She was in her 80's and lived in Kings Point, L.I.
Skittish traders in agricultural commodities sought again in vain for some direction yesterday, and as a result prices of grains and soybeans closed mixed after swinging over wide ranges.

To the Editor: In your issue of Aug. 22, you published a dispatch from Moscow which cannot be too widely read. It covers words of warning from the eminent Russian physicist Andrei D. Sakharoy in regard to the dangers implicit in dealing with the Soviet Union.

President Nixon and his lawyers decided today to appeal Judge John J. Sirica's ruling that the President must turn over White House tapes of conversations involving the Watergate case so he could decide on their use by a grand jury.
George A. Wiley, leader of the National Welfare Rights Organization, died in a tragic accident Aug. 8. The movement he led was trying to achieve elementary rights for the poor in America.

Juan D. Peron, the former Argentine dictator who is again seeking the presidency, told Peronist congressmen tonight that the country was in an emergency and that "if we triumph we will take emeragency measures."

The Government newspaper Izvestia, in an account of the current trial of two dissidents in Moscow, today linked Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the novelist, to an illegal news bulletin that reported political underground news before it ceased publication a year ago.

Mao Tse-tung, Chou En-lai and other experienced leaders sit with a former textile worker, a minority representative and a farmer in a new ruling Politburo announced in Peking yesterday. Members of the Politburo run China on a day-to-day basis.
A man described by the police as a leading narcotics disributor was arrested yesterday in a raid on his Washington Heights apartment.

The Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance Company, Ltd., said yesterday it would be offering holders of its common stock and American depositary shares rights to subscribe to a total of 180,000,000 additional shares. Holders of American depositary shares will be offered one additional American depositary share for each 2-2/9 share held at a subscription price of $9.50. The offering is not underwritten.

The New York Mets wasted another strong pitching performance by Tom Seaver tonight and fell back into last place in the East when they lost to the St. Louis Cardinals, 1-0, in 10 innings.

HELSINKI, Finland Twenty miles north of here, nature loving Finns pitch tents each summer, camping by a lake among tall pines and shimmering birches. The Joonas Kokkonens live here too, but for them it's all year long and in quite a different sort of dwelling.

The Securities and Exchange Commission rejected today a proposed rule change of the New York Stock Exchange that could have denied the nonmember commission discount to broker-dealers doing business for industrial investors.
Four armed men robbed the home of a business executive and lawyer in an exclusive residential area here last night, with one of them raping a governess.

The Administration, responding to a court suit brought by 11 states and three localities, announced today that it would release $66.7-million in "impacted aid" funds to 5,000 school districts next week.
The parents of a youth who was critically injured in an automobile accident ordered doctors to let their son die so his kidneys might give life to two strangers.

Acceding to the demands of New Jersey commuters, the Interstate Commerce Commission has agreed to hold six public hearings in Jersey City and Newark in September on the Port Authority's application to increase fares on PATH tube trains, The authority wants to raise fares from 30 to 50 cents on the trans-Hudson trains, used by 140,000 commuters daily.

An international team of divers worked today to rescue two Britons running out of air in a midget submarine trapped 1,375 feet below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean.
Stock prices opened on a strong note yesterday but profit taking on recent advances forced them gradually lower to a mixed close in diminished trading.

The Public Utilities Commission, in its first ruling since the Nixon Administration ended the 60day price freeze a little over two weeks ago, granted a 3.25 per cent rate increase today to the Jersey Central Power and Light Company and the New Jersey Central Power and Light Company.

The director of the Norwegian Nobel Institute, August Schou, announced that there were 47 candidates for this year's Nobel Peace Prize.
The Committee on Colonialism of the United Nations voted today to keep the Puerto Rican question under its "continuous review."

Twenty five Atlantic City police officers were indicted here by the state grand jury today in what state police authorities described as the most extensive police corruption scandal in New Jersey's history.
The president of the International Brotherhood of teamsters. Frank E. Fitzsimmons, has resigned as vice president of Detroit Local 299 and was succeeded by his son, Richard.
Twenty months after the end of their war over Bangladesh, the Indians and the Pakistanis have finally sorted out a compromise involving three st groups of political hostages.

President Nixon and his lawyers decided today to appeal Judge John J. Sirica's ruling that the President must turn over White House tapes of conversations involving the Watergate case so he could decide on their use by a grand jury.
The bodies of 24 Americans killed in the crash of a United States Air Force cargo jet have been brought to the Torrejon air base to be flown to the United States.

A Long Island Rail Road train bound from New York to Huntington struck some junk on the track east of Mineola at 12:31 P.M. yesterday, damaging 800 feet of third rail and the undercarriage of the train. It delayed about a dozen trains on the main line, a railroad spokesman said. There were no injuries.

Bill Campbell, a former champion off to a running start for the third day in a row, advanced today to the fourth round of the 73d United States Amateur Championship with a 6-and-5 victory overRichard Sharp of Memphis.

A security guard at the College of White Plains was arrested in Brooklyn yesterday and charged with the kidnapping, rape, assault and attempted murder of a 19-year-old prospective student who asked him for directions on the campus Wednesday night.
A Federal judge approved a desegregation plan today calling for reassignment of about 11,000 elementary school children this fall in the city's public school system.
The 23-year-old addict mother of a baby girl removed her child from Lenox Hill Hospital late Tuesday afternoon on the eve of a scheduled hernia operation for the baby.

The Commerce Department said today that the value of foreign direct investment in the United States increased $708-million in 1972 to stand at $14.36-billion at the end of the year. In 1971, there was a net capital outflow of $115-million.
Angel Cordero let them have it with four barrels yesterday at Belmont Park, and failed of his objective. But it could not be said that the generally pleasant jockey from Puerto Rico was not trying.

Al Lapin Jr., the 45-year-old former pancake turner who in 1968 didn't hesitate to swap $100-million in preferred stock of International Industries, Inc., for a corporate shell whose assets consisted solely of $62-million in cash and marketable securities, resigned yesterday as president and chief executive officer of International Industries.
The Mexican Government announced today that the bodies of 527 people killed by the earthquake of early Tuesday had been recovered, but the final toll was still unknown.
Friends told Nick Cutro a year ago he was wrong for accepting an offer to become head coach of the Hartford (Conn.) Knights, a minor league professional football team.
The presence of hundreds and maybe thousands of dead fish - believed to be menhaden-in waters in the New York City area is a puzzle to government agencies.
Dr. John Jennings of St. Petersburg, Fla., won his second North American men's sailing championship in four years today, with a second in the final race.

Three of the nation's largest steel corporations - United States Steel, Bethlehem and Armco-were indicted today on charges of price-fixing and market-sharing in the $40-million Texas market for steel reinforcing bars.

The Cost of Living Council today extended for one week, until Sept. 8, the gasoline price freeze, delaying the start of a controversial new regulation for retail prices. Also put off was the parallel requirement that maximum prices and octane ratings be posted on each Dump.

Chief Judge Stanley H. Fuid granted the City Council an extension yesterday of tomorrow's deadline for holding hearings to try to prepare "an even better" reapportionment bill than the one Mayor Lindsay vetoed.
The steel industry sought to convince the Government today that price increases it wants to make will not ripple through the economy in an inflationary way.

Chief Judge John J. Sirica refused today to consolidate the parallel law suits being brought against President Nixon by Archibald Cox, the Justice Department's special prosecutor, and by the Senate Watergate committee.

The International Swimming Federation (FINA) expelled today South Africa and Rhodesia from tile first world swimming championships, which open here Saturday.
Chief Justice Warren E. Berger permitted the Nixon Administration today to continue suspension of Federal subsidies for low housing.

The New York City Council has been given an extension-until Sept. 17-to come up with a new redistricting plan. Mayor Lindsay vetoed the Council's first reapportionment bill. The International Civil Aviation Organization condemned Israel by an overwhelming majority today for intercepting a Lebanese airliner on Aug. 10.

Lauren Ford, an artist noted for her religious paintings and paintings for children, died yesterday in Waterbury, Conn. Miss Ford pictured scenes of the Nativity and the life of the Holy Family in the modern rural setting of her farm in Bethlehem, Conn.

Yancey (Yank) Durham, a boxing manager whose fighters included Joe Frazier, the former heavyweight champion, and Bob Foster, the present light-heavyweight titleholder, died here this morning at Temple University Hospital, two days after suffering a stroke. He was 52 years old.
Gov. Marevin Mandel said today that he did not intend to accept any more campaign contributions from persons who receive contracts from the state that are awarded on a noncompetitive bid basis.

The United States announced today that it had reached an agreement with Mexico for the removal of salt from the waters of the Colorado River that are used to irrigate 75,000 acres of land in Mexico.
The strike by 40,000 Chilean truck owners entered its 36th day today with no agreement in sight. Doctors, nurses and other professional workers stayed off their jobs.

The marriage of Mrs. Barbara Warburg of New York and Vineyard Haven, Mass., widow of Paul Felix Warburg, the financier and philanthropist, to Leonardo Mercati of East Hampton, L. I., and Athens, took place here today at the home of John L. Loeb, the investment banker, and Mrs. Loeb.

President Allende has once again been able to persuade high-ranking officers of Chile's Army, Navy and Air Force to accept key positions in his Cabinet. It is by no means clear, however, that these men will be able to succeed-where their commanders in chief in the previous Cabinet failed-in ending the strikes and violence, restoring public order and confidence and shoring up Chile's battered democratic institutions.
The Rev. Carl McIntire went to sea in a boat called the Wild Goose today, but was frustrated in his first attempt to get his "pirate" radio station operating from a ship outside the three-mile limit.

This image affects official as well as popular behavior toward the newcomers, but few people realize that it is no longer valid.

Signaling more potential food increases, the Agriculture Department reported today that the average price of all raw farm products soared a record 20 per cent to a new high in the month ended Aug. 15.

Volume continued rising and prices again closed higher yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market. The Amex index closed at 22.92, up .03 after holding steady during most of the session.

Final arguments were heard today in the trial of the Gainesville Eight. The Government charged that the alleged plotters conspired to "cause havoc" at the Republican National Convention, and the defense contended that the case was "nonexistent, pitifully weak at best."

Kermit Washington. the American 'University basketball player who led college rebounders for the last two years, yesterday signed a multiyear contract with the Los Angeles Lakers.

Vietcong troops have increased attacks southwest of Saigon in a drive to isolate the Mekong delta and its rice from the South Vietnamese capital, military sources said today. The sources said the Communist command's goal is to cut Route 4, the main highway through the delta to Saigon.

The Rev. Arthur H. Bradford, a retired Congregational clergyman and former member of the Corporation of Yale University, died yesterday in the Peterborough Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Jaffrey.

A Bronx woman and her 21year-old cousin who was the baby-sitter for the woman's 2year-old son, were found shot to death yesterday morning in an apartment at 320 East 176th Street in the Tremont section of the Bronx.

A chain of coincidences, forged in part through a professor's good luck, has engendered a literary revival of Edith Summers Kelley, an American writer of the naturalist school, 50 years after the issuance of her only published novel.

Signaling more potential food increases, the Agriculture Department reported today that the average price of all raw farm products soared a record 20 per cent to a new high in the month ended Aug. 15.

The Camadian Parliament convened today to legislate an end to a nationwide railroad strike, with d the Government and the Oppo- a sition leaders all trying to r make maximum political capital out of the special session.
A tropical storm known as Christine, with winds up to 50 miles an hour, formed in the Atlantic today about 1,500 miles southeast of Miami.

Cambodian Government forces today reopened Route 5, Phnom Penh's overland link to the rice-rich western province of Battambang, which Communist forces had closed a week ago. The Phnom Penh area was reported quiet.

Getting through the day means getting through the door-again and again. Enter sociology. Prof. Laurel Richardson Walum of The Ohio State University delivered a paper at the New York Hilton yesterday to the annual meeting of the American Sociological Association on "The Changing Door Ceremony."

The Federal Reserve Board published figures today showing that the nation's basic materials industries-from steel to cement-were operating far closer to capacity in the first half of this year than had previously been recognized in official statistics.

The state's new drug abuse legislation goes into effect tomorrrow, requiring the courts and prosecutors to take a far more stringent approach than at present in both the processing of drug cases and the sentencing of people convicted of drug crimes.

Wednesday night in Montreal the Expos scored four runs in the ninth inning and beat the Dodgers. Last night in Philadelphia's Veterans Stadium, the Expos got a taste of their own medicine when the Phillies rallied for

State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist yesterday upheld the city Board of Education's plan to exclude new pupils who live in the largely black Tilden Houses project in Brownsville from the adjoining East Flatbush-Canarsie school district.

Willie Mays's impending retirement moved a step nearer reality today when some friends of the 42-year-old Met outfielder disclosed plans for a "Farewell to Willie" celebration at Shea Stadium on Sept. 25.
Frank Cocchiaro, a reputed underworld leader, returned to New Jersey from Miami to face a Federal tax indictment today and said that charges that he was a fugitive were untrue.

Officials of the Japanese National Educational Television Network cheerfully expect to lose money on their promotion of the heavyweight championship, bout between George Foreman and Joe (King) Roman, the Puerto Rican challenger this week..

The Ford Foundation and the Public Broadcasting Service announced jointly yesterday that Ford had granted $700,000 to guarantee three longrunning public television programs another year on the air. One of them, William F. Buckley's "Firing Line," had been one of the programs under fire from some segments

The state's new drug abuse legislation goes into effect tomorrow, requiring the courts and prosecutors to take a far more stringent approach than at present in both the processing of drug cases and the sentencing of people convicted of drug crimes.

WASHINGTON -- America and Europe stand at an impasse on international economics. Despite the welcome improvement in atmospherics, the Committee of Twenty has bogged down completely in its effort to develop new monetary rules. The longawaited trade negotiations have already been much delayed, and numerous obstacles threaten to abort them entirely. There is no progress toward a common front on energy.

The city suffered through its third consecutive day of temperatures in the nineties and voltage cutbacks, and faced a new water emergency yesterday as many hydrants were illegally opened in an effort to find relief from the heat.
A Brazilian Army intelligence source said today that the kidnapping threats that sent Vice President Agnew's daughter Susan home from the hospital ship Hope had occurred several months ago.

FALMOUTH, Mass. - The land cruisers fume bumper to bumper past the neons on Route 28, and the vodkapowered yachts rock beam to beam along the inlets of Cape Cod. On what nourishment does this golden tide of tourists feed?

Twentyfive Atlantic City police officers were indicted here by the state grand jury today in what state police authorities described as the most extensive police corruption scandal in New Jersey's history.

Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations continued his Middle East tour today with a 30-hour visit to Israel. He conferred with Premier Golda Meir in Jerusalem for three hours, twice as long as had been scheduled.

Dr. Erwin 0. Smigel, a New York University social scientist whose studies of the Wall Street lawyer and of crimes against bureaucracy received national attention, died yesterday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center of a rare blood disease.

The State Department has responded to the nomination of Henry A. Kissinger as the new Secretary of State with an outpouring of ideas and recommendations in the hope that some new life will be breathed into the old bureaucracy.

The Danish Culture Minister, Niels Matthiasen, made a sweeping attack on the Roman Catholic Church today in response to papal criticism of the financial support the Dan-, ish Govennment is giving to a film titled "The Loves of Jesus Christ."
Volkswagen of America has agreed to recall an estimated 112,000 of its Karmann Ghias to correct possible gaso line or gasoline vapor leaks into the passenger compartment.
Sammy Davis Jr., "a golf nut for the last 20 years," said today he was honored to be the first black person to have a Professional Golfers' Association tournament named after him.

New York's three major net work-affiliated television stations have refused to accept commercials for a new Watergate record album by David Frye, the comedian, even though two of the stations have broadcast Mr. Frye performing the same routines on talk shows, Buddah Records said yesterday.

Thirty-four miles southwest of Phnom Penh, where Communist troops have closed the most important supply road in Cambodia, ice-cream venders on bicycles were selling their wares to relaxed Government soldiers in easy rifle range of the enemy today, and not a shot was audible anywhere.

The City Council has wisely decided to go back to the drawing board with its abominable second try at a plan for redistricting the Council. Instead of plowing ahead with its original apparent intention to override Mayor Lindsay's veto of a plan so inequitable that it could never have survived court review, the Council leadership has obtained extra time from the courts to draw up a fairer one.

Heat waves traditionally bring a jolly jingle to hotel and restaurant cash registers along the Jersey shore, and the sizzling temperatures of the last few days are doubly welcome because they may help to salvage a season that up to now has been only so-so.

Residents of eastern Massachusetts were advised to wear long sleeved shirts and long pants despite hot weather as a precaution against dtsease-carrying mosquitos as health officials continue to battle an outbreak of eastern equine encephalitis.
There was something missing just before the first race at Belmont Park yesterday, but nobody could quite figure out what it was. Then it slowly dawned that Sam Koza was not wearing his scarlet coat.
The 77-year-old proprietor of a rare-stamp shop, who worried for years about being held up, was shot to death yesterday in an apparent robbery attempt.
Visits to China by foreign cruise ships will resume next month for the first time since 1949, travel industry sources said today.
Opportunities are rare indeed for what might be called "The Idiot Discard." If you suddenly throw away a valuable honor in a suit held in strength by the declarer, the idea is to alert your partner.

The Cullum Companies, engaged primarily in retail and wholesale food and drug merchandising, posted record earnings and sales in the fiscal year ended June 30, according to the annual report issued to stockholders yesterday.
It was a hot day and Hubert Green's putter was blazing as he took the first-round lead of the $200,000 Sammy Davis Jr..Greater Hartford open with an eightunder-par 63.
Navy Secretary John W. Warner announced today the selection of the name New York City for one of the Navy's new nuclear-powered attack submarines.

Fran Tarkenton, on the bench for almost three quarters, sparked the Minnesota Vikings to a 17point rally that led to the Miami Dolphins' first loss in a year, 20-17, tonight, in a National Football League preseason game.
George Meany said today that Americans obeyed the law when "they know that those entrusted with its enforcement likewise obey."
The Japanese Ambassador to South Korea returned home suddenly nightt amid indications of a political settlement of the Kim bad Jung kidnapping affair.
A caravan of 350 members of the United Farm Workers Union left today to spread a boycott campaign against table grapes and tuce to 63 cities in the United States and Canada.
The United States dollar moved generally higher today, ending the week and the month on an upward trend. The price of gold again fell sharply.
The swollen waters of the Indus River surged toward the Arabian Sea today, leaving Pakistan stunned.
Firemen extinguished blazes in 35 buildings early today and a police car was destroyed by a fire bomb in the second consecutive night of disturbances in the north Camden area.

The Canadian House of Commons, sounding at times like a labor contract-negotiating team, conducted a rambling debate into the early morning hours today on legislation aimed at ending the eight-day strike that has halted virtually every train in the country.
The New York Mets scored three runs with two out in the 10th inning tonight to upset the St. Louis Cardinals, 6-4, and further tightened the sixteam scramble in the National League's East.

Our time has been labeled the "century of the common man," the era in which America seeks to fulfill the democratic ideal by securing the rights of each individual citizen to realize his or her own potential through equality of opportunity and protection from discrimination.

The Shawmut Association, a Boston-based bank holding company, and the Forth Worth National Corporation, a Texas bank holding company, have agreed to form the American Cattle and Crop Services Corporation as a joint venture.

Decisions, decisions, decisions. After cutting nine players only last Monday to get one below the limit of 49, the New York Jets have to cut seven more this weekend to get below the new limit of 44 by Monday when the three college all-stars finally count against their roster.
President Nixon asked Congress today to defer for 60 days a pending pay increase for Federal employes, declaring that it would "needlessly fan the flames of inflation."

A 17-year-old student who was to have begun his junior year next week at Brentwood High School died yesterday at Southside Hospital in Bay Shore after having collapsed during a preseason football practice session.

As anybody who owns a beloved old pair of blue jeans will tell you, you just don't throw them away when they're frayed and tattered. In fact, connoisseurs insist that denim, like wine, improves with age. Stores are selling worn jeans for higher prices than they do new ones, and some package sandpaper with new jeans so the purchaser can "antique" them.

The trial of Karleton Armstrong on charges of murder and arson in connection with the 1970 bombing at the University of Wisconsin has been scheduled for Oct. 15 by Dane County Circuit Judge William Sachtjen.

State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that the state government would have to pay 5 cents a gallon more for gasoline during the present fiscal year if the Federal Government did not extend price controls on petroleum products.
This city took on an uncharacteristically grim appearance to day after two more patients died of cholera.
Commercial banks that deal in municipal bonds disclosed yesterday how they would like to see this part of the securities industry regulated.
Two major makers of appliances and consumer electronic goods announced yesterday that they were asking higher prices for some of their products.

The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, said today that the second phase of the Senate Watergate hearings would produce testimony on "illegal, unethical, and undesirable" campaign practices by Democrats in the 1972 Presidential campaign.

President Kenneth Kaunda said in a surprise news conference here today that his Government was taking immediate steps to gain firmer control of the country's vital copper industry from Western interests.

Jerry Quarry moved closer to another title bout with a second-round knockout of James J. Woody in a scheduled 10-round heavyweight fight at the Las Vegas Convention Center tonight. The 28-year-old Californian dropped his New York opponent three times on route to the 24th knockout in an eight-year career. The end came at 1:59 of the round.
Vast crowds of chanting workers and youths paraded past Juan D. Peron today as the 77-year-old former President opened his new bid for the presidency.

Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz will head a high-level delegation to Moscow in October to discuss further steps toward widening trade relations between the Soviet Union and the United States, Administration officials said today.

Mayor Joseph F. Bradway Jr. left last night to spend the Labor Day weekend in Florida, but before he left he said the indictment of 32 policemen and city officials 'on corruption charges was a step in the right direction.
A water emergency was declared in the city for the second successive day yesterday as illegally opened fire hydrants in the city and allnight lawn watering continued to drop water-pressure levels.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration moved today to close a regulatory loophole that exempts such vehicles as "The Thing," a new Volkswagen product, from many safety standards.

Lord Renwick, a business leader and a powerful influence on the Conservative party, died here yesterday. His age was 68. He was one of a triumvirate of lobbyists who persuaded the Conservative Government to allow a commercial television system in Britain.
Ralph Nader urged the Government today to ban baggagescanning X-ray machines at airports until officials make sure no radiation is reaching passengers or workers.

A former marine whose 1968 conviction on a charge of rape while on duty in Okinawa was overturned because of new evidence was held for mental observation yesterday following his arrest in Brooklyn on charges of attempting to kill a policeman.
Manager Billy Martin of the Detroit Tigers was suspended yesterday for three days for instructing his pitchers to throw illegal pitches against the Cleveland Indians on Thursday night.

George Foreman, defending his world heavyweight boxing championship for the first time, demolished Joe King Roman of Puerto Rico. with a flurry of heavy blows and knocked him out with a right uppercut at 2 minutes of the first round today.

The General Electric Company received $45.4-million in military contracts, it was announced yesterday. These include a $30.2-million addition to an Air Force award for jet aircraft engines, $14.2 million for additional ship nuclear reactor components, and $1-million for Army 20 mm. automatic cannons.

The chairman of a Congressional panel investigating public spending on President Nixon's private homes said today that some documents pertaining to Mr. Nixon's property at San Clemente, Calif., released earlier this week by the White House, had been altered previously.

While the World Council of Churches was being founded in Amsterdam in August, 1948, T. B. Simatupang was in Java directing guerrillas who were soon to drive the Dutch colonial forces out of Indonesia.

TAKARAZUKA, Japan -Her 5 feet 8 inches may not make Margaret Akita look especially tall among her fellow American women. But in the doll-land of Japan, her height is an asset in her ambition to play a coveted male role on the huge, 366by-72.foot-deep stage of the Takarazuka Grand Theater here.

The Pittsburgh Pirates, especially Willie Stargell, are not conceding the National League's Eastern Division pennant. They emphasized that last night in Three Rivers Stadium by sweeping a double-header from the Chicago Cubs, 7-0 and 5-2.

Sandra Haynie, the hometown heroine, rode a miracle shot to a four-under par 68 today and a one-stroke lead in the first round of the $30,000 Charity women's golf classic.

Samuel Dash, the chief counsel for the Senate Watergate com mittee, said tonight that the committee staff planned to hold a "discreet" interview with Mrs. John N. Mitchell about her recent statements regarding a "campaign strategy book" that may have described Watergate-style operations.

The International Civil Aviation Organization (I.C.A.O.), meeting in Rome, has now followed the lead of the United Nations Security Council in condemning Israel for intercepting an Arab airliner over Lebanon last month and forcing it to land at an Israeli airport.

To the Editor: Government officials and media commentators have been bothered by the apparent conflict between the favorable world markets for U.S. agricultural products and the rising domestic food prices. There is a solution to this conflict-export taxation.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 205.1 from 209.5 last week.

The young star of the movie "Zabriskie Point" was being held in Suffolk County Jail today on bank robbery charges. Mark Frechette, who starred in the 1970 film directed by Michelangelo Antonioni, was arrested on Wednesday after an attempted holdup in which another man was shot to death by the police.

Tens of thousands of New Yorkers streamed out of the city yesterday in search of shade or sea breezes and a Labor Day weekend away from igneous streets, power problems and a town that has been hotter than Florida all week long.
The cockroach, as every urban apartment dweller supposes, is an entomological terrorist. He is dirty. He makes one itch. He does not smell nice. He is not a nice bug, say, like the ladybug.

The Dynamics Corporation of America, operating under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since Aug. 2, 1972, again postponed its annual stockholder meeting, this time to Dec. 14. Earlier the company postponed the normal May date to Sept. 14.
Grain traders cast off their traditional pre-holiday caution yesterday and bid up 'most wheat and corn futures prices on Midwest exchanges. But soybean prices sagged as more supplies appeared.

President Idi Amin congratulated President Nixon today on his nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize, but said he believed that Mr. Nixon was nominated "merely to help you recover from your worries of the Watergate affair," the Uganda radio reported.

The manager of a major concert hall in Mobile, Ala., has been indicted along with a pharmacist, a night-club operator and a disk jockey on charges of attempting to shake down some of the biggest soulmusic performers in the country, including Isaac Hayes, the Jackson Five, James Brown and Al Green.
Consolidated Edison is making lots of electricity these days. But, as they say in Jackson Heights, Queens, all that power means very little if your lights and your air-conditioner are out.

Although baseball and hockey continue to dominate the headlines, one part of the hockey season ended today in Essex County. The three sessions of the 10th annual summer hockey school of Essex County closed at the Branch Brook Ice Center and at West Orange's South Mountain Arena.

At least 11 sharks were sighted offshore along Long Beach Island today, the state marine police said. Thousands of bathers here ewer ordered out of the surf for an hour because a shark had been sighted close to shore.

After six weeks of talks and 14 days before a possible strike deadline, negotiations over a new contract between the United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation appeared today to have hit their first major snag - voluntary overtime.

The Cost of Living Council today authorized the Postal Service to put into effect a deferred in crease in rates for newspapers and magazines, junk mail and books and records. In addition, the council approved pay increases for 700,000 postal employes.

Harlem's Mount Morris Park was renamed Marcus Garvey Memorial Park yesterday in honor of one of the first black nationalist leaders. The park, on Fifth Avenue from 120th to 124th Street, contains a swimming pool complex, an amphitheater, a recreation and cultural center and other facilities. France's gross money supply growth slowed to 1.7 per cent in June from 3,9 per cent in the same month last year, the Bank of France reported today.

The superheated West German economy, driven on by an export boom and beset by a high rate of inflation that has resisted the Government's attempts to treat it, has come under pressure in the last two weeks from a new irritant-wildcat strikes in its biggest factories.
Msgr. John J. Flanagan, pastor of St. Clare's Roman Catholic Church in Great Kills, S.I., since 1954, died Sunday in Staten Island Hospital.

A 16-year-old high-school football player from Trenton collapsed and died here after a two-and-one-quarter hour practice session in heat reaching 90 degrees. The player, Walter Richard Wilkinson of 45 Marshall Road, Trenton, who was about six feet tall and weighed 275 pounds, had worked out in full uniform before becoming ill. He died yesterday in Wayne County Memorial Hospital.

Shipping Row's most prominent landmark-the Custom House on Bowling Green is about to become deserted. The building, completed in 1907 from plans by Cass Gilbert, the architect, has served as a center of the port's multibillion-dollar foreign trade and is now the

Congress reconvenes at noon Wednesday after a month's vacation and will press challenges to President Nixon on two major policy issues-his warmaking power and his right to halt the spending of funds appropriated by Congress.

The Victor Company of Japan, Ltd., has agreed to have the Saehan Precision Industrial Company of South Korea, manufacture color and momochrome television receivers, tape recorders and stereo sets mainly for export to the United States and Europe.

Special Watergate prosecutor Archibald Cox announced today appointment of four trial lawyers to his investigation of illegal contributions in the 1972 Presidential campaign and the secret White House "plumbers" operation.

A journalist hired by the Republicans to report on the activities of 1972 Democratic Presidential candidates gathered similar information in 1968 on Hubert H. Humphrey, Jack' Anderson, the columnist, re ports.

" Firing salvos would make it sound like sour grapes," said a caim Billy Martin, the usually hot-tempered man who was dismissed Sunday as manager of the Detroit Tigers by Jim Campbell, general manager.

SAVYON, Israel-A Madison Avenue art gallery recently opened a branch in this manicured Tel Aviv suburb offering original Picasso, Chagall and Dali prints at prices it advertises as "no higher than New York."

The Chartered Bank and Pacific International Lines have joined with Credit Factoring International, Ltd., subsidiary of the National Westminster Bank to establish the first factoring company in Singapore.
Alberta's major natural gas utitilities are planning to join Canadian Arctic Gas Study, Ltd., E. W. King, president of Canadian Utilities, Ltd., said today.

Fire Island, that splendid strip of barrier beach off the south shore of Suffolk County, appears to be in acute danger of destruction by commercial inroads and Federal indifference. Nine years ago Congress voted to incorporate more than half the island into a National Seashore so that the National Park Service could "preserve and protect" it as an "area of great natural beauty in close proximity to large concentrations of urban population."

Hordes of New Yorkers ended the Labor Day weekend and the summer's last fling at mountains and beaches yesterday and returned to their natural habitat-a city sweltering in its seventh straight day of 90-degree temperatures. But a break in the week-long heat wave was expected today.

The bounce was missing from the two American girls today and they could not come close to an East German and the other Europeans in the finals of the women's threemeter springboard diving of the world aquatic championships.
Three dissident labor leaders were sentenced to 18 months in jail by a military court today on charges of participation in a Communist plot to subvert the Saigon labor movement.

Eighty-eight persons lost their lives a month ago when a Delta Air Lines jet failed to clear the Boston airport seawall while attempting an instrument landing in dense fog. A still incomplete investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board has disclosed that the death plane had a three-month history of problems with its radio and instruments. In the six days before the crash, pilots had reported difficulties on seven occasions.

Norman Raben's La Forza del Destino, which led the fleet home on the Stamford Yacht Club's 39th Vineyard race yesterday, was confirmed today as over-all winner of the Vineyard Trophy on corrected time.
Patty Cake, the Central Park Zoo's baby gorilla, was a year old yesterday. She and her parents, Lulu and Kongo, celebrated with a banana layer birthday cake.

The Muscular Dystrophy Associations of America received pledges of more than $12-million during the Jerry Lewis Labor Day Telethon, a 211/2hour show ending at 6:30 P.M. yesterday that was broadcast locally on WNEW-TV.
While the Federal financial aid picture for students preparing for the opening this fall of the nation's colleges and universities is even more muddled than usual, one fact seems clear:
