Congress reconvenes at noon Wednesday after a month's vacation and will press challenges to President Nixon on two major policy issues-his warmaking power and his right to halt the spending of funds appropriated by Congress.
The Coast Guard said tonight that the report of a dangerous chemical aboard a burning ship that resulted in the evacuation of an entire town of 500 persons was all a mistake.
One of the most enduring rituals in New Jersey politics manifests itself every fourth Labor Day weekend in the opening gambits of the Democratic campaign for Governor.

A Japanese trade official indicated today that Japan would align herself with European t countries in opposing liberalization of trade terms in agriculture at international trade talks beginning next week.
NewJersey's tomatoes, known for their plump firmness and bright red color, don't like the heat wave any better than the state's wilting citizens do.

Recreational and swimming areas of 10 large sections of the Palisades Interstate Park System closed for the season tonight because of an austerity budget. They had been open less than two and a half months this summer.
Consumer spending in Britain fell, in real terms, by three per cent in the second quarter of 1973, according to the Central Statistics Office.

Cale Yarborough bagged his first major victory in three years today and David Pearson became auto racing's fifth $1-million career winner in the 24th running of the Southern 500 stock car race. Yarborough, driving a Chevrolet, beat Pearson's Mercury across the finish line by about eight seconds after a late race duel that kept the crowd of about 70,000 on their feet for much of the final 100 miles.

Tickets for the first two weeks of the Metropolitan Opera's 1973-74 season will go on sale today at 10 A.M. at the company's Lincoln Center box office. The season will open Sept. 17 with Verdi's "II Trovatore."
President Nixon will meet with his Cabinet and the Republican leadership at the White House later this week to discuss issues to lay before Congress as it returns from a recess.
A 22year-old Polish tourist, dressed in blue denim slacks and jacket, stood in the dock at Marlborough Street Court with its domed skylight, dark paneling, poor acoustics and bespectacled magistrate.
Some years ago, this writer became intrigued with the idea of catching the world record striped bass on a flyrod, and devoted the evenings through most of one October to that end.

A committee reached a compromise agreement today to permit all Mediterranean nations, including Israel, to take part in the second phase of the European security conference scheduled to begin here Sept. 18.
Three officers held hostage by dissident inmates at the Indiana state prison were released unharmed tonight, and order was restored in the prison, officials said.

Bigh ranking United States and Latin-American military officers opened their 10th annual conference here today. There were indications that the Latin Americans would seek revision of the 27-year-old reciprocal aid treaty.

After a thunderstorm forced a 50-minute halt in the $200,000 Sammy Davis Jr.-Greater Hartford open today, Billy Casper went on to win with a closing 64 for 264. His total is the lowest on the pro tour this year.
David Goodman slapped the flag down on his taxi meter and, like any seasoned New York cabby, addressed himself affably to the rearview mirror.
Brian Redman finished first in the L. M. Formula 5000 championship race today, but a third-place finish gave Jody Scheckter the series title.

DATES It's past Labor Day and the summer showbiz doldrums presumably are over and what is left of cafe society begins perking again Tonight you can have your pick of: Eddie Haywood and his jazz piano at The Cookery, 8th Street at University Place, from 8 P.M.
The Mafia, entrenched in New Jersey for decades but confronted with aggressive law enforcement in recent years, is being challenged by another aggressive force-black racketeers.

" I am prepared to give my life for this cause," Dr. Carl McIntire, a fundamentalist preacher, said today as he dedicated an offshore radio ship and promised to provide "vigorous, controversial programs."

Lator Day is, for many New Yorkers, a day to enjoy the pleasures that sometimes seem reserved for summerholiday tourists. And so it 'was not surprising that at noon yesterday, most of those waiting at the new Times
The nationwide movement toward land-use regulation poses an array of important and nearly inescapable policy decisions that the public is going to be called on to resolve.
Five persons were killed and one critically injured yesterday when an automobile went out of control and careened into a crowd leaving an air show here.
New York State's "work-forwelfare" requirement is back in full force today, ending a year's interruption because of court challenges.

Eleven North Koreans who will serve as their nation's first observers at the United Nations arrived at Kennedy Airport yesterday to a welcoming party that included representatives of the Chinese and other Communist missions.

" It amounts to playing God, and I don't like it," says Edgar R. Fiedler. "It is as painful and difficult a decision for the Government as I can recall." Mr. Fiedler, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Economic Policy, was expressing in an interview a sentiment

Steve Thompson, the defensive tackle who suffered a charley horse and a sprained ankle in last Saturday night's game against the New Orleans Saints, has been deactivated. He will be eligible to return for the season opener Sept. 17 against the Green Bay Packers.... Seven other player cuts to get the roster down to 44 players are expected to be announced today.... Don Maynard still has not

Pierre P. Garven was sworn in today as the youngest chief justice under the present New Jersev Constitution. In a simple noon ceremony at the County Courthouse here, Mr. Garven received the oath of office from Associate Justice Nathan Jacobs. He succeeds Chief Justice Joseph A. Weintraub, who retired.

On 138 College campuses across the country this fall, social action and consumerism and will be joining beer parties ana tootball as major extracurricular activities. Students will be ringing doorbells, scrutinizing merchandise, doing comparison-shopping,
Board of Education officials said yesterday that they were "making every effort to hold the line" on prices that 60,000 students pay for basic meals in public and parochial schools here daily.
The Temporary Emergency Court of Appeals has upheld for the second time the Government's freeze on beef prices, although it said the Government might have made errors in judgment.

WASHINGTON--In the days since he was nominated to be the 57th Secretary of State, Henry Kissinger has arranged a series of intensive discussions with the most experienced former and present leaders of the State Department and the Foreign Service.
The dollar changed direction at midday today and gained in value against most European currencies in quiet trading. Gold also increased slightly.

The Internal Revenue Service said today that it had reversed a nine-year decline in audit coverage by pulling for special examination a record 1.8 million suspicious returns filed during the fiscal year 1973.
The White House refused today to say whether President Nixon had apologized to White House press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, for shoving hi.. during an appearance in New Orleans on Aug. 20.

WOODWINDS Navigation may be somewhat of a problem but it's worth an early evening's sail up 42d Street from Times Square to the Wurlitzer Building just west of the Avenue of the Americas for the first concert of the season by the New York Kammermusiker.

The Senate Watergate committee has not turned up evidence to warrant an Investigation of Vice President Agnew, its chief counsel, Samuel Dash, said today. "We are not planning our own investigation at this time,"

Robert Leckie was stuck in a Route 46 traffic jam one morning about five years ago on his way to a Young Men's Christian Association workout in Montclair and decided, "I'd be better off if I owned my own athletic club."
A six-member East German delegation arrived here today to search for a suitable place to open an embassy when diplomatic relations are established between East Germany and the United States.

If the Watergate affair has paralyzed some part of Government, it has immobilized the White House and not Congress, Senator LowellP. Weicker Jr. said today. "Congress is still in the midst of a whirlwind of activity,"

Four vintage railroad coaches that knew the splendor of the high noon of the American passenger train were sold a' auction here today for a total of $20,800 and will begin new careers of luxury on both sides of the country.

His only emotion a slight twitch of the blond mustache, Stan Smith coolly wore down Tom Gorman yesterday and advanced to the quarterfinals of the $227,000 United States Open tennis championships at Forest Hills.

An effort to revive a 20year-old Columbia College tradition of initiating freshmen into student activities through humorous skits performed by upper classmen sputtered last night as fewer than 250 of the 735 members of the class of 1977 turned out to watch.
Taken as a group, although they are more used to being taken individually, academics have not been ardent supporters of President Nixon.

Secretary General Waldheim completed his five-nation tour of the Middle East today with a statement reiterating that he had been encouraged by the general desire for peace he encountered in talks with government officials.

New Yorkers suffered through the worst heat wave in seven hig years as temperatures went bro into the nineties yesterday for the eighth day in a row. Yesterday's high was 93 degrees at 1:20 P.M., and forecasters said the stretch of nine consecutive days of above-90 heat recorded from July 6 through 14 in 1966 was expected to be equalled today.

In the roseate years when sports for youngsters and even professionals were regarded as fun and games and not simply spectaculars between commercials, Grantland Rice wrote the starry-eyed but nevertheless inspiring lines: "When the One Great Scorer comes to write against your name-/ He marks-not that you won or lost-but how you played the game."

A Lebanese Army officer killed three members of a pro-Palestinian organization and was wounded in a shooting incident early today. The Lebanese Cabinet met later in emergency session to discuss the shooting,

HAMBURG, West Germany-Peering ahead into the future of trans-Atlantic relations, I find it impossible to detect a rationale for fundamental change. At the same time, it is hard not to predict growing friction between Europe and the United States. Separation impossible, accommodation difficult -- this, I am afraid, is the outlook.

Charles Morris, who has headed the city's reorganized program for determining welfare eligibility and grants since March, 1972, was named yesterday as Secretary of Social and Health Services for the State of Washington. He will take the new post on Nov. 1.

Mrs. Josephine Lloyd of New York and East Norwich, L. I., was married here today to Harold Oakley Barker. The wedding, at the Chelsea Registry Office, will be followed tomorrow by a religious ceremony at St.
A lonely voice was raised here today in defense of Andrei D. Sakharov as an officially inspired campaign of denunciation of the physicist, far from abating, showed signs of becoming more intense.

Americans are about to face the most extreme test yet of how much convenience they are willing to give up in exchange for cutting traffic deaths. After years of Madison Avenue efforts at persuasion that failed, the Government hopes to all but force new-car buyers into using safety belts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4--Government and oil industry sources expressed the common view today that Libya's take-over of 51 per cent of several major American oil companies last weekend presaged higher world oil prices generally and intensification of the already growing pressure on Washington to modify its support of Israel.
GREENWICH, Conn. "Take then also unto thee wheat, and barley, and beans, and lentiles, and millet and fitches and put them in one vessel and make bread thereof," it says in Ezekiel 4:9.
The special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, who occasionally investigates paper shredding in high places, has installed a large shredder in his own offices.
Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, under increasing pressure from the political Opposition, today presented a broad program to combat the effects of inflation.

Prices advanced in quiet trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market. The Amex implemented yesterday a new index system for reporting stock price movements, replacing the price index it has maintained since 1966.

The Navy wants to dispose of more than 1,500 acres of land at its Newport, R.I. base, the Senate Armed Services Committee said today. The land, which cost about $60million, has been declared excess because of cutbacks at

Maurice H. Nadjari, the state's special prosecutor, is investigating the handling of a year-long investigation by the Staten Island District Attorney's office of an apparently racially motivated arson case that implicated one and possibly two police officers.

Mrs. Margaret A. Angelo, who had been decorated by two Popes, died here Sunday. She was 82 years old. Mrs. Angelo was awarded the Pro Eclasia et Pontifice, one of the highest lay awards in the church, by Pope Pius XII in 1943 for welfare work in America following her service as president of the National Council of Catholic Women.

Teachers in Detroit and 33 other Michigan school districts went on strike today, one day before the scheduled opening of classes for the 1973-74 term. About 25,000 teachers are involved in the strike, and some 645,000 students are affected.

Igor R. Shafarevich, a prominent Soviet mathematician, has defended the Soviet physicist Andrei D. Sakharov, as an officially inspired campaign of denunciation showed signs of becoming more intensive. While an increasing number of Soviet writers and scientists joined the anti-Sakharov campaign,

THE DESERT SONG, an operetta by Sigmund Romberg; book and lyrics by Otto Harbach, Oscar Hammerstein 2d and Frank Mandel; staged by Henry Butler, at the Uris Theater, 51st Street, west of Broadway, 6:45. NOO JALL, a play in English by Jalma Carrero, directed by Pablo Cabrera; performed by the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, at South Third Street between Keep Street and 7 Rodney Street, Brooklyn, 7:30.
Emerson Boozer is ready to protect Joe Namath when Joe passes, block for Jim Nance when Jim runs and do some running for the Jets, but first he wants a signed contract.

The Montreal Expos, in the thick of a mad scramble for the National League's eastern division championship, plan to add 3,000 extra seats to Jarry Park, if they finish in first place. These seats would be placed in center and right field behind the fence and would increase the seating capacity to 31,500. There have been crowds in that range twice this year, but they included standees.

John B. Connally, who recently ended a brief tour as an unpaid special adviser to President Nixon, has resumed his directorship at Pan American World Airways, which he had previously held for almost as brief a time.

The United States Ambassador, Emory C. Swank, whose tour in Cambodia ends tomorrow, today described the war here as increasingly counterproductive for both sides but sal little prospect that it would end soon.
Futures prices of many foods traded on the commodities exchanges dropped sharply yesterday. Included were grains, soybeans, live cattle and hog futures.
The Swiss team event Monday that concluded the Labor Day tournament at the New York Hilton Hotel resulted in a resounding double victory for John Bookstaver, Mill Valley, Calif.;

A majority of Toulon's 20, 000 Arab workers stayed off their jobs today to protest what they consider racial discrimination. The one-day walkout at this Mediterranean port city followlowed a similar stoppage in the Marseilles area Monday.

Officials said today that they had not yet established full control at the state prison here where inmates took three guards hostage on Sunday. They said that not all inmates were back in their cells, but there had been no new trouble. A spokesman said otficials had not gone into all ot the cellblocks.
The Penn Central Railroad has asked the Federal Railroad Administration to exempt more than one-quarter of its track system from new national track safety standards scheduled to take effect Oct. 16.

The inevitable clash between jobs and people in a city with limited room for business expansion often results in disruption and anguish. That makes both encouraging and important the achievement in Brooklyn's close-knit, ethnic Northside district of an acceptable compromise between the city and the community in a dispute over the conflicting claims of plant location and family relocation.

For three prime-time hours last night, from 8 to 11, the National Broadcasting Company presented an "American White Paper" that might have been labeled "Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About the Energy Crisis but Were Afraid Somebody Might Actually Take Three Hours to Tell You." Energy is not,

Lou Brock is the personification of Willard Mullin's famous cartoon, the St. Louis Swifly. Last night in Pittsburgh's Three Rivers Stadium, Brock doubled home one run in the eighth inning, then scored the deciding run in a controversial play to give the St.
In the current best-selling novel here, an American astronaut flying a spaceship over. Japan looks down and exclaims: "Wow! Japan is splitting apart!"
A lonely voice was raised here today in defense of Andrei D. Sakharov as an officially inspired campaign of denunciation of the physicist, far from abating, showed signs of becoming more intense.
At state examiner has recommended that the Iroquois Telephone Corporation be authorized to raise its local rates by roughly 15 per cent and obtain $300,800 in additional reverse.

A convicted killer who did household chores at Morven, the Governor's mansion, under a workrelease program was arrested yesterday on suspicion of killing a man with a hatchet on Sunday during his first weekend furlough from prison.
The Teleprompter Corporation said yesterday that it had suspended temporarily 20 per cent of its 1973 construction program and is reviewing Its entire program for adding new televions cable systems.

In recent years dance has played a comparatively meager role in the Edinburgh International Festival, where drama and music still reign supreme. The reason is quite simply a shortage of suitable theaters-there is hardly anywhere practicable to place large-scale dance companies.
Three retail merchandisersthe McCrory Corporation, Tiffany Co. and Garfinkel, Brooks Brothers, Miller Rhoads, Inc.--reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the first fiscal half-year.

Government and oil industry sources expressed the common view today that Libya's take-over of 51 per cent of several major American oil companies last weekend presaged higher world oil prices generally and intensification of the already growing pressure on Washington to modify its support of Israel.
Cholera killed four more persons in Italy today, bringing the death toll to 18 as the disease struck for the first time in two northern cities despite official statements that it was waning.
Mickey Lolich, who had been stingy with hits in his two previous appearances this season against the Yankees at Tiger Stadium, made a repeat performance tonight.

" Park Avenue dentistry" came to the Veterans Administration hospital here today with the opening of a $1-million clinic and research center. The center, one of the nation's largest has wall-to-wall carpeting, color-coordinated patient treatment rooms, an intercommunications system and piped-in music in addition to the latest technical equipment.
The elementary school system here was desegregated without incident today, ending 10 years of racial imbalance in which some schools were 97 per cent white and others 96 per cent black.
Leave it to Bobby Riggs, "The Happy Hustler" of the tennis courts, to find a quick way to cash in on his newly found fame as the nation's No. 1-seeded male chauvinist.

The small parking lot off Main Street here was jammed with cars last weekend, with shoppers crowding into the A. P. at one end of the lot and at the other, scarcely 100 yards away, into Pratt's Place, a relatively new country store.

The Goldfield Corporation announced yesterday it had granted an option to Life Investors International, Ltd., of Toronto to settle for $21.8-million its $80-million damage suit against the General Host Corporation.

President Nixon's pending appeal of the court ruling last week that he must surrender the Watergate tape recordings for private judicial inspection will move up to the Supreme Court faster than the parties to the historic lawsuit thought possible.

An offering of 750,000 common shares of the Digital Equipment Corporation at 89 1/4 per share was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Lehman Brothers. The company's stock was up 1/4 at 89 3/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

When the World Journal.Tribune, that bewildered relict of three New York newspapers, died in 1967, the best baseball writer in America retired. His name is Tommy Holmes, and readers deprived of his stuff these six years will be pleased to know that he is alive and well in Brooklyn. ir Alive and well and abreast of the news, as the following letter demonstrates, far better informed than most. Tommy writes:
The Cambodia command said today that Government troops defending the besieged provincial capital of Kompong Cham had managed to reopen the road to the airport.
Britain's balancer of trade with the Common Market deteriorated sharply last year, according to official statistics released today.

Three years ago Beverly Harrell leased five acres of barren desert from the Federal Government for $100 a year. Now, says Mrs. Harrell, the Bureau of Land Management is trying to renege on the agreement because it doesn't like the kind of business she operates.

The oppressive humidity that enveloped Central Park on Monday night made it a bit difficult to summon up the proper mood of sentiment for the occasion-the final Naumburg concert of this summer, celebrating the 50th anniversary of the present bandshell on the Mall and conducted by Joseph Silverstein.

A Parliament commission investigating West Germany's "votes for sale" scandal decided today to summon Science Minister Horst Ehmke, a close aide of Chancellor Willy Brandt. He is the first minister to be called before the inquiry.

The district attorney's office today released an American television employee, Jack L. Begon, from jail without bail pending further action on charges of fabricating his own kidnapping and taking company funds.
A 12-year old boy was wounded yesterday when he was struck by pellets from a shotgun blast that hit a suspected heroin dealer during a shoot-out on a Bronx thoroughfare.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I.-Mrs. Robert A. Lovett carried her bright green basket to another section of the Italian Garden. The temperature was 95 degrees but her bright blue eyes darted along the rows of brilliant blossoms and her hands kept pace-a dead leaf here, a bedraggled flower there, snip, snip.

Two film buffs who felt there were plenty of revival theaters here showing European art films but not many offering Hollywood classics have decided to open a midtown revival house devoted to forgotten American films.

In Tokyo next week some 80 nations, meeting under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, will seek agreement on the basic objectives of a major trade negotiation in 1974-the first since the Kennedy round of the nineteen-sixties.
Tom Seaver witnessed a strange sight in the first inning last night, but managed to keep himself from going into shock and pitched the Mets to a 7-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

The pro-Communist Pathet Lao and Premier Souvanna Phouma publicly applied heavy pressure today on the right-wing politicians and generals who have balked at signing a completed accord that would establish a coalition government in Laos.

A Gallup Poll commissioned by the New Jersey Education Association showed yesterday that despite a State Supreme Court ruling to the contrary, 48 per cent of those polled prefer to keep, the present system of financing the public school system, and 37 per cent favor a new uniform statewide' tax. About 58 per cent of the 459 person.
Describing food supplies as precariously low, the Government said today that Pakistan needed a million tons of wheat immediately as a result of the three-week flooding of the country's river system.

The Radio City Music Hall's traditional policy of stage shows with movies faced possible curtailment as a result of its negotiation with the musicians' union, which has already shut down the New York City Opera.

Mrs. Lydia Todd Shnayerson, a music teacher and the wife of Robert B. Shnayerson, editor in chief of Harper's magazine, died Sunday at their summer home here. She was 46 years old and lived at 118 Riverside Drive. New York.

George A. Phillips, former director of advertising for Cluett Peabody Co., and president in 1953 and 1954 of the Advertising Club of New York, died yesterday at the Center Manor Nursing Home here. His age was 79.
Scores of thousands of leftists marched today in celebration of the third anniversary of the election that brought to power President Salvador Allende Gossens and his Marxist coalition Government.

The Nassau County Police Department has activated a 911 telephone number to enable its 1.5 million residents to report emergency situations and obtain help more quickly for police, ambulance and fire services.
Everett D. Davis, vice president and traffic manager of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad at his retirement in 1962, died yesterday at his home here. He was 81 years old.

Dr. Arthur M. Master, who developed the "Master TwoStep" exercise tolerance test for the diagnosis of heart disease, died yesterday of cancer at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 885 Park Avenue.

AMORY--George S. The Board of Governors of the New York Chapter of the Arthritis Foundation deeply mourn the passing of their beloved friend and colleague, George S. Amory. For the past 25 years his constant Interest and dedication were an inspiration to all of us who were privileged to work with him. Our deepest sympathy Is extended to his family.

A panel of topflight economic experts, appointed to investigate the activities of multinational corporations and devise international rules for their operations, convened for the first time today and elected L. K. Jha of India as chairman.

George C. Branche Jr. is a 47-year-old doctor who in many ways epitomizes the stereotype. of a New, York practitioner: He is tall and urbane, he has a successful practice and a home in the suburbs, a teaching appointment at a medical school and, generally, "a comfortable life."
About 15,000 people in Elmhurst, Queens, many of whom suffered through several days without electricity last week, were without power again yesterday.

Attacking what he called Government puffery, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare has ordered a 77 per cent reduction in the department's public affairs staff and the elimination of 275 publications.
Stock prices bounded ahead again yesterday, extending last week's low-key rally, in a session that produced 1,010 advancing issues and a gain of 7.82 points for the Dow-Jones industrial average.

Picking its way carefully across the playlists of the music radio stations is a song titled "Uneasy Rider," performed by its composer Charlie Daniels. The reason for the careful progress lies in the lyric content of the song, which deals with the rider of the title, long-haired and involved in an auto breakdown in the Deep South.

A Los Angeles County grand jury returned today secret indiotments against unnamed defendants after the final day of testimony in the inquiry into the burglary at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.
The Secret Service said today that there were times when it was legally allowed to record calls to the White House without telling the caller his conversation was being recorded.

Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate for governor, today recommended a narcotics control program that would allow maximum life prison sentences for "major distributors of hard drugs in New Jersey."

Paul Williams, a lawyer who was a special assistant to Assistant Attorney General Thurman Arnold in major antitrust prosecutions during the Roosevelt Administration, died Monday in a Greenwich, Conn., nursing home. He was 85 years old..

Dig we must, said State Supreme Court Justice Gerald P. Culkin, and yesterday he issued a preliminary injunction to prevent the city from enforcing laws that limit public utilities' street-digging hours.

Igor R. Shafarevich, a prominent Soviet mathematician, has. defended the Soviet physicist Andrei D. Sakharov, as an officially inspired campaign of denunciation showed signs of becoming more intensive. While an increasing number of Soviet writers and scientists joined the anti-Sakharov campaign, Mr. Shafarevich pleaded for a halt in the denunciations of Mr. Sakharov, whom Mr. Shafarevich called a credit to the Russian people.
HOUSTON-Placed Lynn Dickey, quarterback, on injured reserve list and reactivated Paul Guidry, linebacker. NEW YORK JETS-Placed Steve Thompson, defensive tackle, on injured reserve list.

Unofficial reports on the secret talks held by Arab oil ministers in Kuwait yesterday carry the welcome news that no common policy of political blackmail against the United States and other major oil-consuming nations was adopted. But even if the Arab states' chronic difficulty in ever being united on anything has averted an immediate showdown, it is plain that the Middle East forces determined to use oil as a weapon for isolating Israel from
An 11-man delegation from North Korea, here to open that Government's first diplomatic office at the United Nations, has chosen the Waldorf-Astoria for its temporary quarters.

To the Editor: The prominence given by the press to the political scandals of 1972 and 1973, involving first the Watergate incident and now the widely published charges against the Vice President, suggests that the news media may be as involved as the politicians.

Dr. Abraham S. Goodhartz, who retired in 1970 as dean of studies of Brooklyn College, with which he had been associated since 1938, died Monday in Maimonides Hospital after a coronary attack. He was 64 years old and lived at 711 Montauk Court, Brooklyn.

Dr. Milton E. Loomis, a former dean and professor of government at New York University, died here on Sunday. He was 86 years old. Dr. Loomis graduated in 1909 from Western Reserve University and received a master's degree from the University of Wisconsin. He went to N.Y.U.
General Motors and Ford, the nation's two largest auto makers, declared their innocence today in United States District Court as they went on trial on criminal charges of price-fixing.

Charles Morris, who has headed the city's reorganized program for determining welfare eligibility and grants since March, 1972, was named yesterday as Secretary of Social and Health Services for the State of Washington. He will take the new post on Nov. 1.

Small jazz groups tend to fall into relatively set instrumental formats-piano trios (piano, bass, drums), quartets or quintets made up of one or two horns and a rhythm section. Benny Goodman's original trio and quartet were unusual because they did not use a bass, and the Modern Jazz Quartet is also slightly different because, instead of a horn, it includes a vibraphone.

The Dodgers star relief pitcher, Jim Brewer, complaining of back pains following last night's game against the San Francisco Giants, flew home today and was put in traction at Centinela Valley Hospital.
The New York Giants did a thriving business yesterday in the sale of tickets on an individual game basis for their five contests at the Yale Bowl in New Haven.

Mayor Lindsay promised yesterday that the city would make "enormous efforts" to insure the security and viability of educational and religious institutions in Morningside Heights. His comment, made on a walking tour of the heights, came after several educational leaders said that safety in the area was their greatest problem.

An American journalist, Seymour Freidin, conceded today that he had received sums of money from the Republican party for relaying information from the Democratic camp during the 1968 and 1972 Presidential elections.

It sounded like a crime of passion-- passion for golf that Joseph C. Dey, commissioner of the Professional Golfer's Association's Tournament Players' Division, was describing yesterday as he announced a year's suspension and $1,000 fine for Jim King of Miami.
Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson said tonight that he had "had indications" that Justice Department employes had leaked information to newsmen about the investigation of Vice President Agnew.

Trees that once burned in forest fires can be salvaged for use in home-building, and logging crews now are hauling out scorched lumber from forests throughout California and other Western States. The worst fires in 20 years in those states have ravaged almost 200,000 acres of trees and brush.

WINDSOR, Vt.--On the first anniversary of Watergate, and for several weeks now, the American public read and heard universal praise, appreciation and applause for a free press in a free country. A confirmation in 1973 of Jefferson's 1787 view that newspapers without government would be preferable to government without newspapers.

Three brothers from the Bronx, accused of being major heroin traffickers. who even shipped gift-wrapped heroin, drew heavy sentences yesterday in Federal Court.

The accounting firm that prepared a special audit of President Nixon's real estate transactions also prepared a complete-but still secret-audit of his entire financial condition, an official of the company said yesterday.

The attorney for Frank A. Sturgis, a Watergate burglar, said today that he would subpoena records to prove that his client was engaged five years ago in undercover work against Cuba and was not involved in a stolen car ring.

A 10 - mile-an-hour wind gust from a thunderstorm smashed across the Texas plains into Big Spring today, killing two children and injuring at least two dozen persons caught in trailer houses that were rolled over and demolished.

James Shabazz, a Black Muslim leader here, was shot to death in the driveway of his home this after. noon. The police were seeking two men believed to have run up to Mr. Shabazz and fired at him as he was getting out of his car.
Miss Mary Ann Livingston Delafield Cox and Brinkley Stimson-Thorne are planning a very small, very informal wedding Sunday in Westhampton Beach, L. I.

President Nixon announced today that he would nominate George H. Hearn, vice chairman of the. Federal Maritime Commission, for a new fiveyear term. Mr. Hearn, a Democrat from Brooklyn, has been a commissioner since July, 1964.
Britain's biggest selling evening newspaper, The Evening News of London, failed to appear for the second day today because of an industrial dispute.
Princess Norodom Bopha Devi, daughter of Cambodia's former Chief of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, left here with her family for Hong Kong last night.

State Police Superintendent William E. Kirwan today delayed the swearing in of four women recruits pending the outcome of a court challenge filed by an upstate policeman who said he had scored higher on an examination than the women.

Steel production for the week ended Sept. 1 fell by 2.6 per cent to 2.73 million tons from 2,803,000 tons in the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The production index slipped to 111.9 from 114.9 in the week ended Aug. 25.

Americans are about to face the most extreme test yet of how much convenience they are willing to give up in exchange for cutting traffic deaths. After years of Madison Avenue efforts at persuasion that failed, the Government hopes to all but force new-car buyers into using safety belts.

During my three-year odyssey through the world of American prisons, an elusive, half-formulated thought kept nagging at the back of my mind: Are there not disturbing similarities between the prison business and an earlier preoccupation of mine, the American funeral industry? What do prison administrators and undertakers have in common?

Qualified Democratic sources reported today that organized labor across the country was prepared to send a quarter of a million dollars into New Jersey in an effort to elect Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate for Governor.
The oil industry appears ready to make a strong stand against the Libyan Government's nationalization action although the companies seem to have few weapons in their arsenal.

In Honolulu, finishing a weekend holiday, Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union discussed the controversial sale of American wheat to his country. Probably running with the grain of Soviet public opinion, Mr. Dobrynin said of the sale,

A convicted killer who did household chores at Morven, the Governor's mansion, under a workrelease program was arrested yesterday on suspicion of killing a man with a hatchet on Sunday, during his first week. end furlough from prison.

The credit markets moved toward lower interest rates and higher prices for fixedincome securities yesterday as investors quietly stepped up their orders to buy from fear of missing what might turn out to be a genuine swing toward lower yields.
A 26-year-old beautician was shot to death yesterday in a beauty shop in Fresh Meadows, Queens, shortly after she told a customer that she feared her husband was going to kill her.
A group known as the Harlem High School Committee accused City College officials yesterday of "trying to take over" a school building that the committee is seeking to use for an expanded Harlem High.
Lawrence and Alice Parker, charged with manslaughter after their 11-year-old diabetic son, Wesley, died when his insulin was thrown away, were released from jail on their own recognizance today.

James shabazz, a Black Muslim leader here, was shot to death in the driveway of his home this afternoon. The police were seeking two men believed to have run up to Mr. Shabazz and fired at him as he was getting out of his car.
A lumbering, now weak, high-pressure air mass that has brought the metropolitan area eight straight days of temperatures above 90 has also clamped a lid over much of the East Coast.
A five-year contract, said to be the longest teacher contract on record in the United States, was agreed to in the Port Washington School District early this morning.

A Los Angeles County grand jury returned today secret indictments against unnamed defendants after the final day of testimony in the inquiry into the burglary at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.
An examination of a seal that died in Boothbay Harbor yesterday disclosed that it had not died of a gunshot wound, the state Sea and Shore Fisheries Commissioner. Spencer Apollonio, said today.
Israel plans to deport a community of 350 American blacks who assert they are the original heirs to the Promised Land, Israeli police officials said today.

More than thirty years ago, while World War II was still on and most domestic concerns were being pushed aside, Congress first introduced into the tax code a provision permitting tax savings for families with extraordinarily high medical costs resulting from severe illness of any kind. Millions of families have since benefited from that provision for tax deduction of out-of-pocket doctor, hospital and related costs exceeding 3 per cent of gross income.

Laffit Pincay showed yesterday that "jockeys are only human, too." The Panamanian, who led the money-winning list for the last three years and is at the top of the heap this season, had to give in to the heat after riding two races at Belmont Park.
The nomination of Henry A. Kissinger to be Secretary of State has raised some hopes in Europe that United States embassies will regain an effective role.

European subsidiaries of two major American manufacturing companies announced yesterday receipt of contracts from the Soviet Union and China. The American Chain and Cable Company, Inc., reported that an Italian subsidiary had received a $22-million order to supply aluminum foundry equipment for the Kama River truck facility in Russia. The subsidiary. Fata.
William L. Brody, who retired in 1968 as the senior law assistant in the State Supreme Court in Manhattan and the Bronx, died Saturday in his home at 2 Horatio Street. He was about 75 years old.
Martin Corey Powers, chief speech writer and special assistant to the Secretary of Agriculture, died Saturday in Suburban Hospital, Bethesda, Md. He was 63 years old.

Consolidated Edison officials in Queens said yesterday that more than 1,100 claims seeking compensation for food spoilage had been received from residents of Jackson Heights, and that none of them had been processed:

Representatives of 23 countries of the Western Hemisphere convened in Washington today to begin drafting structural changes in the Charter of the Organization of American Slates, which many believe is cumbersome and obsolete.
American and Thai Government officials began a second round of talks today on the withdrawal of United States forces from six bases in Thailand.

Drug abuse has caused an outbreak of hepatitis among United States troops in Bavaria, an Army doctor said today. Capt. Ward Cates, preventive medicine officer of the, United States Army's 130th General Hospital, said the contagion could soon reach one of every 50 soldiers and dependents in northern Bavaria at its present rate.

Saul Touster, provost and vice president for academic affairs at City College, has been named by the Board of Higher Education as acting president of Richmond College of the City University, effective immediately. Dr. Touster, a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School, succeeds Herbert Schueler, who resigned last May but will remain on the staff working on special projects for the Chancellor of City University.

Victor Feather left school in the Yorkshire town of Bradford at 15, went to work filling bags of flour, joined a union, came to London for a $25-aweek job and rose to become one of the most important men in the country's power structure.
Vietcong and South Vietnamese military negotiators met today for the first time in four days, averting the threat of a complete breakdown in talks to carry out the Paris peace agreement.

State Police Superintendent William E. Kirwan today delayed the swearing in of four women recruits pending the outcome of a court challenge filed by an upstate policeman who said he had scored higher on an examination than the women.
The nomination of Henry A. Kissinger to be Secretary' of State has raised some hopes in Europe that United States embassies will re. gain an effective role.

Dick Barnett retired as a player yesterday and was named an assistant coach of the Knicks. Jim Chones, once regarded as the bright hope of the Nets, was traded to the Carolina Cougars of the American Basketball Association.

A holdup man with a toy pistol robbed a Manhattan grocer of more than $100 yesterday and then, in a chase and struggle, managed to take the victim's real gun before making his escape, the police reported.
The Federal Power Commission ruled today that it had no jurisdiction to regulate production or transportation of synthetic gas produced from coal when unmixed with natural gas.
New Yorkers suffered through the worst heat wave in seven years as temperatures went into the nineties yesterday for the eighth day in a row. Yesterday's high was 93 degrees at 1:20 P.M.,

Four vintage railroad coaches that knew the splendor of the high noon of the American passenger train were sold at auction here today for a total of $20,800 and will begin new careers of luxury on both sides of the country.
While New Yorkers suffered through an eighth straight day of above-90 degree temperatures, operations were as cool as usual yesterday at the National Weather Service offices in Rockefeller Center.

A suspect in the fatal shooting of a 4-year-old boy and the wounding of an off-duty police officer on Sunday was arraigned yesterday. and. ordered held without bail by Judge Hyman Solniker in Criminal Court. A hearing was set for Friday.

A court hearing scheduled for today on an application by The New York Times for a permanent injunction to bar members of Typographical Union 6 from interfering with production of the paper by holding union meetings during working hours was postponed yesterday until tomorrow.

Miss Pamela Lynn Mars, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mars of Bethesda, Md., was married here this evening to Allan Jeffrey Malester, son of Mrs. Maurice Shugar of Baltimore and the late Frank Malester.
The United- States Export-Import Bank is lending Cathay Pacific Airways, Ltd., of Hong Kong $12 397,500 to cover 45 per cent of the cost of six used Boeing 707 airliners, the bank announced today.

The small parking lot off Main Street here was jammed with cars last weekend, with shoppers crowding into the A. P. at one end of the lot and at the other, scarcely 100 yards away, into Pratt's Place, a relatively new country store.

Michigan's legislative districts, which have been redrawn to the Democrats' advantage, have come under a challenge in Federal court that may have ramifications in several other states. The Republican-inspired suit attacks the constitutionality of the eight-member commission that redrew districts for the state's Legislature and the United States Senate and House in 1972.
A gasoline truck overturned and exploded yesterday on the new Dunn Memorial Bridge, shooting a ball of flame and thick smoke into the air and closing traffic on the Hudson River span for hours.
A five-year contract, said to be the longest teacher contract on record in the United States, was agreed to in the Port Washington School District early today.

The Town Council voted tonight to take "every legal step" to prohibit the reconstruction of the Mallinckrodt Chemical Company's plant here, which was partly destroyed three weeks ago in a fire and explosion that killed seven employes.
An American male lowered a world record twice today but his countrywomen were no match for the thickly muscled East German girls at the world swimming championships.
A gang of about 25 youths harassed the audience and musicians yesterday to the point where the season's last free noontime concert in Bryant Park had to be cut short.

A surprisingly tame tropical storm Delia sloshed onto land today, spreading moderately heavy rains and little reported damage along the eastern Texas and western Louisiana Gulf coasts.

It sounded like a crime of passion -passion for golf-that Joseph C. Dey, commissioner of the Professional Golfer's Association's Tournament Players' Division, was describing yesterday as he announced a year's suspension and $1,000 fine for Jim King of Miami.

President Nixon's pending appeal of the court ruling last week that he must surrender the Watergate tape recordings for private judicial inspection will move up to the Supreme Court faster than the parties to the historic lawsuit thought possible.
Ten members of a group that calls itself the National Caucus of Labor Parties, including its announced candidate for Mayor, were arrested today after a melee in the City Council chamber.

Moody's Investors Service, which publishes manuals, weekly stock and bond surveys and investors ratings, has named Richard D. Simmons as president. Mr. Simmons, however, is no stranger to the Dun Bradstreet Companies, Inc.,

Bowlers are not the only group of sports-minded people seeking that elusive score of 300. Members of the 22 teams in the Essex County Police Revolver League shoot for that perfect score once a week from March until June.

The Federal Government's star witness in the recent trial of the Gainesville Eight in Florida has shown" indications of deception" during a lie detector test he sought to deny an acquaintance's charges that he was a violence-prone agent provocateur last year.

Sanford D. Garelik, president of the City Council, charged yesterday that Phoenix House, a program to fight drug addiction, had been recruiting addicts from outside the state for treatment here and had been getting them on welfare.

A request by the Long Island Lighting Company for a $5,225,500 increase in electricity and gas rates for its 800,000 customers in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and part of Queens was criticized here today at a public hearing held by the Public Service Commission.

" I'm faster than ever. I'm a sight for the world." So spake Muhammad Ali yesterday as he abandoned his natural modesty and reticence. This pronouncement was in the nature of a farewell address as the one-time champion of the universe reluctantly left his elaborate training camp in Deer Park, Pa., and headed to California for his return match with Ken Norton on Monday.
President Nixon said today that he was giving "highest priority " to' achieving a Middle East settlement that would put an end to Arab threats to curtail future oil deliveries to Western countries.

President Nixon said today he hoped to restore confidence in his Administration, shaken by the Watergate disclosures, by not permitting his own confidence to be destroyed and by showing the country that he was "doing something."

Outstanding consumer credit, an indication of spending activity in the economy, increased $2.18-billion in July, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. It was the fourth largest monthly increase ever and compared with the record of $2.47billion last December.

The police blanketed downtown Santiago with tear gas tonight in an attempt to keep antiMarxist demonstrators from marching on the Presidential palace. More than 100,000 mostly middle-class women had massed a few blocks away from the squat gray palace to protest

The knight, like the other pieces, reaches its maximum power when it is posted in the center, or when it bears directly on the center. Unlike the other pieces, the knight undergoes a dramatic difference in range when it moves to the center from the edge of the board.

Capt. Alan L. Bean, of the Navy, the 41-year-old commander of Skylab 2, became the world champion of space flight today, setting a mark for the most time in space. The record came at 6:11 A.M. as Captain Bean and his crewmates, Dr. Owen K.

Governor Rockefeller said today that the country's present "agony" underscored the people's desire for "Government leadership that will place enduring moral principle over immediate political advantage"

In an atmosphere of general calm, ruffled only by one facultyschool board dispute of immediate consequence, most of the hundreds of thousands of pupils and their teachers returned to classrooms today in North Jersey's school districts.

The Mets took another large step last night toward fulfilling their faint pennant hopes. By defeating the Philadelphia Phillies here, 4-0, behind the combined four-hit pitching of Ray Sadecki and Tug McGraw, they sneaked ahead of the rained-out Chicago Cubs into fourth place, their loftiest status since June 24.

Two major chains of furniture warehouse showrooms, the Levitz Furniture Corporation and the Wickes Corporation, reported yesterday increased sales for August compared to the year-ago-month. However, Levitz had a much smaller gain than it has traditionally reported.

The second of the two major political gatherings China has scheduled for this year-the National People's Congress-will take place later this month, according to reliable sources in the Chinese capital.

Three thousand city firemen marched in silent procession to a muffled drum beat in Brooklyn yesterday as a Fire Department pumper truck bore the coffin containing the body of Fireman Joseph Johnson Jr., who died at a fire last Saturday night.
A 43-year-old man burned to death early today when fire swept through a house he was visiting here, the Suffolk County police reported. They tentatively identified the man as George Blackman
Congress is only weeks away from passing legislation that would end television blackouts of many home games in professional sports, Representative Torbert H. MacDonald said today.

Long Island officials met today with former Gov. John A. Love of Colorado now director of the White House Energy Policy Office, and warned of a cold winter for Long Island homeowners in the absence of mandatory allocations by the major oil companies to independent retailers.

Norman Desser, the newly appointed principal at Public School 208 in Brooklyn, said yesterday that he intended to perform his duties despite the opposition of part of the local school board and of parents holding a sit-in at the school.
The poor nations of Asia, Africa and Latin America opened today their biggest effort to date to achieve unity against the industrial world.

Smiling, even applauding, as Ken Rosewall's stinging backhanders went by him, Vijay Amritraj of India was eliminated yesterday in the quarterfinals of the $227,000 United States Open tennis championships, 6-4, 6-3, 6-3.

The professional conduct of Henry A. Kissinger, the nation's most prominent political scientist, was called into question today by a portion of the American Political Science Association, of which he was once a member.
The Senate rejected today moves to cut the White House budget and curb future "security improvements" on President Nixon's two private homes.
Following is a transcript of President Nixon's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT Won't you be seated, ladies and gentlemen.

Nearly four decades ago Maxwell Anderson won the New York Drama Critics Award for "High Tor," which stated the case for preserving the mountain, a Rockland County landmark, rather than letting it become a quarry.

Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator and mass-transit advocate, announced yesterday a new legal move designed to force the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to spend billions on mass-transit development.
Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, sent word to House leaders today that his Ways and Means Committee would approve a new trade hill before October.
Federal officials, seeking to curb cargo hijackings, are working on a plan to send out radio signals asking trucks where they are and getting a signaled reply from the truck.

Back in 1925, when the Lost Generation was whooping it up in Paris and a new, free kind of love was making the world go around, the French couturier, Jean Patou, introduced a fragrance called Amour Amour.

Premier Souvanna Phouma and rightist members of his Cabinet today backed off from a showdown ove; disagreements concerning a completed protocol that would establish a coalition government with the Communist-led Pathet Lao.

The stock market swung higher yesterday afternoon to post its seventh advance in the last nine sessions. Activity edged up from Tuesday's level but remained subdued at 14.58 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The above - 90 - degree heat! wave ended yesterday for much of the metropolitan area as a cold front moved down from New England faster than expected.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation has uncovered evidence showing that almost all of the superfecta races that were run at Roosevelt, Yonkers and Monticello Raceways from December, 1972, through March, 1973, were fixed, according to sources close to the Federal investigation.
Ten members of a group that calls itself the National Caucus of Labor Parties, including its announced candidate for Mayor, were arrested today after a melee in the City Concil chamber.
Prices eased yesterday in continued moderate trading on the American Stock Exchange. The over-the-counter market remained firm on slightly increased volume.

For the second straight day, the East German girls, referred to by the American girls as "those guys," muscled their way into what was once predominantly an American sport.
Frank Eikins, a former New York Times sports writer whose coverage of skiing spurred its development in the nineteenhirties and forties, died of leukemia yesterday in Mount Sinai hospital.
A small band of Palestinian gunmen took over the Saudi Arabian Embassy here yesterday morning and reportedly seized at least 15 of of its diplomats and employes as hostages.
Question: What woman was chosen over Babe Ruth and Jack Dempsey to earn an "Athlete of the Year" title? Answer: Gertrude Ederle, who finally is obeying her doctor's order to stay out of the water.

WASHINGTON-In the arcane lingo of the newsmagazine business, a "violin" is a mood-setting article in the front of the national affairs section; a "tick-tock" is a detailed chronology of events leading up to decision; and a MEGO is a big problem.

Judge Morris Lasker of the Federal Court, yesterday sentenced William Mason, the operator of Camp Napanoch in Ulster County, to 30 days in prison for his part in a bribeconspiracy involving the Model Cities program in Harlem.

Eastern Gas Fuel Associates announced yesterday it had purchased 110,000 shares of its own common stock at $15 a share from the S. H. Scheuer interests. The company's stock closed at 163/8, down 1/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Meat supplies have climbed back to just about normal in supermarkets here, along with improving stocks for wholesales who serve small retailers, butchers and restaurants, the city's Consumer Affairs Department reported yesterday.
The flight of 15 steps that fills the converted storefront window on East 19th Street isn't there purely for decoration.

The united states maintains a commanding position in world science, but that leadership is declining in several important indicators of scientific activity, according to a report sent to Congress today by President Nixon.
Dr. JULIUS r. Miner, clinical professor of oral surgery at New York University Bellevue Medical Center, died last night at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Lawrence, L. I.

The Canada Development Corporation, wholly owned by the Canadian Government, won the right in United States District Court today to buy 10 million shares of Texasgulf, Inc., a major American mining and natural resources company with holdings in Canada.

The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it was "beginning immediately to intensify work" on the first of two phases of development for coal gasification and coal liquefaction. The company estimated it would spend 'about $10-million" on the first phase.

The city today sold a record $900-million of short-term notes at an average interest rate of 6.237 per cent. The interest rate was described as "good" in the present market by Controller Abraham D. Beame,

Crew members were examining their Soviet passenger ship today for possible damage incurred while the liner was lodged on an offshore reef for four days here. Tom Gorman criticized the Nastase of Rumania yesterday for pulling out of the doubles after his loss in the singles at Forest Hills.
Toward the end of August, the Baltimore Orioles put together a 14-game winning streak and threatened to break open the four-team battle for first place in the American League's Eastern Division.

Millions of people own stock today, but millions more who can afford to invest are not in the market at all. Many are on the sidelines because they were frightened off by the declining market. Others do not invest because it seems too complicated.
Controller Abraham D. Beame urged the Federal Government yesterday to begin an immediate investigation of the safety of the entire city subway system.

The Mayor of this largest of American cities must be capable of vigorous, imaginative, creative leadership. He must be able to attract and to hold the confidence of the people, to work with this city's diverse groups and persuade them of the mutuality of their interests.

NEW HAVEN-It may seem odd, but I feel the shadow of the last few years is lifting. There may be no amnesty as yet for those who stepped beyond the law. There may be no physical repatriation for those who chose literal exile.

The PBW Stock Exchange today unveiled a data dissemination system that officials said would be compatible to a new trading concept envisioned by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Strikes at Canadian paper mills continued today with 4,500 employes staying off the job. The action has closed mills owned by the Canadian International Paper, Ltd., and the Price Co., Ltd.

Representative John Melcher was released from jain today after being arrested onadrunken driving charge. The police said the Montana Democrat had yeled obscenities at jailers and refused to take a sobriety test.

MIDDLESEX, England-An eminent actuary has estimated that if the expectation of life in the world generally were to be increased by an average of 25 years, the population of the world at the turn of the millennium would be five billions more than is at present thought likely.

Jersey City's Council voted 8 to 1 today to fluoridate the city's water. A Council spokesman said equipment for fluoriation expected to cost $15,000 to $20,000 and a year's supply of the chemical would cost about $40,000.
Resident Nixon ordered the Secret Service to tap the telephone of his brother F. Donald Nixon, The Washington Post said in its Thursday editions.

President Nixon has made it plain that the United States will not sell Israel's independence for Arab oil, no matter how tight the energy squeeze becomes. But he has also made it plain that he faults both Israel and the Arabs for failure to do as much as they should to advance a negotiated peace in the Middle East.

President Nixon, acknowledging the possibility of energy shortages this winter, urged Congress today to enact seven legislative measures that he said were intended to increase the country's indigenous energy supplies.
A chestnut colt named Ritz Hanover brought the highest individual price-$68,000-today at the 35th annual standardbred horse sale at the Farm Show arena.

President Nixon indicated today that he had paid no capital gains tax on a $1.24-million sale of some of his property at San Clemente, Calif. He explained that the Internal Revenue Service had not ordered him to make any changes in his income tax returns.
The New York Giants gave Rich Glover a vote of confidence today, but may lose the services of another promising rookie, Clifton Davis, for the remainder of this season.
Two Soviet dissidents who turned state's evidence last week at a closed trial were presented here today at a major news conference to recant once more in public.

To hear Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League tell it, free enterprise will be permanently kicked back of its own goal line if Congress passes a bill lift ing the local television blackout on sold-out home games by professional football teams.
