Wiliam M. Davy, first international organizer for what is now the Newspaper Guild and exexecutive secretary of Local No. 1 of the Cleveland Newspaper Guild for more than 30 years, died today in Lakewood Hospital. He was 78 years old.
Retired Gen. Duong Van Minh, a former South Vietnamese leader, attacked both the Government and the Communists today for keeping political prisoners behind bars despite the Jan. 28 peace accord.

Connecticut Blue Cross received state approval today to raise its rates for direct-payment subscribers 5.61 per cent-less than half of the amount it had requested. State Insurance Commissioner Paul B. Altermatt approved the rise.

Henry K. Goldman, manager of the new Coram Theater at Routes 25 and 112, was arrested last night for the second time in a week and charged with second degree obsecenity for showing the film "The Devil in Miss Jones," the Suffolk County police reported.

The Radio City Music Hall notified seven unions representing its employes yesterday that it would suspend operations after next Wednesday if contract settlements with four of them had not been reached.

Avnet, Inc., a diversified industrial producer, achieved the highest sales and earnings of. any quarter in its 18-year history and set record levels for the year ended June 30, according to results issued yesterday.

The Palestinian commandos who seized the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Paris today were seeking the release of a Palestinian guerrilla leader from prison in Jordan. They demanded his freedom shortly after storming the embassy.
Adelphi University's "Classroom on Wheels" yesterday awarded its first master's degree-to a Penn Central commuter-in a 20-minute capand-gown ceremony in Grand Central Terminal.
The Pentagon reported today that a damaged Soviet submarine had been sighted in the Caribbean with a hole in its deck presumably after crashing into a Soviet surface vessel.

Teachers went on strike today in two Westchester County suburban areas-the wealthy, white Harrison school district and the poorer, integrated Greenburgh Central 7 District outside the city of White Plains.
The Federal National Mortgage Association reported today it had issued $350.4million in four-month commitments to purchase home mortgages at its auction yesterday.

Three Black Muslims were arrested today on charges of kidnapping a policeman as they conducted their own investigation into the slaying of their leader, James Shabazz, who was shot to death in the driveway of his home yesterday.
Evonne Goolagong, an aborigine who learned tennis on the baked red clay of the Australian outback, shook her tight curls, soggy with the perspiration of her match at Forest Hills, and said:
New Hampshire's move to control its recent outbreak of Eastern equine encephalitis has canceled, for all practical purposes, bird-dog field trials scheduled for this fall in the state.
At moments of particular stress Queen Juliana of the Netherlands tells people to call her "Mevrouw" (Madam), not "Majesteit" (Majesty).

Rafael Kubelik, the first musical director in the Metropolitan Opera's history, smiled beatifically. Yes, he said, there was a simple explanation for why Hector Berlioz's monumental opera "Les Troyens" had never been produced in New York:

President Nixon indicated today that he had paid no capital gains tax on a $1.24-million sale of some of his property at San Clemente, Calif. He explained that the Internal Revenue Service had not ordered him to make any changes in his income tax returns.

Abbie Hoffman, the former antiwar activist, Yippie and defendant in the Chicago Seven trial, was indicted here yesterday by a special narcotics grand jury on charges of possession and sale of cocaine valued at $500,000.
A hearing that could delay trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans was set yesterday by Judge Henry J. Friendly of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

" The Desert Song" was first staged in 1926, was made info three Warner Brothers movie versions and has had a long life in summer tents and stock companies-but it had had only one major New York revival (in 1946) until last night, when it began the new Broadway season.

The chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Richard C. Gerstenberg, said today that sales of new cars in the 1974 model year would "approach 11 million units"-a sharp decline from this year's record of 11.7 million.
Tom Gorman criticized the Nastase of Rumania yesterday for pulling out of the doubles after his loss in the singles at Forest Hills.

A Miami builder, John Priestes, has pleaded guilty to falsifying a Federal Housing Authority sales agreement and rigging income tax returns to conceal more than $200,000 in kickbacks from subcontractors.

The swing of interest rates down from the peaks they reached at the beginning of August reached substantial pro portions yesterday in several parts of the credit market. New York City sold $900 million of notes - its biggest borrowing ever-at a rate of 6.24 per cent, almost a full

Natale Marcone, the president of the Italian-American Civil Rights League, was sentenced yesterday to one year in prison for having paid a $4,000 bribe to an Internal Revenue Service agent investigating his personal and corporate income taxes.

Mis. Mary rowers Farrel widow of James W. Farrell, a retired attorney and secretary of Bell Telephone Laboratories, died yesterday in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Queens. She was 84 years old and lived at 165-09 85th Avenue, Jamaica.
FALMOUTH, Mass.-Can a family grow a year's supply of fish in its back yard at negligible cost? Will the fish be good to eat?

The police announced yesterday the arrest of two brothers described as part of a $2.5-million Volkswagen theft ring. Auto-squad policemen arrested the brothers Tuesday night after they left a garage at 712 East 216th Street, the Bronx, in an unmarked commercial truck.

Queen Juliana celebrated her 25th anniversary on the throne in this textile city in the southern Netherlands today amid school bands, parachute demonstrations and a popular enthusiasm that surprised even the sedate Dutch.
Jesse Dunsmore Clarkson, author and professor emeritus of history at Brooklyn College, died yesterday at the Good Samaritan Hospital, West Islip. His age was 76 and he lived here.
Volvo, the Swedish automobile maker, is expected to announce next week that it will build a plant to assemble passenger cars in Virginia.
Federal Judge John J. Sirica silenced two major figures in the Watergate scandal today, calling it a disgrace that criminals could "profit by their wrongdoing" by traveling the lecture circuit.
Question: What woman was chosen over Babe Ruth and Jack Dempsey to earn an "Athlete of the Year" title? Answer: Gertrude Ederle, who finally is obeying her doctor's order to stay out of the water.

President Nixon said today he hoped to restore confidence i his Administration, shaken by the Watergate disclosures, by not permitting his own confi see dence to be destroyed and bylsha showing the country that he tra' was "doing something."

Yielding to subscriber pressure, Iowa's largest newspaper announced today that it would not reduce the size of comic strips. In a statements Monday, The Des Moines Register informed readers that the comics would be reduced in
Volvo, the Swedish automobile maker, is expected to announce next week that it will build a plant to assemble passenger cars in Virginia.

An executive of two sand-hauling companies was indicted on Federal charges of understating the company's corporate income on tax returns filed in 1968-69. The defendant, Frank Caprio Sr., 56 years old, of Deal, is president of the Industrial Service and Supply Company, Sayreville, and is an officer of Industrial Sand and Supply Company, Newark.

President Nixon refused today to say what sort of Supreme Court decision he would consider "definitive" enough to obey in the controversy over making White House tape recordings available to a Federal judge for possible transmittal to the Watergate grand jury.

UPTOWN Tonight is the next to last chance to attend one of the series of free original musical revues that have been held throughout the summer at the St. Philips Center Open Air Theater, 207 West 133d Street.

United States and Than officials have agreed on the withdrawal of 70 more American planes from Thai air bases beginning tomorrow. Premier Thanom Kittikachorn announced the withdrawals at news conferenrce today.
A district attorney who has obtained hundreds of marijuana convictions argued today that a new Texas law that might reduce the sentences of convicted marijuana offenders was unconstitutional.
A Federal judge ruled today that franchising practices by Holiday Inns, Inc., the nation's largest hotel-motel operation, violate antimonopoly laws.
Congress is only weeks away from passing legislation that would end television blackouts of many home games in professional sports, Representative Torbert H. MacDonald said today.
The Supreme Court today confirmed a lower court bankruptcy ruling on a Swift meatpacking operation here and extended some debt liability to Deltec International Ltd. and Deltec Argentina.

Channel 13 (WNET) will provide taped coverage tomorrow of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearings on Henry A. Kissinger's nomination as Secretary of State, beginning at 10 P.M. The hearings will be taped for transmission over facilities of the Public Broadcasting Service beginning at 9 P.M.
The top American general in West Germany visited his Soviet counterpart in East Germany yesterday in the first such courtesy call since 1962, the United States command in Heidelberg announced today.

Representative Ogden R. Reid charged today that the Soviet Union had intensified its repression of Jews since President Nixon's meeting last June with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader.

Disagreement involving the United States and the Common Market countries were reported to have arisen again today at a high-level monetary conference, imperiling a broad accord for a new monetary system that the major nations hope to reach in Nairobi, Kenya, later this month.

President Nixon, citing Arab threats to the West's oil supply, said he was giving highest priority to achieving a settlement in the Middle East. And he warned that Arab nations could lose their oil markets as the West looked to "other" sources of supply. [Page 1, Column 5.]

A Richmond electronics engineer, identified by a Virginia newspaper as a communications expert for President Nixon's 1968 campaign, pleaded not guilty today to charges of illegally possessing eavesdropping equipment.
Getting a jump on the new season, which officially begins next Monday, the American Broadcasting Company is offering two whole fresh hours (excluding the commercials) of entertainment this evening.
United States health officials are strongly recommending that travelers to Italy receive cholera vaccinations in view of the outbreak of the disease there.

The Defense Department has confirmed that secret bombing raids were made in Cambodia during 1970 into areas the United States said it was not bombing at that time, Senator Harold E. Hughes, Democrat of Iowa, said today.
President Nixon, declaring that he would veto the minimum wage bill, challenged Congress today to improve upon a "disappointing" record by enacting his "bipartisan" legislative proposals.
A young black businessman's attempt to win a Democratic nomination for Alderman against a white lawyer accused of racism has embroiled this small industrial city in a political campaign marked by

Heavy rains in Texas Tuesday as a rseult of strong thunderstorms sent near cotton futures deliveries soaring the daily limit in early trading yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The near October contract traded at a record of 92.60 cents a pound.
Japanese police authorities reported today that they had evidence showing that South Korean Government officials took part in the kidnapping of a Korean opposition leader here last month.

Meat supplies have climbed back to just about normal in supermarkets here, along with improving stocks for wholesales who serve small retailers, butchers and restaurants, the city's Consumer Affairs Departme reported yesterday.

Norman Desser, the newly appointed principal at Public School 208 in Brooklyn, said yesterday that he intended to perform his duties despite the opposition of part of the local school board and of parents holding a sit-in at the school.

Occasionally at a dog show, there's an urgent call for a doctor over the public address system. At the recent Newtown fixture, the physician who responded ran from a ring, where she was showing a Skye terrier, to care for an exhibitor.

The holders of three tickets numbered 939800 and three tickets numbered 302635 won chances at a top prize of $50,000 a year for life in the preliminary drawing yesterday for the New York State Lottery's "million. dollar summer special."
The number of suspected cases of cholera was reported to be dwindling in Italy today, raising hopes that the outbreak was on the wane.

A statement issued by the Supreme Court said that Chief Justice Warren E. Burger underwent surgery for a hernia condition. The operation, the Court said, was performed on the 65-year-old Justice at the Mayo Clinic in
A 2 1/2-year-old boy who died shortly after he was taken to St. John's Hospital in Brooklyn on Tuesday night was beaten to death by his mother's boyfriend, the police charged last night.
Kameny Associates, one of the world's smaller agencies, believes it has come up with one of the bigger, bolder creative concepts. And everybody is entitled to his beliefs.

Paul Kempf Jr., who retired last year after 29 years with The New York Times, where he was a news clerk in the Society News department, died yesterday, apparently of a heart ailment, in his apartment at 171 West 71st Street. His age was 64.

Sanford D. Garelik, president of the City Council, charged yesterday that Phoenix House, a program to fight drug addiction, had been recruiting addicts from outside the state for treatment here and had been getting them on welfare.
A small band of Palestinian gunmen took over the Saudi Arabian Embassy here yesterday morning and reportedly seized at least 15 of of its

The National Transportation Safety Board, alarmed by the July 11 airliner crash in Paris. in which 124 persons died, recommended yesterday broad new governmental measures to deal with the danger of fires in flight.

Grim fighting for the provincial capital of Kompong Cham, 45 miles northeast of here, continued inside the city today under a barrage of Communist shells but a Government spokesman here said the situation seemed "stabilized."
The city welfare administration was accused yesterday of refusing aid to six children and their 38-year-old mother, who is without hands.

BUFFALO--Waived Leo Hart, quarterback, Chuck Detwiler, safety; Steve Okoniewski, defensive tackle; Andy Selfridge and Merve Kraskau, linebackers; Dave Beverly, printer, and Dan Dycnes, center. CLEVELAND--Gloster Richardson receiver; Brian Sipe, quarterback; Ken Smith, light end, and Mel Long. ??, cleared waivers and will continue to work with squad: Dale Linosey, linebacker, retired.

The United States today charged North Vietnam and the Vietcong with deliberately holding back information on missing Americans and delaying the return of the remains of United States prisoners of war buried in the North.

Persistent winds and rains from tropical storm Delia flooded thousands of acres of Gulf Coast marshland today and threatened grain crops worth $100-million in Texas and Louisiana, producers of half the nation's rice.

An American, John Fitzgerald, and two Finns, Risto Hurme and Martti Ketelae, shared the lead after the tough riding section of the world modern pentathlon championships today at London's Crystal Palace sports complex.

Next week, the Senate begins debate on two rival bills to reform the private pension industry. One is S.4 sponsored by Senators Williams (Democrat, N. J.) and Javits (Republican, N. Y.) and endorsed by the Senate Labor Committee and practically the whole liberal establishment in the Senate.
Andre Malraux slept there. Graham Greene's quiet American had a fateful encounter on its terrace. During the Communists' 1968 Tet offensive, American journalists took refuge in its hallways.
A chestnut colt named Ritz Hanover brought the highest individual price-$68,000-today at the 35th annual standardbred horse sale at the Farm Show arena.

The skull of a 15-year-old white boy was fractured this morning in a melee between black and white youths at the Westbury Junior High School. The police identified the youth as William Kelly of 504 Rockland Street.

Manager Yogi Berra was getting his pitching staff geared up for the stretch run. He changed his plans for the four-game series in Montreal starting tomorrow, moving up Jerry Koosman to the opening game and Tom Seaver to Saturday night, each on three days' rest instead of the customary four.

All things being equal, Roy Kirksey would much rather be in Philadelphia. The third-year National Football League guard from Maryland's Eastern Shore was in Philadelphia for a brief time last week after Weeb Ewbank, the Jets' coach and general manager, put him on waivers.

Col. M. Preston Goodfellow, the publisher of The Brooklyn Eagle in the nineteen-thirties and a deputy director of the Office of Strategic Services in World War II, died in Washington yesterday apparently of a heart attack.
Helena Rubinstein, Inc., became a wholly owned subsidiary of the Colgate-Palmolive Company yesterday with approval of the $219-million merger by shareholders of Helena Rubinstein.
